column1: 264;badlands;badlands;"Bad Lands (c) 1989 Atari Games Corp.

;It has been 50 years since the nuclear disaster. The sport of sprint racing is now a ruthless battle between armed cars. These races take place on tracks built in the ruins of the dangerous nuclear zone known only as the BADLANDS. It's all-out war on the track as players blast away at the drones (and each other) to finish first. Players shoot play-field targets for extra points and bonus missiles.
Bonus wrenches appear at regular intervals which can be collected and used to upgrade the player's vehicle. The available upgrades are : missiles
column2: tires
column3: turbo
column4: increased speed
column5: and shields. This was to be Atari's last game in the 'Sprint' series."

column1: 265;bagman;bagman;"Bagman (c) 1982 Valadon Automation [VA].
;The objective of the game is to maneuver Bagman through various mine shafts
column2: picking up money bags and placing them in a wheelbarrow at the surface of the mine. The player must avoid pursuing guards
column3: moving ore carts
column4: and descending elevators. The player may temporarily stun the guards by striking them with a pickaxe or by dropping money bags on them when they are below the player on the same ladder. The player may move between the three screens which make up the level via shafts and on the surface.

column1: Bagman is played using one 4-way joystick and one action button. The joystick is also used to jump out of the ore cart. The Action Button is used to make the Bagman perform the following tasks:
Pick up and drop money bags
Pick up and drop pickaxe
Grab and release the ceiling beam to avoid the ore cart (this can be done while carrying a money bag)
Placing a money bag in the wheelbarrow
Pick up and drop the wheelbarrow
Points are scored for each horizontal step the player takes
column2: for each money bag placed in the wheelbarrow
column3: and for each guard stunned."

column14: he will explode and send his eyeball flying - and if the player catches the eyeball he will receive a single point. Several new enemies have also been introduced (one of which
column19: is an evil version of the Paccets); the boss for the thirtieth stage
column21: is also an enormous evil version of the Paccets. If the player defeats Dark Paccet on his first try
column22: the game shall not end - instead
column23: six more stages will have to be played
column24: and if a player wins the game (regardless of if it ends on Stage 30 or 36)
column25: he will not be able to enter his name on its high score table. There are now four different types of capsules; as a general rule
column27: while the red ones contain Baganns (the Pac-Man-like aliens from the original title)
column28: the blue ones contain shot powerups
column29: and the green ones contain speed powerups. It is also now impossible to move backwards (like in Super Mario Bros.) - but if the player dies
column30: he will be sent back to the beginning of the stage (unlike in the original
column31: where he would restart in the place where he died) and be reprimanded by the ""Paccet Ojisan""
column32: who also appears for the start of some stages to give him advice."

column4: and special blocks containing powerups) advance down from the top of the screen. The player dies when the ball goes down through a hole in the bottom of the screen
column5: or if the blocks reach the bottom of the screen. When you die
column6: you start over at the beginning of the level. Although the game has a ball and paddle look and feel
column7: puzzle elements come into play later in the game."

286;bankp;bankp;Bank Panic (c) 1984 Sega.
;A reaction-based shoot-em-up in which the player takes on the role of a gun-slinging Deputy
column2: who has been charged with protecting the town bank from outlaws.

column1: Each stage contains twelve numbered doors
column2: with three doors visible on-screen at any one time. The player must scroll the screen left or right to bring other doors into view. At regular intervals
column3: one or more doors will open to reveal either a bank customer or an outlaw. The customers must be allowed to deposit their money unharmed while the outlaws must be shot before they have a chance to shoot the deputy. Some of the outlaws must be shot twice before they are killed. If the player kills an innocent citizen
column4: a player life is lost.

column1: Doors will only open when they are on-screen and a level is only completed once cash has been deposited safely into the bank via each of the twelve doors. Each level has a tight time limit
column2: so it's important to ensure that the player reaches the doors that are about to be opened as quickly as possible. Imminent visitors are indicated by a bar graph situated above each door
column3: with a moving red marker showing the approach of either a customer or robber.

column1: In addition to the outlaws
column2: players must also be wary of time bombs that occasionally appear on one of the doors; this is indicated by both a timer and an icon above the door with the bomb. The bomb must be reached and its fuse shot before the timer runs out. As well as the outlaws and customers
column3: a small
column4: bow-legged cowboy occasionally appears holding gifts above his head
column5: these can be shot for bonus points. Occasionally
column6: an open door will reveal a town citizen bound by ropes. The player must shoot the ropes with a single shot to free the citizen.

column1: Bonus points are awarded for the completion of a level
column2: with the amount determined by remaining level time and the number of moneybags deposited. Players can choose to start the game on either level one
column3: three or six
column4: with the harder levels earning higher bonus points for stage completion."

column1: 287;baraduka;baraduke;"BaRaDuKe (c) 1985 Namco
column2: Limited.

column1: ;A side/vertical scrolling shooter in which the player walks and flies Kissy through an alien base blasting baddies on the way. The scrolling isn't forced
column2: but players aren't able to go back once they've passed into a new area. Rescuing little rabbit-eared blobby cyclopses will give you a chance at extra hit points. It's not a brilliant game
column3: but there's something oddly compelling about it. The little aliens saying ""I'm your friend!"" when you save them is much appreciated
column4: as is their willingness to sacrifice themselves by suiciding against the boss monster at the end of every level."

You move your little triangle around on the grid, while attempting to avoid the little diamonds that are also moving around on the grid. column1: As enemies are destroyed
column2: the player gains experience points that are separate from the score. For every 288 experience points gained
column3: the main gun will 'level up'
column4: becoming much stronger. This is analogous to experience points and leveling up in role playing games. The weapon can only level up twice
column5: so after it has achieved its maximum level
column6: 288 experience points will grant the player an extra bomb.

column1: The player can also grab P icons to increase the power of the current level gun. A maximum of five ""P""s can be collected per experience level; getting more after this gives extra points instead.
Collecting B icons increases the number of bombs
column2: to a maximum of 7.

column1: Apart from destroying enemies

column3: 3000 points are awarded for every small one
column4: and 5000 points for every large one. If the player's ship is destroyed during a level

column1: ;In this special version:
* Different colours for all stages.
* Some sprites have different colors.
* The title screen/demo & the ship selection screen have different colors.
* The 4-lap end is different.
* The power-ups are different.
* The collision detection area is tighter than the original.
* The smart-bombs are bigger and nicer looking. They also do more damage.
* You get 8 credits instead of 4 to complete the game.
So basically the Special version is an Easier version.
- TRIVIA -
The special version of Batsugun was originally shown at the AOU show (an arcade game show held in Japan every year) and was not for sale. After the Toaplan bunkruptcy
column2: the board started to appear on the second hand market.

327;bbonk;bbonk;Bigfoot Bonkers (c) 1976 Meadows Games.

;This game was 2-player only, you must have a live human opponent to play against, or else the other players mouse (the games promotional material said the character was a mouse), will go straight into a wall, making for a very quick and boring game. Each player moves their mouse around leaving a solid line behind them. All moves are made on an invisible grid, so you can only turn at 90 degree angles. Scattered around the gameboard are several 'fee' that you must avoid, as hitting a foot is just like smashing into a wall or a line. To win you must last longer than your opponent before hitting something (first person to hit something loses). One good strategy is to try and box your opponent in to a small section of the screen, and then just move carefully until they crash. Pushing backwards on the stick will cause you to crash into your own line, so avoid that at all cost.

366;biomtoy;biomtoy;Biomechanical Toy (c) 1995 Zeus.

;Biomechanical Toy is a colourful eightway-scrolling platform game set in a world of magically animated toys. The magical pendulum that animates the toys has been stolen by the evil 'Scrubby' - a criminal once imprisoned for trying to steal the pendulum who has managed to escape and take his revenge.
Evil toys now patrol the kingdom and must be destroyed or avoided. Good toys have been trapped throughout the levels and if freed by Inguz
column2: will give help by providing additional firepower for a short time.

column1: Inguz carries a basic
column2: single-firing gun
column3: although additional ammo clips can be found throughout the game that upgrade the gun with either extra shot power
column4: automatic firing or exploding bullets. When the gun's current ammo clip is empty
column5: Inguz will take a moment to reload
column6: leaving him vulnerable to attack.

column1: Inguz begins each stage (and each new life) with a full health meter of eighty units
column2: but food can be found that will boost the health meter. The player can lose a life either by running out of health
column3: falling off the bottom of the screen
column4: or running out of time. Clearing each stage awards bonus points based on both remaining time and health units.

column1: Checkpoints - indicated by red flags - are located at certain points throughout the stages. In the event of losing a life
column2: the player will restart at the last checkpoint reached. Objects with Inguz's face on them (such as wooden chests and balloons) release bonus items when shot.

column1: An abstract
column2: oriental-looking face occasionally forms part of a level's platform which
column3: when shot
column4: releases balloons which can in turn be shot for bonus items. A giant flying hat also occasionally appears and will drop bonus items when shot. Smart Bombs can also be found at certain points that
column5: when run into by Inguz
column6: will damage or destroy all enemy toys on screen."

column1: 367;bionicc;bionicc1;"Bionic Commando (c) 1987 Capcom.
;Export version. For more information about the game itself
column2: please see the original Japanese version entry; ""Top Secret"".

column1: - TRIVIA -
Bionic Commando was released in March 1987. It is known in Japan as ""Top Secret"".
In addition to the different title
column2: Bionic Commando adds:

column1: - The bonus life information that was not present on the original Japanese version.
- Player number information (not present in Japan)
- Weapon's icon below the player information.
- A new color palette for the second player character.
Also:
- The player keeps whatever gun they had in the previous stage (not in Japan)
- The Clear Bonus and Time Bonus are faster to display.
- Scoring changed.
- Many bug and graphics fixes.
- SERIES -
1. Bionic Commando (1987)
2. Bionic Commando - Elite Forces (2000
column2: Nintendo Game Boy Color)

column1: 3. Bionic Commando Rearmed (2008
column2: Microsoft XBOX 360 [XBLA]
column3: Sony PlayStation 3 [PSN])

column1: 4. Bionic Commando (2009
column2: XBOX 360
column3: Sony PlayStation 3
column4: PC DVD-ROM)

column1: 5. Bionic Commando Rearmed 2 (2011
column2: Sony PlayStation 3 [PSN]
column3: Microsoft XBOX 360 [XBLA])"

column1: 369;bioship;bioship;"Bio-Ship Paladin (c) 1990 American Sammy Corp.
;While the game is essentially a standard horizontally scrolling shoot'em up
column2: it has an innovation that makes it unique in the genre. The player flies a spaceship (specifically
column3: a bioship) which has the standard forward guns to be found in all horizontal scrollers
column4: but it also possesses a weapon that can be manually targeted with a crosshair
column5: in the same manner as in the game ""Missile Command"". This allows the player to fire in any direction with pinpoint accuracy
column6: and adds an extra level of strategy to the game. The player's bioship can also collect power-ups to grow bigger (becoming more powerful)
column7: and can acquire spherical pods which attach to the ship and increase its firepower."

column1: 370;birdtry;birdtry;"Birdie Try (c) 1988 Data East.

372;bjourney;bjourney;Raguy (c) 1991 Alpha Denshi Company
column2: Limited.

column1: ;Raguy is an environmentally-themed side-scrolling platform game for one or two players.
The player controls a heroic young man named 'Blue' (in the two-player game the second player controls 'Princess Fa'
column2: who has identical powers to Blue)
column3: whose peaceful home planet of 'Raguy' has been invaded by the evil Daruma tribe. The Daruma are polluting the planet as they consume its dwindling resources and it falls on Blue and the Princess to stop them and save Raguy.

column1: Both Blue and Princess Fa have the ability to stun enemies by hitting them with a large leaf. Once stunned
column2: they can be picked up and thrown as projectiles at other enemies. Blue and Princess Fa can also shrink in size in order to access hidden areas
column3: but they are not able to stun enemies while shrunk. If only one player is shrunk
column4: they can be picked up by the other player and thrown as a projectile at the enemies.

column1: Flowers
column2: bonus items and power-ups are littered throughout the levels. The flowers are the game's form of currency and can be used in the shops that are located throughout the game. There are two different types of shop
column3: offering either tips and help with overcoming certain obstacles
column4: or health and weapon power-ups."

column1: 373;bjtwin;bjtwin;"Bomb Jack Twin (c) 1993 NMK.
;Bomb Jack Twin is a direct sequel to the 1984 original
column2: and retains the same platform-based collect-the-bombs gameplay of its predecessor.

column1: Changes over the original include a slightly faster playing tempo
column2: and the option for simultaneous two-player gameplay. As with the original game
column3: extra points and bonuses can be earned by collecting bonus coins and bombs with their fuses still lit.

column1: Bomb Jack Twin also retains the 'Powerball' feature of its predecessor which
column2: when collected
column3: freezes the level's enemies for several seconds
column4: allowing them to be destroyed."

383;blasted;blasted;"Blasted (c) 1988 Bally Midway.

;Using your high-powered scope rifle, blast aliens and other bad guys who have invaded an apartment complex, but be careful not to shoot the tenants or get hit by return fire. In 2-player mode, you shoot at your opponent's building and he shoots at yours.
384;blaster;blaster;Blaster (c) 1983 Williams.
;The player takes control of a spaceship and must fight against wave after wave of enemy fighters
column2: while trying to rescue the stranded astronauts that represent the last surviving remnants of the human race. Enemies attack the player both with weapons
column3: and by making 'suicide runs' at the player's ship. The game consists of eleven different levels
column4: nine of which are repeated
column5: bringing the total number of levels to 20.

column1: The levels are : Planetoid Waves
column2: Robot Grid Waves
column3: Saucerland Waves
column4: Vampire Waves
column5: Time Tunnel Waves
column6: Outer Space Waves
column7: Enduro Waves
column8: Cat World Waves
column9: and Mastermind Waves (there are two of each of these).

column1: There are also two unique waves that occur only once
column2: they are Armageddon and Paradise.

column1: Players can select their starting wave at the start of the game; choosing from Planetoids
column2: Robot Grid
column3: Saucerland
column4: and Vampires. During the game
column5: players must be careful to NOT shoot the human astronauts that drift through the levels. These must be rescued by 'running' into them.

column1: Despite the presence of an energy meter
column2: the player can take exactly three hits before he or she dies. Upon death
column3: the window of the player's virtual cockpit breaks and one of the player's lives is lost. Blaster has a 'Continue' option but this can only be used once."

column1: 386;blasto;blasto;"Blasto (c) 1978 Gremlin.

;Your are in control of your spaceship as you maneuver it through a mine field. Beat the clock to explode all the mines. With two players, Blasto gets even more challenging, more exciting, as each one battles for the most mines and ultimately-for each other!
387;blastoff;blastoff;Blast Off (c) 1989 Namco.
;A vertically scrolling shoot'em up. Despite the drastically different gameplay
column2: Blast Off is the sequel to Bosconian which was released eight years earlier.

column1: As in many other vertical scrolling shooters (including Namco's own Xevious)
column2: the player controls a ship
column3: facing the top of the screen
column4: that can move freely while the background scrolls down
column5: bringing enemies in to view; the player may destroy enemies for points. The game uses two buttons - one is used to make the ship fire circular lasers
column6: while the other is used to cycle through its four firing patterns. The red pattern is two lasers in a spiral pattern
column7: while the blue one is one laser straight ahead and one behind
column8: the yellow one is one laser straight ahead
column9: one left
column10: and one right and the green one is two lasers diagonally forward (one to the left and one to the right)
column11: and one straight behind; by holding down the button
column12: the ship fires more powerful
column13: spherical lasers."

column1: 388;blazeon;blazeon;"BlaZeon (c) 1992 Atlus Company
column2: Limited.

column1: ;The player is set in control of The Garland TFF-01
column2: a sub-standard space fighter ship that is only armed with a semi-auto or rapid fire laser gun known as the Beam Vulcan and the Tranquilander. Some enemy units can be captured and used in play; certain enemy robots
column3: when shot by the player's Tranquilander
column4: will morph into an outline of themselves. The player can then fly into the outline
column5: and take on the form of the enemy robot
column6: taking control of its weapons
column7: abilities and special attacks.

column1: There is also addition to the boss battle scoring: similar to some shooters
column2: players have the opportunity to increase their scores by beating the end level bosses within a certain time limit. Every time a boss battle is initiated
column3: a timer will count down and once the boss is destroyed/killed before the timer reaches zero
column4: then the time left will add to the player's end-level score; if the timer runs out
column5: then the score at the end of the level will remain unaffected."

column1: 389;blazer;blazer;"Blazer (c) 1987 Namco.

;An isometric scrolling shoot 'em up featuring a tank and occasionally a helicopter battling multiple land and air based enemies.

392;blckout2;blockout2;Block Out (c) 1989 Technos Japan Corp.
;Block Out is a 1-player or a simultaneous 2 players competitive game of unique dimensional action and strategy.
As the blocks drop one-by-one into the three-dimensional pit
column2: rotate them by using the three buttons and joystick. Once the player has decided on the the rotation of the block
column3: use the button to drop the block into place. The objective is to place the blocks into the pit without leaving any empty spaces. Once this is achieved
column4: the layers without empty spaces
column5: will disappear.

column1: The player begins the game by selecting a starting stage. Game start level select can be chosen from stages 1
column5: or 20. There is a total of 100 stages in the game and as the players progress through the game
column6: the stages get more and more difficult.

column1: Each stage has a certain number of layers (faces) that must be erased. Once these faces are erased
column2: the player will move on to the next stage. The less blocks the players has left in the pit at the end of the stage
column3: the more points are awarded.

column1: In addition to the one player mode
column2: Block Out offers a competitive simultaneous two player mode. The split screen effect gives each player their own pit with which to play in. They compete against each other in the race to erase the faces. As one player erases a face
column3: that face will be added to the opponent's pit
column4: making their pit rise. This allows less room to work. There are two ways to win in the 2-player mode :

column1: 1) Force the opponent to the top of their pit and out of the game
or
2) Erase 21 faces first."

399;blkdrgnb;blkdrgonb;Black Dragon (c) 1987 Capcom Company
column2: Limited.

column1: ;Black Dragon is a scrolling platform shoot-em-up set in a fantasy world and is the spiritual successor to the Capcom classic
column2: ""Makaimura"" (""Ghosts'n' Goblins"" outside Japan).

column1: The player takes on the role of a barbarian hero who must jump and fight his way through a variety of colourful
column2: enemy-packed levels
column3: collecting treasure and weapon power-ups and rescuing the trapped 'wise old men' that litter the levels.

column1: Rescuing the wise men sees the player awarded 'Zeny coins'; these are the game's currency and allow the player to buy such items as weapon and armour upgrades
column2: keys for treasure chests
column3: anti-poisoning potions and health potions from the shops that appear on each level. Occasionally
column4: a rescued wise man will also offer to sell the player weapon and armour power-ups.

column1: The barbarian hero is armed with a spiked mace on the end of a long chain
column2: as well as unlimited throwing daggers. Both these and the armour worn by the barbarian (which offers limited protection from enemy attacks) can be upgraded by finding or buying the relevant power-ups.

column1: The sprawling
column2: eight-way scrolling levels are packed with hidden bonuses to encourage and reward exploration. These bonuses are in the form of weapon and armour power-ups
column3: as well as valuable treasure items. Many levels also include a hidden dungeon and each dungeon is filled with both bonus items and trapped wise men.

column1: Special items that reveal coins
column2: upgraded armour
column3: or simply bonus points can be found by attacking certain walls."

;This game was two player only, you must have a live human opponent to play against, or else the other players character will go straight into a wall, making for a very quick and boring game. Each player moves their character around leaving a solid line behind them. All moves are made on an invisible grid, so you can only turn at 90 degree angles. To win you must last longer than your opponent before hitting something (first person to hit something loses). The game ended after one player chalked up six wins, but this was operator adjustable down to as low as three.

column1: 419;bloods11;bloodstm11;"Blood Storm (c) 1994 Strata.

;Blood Storm is considered by many as a quasi-'sequel' to Time Killers. The game had a rather dark storyline as there were few ambiguously good characters as the other ranged from being sociopathically insane or deceptive folk.
BloodStorm was dubbed as a possible “MK-killer” in an attempt to surpass rival Midway's success with Mortal Kombat
column2: though it did not prevail. It was the last game Strata produced before the company went out of business.

column1: As with its predecessor Time Killers
column2: BloodStorm features many of the aspects carried down from it
column3: such as the removal of an opponent’s arms and an ‘instant kill’ attack
column4: as well as a Special Death Move. The button layout is virtually the same. They are labeled as ""back leg""
column5: ""front leg""
column6: ""back arm"" and ""front arm"" respectively. A button in the center is used to make the character block. As one would suspect
column7: if a particular limb is lost in combat
column8: its corresponding button is rendered useless.

column1: BloodStorm is also a weapons-based fighter
column2: though it differs from Time Killers in that the characters use weapons called ""Gauntlets"" that also allow them to use particular powers and attacks with them. Other than being able to bash off an opponent’s arms
column3: a technique called a ‘Sunder’ is also in the game. If executed when an opponent is stunned
column4: it will destroy their lower body. The character will not be able to jump or use kicks
column5: but can still move back and forth a little with the leg buttons.

column1: Even after a successful Sunder attack
column2: the fight can still go on
column3: if the character’s life bar is not totally drained yet. However
column4: if both limbs are lost afterwards (if they weren't already torn off prior to the Sunder attack) then s/he is almost completely helpless. (There are a few special moves that don't require arms or legs
column5: and those can still be performed). Characters are restored back to normal form after a round is over much like Time Killers as well.

column1: A notable feature in the game is that when an opponent is defeated
column2: the player gains a ‘passable power’ much like in a style akin to the Mega Man series. These powers or weapons can be used at any time to give the player a further advantage. Also
column3: players can save their progress in a game with a password feature by pressing buttons during the player select screen. However
column4: since the data was saved only until the machine was turned off
column5: it was less than beneficial unless used to pick the game back up where it ended."

column1: 420;bloods21;bloodstm21;"Blood Storm (c) 1994 Strata.

;Blood Storm is considered by many as a quasi-'sequel' to Time Killers. The game had a rather dark storyline as there were few ambiguously good characters as the other ranged from being sociopathically insane or deceptive folk.
BloodStorm was dubbed as a possible “MK-killer” in an attempt to surpass rival Midway's success with Mortal Kombat
column2: though it did not prevail. It was the last game Strata produced before the company went out of business.

426;blsthead;blstroidh;"Blasteroids (c) 1987 Atari Games Corp.
;Blasteroids is a 1 or 2-player update of Atari's seminal ""Asteroids""
column2: where the object of the game is to clear all sectors of the asteroids and enemy ships. Once this task is completed
column3: the player goes on to battle Mukor - the ""boss"" asteroid who rules all galaxies - and destroy him.

column1: The player's ship appears first in the center of four vortices
column2: he or she must chose which vortex they wish to enter
column3: which then transports them to a sector of their chosen star system.

column1: Unlike in ""Asteroids""
column2: the player ship has a finite amount of fuel which must be replenished as often as possible. This is achieved by destroying specifically-colored asteroids which turn into collectible crystals. Not all sectors contain the crystal-bearing asteroids
column3: however
column4: and if the player runs out of fuel
column5: a ship is lost. The game contains three different ship configurations and the player can switch between them at any time during a level. The three configurations are : Speeder (small and fast
column6: but weak)
column7: Fighter (medium speed and strength) and Warrior (large and strong but very slow).

column1: Additional power-ups can be collected to improve the player's chances
column2: some of the items available are : additional guns
column3: larger fuel tanks
column4: crystal magnets and impervious shields. Some of these add-ons are time-limited while others last until the player's current ship is destroyed. In the asteroid field
column5: there are also 'popcorn' asteroids; small blue rock formations that grow larger and travel faster with each hit they take until they become large
column6: non-moving objects on the screen. These obstacles must be avoided since hitting them will drain all of the ship's fuel
column7: costing the player a life. A popcorn asteroid can not be destroyed. Hitting anything other than bonus power-ups and energy crystals costs precious fuel. Clearing a sector of all of its asteroids takes the player back to a screen and shows a preview of all of the cleared and uncleared sectors in this star system. Some sectors are marked as ""unknown"" and no preview is offered for these levels. From here
column8: the player can choose which system they wish to tackle next. All systems need to be cleared before the player is given the chance to battle against Mukor himself. To kill Mukor
column9: the player must eliminate each of the volcanoes with multiple blaster hits. Destroying a volcano causes Mukor to release bonus power-up items
column10: and destroying all of the volcanoes causes Mukor to flee
column11: returning the player to the selection vortices.

column1: Later
column2: after all other sectors have been cleared
column3: the player will eventually have to face Mukor again and this time
column4: the enemy boss will have to be destroyed. After Mukor has been destroyed
column5: the game ends.

column1: In the simultaneous two-player game
column2: the first person to fly their ship into a vortex chooses the star system to which the players go. A unique feature of two-person play is the docking of ships : to dock
column3: one player must transform their ship to the largest size while the other transforms to the smallest. By touching the two ships together
column4: they dock and form one large ship. The player originally with the larger ship now controls the speed and direction of the docked ship and can fire straight forward. The player with the smaller ship controls a turret that can rotate and fire independently of the main ship. The dock is broken when the player with the small ship hits their 'thrust' button."

;Follow along with the song by scratching the turntable and pressing the keys as the bars reach the bottom of the screen. column1:
;Follow along with the song by scratching the turntable and pressing the keys as the bars reach the bottom of the screen. If you manage to successfully hit each note on-key perfectly, a combo meter will go up, increasing your score. Do well enough by the end of the song, and you can progress to the next level.

column1: 448;bnzabros;bnzabros;"Bonanza Bros. (c) 1990 Sega.
;Bonanza Bros. is a strategic platform shoot-em-up with one or two players taking on the roles of Robo and Mobo
column2: two cat-burgling brothers who must negotiate scrolling platform-based levels and steal a set number of valuable items
column3: before making their way to the roof to escape in a waiting airship. The location of the items is highlighted on a cut-away map displayed in the middle of the screen and each stage must be completed within a set time limit.

column1: The game's 2D platforms are displayed using forced-perspective 3D
column2: this allows both the players and enemies to move between the front and back of the platforms. The game's enemies have a limited field of vision
column3: making it possible for players to hide from them by ducking into alcoves
column4: stairwells and other background scenery. Players can walk
column5: jump and shoot and enemies can be neutralized either by being shot
column6: or by slamming doors against them. They will only remain stunned for a few seconds
column7: however.

column1: Bonanza Bros."" promotes the use of stealth
column2: with enemies alerted by sounds or by players entering their field of vision. Once alerted
column3: enemies will either hide
column4: call for help or fire at the players. On some stages
column5: hazardous items litter the ground that should either be avoided or jumped over. These include discarded Coke cans
column6: banana skins and garden rakes and if players walk into them
column7: they will slip and fall
column8: creating a noise and alerting nearby guards to their presence. Some guards carry a riot shield and can only be hit when they are walking away from the player. If players get shot too many times
column9: or if they fail to steal all treasure items and reach the escape point within the time limit
column10: the brothers end up in jail and it's game over.

column1: The game has a total of twelve stages
column2: with extra bonus stages appearing after every second level. These bonus rounds take place on a single screen and the aim is to collect treasure items from a number of ledges within a set time limit. Search lights constantly move around the screen and if one touches the player
column3: the bonus round ends. Each bonus screen has alcoves that players can hide in to evade the search lights.

column1: Each of the game's twelve stages is set in a different building. The stages are:
* BANK
* MILLIONAIRE'S MANSION
* CASINO
* MINT
* DEPARTMENT STORE
* GOLD MINE
* JEWELLERY STORE
* LABORATORY
* DELUXE LINER (YACHT)
* ANTIQUE SHOP
* ART MUSEUM
* PYRAMID"
449;boblbobl;boblbobl;"Bobble Bobble (c) 1986.
;This game is a bootleg of ""Bubble bobble"". Unlike the original game:
* The left player ('Bub') can have only a total of two extends.
* This bootleg has a new feature in Dip switch where you may control the speed of monsters.
* The monsters 'Mighta'
column2: 'Hidegonsu'
column3: and 'Drunk' do not throw their projectile weapons (i.e. 'Mighta' does not throw his slow-moving stone balls
column4: 'Hidegonsu' does not throw his fast-moving fireballs
column5: and 'Drunk' does not throw his boomerang bottles). However
column6: the 'Invader' monster
column7: who appears in 'Normal' mode only
column8: does throw his laser projectile."

column1: 451;bogeyman;bogeyman;"Bogey Manor (c) 1985 Technos.
;A great platform game.
You play as a young ghost hunter boy who runs around a haunted house. Your objective is to destroy with your sword all the crystal balls that are in the house
column2: you must go through all the floors and go through the doors guided by the map at the top of the screen in a time limit without getting caught by the ghosts
column3: frankenstein
column4: witches and other creepy creatures. With the help of your magic glove can freeze ghosts for a short period of time to later hit them with the sword.

column1: Once you've destroyed all the crystal balls
column2: the haunted house starts falling apart
column3: and you must run for your life towards the exit to win the stage. You can transform into a super hero
column4: entering through the flashing door to grab special items."

column1: 452;boggy84;boggy84b;"Boggy '84 (c) 1983 Eddie's Games.

;Bootleg of the Kaneko original.
453;bombbee;bombbee;Bomb Bee (c) 1979 Namco.

;In this old ball and paddle game, you control a paddle that must rebound a ball into the colorized bricks and pop-bumpers.
454;bombjac2;bombjack2;Bomb Jack (c) 1984 Tehkan.

;Bomb Jack is a fast-moving platform game in which the aim is to collect all of the bombs on each level before progressing to the next. A variety of constantly spawning mechanical enemies patrol the platforms and airspace so the longer a player takes to collect all of the bombs
column2: the more difficult progress becomes.

column1: Extra point bonuses are awarded for collecting bombs with their fuses lit. Only one bomb at any time has a lit fuse
column2: and collecting twenty or more of these lit bombs on any given level will earn the player points bonus (see TIPS AND TRICKS for details). Jack is pursued around each level by the spawning enemies and when he gets killed
column3: he drops down to the nearest platform
column4: always landing on his head.

column1: A 'Powerball' appears at semi-regular intervals and moves diagonally around the screen. If the player manages to grab this
column2: all of the level's monsters are frozen for several seconds and can then be killed by having Jack fly into them (similar to the 'Powerpill' feature in ""Pac-Man""). Collecting the Bonus 'B' symbols will increase the amount of points awarded for collecting bombs with their fuses lit. Picking up an 'Extra' symbol awards the player with an additional life
column3: while catching the 'Special' symbol will give the player an extra credit.

column1: Each of Bomb Jack's levels feature one of five different background pictures
column2: some of which represent famous historical landmarks. They are: the Sphinx in Egypt
column3: the Acropolis in Greece
column4: Castle Neuschwanstein in Bavaria
column5: skyscrapers and a cityscape by night. While the backgrounds themselves are repeated as the game progresses
column6: the platform layouts for each level are completely different. At least until level 18
column7: after which the levels are repeated.

column1: The basic play mechanic of collecting objects to clear a level
column2: as well as the powerball feature
column3: is hugely reminiscent of Namco's seminal ""Pac-Man""."

Have a blast, but don't get blasted yourself!

460;boomrang;boomrang;"Boomer Rang'r (c) 1983 Data East Corp.

;The player controls Whirley, a caveman armed with a boomerang whose quest it is to find a lost treasure in that prehistoric land. As he searches for the lost treasure, he must fight off enemy cavemen armed with clubs, dinosaurs and other prehistoric monsters. He must also look out for vultures who drop rocks. Whirley can also mount a dinosaur and ride it after he kills the caveman who is riding it, and whenever he is riding a dinosaur, he can have the dinosaur breathe fire for a weapon.

column1: 462;boothill;boothill;"Boot Hill (c) 1977 Midway.
;A classic 1 or 2-player western gunfight game
column2: featuring a monochrome display overlaid via mirror onto back-lit plastic background. Each player uses a small joystick to move their cowboy up and down the play area
column3: while a second
column4: much larger joystick is used to aim the pistol and shoot - this larger stick also has a trigger button. The game's single goal is simply to shoot the other player
column5: who is situated on the opposite side of the game area. Wagons and cacti litter the middle of the play area
column6: providing temporary cover from the opponent's gunfire (while
column7: of course
column8: providing the opponent with cover from the PLAYER'S shots). These obstacles slowly disintegrate as they are shot; much like the shields in Taito's ""Space Invaders"".

column1: Boot Hill is time-based NOT life based
column2: with the factory default set at ninety seconds. This is
column3: of course
column4: operator adjustable via the dip settings. The computer opponent is quite easy to beat with a little practice
column5: but a human opponent provides a much stronger challenge."

464;bosco;bosco;"Bosconian - Star Destroyer (c) 1981 Namco.

;Bosconian is a multi-directional space shooter where the player must destroy several enemy bases on each round while evading enemy ships, asteroids and mines. Enemy bases are destroyed either with a shot to the center or by shooting out all six base cannons. The player's ship is always positioned in the center of the screen with everything else scrolling around it as the player flies. A radar map to the right shows the position of the player, enemy bases, and occasional formation attack groups.

475;bowlrama;bowlrama;Bowl-O-Rama (c) 1991 P&P Marketing
column2: Incorporated..

column1: ;This game has 3 different bowling variations to choose from 'Regulation Bowling'
column2: 'Flash-O-Matic'
column3: and 'BlackJack' :

column1: * In 'Regulation Bowling' the rules and scoring are just like real bowling
column2: following the regulations of the American Bowling Congress (ABC). In all three games players can join in at any time during the first frame.

column1: * 'Flash-O-Matic' is a variation on the bowling theme. In this game a flashing score value moves back and forth across the alley. The player bowls
column2: and the score value stops when the ball first hits a pin. If the player throws a strike he receives that score value. If he gets a spare he gets half the original value. If he fails to convert the spare then he gets 1 point for each pin that he did knock down. Scores can go up to nearly 10
column3: 000 points!

column1: * In 'BlackJack' each player gets up to 3 throws to attempt to knock down 21 pins. Each time the full rack of ten pins is set. All pins knocked down by all players in one frame are added to the pot. The player who gets closest to 21 without going over gets all the points in the pot
column2: and the pot is cleared to zero for the next frame. If a player gets 21 exactly then he gets twice the value in the pot. If 2 or more players tie in a frame they each get the points from the pot (or twice the points if they each have 21). Players who do not get closest to 21 or who bust (go over 21) get no points for the frame. Knocking down one pin scores as an ace
column3: and is worth one or eleven
column4: depending on what the player needs. his game is best played by several players together. The more players
column5: the more points each frame is worth!"

column1: Bombs are randomly located outside the wall. Each bomb has a lite fuse. Three bugs are also randomly scattered outside the wall. The player's score
column2: the number of cannons remaining
column3: and the number of bugs that must be knocked out to complete the round are shown at the top of the screen."

492;brkthruj;brkthruj;"Kyohkoh-Toppa (c) 1986 Data East.
;Kyohkoh-Toppa is a horizontally scrolling shoot'em up in which the player drives an armoured car
column2: equipped with a front-mounted gun and super jump capability. The aim of the game is to fight through five enemy-controlled zones to retrieve a stolen top-secret fighter plane
column3: the PK430.

column1: The game's levels force-scroll from right to left
column2: although the vehicle's speed - and rate of scrolling - can be slowed down and speeded up to some degree. As well as a forward-firing gun
column3: the car can be made to jump huge distances. This is necessary to avoid background obstacles such as rock falls and broken bridges. It can also be used to avoid incoming enemy fire and vehicles. Land mines also litter the levels and need to be shot or avoided.

column1: Kyohkoh-Toppa consists of five stages: Mountain
column2: Bridge
column3: Prairie
column4: City and Airfield."

509;bubblem;bubblem;Bubble Memories - The Story of Bubble Bobble III (c) 1995 Taito.
;The third and final arcade outing for Bub and Bob (not counting the 'Puzzle Bobble' series)
column2: Bubble Memories returns once more to the classic
column3: single-screen gameplay of the series' legendary first outing. Graphically
column4: the game is very similar to 'Bobble Bobble II'
column5: released a year earlier; the only real visual difference between the two is the latter game's use of some rather charmless digitized animal photographs that form the game's backdrops.

column1: One new gameplay addition
column2: however
column3: is the introduction of 'Super Bubbles'; There are now two sizes of bubble. Hold down the bubble button for about 1 second until you glow to produce a giant bubble. This giant bubble can trap either a single large enemy
column4: or several smaller enemies. This replaces the 'Multiple Bubble' facility of the previous game in the series; 'Bubble Bobble II'."

column1: 511;bubbles;bubbles;"Bubbles (c) 1982 Williams.

;In Bubbles you control a cartoon soap bubble inside a large sink. The object of the game is clean out the sink. You can safely scrub away ants, grease, and crumbs all the time. But sponges, roaches, brushes, and razor blades are deadly to a small bubble. Don't worry too much though, because your bubble grows in size as it swallows up the dirt in the sink. When it gets big enough it will be able to hit brushes and sponges (but still not razors).

column1: - UPDATES -
Revision 2 (October 1986 in USA):
* Software version : 1.0
Revision 3 (November 1986 in USA):
* Software version 5.1
* Added mode selection at the beginning of the game (Normal or Super mode).
In Super mode :
The rooms are all in different colors.
All 'Zen-Chan' are replaced by 'Hidegonsu' and vice-versa.
All 'Mighta' are replaced by 'Drunk' and vice-versa.
All 'Monsta' are replaced by 'PulPul' and vice-versa.
The only monster that remains unchanged is 'Banebou'.
'Invader' does not appear at all in Super mode ('Hidegonsu' takes its place)."

516;bublbob2;bublbob2o;"Bubble Bobble II (c) 1994 Taito.
;Bubble Bobble II
column2: also known as Bubble Symphony
column3: is the first direct sequel to Taito's 1986 platform classic
column4: ""Bubble Bobble"" ('Rainbow Islands' was the first official sequel
column5: but played very differently) in which one or two players take on the role of the infamous bubble-blowing dinosaurs who must once again fight their way through a large number of single-screen platform-based levels
column6: trapping monsters with their bubbles before bursting them to destroy the trapped enemies.

column1: While the game plays identically to its predecessor
column2: several new changes and additions have been made to breathe new life into the classic gameplay. As well as new bonuses
column3: weapons
column4: enemies and characters
column5: players can now create 'Multiple Bubbles'; if the player holds the button down for a few seconds before releasing
column6: up to three bubbles are produced at once.

column1: Other gameplay changes include Boss encounters that occur every five to ten levels. These boss screens are part of a new 'branching level' structure; once a boss is defeated
column2: players chose to enter one of two doors to determine what level set they tackle next.

column1: In addition to the Bubble Bobble's original heroes
column2: Bub and Bob
column3: two new selectable female characters have been added
column4: called Kululun and Cororon. Each of the four dinosaurs possess different gameplay attributes
column5: which are as follows :

column1: * Bubblun - Average
* Bobblun - Faster speed
* Kululun - Bubbles float the furthest
* Cororon - Bubbles float the fastest
The game's graphics are
column2: inevitably
column3: a vast improvement over the original game; with lush
column4: colourfully rendered backgrounds and detailed
column5: smoothly animated sprites doing full justice to Bubble Bobble's legendary characters. The game also features cameo appearances by a number of characters from many other Taito classics.

column1: The game features multiple endings."
517;bublbobl;bublbobl1;"Bubble Bobble (c) 1986 Taito Corp.
;One or two players take on the role of Bub and Bob
column2: two cute dinosaurs who must battle through 100 platform-packed single screen levels to rescue their girlfriends. Bub and Bob are armed only with the ability to blow bubbles
column3: in which the game's many enemies can be trapped and killed. The bubbles can also be used as temporary platforms
column4: to help the dinosaurs reach previously inaccessible areas of a level.

column1: Any trapped enemies who are not killed quickly enough will turn red and escape their bubble prison. These angry enemies are much faster than before
column2: making them harder to kill. Enemies also become angry if players are taking too long to complete a level. Defeated enemies are turned into bonus fruit items that can be collected for points.

column1: On many levels
column2: bubbles containing fire
column3: water or a lightning bolt appear. These can be burst by players to release their contents and destroy enemies. The fire bubble drops flames down onto the nearest platform
column4: killing any enemies it hits. The lightning bubble sends a lightning bolt horizontally across the screen
column5: its direction dictated by whichever side of the bubble the player hits to burst it. The water bubble releases a torrent of water that will quickly flow down the platforms to the bottom of the screen. Any enemies caught in the flow are killed.

column1: Bubbles containing letters also appear. The aim is to collect the letters needed to speel the word E.X.T.E.N.D. which earns players an extra life.
The game's simple-yet-involving game-play saw Bubble Bobble become an instant classic. Its two-player co-operative mode
column2: coupled with the incredible amount of hidden secrets and potential for strategic play - unheard of in the platform genre - would set the standard by which all other platform games were judged."

column1: 522;buckrog;buckrog;"Buck Rogers - Planet of Zoom  (c) 1982 Sega.

;Buck Rogers: Planet of Zoom is a forward-scrolling rail shooter where the user controls a spaceship in a behind-the-back third-person perspective that must destroy enemy ships and avoid obstacles. The game was notable for its fast pseudo 3-D scaling and detailed sprites. The game would later go on to influence the 1985 Sega hit Space Harrier. Buck is never seen in the game, except presumably in the illustration on the side of the arcade cabinet, and its only real connections to Buck Rogers are the use of the name and the outer space setting. In Japan, the game was known as Zoom 909.

540;bzone;bzonea;Battlezone (c) 1980 Atari
column2: Incorporated.

column1: ;Battlezone is a classic one-player first person 3-D wire frame shoot-em-up in which the player controls a tank patrolling a dangerous war zone. Set in a valley surrounded by mountains
column2: the aim is to destroy as many enemy tanks as possible
column3: while avoiding return fire and destroying or avoiding the homing missiles that occasionally appear.

column1: Enemy tanks come in two varieties; standard slow-moving tanks and fast-moving 'Super Tanks'. A single hit taken from either an enemy tank or homing missile will result in the loss of a player tank. A flying saucer also occasionally appears but does not attack the player and can be either ignored or destroyed for bonus points.
A radar screen at the top of the play area shows the current position of any enemy tanks or missiles within range
column2: and the war zone is littered with indestructible pyramids and boxes that can provide temporary cover. Only a single shot is allowed on screen at any one time so accuracy of shots is vital to survival."

column1: 543;cabal;cabal;"Cabal (c) 1988 TAD Corporation.

;Cabal is a war themed shoot-em-up with one or simultaneous two-player gameplay in which two unnamed commandos must battle through five different stages - each containing four screens of play - to reach and defeat an evil dictator.

The game is an into-the-screen shooter with the action viewed from an over-the-shoulder perspective. The commandos can move left and right to avoid incoming fire while the enemies themselves are targeted by moving an on-screen cross-hair over them and pressing fire. If the fire button is held down
column2: the commando remains static
column3: allowing for more accurate targeting of the cross-hair. While static
column4: the commandos are vulnerable to incoming enemy fire.

column1: Initially
column2: the commandos are armed with only a standard single-shot gun (albeit with unlimited-ammunition) and a limited number of grenades
column3: but additional grenades and weapon power-ups can be earned as play progresses.

column1: As well as enemy troops
column2: vehicles such as tanks
column3: armoured cars and helicopters also appear and take numerous shots to destroy. When destroyed or killed
column4: some on-screen targets release points bonuses and weapon power-ups that drop to the bottom of the screen and can be picked up by the commandos. Weapon power-ups include additional grenades
column5: a rapid-fire machine and an automatic shotgun
column6: which has a slightly lower firing rate but has a larger targeting cross-hair
column7: allowing it to strike a wider area with each shot.

column1: Each of the game's screens is littered with buildings and barricades that can also be destroyed. This removes enemy cover as well as earning players bonus points."

;The player must guide a ball through a number of mazes

column3: ""Sonic the Hedgehog"". Each maze must be completed within a tight time limit and a number of traps and obstacles litter the mazes to slow players down.

column1: There are
column2: however

column5: the JUMP button can be used. If the player runs out of time before reaching the goal
column6: a random matching game is run to allow the player more time to complete the maze. This challenge
column7: however is very difficult to win."

column1: 560;cannball;cannball;"Cannon Ball [Horizontal Screen version] (c) 1995 Yun Sung.

;This game is like a crossover between ""Arkanoid"" and ""Puzzle Bobble"". You have a paddle and must shoot the ball trying to match with the same color balls on the descending balls. If you connect three or more balls in the same color they will disappear. After the balls disappear
column2: any balls that become detached from the descending structure also disappear. Balls can be shot in three directions: 45 degrees to the left
column3: 45 degrees to the right
column4: or strait up. If you are in difficult situation
column5: you can shoot a bomb.

column1: Once you clear a set number of disappearances
column2: the stage is cleared and the player is rewarded with a digitized photo image of an Asian girl in her underwear.  Each stage features a different picture with a different girl.

column1: If the descending balls reach the players paddle
column2: then the game is over. If you continue you restart at previous stage."

562;canyon;canyon;Canyon Bomber (c) 1977 Atari.

;Canyon Bomber is a 2-D shooter. You control either the blimp or the plane while dropping bombs on the rocks below. Your goal is to get the highest amount of points (either against the computer or another player). You are allowed so many misses before your game ends. Misses are counted as the times you do not hit any rocks. The scores for the rocks are directly proportional to the difficulty in hitting those rocks. This game boils down to precision bombing and thinking ahead as to where the next bomb will fall. Good luck in taking out all of the rocks in the canyon.

567;captaven;captaven;Captain America and the Avengers (c) 1991 Data East Corp.

;A side-scrolling beat'em up (punctuated with occasional shoot'em up sections) in which one or more players take on the role of either Captain America, Iron Man, Vision, or Hawkeye as they prepare to do battle with Red Skull and his henchmen. Each player character has a different weapon or power that can be used throughout the game to assist them in combat. Captain America uses his shield, Iron Man uses his repulsor rays, Vision uses his solar beam and Hawkeye uses his bow and arrows. There are also additional superheroes such as Quicksilver, Sub-Mariner, Wonder Man, and The Wasp who appear at certain points in the game to assist the player characters. Some of the super-villain foes that await the heroes are Klaw, The Living Laser, Whirlwind, The Grim Reaper, The Wizard, The Controllers, The Mandarin, The Juggernaut (from X-Men), Ultron and Crossbones. The game consists of all five stages.

column1: 578;carnevil;carnevil;"CarnEvil (c) 1998 Midway Games
column2: Incorporated.

column1: ;CarnEvil is a rail shooter arcade game using a light gun. The game is set in the fictional town of Greeley Valley
column2: Iowa. The main character's
column3: Jacob (Player 1) and Lisa (Player 2)
column4: join a tractor-drawn trailer called Spooky Sam's Ghost Tour on its path through a cemetery. According to an urban legend
column5: if a golden token is inserted into the jester's mouth on top of the tombstone of someone by the name of Ludwig Von Tökkentäkker
column6: a haunted amusement park will rise from the earth.

column1: Jacob leaves the tour with his friend
column2: Lisa
column3: and approaches the tombstone to find a golden coin sitting in a small hole on the tombstone
column4: and surprised
column5: Jacob inserts the coin into the jester's mouth
column6: resulting in the legendary undead carnival rising from the ground. Jacob and Lisa take 2 [shotgun or shotguns] from the shooting gallery at the entrance and use them to fight through hordes of monsters
column7: zombies
column8: and insects as they escape.

column1: First
column2: Jacob and Lisa go to the ""Rickety Town"". There
column3: they hop on the ""Slay Ride"" and battle several demonic elves
column4: zombies dressed as goofy dinosaurs and flying bug like things and see Betty trapped on a ferris wheel. Finally
column5: they battle ""Krumpas""
column6: a Santa Claus like monster.

column1: Jacob and Lisa then go to the ""Haunted House"" and battle through hordes of zombies
column2: spiders
column3: ghosts and bats. They notice that Betty is being chased by zombies. Jacob and Lisa enter the building and encounter Hambone
column4: a large Jason Vorhees-like creature with a gatling gun for a hand. Jacob and Lisa defeat Hambone and proceed through the building. They find Betty being kidnapped by a Giant Spider upstairs and go after them. After going through ""the hall of hands""
column5: Jacob and Lisa fight Hambone once again
column6: who now has a skull launching grenade launcher for a hand
column7: and is defeated again. Jacob and Lisa go onto the rooftop only to be pushed off by the car into a grave with a tombstone saying ""Rest in Pieces"". Jacob and Lisa at last fight ""Evil Marie"" who
column8: after being defeated
column9: falls on a tombstone.

column1: The 2 then visit the ""Freak Show"" where they encounter Conjoined Acrobatic Men
column2: Flies and Maggots with human heads
column3: 8 legged monkeys
column4: and a giant demon called ""Eye-clops""
column5: a cyclops with more than one eye. They kill the monster and enter ""The Chamber of Horrors""
column6: where they find Betty in a torture device. They leave to a Colosseum and fight ""Junior""
column7: a Frankenstein-Like baby (or through the options menu
column8: they can fight ""Deddy""
column9: a disfigured Teddy Bear).

column1: Then
column2: they enter the Big Top
column3: and fight clowns and circus animals to reach the center ring
column4: whence they are taken to Tökkentäkker's zeppelin to face Tökkentäkker and his jester Umlaut.

column1: After defeating Tökkentäkker and surviving the explosion of his airship
column2: Jacob
column3: Lisa
column4: and Betty awaken a few hours later in a pile of leaves in the cemetery
column5: and in front of Tökkentäkker's tombstone. Jacob then sees the token in its slot and
column6: ignoring Betty's protests
column7: puts it into the jester's mouth for a repeat performance."

column1: 579;carnival;carnival;"Carnival (c) 1980 Gremlin/Sega Ind.
column2: Incorporated.

column1: ;CARNIVAL is a 1 or 2 player alternate action game that simulates a carnival shooting gallery. The playfield consists of three target rows
column2: a rotating pipe wheel
column3: a bonus message panel
column4: and a 'special' target block.

column1: The player uses a left right control to position a rifle at the bottom of the screen
column2: and a shoot control to fire the rifle. Two rows of bullets at the bottom of the screen indicate the number of shots remaining to the player. Every time the player shoots
column3: one of the bullets disappears from the screen. More bullets are given during the first round than the others
column4: so
column5: the inexperienced player will have a chance to enjoy the play.

column1: The game ends when the player runs out of bullets. This can occur on any round. A round ends when the player clears the playfield of all targets. At this point
column2: a special 'shoot the bear' sequence appears
column3: and when this is finished the player proceeds to the next more difficult (and higher scoring) round. This is Gremlin's Multi-Phase design concept that keeps games challenging to players of all levels.

column1: When a player completes a round (ending with 'shoot the bear' sequence)
column2: the screen flips to the other player. When the original player resumes play
column3: he advances to the next level of difficulty
column4: exactly as he would have if the screen had not flipped to the other player. This method allows the players to more directly compare their scores
column5: since they are always within one round of each other. Note that the player who ends the game first does not necessarily lose--he might still have the higher score when the game ends.

column1: The three target rows move in a horizontal line from left to right (top row)
column2: right to left (middle row) and left to right (bottom row). There are five types of targets. The rows move as a continuous band--the targets exiting the playfield from the right side of the bottom row reappear at the left of the top row. The point value for hitting a row target is indicated along the right side of the game--maximum points for a top row target
column3: medium points for a middle row target
column4: and minimum points for a bottom row target. These values increase from round to round.

column1: Rabbits and owls are simple targets
column2: which disappear when hit.

column1: Numbered sign targets award additional bullets to the player when hit
column2: as well as awarding the points indicated for the row. These targets appear only on the top two rows to make them relatively difficult targets.

column1: Five small letters
column2: B
column4: N
column5: U and S are randomly interspersed through the target rows. At the upper right of the playfield is the word ''bonus"" spelled out is small letters. If the player manages to hit the moving bonus letters in order (b-o-n-u-s) a special bonus is awarded. The fact that the bonus is still active is shown by the bonus word in the upper right of the playfield. Every time a bonus letter in the correct order is hit
column6: the small corresponding letter in the bonus panel enlarges to show that it has been hit. Whenever a bonus letter is hit out of order
column7: the bonus panel disappears until the next round. The bonus panel reappears at the beginning of every round. The bonus value is determined by adding row target points into the bonus value. When the ""B"" letter is hit
column8: the bonus value freezes for that round. This encourages waiting as long as possible before attempting to score the bonus.

column1: Ducks are special targets. Whenever a duck reaches the bottom row
column2: it is capable of leaving the row and flying down toward the player. If the duck manages to get past the player's rifle without being shot
column3: it flies down to the bullet row and quickly eats 10 bullets. A maximum of three ducks can escape simultaneously.

column1: The target rows move as a continuous band of targets
column2: and no new owls
column3: rabbits
column4: or bonus letter targets are added once the round starts. 'More shots' targets and ducks are added during a round. The frequency of adding duck targets is tied to the round number. As the rounds get more difficult
column5: more ducks are added as the round progresses.

column1: A flying duck hit scores no points.
Bullets left over at the end of a round earn 50 points each.
The between rounds 'shoot the bear' sequence operates as a shooting gallery bear. Whenever the bear is hit
column2: it rears up
column3: roars
column4: and continues motion in the opposite direction. Each hit speeds up the bear
column5: and increases the point value
column6: which is shown above the bear for each hit. When the bear leaves the screen (which it will always do eventually
column7: since it speeds up with each hit) the between rounds sequence ends and a new round begins. As the rounds progress
column8: more bears (a maximum of 4) appear on the screen simultaneously.

column1: A special yellow-rimmed score panel appears in the upper left of the playfield
column2: and stays on for random lengths of time. Four types of panels appear here
column3: which either add or subtract points or bullets. Hitting any part of the panel border awards the score shown inside.

column1: The bullet bonus panel is shown with a large plus sign
column2: and a row of bullets. Immediately after appearing
column3: the bullets begin disappearing fairly rapidly. When the bullets are depleted
column4: the panel disappears. If hit
column5: the player is awarded the number of bullets left in the panel when it was hit.

column1: The score bonus is shown with the same large plus sign
column2: and a score value. As with the bullets
column3: the score value quickly decreases
column4: until it hits zero and disappears.

column1: The minus panels are similar to those above except a large minus sign indicates the number of bullets or points subtracted when hit. This discourages the practice of parking on the left margin and shooting--a miss will hit the negative target. These panels show a fixed number of bullets or points
column2: and after a random time interval
column3: disappear.

column1: The pipe wheel contains 8 pipes of 4 different colors. A panel beneath the wheel restricts pipe hits to horizontally oriented pipes
column2: and also indicates the point value for hitting a pipe. Every shot the player takes decrements the pipe value
column3: except a shot which hits a pipe. This makes it advisable to hit pipes early in the round
column4: when it is most difficult (since the player must shoot through heavily populated target rows). Hitting two pipes of the same color with two consecutive shots awards a bonus of four times the pipe value shown in the panel.

column1: CARNIVAL is accompanied by background music. At the beginning of every round
column2: the music begins at a slow rate and relatively low key. As the round progresses
column3: the music speeds up and the melody shifts up in key. This gives the player a growing sense of urgency. As the round progresses
column4: the playfield motion also gradually speeds up.

column1: A small panel on the right of the playfield contains a musical note symbol. If the player wishes to turn off the music
column2: he simply shoots the note panel. This makes the note disappear
column3: and turns off the music. Hitting the panel again makes the note reappear and resumes the music. The note thus acts as a 'flip-flop' switch to turn the music on and off.

column1: Every round begins with the music on.
There is a special case to consider near the end of a round: the player has cleared all of the targets except the ducks
column2: and has plenty of bullets left so that he can simply sit and wait for the ducks. He would
column3: in effect
column4: prolong the game by refusing to end the round.

column1: Theoretically
column2: by hitting the ducks and 'more shots' signs
column3: the round could be prolonged indefinitely. However
column4: an internal ""doomsday"" timer in the game keeps track of how long a round has lasted. After a certain time limit (the same for each round)
column5: the frequency of new duck appearances increases dramatically.

column1: The top 3 scores are shown during advertising
column2: along with the player's initials. A player who scores in the top 3 is allowed to enter 3 initials by a special routine explained at the time of their writing. The rank is updated during the round. The player is both audibly and visually rewarded. There is a pronounced audible sound as the player's score passes that of another ranking player's score. And
column3: they may watch their rank progress during the game.

column1: CARNIVAL's basic play action is outlined below
column2: as it appears in the game instructions.

column1: Shoot all targets and pipes to advance to the next round.
Game is over when you run out of bullets.
Escaped ducks eat 10 bullets.
Hit B-O-N-U-S letters in sequence for special bonus. Bonus value stops increasing when 'B' is hit.
Hit same color pipes with 2 consecutive shots to score 4 times pipe value. Shoot number signs for more bullets.
Shoot the bear between rounds for extra points."

column1: 581;carpolo;carpolo;Car Polo (c) 1977 Exidy.

;Car Polo is an 'up-to-four player' full color video game that combines the skills of driving with the intense player interaction of team sports. The object is to score by bumping or pushing the ball with a car into your team's goal. Teamwork revolves around passing and blocking strategy. Play becomes fast and furious, and excitement is enhanced by car motor noises, crash sounds, controlled grass skids and bouncing ball motions.
582;castfant;castfant;Astro Fantasia (c) 1981 Data East Corp.

;This is a ""Galaga"" style vertical shoot'em up with a few unique twists that make it interesting. You pilot a single fighter ship against an armada of enemies (sound familiar?). There are 2 different play screens that alternate.

The opening screen uses pseudo 3-D graphics and has a large red bit of what appears to be machinery (or perhaps part of a very large spaceship) as background on the bottom half of the screen. You can move your ship around anywhere on the red background
column2: but the black area beyond is off limits.

column1: The game opens with a large mothership craft visible at the top of the screen
column2: but your shots cannot reach it at this point. Red UFOs quickly begin attacking you
column3: swooping in line formations from the top area of the screen. They actually scale in size as they get closer to you (a nice effect for a 1981 raster title). By moving around you will discover that the screen can scroll upwards quite a bit
column4: and the enemy armada comes into view if you get near the top of your area.

column1: The armada consists of several rows of ships in classic ""Space Invaders"" style
column2: except for the fact that they are tiny. You can quickly blast the armada away
column3: as you have twin shots on this opening screen
column4: and you can have several sets of them on screen at once (it really only takes a few seconds to take out the armada).

column1: After the armada is gone
column2: the mothership begins spewing out groups of red UFOs (who make suicide runs at your ship)
column3: and a new green ship that actually fires at you. Be sure and shoot these green ships quickly
column4: as they split into 3 separate enemies once they reach your movable territory. Eventually the mothership will stop spewing fighters at you
column5: and the entire screen will scroll up (taking you completely away from your red 'home base')
column6: and the game will begin the second wave.

column1: The second wave pits you against the mothership directly. You will find that your multi shot is gone
column2: and you can only have one shot on the screen at a time. The mothership has 3 areas that must be blasted away (a 'spark' on each side
column3: and then the center which takes several more hits than the sparks do). The mothership does not flash
column4: or otherwise provide any feedback on a successful hit
column5: but just blast away
column6: and eventually you will get it.

column1: After killing the mothership
column2: the game will award you bonus points based upon how much fuel you have left and then the game will begin again with increased difficulty."

column1: 583;catapult;catapult;"Catapult (c) 1982 Epos.

;The player controls a dog named Bruno who must catapult cats and mice out of his owner's house before the cats destroy all the furniture.
584;catch22;catch22;Catch-22 (c) 1985 Exidy.

;A shooting game with a military motif. The player uses a gun, mounted to the cabinet, to protect allies from a variety of dangers while attempting to break through and conquer enemy lines and get promoted to a higher rank (from Private to General Of The Army) and be awarded a campaign medal.
585;cavelon;cavelon;Cavelon (c) 1983 Jetsoft.

;In this horizontally-scrolling maze game, You the heroic knight must reach the top floor of Castle Cavelon, rescue a fair maiden and do battle with the Black Wizard!  Armed with bow and arrow and a magic sword, you must avoid or kill the castle security guards while collecting the 8 pieces of the exit door that are scattered around the corridors, in order to proceed to the next floor.
586;cavenger;cavenger;Cosmic Avenger (c) 1981 Universal.
;An early space shoot'em up game.
How to Play:
1. Your Avenger can be moved in 8 directions. The speed increases as it advances
column2: while it decreases as it retreats.

column1: 2. Destroy the front enemy by pressing the Fire Button
column2: and destroy the target below by pressing the Bomb Button.

column1: 3. The enemy UFO will assault you flying either from in front of you or from behind you.  You can locate it by using the radar.
4. A tough chase missile will pursue your Avenger persistently. Dodge it successfully
column2: and you can cause the enemy to fight among themselves.

column1: 5. When you pass the enemy radar site
column2: an ant-aircraft gun will fire at your according to the altitude of your Avenger.

column1: 6. When the screen advances further
column2: the X station will appear. When you destroy it in good time
column3: you can destroy all the targets appearing on the screen at once. You are then awarded a high score.

column1: 7. Your Avenger will be destroyed when it is affected by any explosion.
8. The 1st – 5th highest scores for the day can enter their names on the screen."

column1: 588;cawingj;cawingj;"U.S. Navy (c) 1990 Capcom.

;A solid and hugely playable sequel to 1989's superb sideways scrolling shoot-em-up, Area 88. As with the original, players chose any one of three different jet fighters and battle their way through ten enemy-packed stages. Another idea carried over from Area 88 is the end-of-level shop, which allows players to buy weapon and shield upgrades for their jet fighter.

596;cbuster;cbuster;"Crude Buster (c) 1990 Data East.

;In the near future, ruthless gangs are the new rulers of the streets. Only a brave duo of seasoned street brawlers can end this terror and return peace to the streets. Don't forget to grab and use anything you can find as a weapon (pipes, stones, signs, cars, even enemies!) to survive this onslaught. Features solid graphics & sound and very fun gameplay mechanics!

600;ccastle2;ccastles2;Crystal Castles (c) 1983 Atari.
;Crystal Castles is an inventive variation on the maze-driven collect-the-dots gameplay first seen in Namco's legendary ""Pac-Man"". The player takes on the role of 'Bentley Bear'
column2: who must run around a number of ""castles"" - each presented in the form of an isometric forced 3D maze - picking up the gemstones that litter its walkways and platforms
column3: before moving onto the next castle.

column1: Each level is populated by a variety of enemies
column2: including sentient trees
column3: gem eaters
column4: a swarm of bees and Berthilda the Witch. Some enemy types move around the levels randomly
column5: while others will actively chase Bentley. Gem Eaters will devour any gems they reach before the player.

column1: In addition to four-directional walking
column2: Bentley can also jump to avoid pursuing enemies and obstacles. Many levels have platforms that can only be reached via an elevator and some screens also contain hidden secret passages and ramps
column3: as well as 'warps' that move players forward several levels.

column1: Jumping over the trees will shrink and temporarily disable them
column2: while wearing Berthilda's red hat grants the player temporary invincibility
column3: allowing them to kill the witch should they manage to catch her. If Bentley Bear touches a Gem Eater while it's in the process of eating a gem
column4: the Gem Eater dies and 500 points are awarded to the player. However
column5: if the Gem Eater is not eating a gem when touched
column6: Bentley Bear dies.

column1: Some levels contain a large pot of honey. A swarm of bees appears near the honey approximately every five seconds but collecting the honey pot earns the player 1
column2: 000 bonus points and causes the bees to appear less frequently. Other enemies
column3: such as the balls
column4: skeletons and ghosts must be avoided.

column1: If Bentley collects all of the gems on a castle
column2: the player receives bonus points. A bonus is also awarded in the event of the player picking up the last gem on the level.

column1: Crystal Castles consists of ten different stages broken down into 37 castle mazes (with four castles making up each stage
column2: apart from 10th
column3: which has only one castle)."

column1: 603;ccboot;ccboot;"Crazy Climber (c) 1980 Nichibutsu [Nihon Bussan Company
column2: Limited.].

column1:
;Crazy Climber is a 2-D, strategy style game. The game is strategic in the fact that you must plan your moves as you climb up the building and anticipate the hazards that await you. You start out the game at the bottom of a building to be scaled. As you climb up the building, you will be assailed by bald people throwing flowerpots, signs with loose electrical wires, very large apes, falling signs, trash and barbells, and a bird that likes to drop bad things on your character. Your goal is to make it to the top of the building and catch the helicopter, which will transport you to the next building to be scaled. Of course, you will be rewarded for quickly making it up the building by getting a bonus (that is as long as you can catch the helicopter). The things one does for publicity.
604;ccboot2;ccboot2;Crazy Climber (c) 1980 Nichibutsu [Nihon Bussan Company
column2: Limited.].

column1:
;Crazy Climber is a 2-D, strategy style game. The game is strategic in the fact that you must plan your moves as you climb up the building and anticipate the hazards that await you.
