;Depthcharge is a 2-Dimensional shooter. You control your destroyer on the surface of the water while submarines patrol underneath. Your job is to drop depth charges to eliminate these submarines. The submarines aren't defenseless as they launch mines straight up toward your ship.
Depthcharge was one of the early video games. Action was simple. This game also had the ability to retain the highest score (without the initials of course). Although the game is simple in concept
column2: just trying to get enough points was enough to keep you working at it. Good luck on your submarine hunting mission."

986;dfeveron;dfeveron;Dangun Feveron (c) 1998 Cave.
;A vertically scrolling shoot-em-up from the undisputed masters of the genre
column2: 'Cave'
column3: Dangun Feveron features the usual Cave trademarks of intuitive
column4: power-up driven gameplay backed-up with superb graphics and sound.

column1: Dangun Feveron features a very high level of player customisation. At the start of a new game
column2: players are prompted to select 3 different ship attributes; the speed of ship they wish to pilot (from a choice of four)
column3: which of the 3 rapid-fire weapons they prefer
column4: and their preferred choice of sustained-fire weapons (activated by holding down the FIRE button). This allows players to tailor the ship to suit their individual needs and gameplay styles
column5: be it a fast-flying speeder with widespread shots to handle enemy squadrons
column6: or a ship with a lower speed that makes it easier to negotiate the swathes of enemy bullets that often fill the screen.

column1: Another of the game's selling points is the capture-and-score system. Initially
column2: every enemy destroyed is worth only one point. However
column3: whenever an enemy is destroyed
column4: coloured spheres appear in its wake
column5: each containing a trapped
column6: human prisoner. The spheres can then be collected by the player to earn additional points. For each prisoner saved
column7: the total points gained from each enemy killed increases by one. For example
column8: saving 56 prisoners means every subsequent defeated enemy is worth fifty-seven points. When the spheres appear
column9: they drift slowly towards the bottom of the screen
column10: before moving back up towards the top where
column11: if they are not collected in time
column12: they drift out of the screen and beyond the player's reach. This resets enemy-destroyed score back to a single point per enemy. If the player loses all of their lives and chooses to 'Continue' the game
column13: the rescue count is reset to zero.

column1: Dangun Feveron's final distinction was in its use of music and sound effects
column2: with the game's creators drawing heavily on the disco sound of the 1970s."

column1: 987;dharma;dharmaj;;
988;diamond;diamond;"Diamond Run (c) 1989 KH Video.
;An arcade puzzle game in which a single player must tunnel their way through a number of underground caves
column2: collecting the many gems spread throughout the levels. Each cave is littered with rocks which
column3: should they fall onto the player
column4: will result in a loss of life. Carefully planned tunnels can be dug to manipulate the direction in which the rocks fall
column5: however
column6: which makes them an effective weapon against the many enemies that populate the levels. A number of red explosives can be found which can also be used to kill enemies and also to destroy any walls blocking the player's path. Again
column7: like the rocks
column8: these must be used carefully to prevent the explosion from killing the player.

column1: In order to complete a level
column2: a specified number of gems must be collected. Once a sufficient amount of gems have been collected
column3: an exit will open which the player must enter to proceed to the next cave.

column1: Diamond Run is heavily based on First Star's Commodore C64 classic
column2: 'Boulder Dash'."

column1: 989;diehard;diehard;;
990;digdug;digdug;"Dig Dug (c) 1982 Namco.
;Dig Dug is a 1- or 2-player game with a color raster-scan video display. The screen shows a cutaway view of the land
column2: most of which is below ground. The player controls the Dig Dug character who travels through and digs tunnels in the dirt. The object is for Dig Dug to destroy monsters by pumping them up or dropping rocks on them and to capture vegetables.

column1: Gameplay takes place on a cutaway section of the land. The characters are Dig Dug and two monsters - one is a round
column2: orange monster with goggles called Pooka
column3: the other is a green
column4: fire-breathing dragon named Fygar. The underground area is divided into four different colored layers of dirt. Rocks are scattered in the dirt. The sky is at the top of the screen.

column1: The player controls Dig Dug
column2: the hero of the garden
column3: clad in white. He moves through horizontal and vertical tunnels. When Dig Dug digs new tunnels he moves slowly. When he is on the surface or in an existing tunnel
column4: he moves faster. The object of the game is for Dig Dug to destroy all the monsters and go to the next round.

column1: Monsters are trapped in caves. A monster may get out of a cave two ways. Dig Dug may dig him out. Then
column2: the monster chases Dig Dug. The monster may also get out of the cave by turning into a ghost. As a ghost
column3: he cannot be destroyed. The ghost does not travel in the tunnels. He travels through the dirt
column4: and can travel diagonally. However
column5: he reappears as the monster when he goes into a tunnel.

column1: The monsters move faster than Dig Dug in vertical tunnels and slower on the surface. They destroy Dig Dug by catching him. In addition
column2: Fygar can destroy Dig Dug by breathing fire on him. Fygar can only breathe fire horizontally. The fire can also penetrate thin layers of dirt.

column1: Dig Dug destroys the monsters by pumping them up until they burst
column2: or by causing rocks to drop on them. To pump up and destroy a monster
column3: the player presses and holds down the Pump button. It is possible to stun a monster for a few seconds by pressing the pump button once or twice. While a monster is stunned
column4: Dig Dug may pass over him without being destroyed. If two monsters are very close together
column5: only one may be stunned. The other will catch and destroy Dig Dug.

column1: Dig Dug must dig tunnels under the rocks to get them to drop. A rock may fall in a vertical or horizontal tunnel. A rock also goes through a thin layer of dirt from one tunnel to the next. In a vertical tunnel
column2: Dig Dug may stay directly under a rock and it will not drop. However
column3: in a horizontal tunnel
column4: Dig Dug must move out from under a rock right away
column5: or he will be crushed.

column1: After two rocks are dropped
column2: a vegetable (worth extra points
column3: see Scoring below) appears in a tunnel in the center of the screen. Dig Dug has ten seconds to capture (touch) the vegetable or it will disappear. There is only one vegetable per round.

column1: The game progresses by rounds. Round 1 starts with four monsters (one Fygar and three Pookas) and three rocks. The vegetable is a carrot. One flower on the surface (top right of the screen) represents Round 1. Two flowers represent Round 2
column2: etc. As the rounds progress
column3: the monsters move a little faster
column4: and are better at avoiding falling rocks. In each round
column5: the last monster tries to escape. If he is not caught by Dig Dug
column6: he exits on the surface (top left).

column1: The game ends when all of Dig Dug's lives are used up. A player may continue to play at the beginning of the same round (level) by following instructions on the screen. He or she has 16 seconds to insert a coin(s). Then he or she must push and hold the Pump and Start buttons at the same time."
991;digdug2;digdug2;"Dig Dug II (c) 1985 Namco.
;For this sequel to the 1982 classic
column2: ""Dig Dug""
column3: Namco changed the game's perspective from a sideways viewpoint
column4: to an overhead one. Action now takes place on a series of small islands.

column1: The gameplay itself retains much from its predecessor
column2: with players still armed with a pump that allows them to inflate and burst the enemies. For this sequel
column3: however
column4: Namco also introduced ground-based charges. Players can activate the charges in order to join them up with other charges
column5: represented on screen by the appearance of trenches. Once a line of charges is linked to two of the island's edges
column6: the charges will detonate and destroy a piece of the island
column7: killing any enemies that happen to be standing on the piece when it's destroyed. Players must be careful not to be standing on a piece that is destroyed
column8: or they themselves will be killed."

column1: The gameplay itself retains much from its predecessor

column7: killing any enemies that happen to be standing on the piece when it's destroyed. Players must be careful not to be standing on a piece that is destroyed

996;digger;digger;"Digger (c) 1980 Gremlin Ind.

;Digger is a game that requires you to dig strategically placed holes within a maze format so you can capture and fill in over the invading creatures before they can attack and destroy your man. The maze format changes with every round played.
The creatures are confined behind a wall. In the first of three rounds of game play
column2: four creatures are let out of the holding area through a gate. You must conquer these four before advancing to the next round
column3: where you face six creatures. Your third round has you battling eight creatures. This process is repeated and the point value increased with each three-round victory. Also
column4: creatures' speed increases each round. Any contact at all with the creatures will be fatal to your man.

column1: While you are busy digging holes and entrapping creatures
column2: the rest are behind the retaining wall scurrying back and forth. After about three minutes
column3: the gates at each end will open and all of the remaining creatures will stream into the play area at once. However
column4: a skillful player will conquer all of the creatures of each round and the gate will not be a threat."

;Bootleg of the famous Nintendo's original.
1017;dkong3j;dkong3j;Donkey Kong 3 (c) 1983 Nintendo.
;The third and final arcade outing for Donkey Kong sees the giant ape once again cast as the enemy. Unlike the first two Donkey Kong games
column2: the legendary character Mario is not featured in this game. Instead
column3: the player takes on the role of Stanley the Bugman
column4: a gardener who is armed with a bug spray with which he must destroy the swarms of insects that attack him and try to steal his plants.

column1: Each level has five plants that must be protected. Stanley must also spray Kong to force the ape to the top of the screen and complete the level.
- CAST OF CHARACTERS -
Stanley - Stanley's job is to defend the greenhouse that Donkey Kong has invaded. He does this with his trusty bug spray. When Stanley pumps his spray can
column2: the spray travels a certain distance before dissipating so it's not useful against targets that are far away. Stanley primarily uses his bug spray to zap bugs or to make Donkey Kong scoot up the vines that he holds onto. In order to complete each stage
column3: Stanley's goal is to either push Donkey Kong all the way up the vine using bug spray
column4: or defeat every insect present in that stage. There are many ways for Stanley to lose a life
column5: including touching an insect
column6: getting shot by any of the bee stingers
column7: running out of time
column8: or allowing Donkey Kong to slip off the bottom of the vine.

column1: Donkey Kong - Nintendo's favorite simian seems to have been working out a little bit compared to his previous appearances. Donkey Kong attempts to keep himself above harm's way by hanging onto two vines that descend from the greenhouse ceiling. If left alone
column2: Donkey Kong slips down the vines little by little
column3: hoping to land on Stanley by surprise. Occasionally
column4: he will reach over to one of the two beehives along side him and tap them in order to send more bees after Stanley. In the yellow stages
column5: he even grabs coconuts from time to time and lobs them at Stanley's head. Starting in round 15
column6: he will throw coconuts at you regardless of the stage.

column1: Super Spray - One time for every one of Stanley's lives
column2: a more powerful bug spray will be perched on Donkey Kong's right vine. When Stanley pushes Donkey Kong high enough so that his hand is touching the spray
column3: the spray falls to the ground
column4: at which time Stanley can pick it up. The Super Spray lasts for a number of seconds
column5: and continues with Stanley to the next stage until the full time runs out. When this spray is activated
column6: Donkey Kong is forced up the vines much faster
column7: Creepies die when hit
column8: and Queen Bees die in one hit. It will not be replenished after it runs out until Stanley loses a life
column9: so it's not a good idea to plan your strategy around it's use.

column1: Beespy & Buzzbee - These bugs are the primary attack force of the hive. Stanley starts the game squaring off against the Beespies as they swoop down and try to steal Stanley's vegetables. Starting in round 12
column2: the hive switches to their faster and more aggressive soldiers
column3: the Buzzbees. Buzzbees strike at Stanley more directly than Beespies. Either bee may or may not be accompanying a Queen Bee
column4: but they are dangerous either way.

column1: Queen Bees - Starting in round 3
column2: the Queen Bees of the hive will from time to time enter the fray surrounded by their royal escorts. One shot isn't enough to do them in
column3: it simply changes them from red to blue. Even after you shoot them a second time
column4: the threat isn't over. When killed
column5: they split up in to 4 tiny projectiles that can kill you if they connect. You are only safe directly beneath them when they die.

column1: Buttifly & Beetle - Starting in round 6
column2: the Buttiflies escape from the hive. They fly down along the side of the screen until they are even with Stanley
column3: pause for a brief moment
column4: and then charge across the screen in an attempt to collide with him. They disappear after round 16
column5: only to be replaced with Beetles in round 18
column6: who are bigger and a bit harder to dodge. Beetles do not pause as Buttiflies do
column7: and attack immediately.

column1: Moth - The Moth is the mercenary of the bee hive
column2: employed from round 24 and on. They move erratically
column3: so it's slightly difficult to predict where they are going to end up. They will occasionally attack Stanley
column4: or they will swoop down for his vegetables. Don't let them distract you from your efforts to force Donkey Kong up the vine
column5: but don't get in their way either
column6: or let them fly away with your plants.

column1: Creepy - This worm likes to play interference. In the blue and gray stages
column2: he crawls down to the platforms from the plants along the side of the screen. Once he reaches the platform
column3: he will wiggle back and forth and make a nuisance of himself. He cannot be killed by the normal bug spray
column4: but he is quite allergic to it
column5: and spraying him causes him to stop in his tracks until he finishes coughing. He can be persuaded to climb back up the plant for a while if you blast him with spray before he reaches the platforms. In yellow stages
column6: three or more Creepies will slide along the vines below Donkey Kong and try to get in the way of your bug spray. If you hit one
column7: not only with it absorb the spray
column8: but you'll have to wait for it to finish coughing before he will move on and allow you to shoot Kong. They can be killed by super spray.

column1: Beebomb - After an insect successfully steals one of your plants
column2: it turns into a Beebomb. Beebombs circle around a few times near the hive that they came from
column3: and then immediately dive bomb towards Stanley. They are incredibly fast when diving towards you
column4: but due to their direct attack nature
column5: they are easy to defeat as long as you keep your eyes on them and time a blast of bug spray just as they are about to hit you.

column1: Vine Eater - These creatures appear when the bonus timer runs out. When the timer reaches zero
column2: two of these appear on either side of the screen. They are oblivious to bug spray. When they reach the vines
column3: they eat the vine from the bottom up to the ceiling. If they eat the section of vine that Donkey Kong is holding on to
column4: Donkey Kong falls down and Stanley loses a life just as if he had allowed Donkey Kong to drop off the vine himself."

column1: 1018;dkongjo;dkongjo;"Donkey Kong (c) 1981 Nintendo.
;Donkey Kong is a legendary arcade platform game in which the player takes on the role of ""Jumpman""

column3: he must battle his way to the top of each level to rescue his beloved Pauline; who has been kidnapped by the giant ape
column4: Donkey Kong.

column1: Jumpman is controlled with a joystick and a single JUMP button and must avoid the rolling Barrels thrown at him by Donkey Kong
column2: as well as other enemies
column3: including Fireballs
column4: Cement Pies
column5: Springs
column6: and Firefoxes. Screens are negotiated with the use of ladders
column7: ramps
column8: conveyor belts and elevators.

column1: For additional points
column2: players can collect umbrellas
column3: hats
column4: purses and other bonus items that Pauline has dropped on her way to the top of the building. Jumpman can also grab a hammer to smash Barrels
column5: Beams
column6: Fireballs
column7: Cement Pies
column8: and Firefoxes to earn additional bonus points. The hammer can only be used for a limited time
column9: however
column10: and Jumpman cannot jump or climb ladders while in possession of the hammer.

column1: On the Ramp
column2: Elevator and Conveyor Belt stages
column3: whenever Jumpman reaches Pauline
column4: Donkey Kong will grab her and carry her off to the next level. (Exception: On the Conveyor Belt stage
column5: Jumpman only needs to reach Donkey Kong's platform to clear the stage.)

column1: On the Rivet stage
column2: Jumpman must remove eight rivets by running or jumping over them. After all eight rivets are removed
column3: Donkey Kong will fall head first onto a stack of girders
column4: knocking him out
column5: and Jumpman and Pauline will finally be reunited.

column1: The game then starts over again with an increased level of difficulty.
- CAST OF CHARACTERS -

Jumpman (aka Mario) - This is the one and only Mario who will go on to become one of the biggest video game stars of all time. This is the game that started it all for him. His given profession in Donkey Kong is that of a carpenter
column2: instead of a plumber.

column1: Pauline - Jumpman's girlfriend and damsel in distress. She is stuck at the top of each screen awaiting rescue from the clutches of Donkey Kong. (When the arcade version of the game was first released
column2: she did not have an official name and was just referred to as ""Lady""; she was renamed ""Pauline"" about the same time Jumpman was renamed ""Mario"".)

column1: Donkey Kong - The most well-known video game ape and only character to retain his original name in future games. Donkey Kong has kidnapped Pauline and carried her up to the top of the construction site that Jumpman is working at.
Hammer - Except for the Elevator stage
column2: two hammers can be found on each stage. Jump to grab the hammer and use it to smash nearby dangers for points. It only lasts for a short time and Mario cannot climb ladders while he is holding the hammer.

column1: Barrel - Donkey Kong throws these at Jumpman on the Ramp stage. Many of them roll down the ramps and randomly drop down ladders that they pass. Sometimes Kong throws them directly down the building.
Beam - These are the blue Barrels that Kong throws. The only difference between them and the Barrels is that Beams will turn into Fireballs when they reach the burning can of oil at the bottom.
Fireball - These appear on every stage except the Rivet stage. They move about randomly and can be jumped
column2: but it's dangerous to try because they change directions frequently.

column1: Cement Pie - These appear on the Conveyor Belt stage only. They passively travel along the conveyor belt and are harmful to touch. The only danger they pose is when the conveyor belt suddenly changes directions.
Spring - These bounce along the roof of the Elevator stage before falling down to the bottom of the screen creating a dangerous but predictable obstacle to avoid.
Firefox - The fire enemies that roam around the Rivet stage. They are even harder to jump over and they seem to track Mario a little more closely.
Prizes - Except on the Ramp stage
column2: some of Pauline's dropped items (namely her purse
column3: hat and umbrella) litter the construction site and can be retrieved by Jumpman for bonus points."

column1: 1021;dkongjr;dkongjr;"Donkey Kong Junior (c) 1982 Nintendo of America.
;Export release for North America. Game developed in Japan. For more information about the game itself
column2: please see the ""Donkey Kong Jr."" (Japanese version) entry."

column1: 1022;dkongjrb;dkongjrb;"Donkey Kong Jr. (c) 1982 Nintendo.
;Something of a role reversal for this superb sequel to the seminal 1981 platform-based original
column2: with Mario now cast as the villain (the only Mario game in which this occurred) and Donkey Kong cast as the captured victim.

column1: Donkey Kong's son
column2: DK Jr.
column3: must rescue his captured father from Mario's clutches by climbing and jumping his way over vines
column4: chains and platforms before he can reach his father. Jr. has to race against time while avoiding the horrible Snapjaws
column5: Nitpickers
column6: and Sparks released by Mario.

column1: Like the original
column2: Donkey Kong Jr. features four different stages
column3: but in the US version
column4: one or both of the middle stages are omitted in the first three levels. In the Japanese and bootleg versions
column5: all four stages are played in their logical order. Please refer to the ""Donkey Kong Junior"" (North American version) entry
column6: Updates section
column7: for complete details.

column1: - CAST OF CHARACTERS -
Donkey Kong Jr. - The baby ape in the white unitard with a big J printed on the front
column2: this is the son of Donkey Kong and he must rescue his father from Mario's cage.

column1: Mario - This game is quite possibly the ONLY game in Mario's long history where he is the enemy.
Donkey Kong - Poor DK was captured by Mario after the events portrayed in Donkey Kong. Now he must helplessly watch as his son comes to the rescue.
Snapjaws - These mechanical mouths must be avoided. Blue Snapjaws will drop down a vine and continue to fall off the screen
column2: while Red Snapjaws will climb back up a vine and pose a more permanent threat.

column1: Nitpickers - There are two types of Nitpickers in the game. Small Nitpickers appear on the Springboard Stage and occasionally drop eggs on Jr. as they fly around the top branch. Large Nitpickers appear on the Chains stage and weave back and forth in an attempt to hinder Jr.'s chances at rescuing his father.

Sparks - These volts of electricity patrol the Mario's Hideout Stage. The red variety follows the loop that they begin on while the blue version follows the vertical strips from one level to the next as they drop to the bottom of the screen.

Fruit - Jr. will find various pieces of fruit scattered throughout each stage that he will pluck when he touches them. The fruit will fall and take out any enemy in its path until it reaches the bottom of the screen. They are one of the best sources for bonus points.
Keys - On the first three stages
column2: Jr.'s goal is to reach the key at the top of the stage. Once he jumps onto the vine or chain with the key at the top
column3: he automatically climbs it to the adjacent platform and advances to the next stage. On the Chains Stage
column4: Jr. must push six keys up the chains into the locks positioned at the top of the stage. When all six keys are inserted into the locks
column5: Papa will be set free."

1026;dlair;dlair;Dragon's Lair (c) 1983 Cinematronics.
;Dragon's Lair is THE original laser disc video game
column2: the video and sound sequences for the game are stored on a LASER DISC. This unprecedented game lets a player participate in an animated AND INTERACTIVE motion-picture experience.

column1: Dragon's Lair is the first game born to the new generation of video games. This unprecedented game is the first motion-picture type fairy tale you interact with.
As Dirk the Daring
column2: a player's goal is to rescue the princess. The adventures along the way are horrible and terrifying
column3: but
column4: a skilled and brave knight
column5: like honor and truth
column6: can prevail.

column1: A player has a choice of 5 moves at any given time. A complete game of Dragon's Lair requires more than 200 correct moves. Timing is critical! Dirk can be too hesitant or too eager to make a move. Only experience and a good memory enable Dirk to complete his mission.
The game opens with the dark visage of a foreboding castle looming in the distance. The next thing you know
column2: you are Dirk
column3: running across the castle drawbridge. The gate clangs shut behind you
column4: and your quest to kill the dragon and save Princess Daphne has begun!

column1: More than 40 possible episodes will be presented to you. Some require many fast repeated moves; others will require fewer
column2: more calculated moves.

column1: Dragon's Lair can be a 1-or 2-player game. If 2 play
column2: 2 twin knights engage in mortal combat with the same demons until they both die (use up their lives)
column3: or until one rescues the fair princess from the dragon's lair.

column1: At the beginning of the game
column2: if the player makes a wrong move and loses a life
column3: a new scene will appear at random. Later in the game
column4: a scene that is not completed properly is repeated until it is mastered. Also
column5: when a player loses a life
column6: the scene stops
column7: the screen turns blue
column8: and PLAYER 1 or PLAYER 2 is displayed on the screen
column9: along with that player's number of remaining lives.

column1: As you play the game you may find that sane scenes are repeated
column2: but the image is reversed on the screen (the scene is reversed on the disc
column3: not by the hardware).

column1: Princess Daphne appears during the game
column2: in distress and crying for help. She is unattainable until the end."

column1: 1027;dleague;dleaguej;;
1028;dnmtdeka;dnmtdeka;;
1029;doapp;doapp;"Dead or Alive ++ (c) 1998 Tecmo
column2: Limited.

column1: ;An update of the 1996 original
column2: this game run on the ZN-1 architecture
column3: hardware based the Sony Playstation.

column1: Upon its initial release
column2: the now-respected series drew attention and notoriety as much for the gravity-defying 'bouncing breasts' of its female protagonists as for its solid
column3: inventive gameplay."

column1: 1030;docastl2;docastle2;"Mr. Do's Castle (c) 1983 Universal.
;For the second game in the Mr. Do! series
column2: the clown finds himself in a traditional platforms and ladders game. Each level is made up of six floors (seven including the castle's ramparts) and all are joined by a number of inter-connecting ladders. The ladders come in two different varieties: vertical ladders
column3: which are fixed and cannot be moved; and diagonal ladders
column4: which can be pushed left or right from the top of the ladder. This allows Mr. Do to reach other areas of the level and is sometimes necessary to redirect the path of any pursuing enemies.

column1: The enemies in Mr. Do's Castle come in the form of unicorns
column2: and as with the enemies of the first game
column3: they will hunt down and try to kill Mr. Do. Replacing the 'Powerball' weapon of the original game
column4: Mr. Do is now armed with a mallet. This can be used to temporarily stun the unicorns and buy Mr. Do some time to escape; but its primary function is to knock out the floor blocks that form each level's platforms.

column1: Most blocks are marked with a cherry and collecting all of these will complete the level (on later revisions only
column2: see Updates below). A level can also be completed by killing all of the unicorns. This is achieved by using the mallet to remove blocks and knock holes in the platforms. The unicorns will fall into any holes that the player has created; some simply fall through to the platform below
column3: whereas others are trapped. Trapped unicorns can be hit with Mr. Do's mallet and knocked to a lower platform - useful for buying a few extra seconds for the player. If left alone
column4: however
column5: the unicorns will climb out
column6: filling the hole in behind them
column7: and transform into much nastier enemies. These new enemies cannot be stunned with the mallet and must be killed by dropping blocks onto them from the platform above.

column1: Some sections of a platform have two 'skull' blocks at either end of them
column2: with normal blocks in between. When both skull blocks are knocked out with the mallet
column3: all of the blocks in between will fall to reveal wooden floorboards. This is highly effective in killing several enemies at once.

column1: Each level also has three 'key' blocks. If Mr. Do knocks out all three key blocks
column2: a large door opens at the top of the screen to reveal a shield which
column3: when collected
column4: turns the unicorns into 'Alphamonsters'. The Alphamonsters flee from Mr. Do and can be killed either with the mallet
column5: or by dropping a floor block onto them from above. When Mr. Do kills an Alphamonster
column6: its letter appears on a flagpole at the top of the screen. If the players collects all five letters
column7: an extra life is awarded."

column4: Mr. Do is now armed with a mallet. This can be used to temporarily stun the unicorns and buy Mr. Do some time to escape; but its primary function is to knock out the floor blocks that form each level's platforms.

column1: Most blocks are marked with a cherry and collecting all of these will complete the level (on later revisions only
column2: see Updates below). A level can also be completed by killing all of the unicorns. This is achieved by using the mallet to remove blocks and knock holes in the platforms. The unicorns will fall into any holes that the player has created; some simply fall through to the platform below
column3: whereas others are trapped. Trapped unicorns can be hit with Mr. Do's mallet and knocked to a lower platform - useful for buying a few extra seconds for the player. If left alone
column4: however
column5: the unicorns will climb out
column6: filling the hole in behind them
column7: and transform into much nastier enemies. These new enemies cannot be stunned with the mallet and must be killed by dropping blocks onto them from the platform above.

column1: Some sections of a platform have two 'skull' blocks at either end of them
column2: with normal blocks in between. When both skull blocks are knocked out with the mallet
column3: all of the blocks in between will fall to reveal wooden floorboards. This is highly effective in killing several enemies at once.

column1: Each level also has three 'key' blocks. If Mr. Do knocks out all three key blocks
column2: a large door opens at the top of the screen to reveal a shield which
column3: when collected
column4: turns the unicorns into 'Alphamonsters'. The Alphamonsters flee from Mr. Do and can be killed either with the mallet
column5: or by dropping a floor block onto them from above. When Mr. Do kills an Alphamonster
column6: its letter appears on a flagpole at the top of the screen. If the players collects all five letters
column7: an extra life is awarded."

column1: 1032;docastlo;docastleo;"Mr. Do's Castle (c) 1983 Universal.
;For the second game in the Mr. Do! series
column2: the clown finds himself in a traditional platforms and ladders game. Each level is made up of six floors (seven including the castle's ramparts) and all are joined by a number of inter-connecting ladders. The ladders come in two different varieties: vertical ladders
column3: which are fixed and cannot be moved; and diagonal ladders
column4: which can be pushed left or right from the top of the ladder. This allows Mr. Do to reach other areas of the level and is sometimes necessary to redirect the path of any pursuing enemies.

Game ends when the player has lost all of his portmen or if the player fails to load the ship before the entire cargo has fallen from the conveyor belt onto the pier."

Successfully get through one maze and many more await you. This is good practice for sailing through Hong Kong Harbor.

;Dogosoken is the sequel to Ikari. It was developed by SNK
column2: and released in the arcades in 1986
column3: later in the same year that the original game appeared. Like the original
column4: Dogosoken featured an 8-way rotary joystick that could be twisted in place to rotate the onscreen character allowing the player to face in one of eight directions while moving in another. The rotary joystick serves two simultaneous purposes. The joystick can be pushed in any one of eight direction to direct the players to move in that direction. As either player advances to the top of the screen
column5: the screen will automatically scroll down. If the player retreats
column6: the screen will scroll up
column7: but only to a limited extent. The second purpose of the joystick is to control the orientation of the players. The joystick can be rotated clockwise or counter-clockwise. As the joystick is rotated
column8: so too will the players rotate in the same direction. In this manner
column9: a player can move in any direction while continuing to face one particular direction.

column1: The objective is to defeat the enemy aliens using grenades and other weapons. The story directly picks up at the ending of Ikari Warriors. Congratuled by General Kawasaki for rescuing him
column2: Paul and Vince return home to their native country in a plane arranged by the general. Expecting a hero's welcome upon arriving home
column3: a mysterious storm appears and they are hurtled thousands of years into the future. They are met by an alien creature who says that the villain Zang Zip has taken over the land.

column1: The arcade features sampled voiceovers from the main characters and the game's bosses."

1044;domino;domino;Domino Man (c) 1982 Bally Midway.
;The player controls Domino Man
column2: a bespectacled
column3: moustachioed artist who must set up a chain of giant dominoes across the screen
column4: to form a chain of dominoes which can then be toppled.

column1: The dominoes must be placed on sites marked by black spots
column2: achieved by simply running over each spot. Once all of the spots are covered with a domino
column3: the chain is complete. The player will then have the choice of either knocking them all down to clear the level
column4: or simply wait for a few seconds to continue to the next screen
column5: in hope of completing the chain on THAT level
column6: and so on. In this way
column7: the player can set up several chains and knock them all down in one fell swoop
column8: earning many bonus points in the process. Multiple chains are
column9: of course
column10: very difficult to achieve.

column1: Domino Man's progress is hampered by a neighborhood bully who walks onto the screen and tries to knock over the first dominoes he comes across. The player must either try to complete and topple the chain of dominoes before the bully knocks them over
column2: or hit the bully with a domino; causing the bully's trousers to fall down and disabling him for a few seconds. A killer bee also appears
column3: and if it manages to sting the player
column4: a life is lost. A bag lady and a boy pushing a shopping cart wander blindly around the levels
column5: occasionally knocking over some of the dominoes. Domino Man can hit them
column6: however
column7: causing them to change direction.

column1: Once a game is over
column2: a poem is displayed on-screen to evaluate the player's performance on the game. For example :

column1: Roses are red
Or so goes the verse
You set up fifty-two
You could have done worse."

1051;donpachi;donpachi;DonPachi (c) 1995 Atlus.
;An excellent vertically scrolling shoot'em up. The player assumes the role of a pilot who is sent by their squadron to fight their former allies until one side destroys the other
column2: all of which is a part of a mission to strengthen the military power that controls each side. The player flies their selected fighter over 5 areas of various terrain
column3: encountering a number of land
column4: sea and air enemies. The player's ship has two modes of fire : by tapping the fire button
column5: shots are fired; holding it down produces a concentrated vertical beam
column6: but also reduces the ship's speed.

column1: The player can choose one of 3 aircraft at the start of the game
column2: or upon continuing :

column1: Type A : A red (or yellow/orange
column2: for player two) fighter
column3: which fires a narrow stream of shots

column1: Type B : A green (or purple
column2: for player two) helicopter
column3: which fires its main guns forward
column4: but has side guns that rotate in the direction of movement

column1: Type C : A blue (or black
column2: for player two) fighter
column3: which fires a wide
column4: three-way spread of shots"

1057;dorunru2;dorunrun2;Do! Run Run (c) 1984 Universal.
;A superb final entry into the ""Mr Do!"" series (not counting the Neo Geo-based ""Neo Mr. Do""
column2: which was merely a remake of the first game in the series)
column3: ""Do! Run Run"" takes its inspiration from Namco's ""Pac-Man"".

column1: As in his previous games
column2: Mr Do! must once again collect coloured dots and/or fruit while avoiding or killing a number of enemies. For the fourth Mr Do! outing
column3: Universal ditched the sideways viewpoint of the series' previous games and switched to an overhead perspective. This allowed the game to give an impression of 'depth'
column4: with slopes and steps affecting Mr Do!'s mobility and speed.

column1: Mr. Do. has two items at his disposal with which he can kill the his enemies. The first is the 'Powerball'
column2: which featured in the original 'Mr. Do!' but was dropped from the first two sequels. The Powerball can be shot directly at an enemy to kill it instantly.

column1: The second offensive option is provided in the form of the large wooden logs that litter the levels. These work in the same way as the apples did in the original game
column2: and can be pushed free of their supporting struts
column3: causing them to roll down the screen and kill everything in their path
column4: including Mr. Do. himself if he strays too near.

column1: As Mr Do! moves around a screen
column2: he trails a line behind him. Players can join the two ends of the line up to form a rectangle (in a similar fashion to Taito's 1981 classic
column3: ""Qix"") which will change any dots within the rectangle into cherries. A second rectangle can be drawn around the cherries which in turn will change them into apples. This can be repeated twice more
column4: changing apples into lemons
column5: and lemons into pineapples. The better the fruit
column6: the more bonus points Mr Do! will earn when he collects them."

column1: 1066;douni;douni;"Mr. Do! vs. Unicorns (c) 1982 Universal.

Mr. Do! vs. Unicorns was released in November 1982 in Asia. This game is known outside Asia as ""Mr. Do's Castle"". For more information about the game itself

1067;dowild;dowild;"Mr. Do's Wild Ride (c) 1984 Universal.
;Mr Do's third arcade outing is another platform game
column2: following on from the superb ""Mr. Do's Castle""
column3: released a year earlier. The synonymous Mr. Do! cherries are present and correct
column4: but are not used in the same way as in other games in the series. In both ""Mr Do!"" and ""Mr. Do's Castle""
column5: collecting all of the cherries available was a way of completing a level. In Wild Ride
column6: however
column7: collecting them merely changes the 'prize' awarded upon reaching the level's goal. This can be one or two letters from EXTRA
column8: or other items which simply award bonus points. When Mr. Do reaches his goal
column9: he waves a flag while the bonus counter is added to his score.

column1: The gameplay is similar to that of Nintendo's legendary ""Donkey Kong""
column2: with Mr. Do starting each level at the bottom of the screen
column3: trying to make his way to the exit at the very top. Mr. Do doesn't have either his Powerball or mallet in this game
column4: but holding the ACTION button makes him run faster along the track. The trade-off of this is that his bonus points deplete much quicker. When all of the EXTRA letters are collected
column5: the player is awarded with an extra life.

column1: Each of the game's six levels is set on a roller coaster
column2: with each having its own theme
column3: traps and pitfalls. Wild Ride doesn't feature the intermission screens that appear in previous Mr.Do games.

column1: The levels are :
Level 1
column2: Roller Coaster.

column1: Level 2
column2: Pirate Ship.

column1: Level 3
column2: Three Elevators.

column1: Level 4
column2: Castle on Screen.

column1: Level 5
column2: Multiple Columns.

column1: Level 6
column2: Six Rings.

column1: After level six the levels are repeated."

1076;dremshpr;dremshpr;Dream Shopper (c) 1982 Sanritsu.

;Dream Shopper is an arcade game which was released by Sanritsu in 1982; it runs on Namco's Pac-Man hardware. The player must use a four-way joystick to take control of a shopper. At the start of the game the text YOUR PRESSING GOAL IS 10000 POINTS will appear on the screen. The screen will then cut to a shot of a room whose floor is comprised of 144 tiles as they flash up and give you a brief idea of what they all are; all except the 66th tile (which is the one with the apple) will then go black
column2: and the Dream Shopper will have to walk around the room and use the Reveal Button to reveal the type of tile he is standing on.

column1: Yellow tiles are worth 50 points
column2: green ones are worth 100
column3: blue ones are worth 250 and red ones are worth 500 - and if the Dream Shopper should walk over that 66th tile (with the apple)
column4: all the remaining tiles will be revealed for a short period of time and he can walk over the strange-looking yellow creatures that are pursuing him for extra points. Once the apple has turned into a bunch of grapes all the remaining tiles will go black again; there's only one apple on each round. Not only must the Dream Shopper normally avoid contact with the yellow creatures
column5: but he must also watch out for ""holes"" (which are indicated by the black tiles after he has walked over the 66th tile with the apple) - and if he reveals a bomb
column6: he will only have a few seconds to vacate that blast radius (but you will receive extra points if one or more of the yellow creatures perish in that explosion). Also
column7: if the Dream Shopper should reveal a frog
column8: he will start to bounce around the room and you will receive extra points for every tile he reveals based upon his color.

column1: Once you have reached 10000 points
column2: the Dream Shopper will have to make his way along a path comprised of copyright symbols towards his girlfriend's castle
column3: while again watching out for yellow creatures and collecting dropped items like shoes
column4: necklaces
column5: handbags and rings as he goes."

column1: 1077;drgnbstr;drgnbstr;"Dragon Buster (c) 1984 Namco.

;Dragon Buster is a role-playing game in which you travel through various scenery to rescue the princess from an evil dragon.
1078;drgninja;drgninja;Dragonninja (c) 1988 Data East.
;Dragonninja is a sideways scrolling platform beat-em-up for one or two players in which the US president
column2: President Ronnie (based on ex-U.S. president
column3: Ronald Reagan)
column4: has been abducted by the nefarious DragonNinja clan.

column1: Players take on the role of two government agents - 'Blade' and 'Striker' - who must fight their way through 7 enemy-packed levels to defeat the DragonNinja and save the President.
Each stage must be completed with a set time limit and initially the agents can only punch
column2: kick and jump
column3: although they can execute powerful spinning kicks and have the ability to charge themselves up with ""inner energy"" - by holding the punch button - to throw a powerful
column4: long-range flaming punch that hits all opponents in front of the player.

column1: Players will also come across weapon power-ups in the form of knives and Nunchuks. Player health can be replenished by picking up the drinks cans (resembling Coco-Cola cans) that also occasionally appear. Clocks can also be picked up to extend the stage's time limit.
At the end of each stage
column2: players must defeat powerful end-of-level bosses
column3: the first of which is Karnov
column4: who was the star of his own 1987 video game of the same name.

column1: For the game's 7th and final stage
column2: players must re-fight all of the bosses from the previous stages
column3: before finally confronting the Dragon Ninja himself. Defeating the Dragon Ninja frees the U.S. president and the game is over."

1086;drius2do;darius2do;Darius II (c) 1989 Taito.
;The direct sequel to the 1986 original
column2: Darius II retained the distinctive 3-screen format of the first game.

column1: The power-up system of Darius II was changed from that of its parent game
column2: with players having to destroy complete waves of a particular enemy to earn a power-up. 2 new power-ups were also added; the 1st was a new weapon power-up that gave the player green
column3: vertical lasers
column4: the 2nd power-up was a rainbow-colored item that powered up all of the players weapons.

column1: Another new feature of Darius II is the appearance of mini-bosses - large enemies that appear at the mid point of a level
column2: possessing similar strength and abilities to those of the game's normal bosses (such as extravagant weapons
column3: or the inability to be damaged without first exposing a vulnerable area). The mini-bosses in Darius II are in fact smaller versions of the bosses from Darius.

column1: The game is set in the inner regions of the Solar system
column2: and has the same branching level structure as Darius
column3: allowing players to select their own route through the game."

column1: 1092;drmicro;drmicro;"Dr. Micro (c) 1983 Sanritsu.
;An early platform game in which the player must defeat a mad scientist

column1: The game consists of 3 single-screen levels :
On the first the player must move from the left to the right of the screen
column2: dropping down onto constantly moving metal pillars and shooting the enemies.

column1: On the second level
column2: the player must steer a floating ball around the screen
column3: killing as many enemies as possible. Once enough enemies have been killed
column4: an exit will open which the player must enter. The floating ball gradually diminishes and the player will have to drop to the bottom of the screen several times to get a replacement ball.

column1: The final screen takes place on the scientist's production line; with machinery that must be carefully negotiated. Two large robots bar the route to the scientist and must be destroyed before the scientist can be reached."

1100;dspirit;dspirit;Dragon Spirit (c) 1987 Namco.

;Dragon Spirit scorches the screen with a mythical fantasy theme hot enough to thrill players throughout the land. Come with us, and journey to a time long ago when prehistoric beings populated the globe. Where after a millennium of captivity, an ugly serpent demon named 'Zawell' escapes imprisonment and kidnaps Alicia, princess to the kingdom of Mitgult. A young, crafty soldier Amul is selected to rescue the princess and destroy Zawell. In praying to the gods for strength and courage, he points his sword high toward the heavens. Suddenly he is transformed into an all-powerful blue dragon, bestowed with special powers. Though gifted with a lethal air and ground attack, this is not enough. He must locate and obtain extra powers along the way. The demon has instructed nine of the mightiest beasts to stop Amul before reaching his goal. Do not underestimate this soldier, he has the Dragon Spirit!

1132;edrandy;edrandy;The Cliffhanger - Edward Randy (c) 1990 Data East.

;A fast moving platform game in which the player controls the Indiana Jones-esque and unfortunately named 'Edward Randy'. The levels are an inventive mix of standard platform action and 3-D scrolling levels; the latter usually having the player driving a jeep and repelling the enemy attacks. The game is based on the archetypal Hollywood action blockbuster and features a filmic score to back up the on-screen action. The player's only weapon is a whip - another nod to the Indiana Jones character - which can be used to both attack enemies and as a 'rope'
column2: to enable the player to reach distant platforms."

column1: 1135;eggor;eggor;"Eggor (c) 1983 Telko.

;Eggor is a multi-directional shooter/maze arcade game. It runs on Namco's Pac-Man hardware and appears to be based on Digitrex Techstar's Eyes, which was released the previous year. The player must use a 4-way joystick to take up control of a baby vulture, Eggor through eight different mazes and use a single button to shoot all the eggs while getting pursued by five adult vultures. If Eggor shoots one of them, they will disappear for a few moments before rehatching. If one of the adult vultures shoots Eggor he will lose a life. Shooting an egg is worth 500 points on the first round and increases by 250 for every subsequent round, while shooting an adult vulture is worth 100 points upon the first round and increases by 100 for every subsequent round.

1147;elevatob;elevatorb;Elevator Action (c) 1983 Taito.

;Agent 17 (code name 'Otto') is to secure the top secret documents from the security building. The enemy spies are in pursuit and their orders are to stop him at any cost. Having made it to the top of a 30 story building, Agent 17 has to make his way down to the basement to get to the getaway car and save the documents. Enemy spies are everywhere and the documents are hidden behind the red doors (bonus points awarded). He has to open the door and keep moving. If either of them shoots the lights out there will be a temporary blackout. If Otto finds himself on top of the elevator the player will not be able to control the elevator. If he gets caught in the elevator he is a sitting duck and cannot duck the bullets. By using the escalator he can reach the basement quicker. Otto can defeat his enemy by jump kicking or firing at them. Help Otto to grab all the documents and escape the spies.
1148;elevator;elevator;Elevator Action (c) 1983 Taito.

;Agent 17 (code name 'Otto') is to secure the top secret documents from the security building. The enemy spies are in pursuit and their orders are to stop him at any cost. Having made it to the top of a 30 story building, Agent 17 has to make his way down to the basement to get to the getaway car and save the documents. Enemy spies are everywhere and the documents are hidden behind the red doors (bonus points awarded). He has to open the door and keep moving. If either of them shoots the lights out there will be a temporary blackout. If Otto finds himself on top of the elevator the player will not be able to control the elevator. If he gets caught in the elevator he is a sitting duck and cannot duck the bullets. By using the escalator he can reach the basement quicker. Otto can defeat his enemy by jump kicking or firing at them. Help Otto to grab all the documents and escape the spies.
1149;elim2;elim2;Eliminator (c) 1981 Gremlin.
;Eliminator is the title of Gremlin Industries' last arcade game
column2: released in 1981 and licensed to Sega for Japanese manufacture and distribution
column3: It was also the only vector game Gremlin ever made
column4: and ran on their distributing company's G80 Vector hardware which they had previously released their own Space Fury on. Additionally
column5: Eliminator is also the only four-player vector game ever made.

column1: It is a multi-directional shooter in which players must use four buttons to take control of their ship: two to make them rotate left and right
column2: and two more to make them fire and accelerate. Players pilot a space ship around the playfield and must destroy alien drones. The ultimate goal is to evade and destroy the Eliminator
column3: a huge asteroid base. The players fire causes any enemy that is struck (with the exception of the Eliminator itself) to rebound and careen off in another direction.

column1: There is only one way to destroy the Eliminator
column2: fire a cannon blast down the trench into its center. This can be done directly or via a ricochet. Failure to destroy the Eliminator after a preset time causes the center to activate a drone that flies out of the Eliminator to shoot down the player with a destructive energy blast. The playfield becomes enclosed in an invisible barrier that bounces shots and ships off it
column3: thus increasing the chances of death. Once the Eliminator is destroyed
column4: the game restarts with a tougher set of enemies. The four player version allowed four players to simultaneously make attack runs on the Eliminator while trying to evade or destroy various other opponents. In four player mode
column5: players must also dodge other player's ships."

column1: 1155;embargo;embargo;"Embargo (c) 1977 Cinematronics.

;Embargo is a one to four player blocking genre game. Each player must deposit a coin. There is a stylized map of Cuba (with a canal through the center) in the middle of the screen. There are four boats
column2: one in each corner of the screen. If there were less than four players then the computer played the remainder. As the boats sail out they leave a continuous trail of mines behind. The players can control the direction and
column3: with a single button
column4: stop two mines from being laid in every twelve.

column1: Each time a boat hits another boat
column2: a mine
column3: the screen edge or Cuba
column4: it explodes and the surviving boats each get one point. This continues until zero or one boat is left. (If two boats collide they both blow up.) I believe there were four rounds per game. The strategy was to block off as much open water as you could while leaving a hole in your line of mines so you could double back and duck through it."

column1: 1156;emeralda;emeraldaj;"Emeraldia (c) 1993 Namco.

;A puzzle game where the player must line up squares of the same color. When three tiles have been stacked in a vertical row, they crack. When a fourth square of same color lands on the cracked ones, all four squares disappear.

1160;endurob2;endurob2;Enduro Racer (c) 1986 Sega.
;Enduro Racer is an off-road racing game in which players ride a dirt bike across five extremely hilly and twisting courses. Each course is littered with logs
column2: rocks
column3: trees and rival racers that must be either jumped over or avoided.

column1: Jumps can only be performed at specific locations on each track. These locations feature a dirt ramp that spreads across the width of the track. Players must have the bike in the 'wheelie' position when the ramp is struck
column2: the bike will then be launched into the air. If the bike is not in a wheelie position when the ramps are struck
column3: the bike will still clear the ramp
column4: but will land front-wheel first and crash.

column1: Enduro Racer is perhaps best remembered for its 'Wheelie' feature
column2: which required the player to physically lift the cabinet's handlebars to raise the front wheel of the game's on-screen counterpart."

column3: Ltd.). The game was licensed to Game Plan in the US 3 years before (in 1981) using a color hardware!"

column1: 1166;eprom;eprom;"Escape From The Planet of the Robot Monsters (c) 1989 Atari Games Corp.
;Escape From The Planet Of The Robot Monsters is a one or two-player game in which the players must rescue Dr. Sarah Bellum from Planet X
column2: where her research facility has been taken over by the evil Reptilons. The game is played from an isometric perspective where players control their avatars using Hall effect joysticks. The Hall effect is the production of a voltage difference (the Hall voltage) across an electrical conductor
column3: transverse to an electric current in the conductor and a magnetic field perpendicular to the current. It was discovered by Edwin Hall in 1879.

column1: The player must shoot their way through a series of simple maze-like levels
column2: releasing the human hostages along the way. Levers must be found and thrown to activate the escalators which allow access to new areas. Gems can be collected to increase the power of the player's ray gun
column3: and food lockers may be broken into for a health boost.

column1: At the end of each level the play switches to an isometric auto-scrolling sequence in which the player controls his character in a small spaceship
column2: and must steer left or right to navigate through a maze of obstacles. If the player reaches the end of this sequence they will progress to the next level."

1170;esb;esb;The Empire Strikes Back (c) 1985 Atari Games.

;The third arcade outing based on the legendary trilogy of films; ""Empire Strikes Back"" eschews Jedi's Zaxxon-inspired gameplay and returns once more to the 3D vector graphics of the first game. Empire features four stages of play
column2: with the first two putting the player in control ""Luke Skywalker's"" SnowSpeeder
column3: and the second two in control of ""Han Solo's"" Millennium Falcon.

column1: * The first level
column2: Probots
column3: takes place on the ice planet of Hoth
column4: with the player flying the Snowspeeder over the planet's surface to find and destroy the Empire's search droids that are sending signals to the Empire warning them of the rebels' presence.

column1: * The second Snowspeeder stage sees the player taking on the Empire's ""AT-AT"" Imperial walkers
column2: as well as a number of smaller
column3: bi-pedal ""AT-ST"" walkers. On this level
column4: as well as the standard guns
column5: the Snowspeeder is armed with a limited number of harpoons; these can be fired at the AT-AT's legs to send them crashing to the ground. AT-ATs can also be destroyed by shooting a small
column6: highlighted area on the AT-ATs' head.

column1: * The third level has the player piloting the Millennium Falcon and is a repeat of the original game's in-space Tie Fighter battle.
* For the fourth and final level the player must pilot the Millennium Falcon safely through a densely packed and fast-moving asteroid field.

Bonus points can be earned by destroying a certain number of targets. A JEDI letter will also be awarded in addition to the bonus points. Once all the letters that spell the word 'JEDI' have been awarded
column2: players will have attained true JEDI FORCE
column3: making them invincible to the Empire's forces for a limited amount of time.

column1: In all levels of play
column2: collisions with objects and enemy shots will cause damage to the player's deflector shields."

column1: 1171;esckids;esckidsj;"Escape Kids (c) 1991 Konami Industry Company
column2: Limited.

column1: ;An unusual take on the overhead racing genre
column2: Escape Kids has up to 4 players taking on the role of an athletic runner and competing to be the first to cross the finish line in a number of 3-lap races. As well as running
column3: each player has a limited number of 'Super Jumps'; these allow the player to leap over both rival runners and obstacles.

column1: Money is awarded for finishing first
column2: and players can upgrade their runner depending on the amount of money they have available. Runners can be given extra super jumps
column3: an upgrade to stop the runner from skidding when going through a bend in the track
column4: quicker recovery time from falls
column5: or be made stronger (and thus less likely to be knocked over by a rival runner). Special items occasionally appear and can be picked up and used. These range from an item that causes a small earthquake (causing all of the rival runners to tumble along the ground
column6: thus slowing them down) and a bomb
column7: which renders any runner that runs into it unable to move for several seconds.

column1: Each race has a total of five competitors (either human or computer controlled) and players must finish in first place or are disqualified. Any player who wins all three races in a round will be taken to a bonus screen. Here
column2: the player's on-screen counterpart rides a bike and the player must collect as much money as possible."

1178;eswatbl;eswatbl;"Cyber Police E-SWAT - The Ultimate Factor in the Battle Against Crime (c) 1989 Sega.

;The player takes on the role of a rookie cop in this sideways scrolling platform shoot-em-up from Sega. A powerful crime syndicate is creating chaos in the cop's home city and he must prove his ability as a police officer by capturing a number of crime bosses
column2: killing as many of their henchmen as possible in the process. The policeman carries a standard issue pistol which only has a limited amount of ammunition. In the event of the ammunition running out
column3: players will only be able to kick their enemies. Extra Ammo can be picked up at various points in the levels.

column1: As the player progresses through the game and makes more and more arrests
column2: their on-screen character will be promoted through the ranks. First to Captain
column3: then Assistant Chief
column4: Chief and finally
column5: once three crime bosses have been arrested
column6: to a full E-SWAT agent. Adorning full
column7: robot-style body armour that bears more than a passing resemblance to the ""Robocop"" character from the games and movies of the same name. In armoured mode
column8: the cop has vastly increased firepower
column9: including a limited number of bombs that are ejected by a mechanical device on the policeman's back.

column1: As the armoured cop is shot
column2: his armour will gradually disappear until he is finally killed.

column1: E-Swat plays very much like a cross between Sega's own 1987 classic ""Shinobi""
column2: as well as Namco's superb ""Rolling Thunder""."

;European version. Game developed in Japan. For more information about the game

column1: - TRIVIA -
This game is known in Japan as ""Hattrick Hero"" and outside Europe as ""Football Champ"".
In this version
column2: the conditions (timer and score required) for the SUPER SHOOT are differents
column3: see TIPS & TRICKS for more information.

column1: - TIPS AND TRICKS -
How to perform a SUPER SHOOT (Euro Champ '92 version):
* Timer should be between 10 and 36 seconds.
* Score must be a tie (0-0
* Only Player's selected Captain can perform a Super Shoot and only ONCE in a whole game (After GAME OVER
Super Shot becomes enabled again).
* Player's Captain should receive the ball in a certain area of the gamefield with High Pass (Button B long press)
and must not be moving at all
column2: while receiving the ball.

column1: -- #8: Between center point and 1/4 of the upper field.
-- #9: Between 1/4 and 1/2 of the upper field.
--#10: Between 1/2 and 3/4 of the upper field.
--#11: Same as #10 and also in a defensive position as #9.
- SERIES -
1. Euro Champ '92 (1992)
2. Taito Cup Finals (1993)
3. International Cup '94 (1994)
4. Taito Power Goal (1994)"

1184;excthour;excthour;Exciting Hour - The Prowrestling Network (c) 1985 Taito Corp.

;A match of wits and skill with classic ring techniques used in today's popular professional wrestling arenas. The ringside announcer to signal the start of the match introduces the events. The player battles each of his 5 awesome opponents in quest of the championship. Timely use of joystick and buttons maneuvers the player into position and activates all the standard as well as spectacular moves including : Pile Driver, Sunset Flip, Rolling Sole Butt, Lariat, Plunger, Flying Body Press, everything to weaken the enemy for a pin-fall win for the count of 3, or keeping the challenger out of the ring for a twenty count. After each win, the player takes on the next opponent for another three-minute period. If he defeats all of the opponents, he earns the right to the Championship Belt and goes on to the next four in defense of his title. Colorful, fast-paced action plus realistic sound effects of hits, moves, count-down and crowd cheers adds to the atmosphere and excitement associated with the current rage of professional wrestling.

column6: Austria

column1: The game allows for one or two players to play and has a control scheme where they can tackle
column2: shoot

column4: and long pass. Exciting Soccer had realistic touches for the time: corner kicks
column5: throw-ins
column6: penalty shots
column7: and cheerleaders
column8: as well as digitized voices and an influential overhead view."

column1: 1190;exedexes;exedexes;"Exed Exes (c) 1985 Capcom Company
column2: Limited.

column1: ;Exed Exes is an arcade vertical shooter developed by Capcom. It was licensed to Memetron and released outside of Japan in the arcades as Savage Bees Memetron (licensor to the game). It uses similar hardware to Capcom's 1942
column2: but it is more of a spiritual successor to Capcom's earlier shooter Vulgus. It takes place in a science fiction alien hive where you must pilot your ship through many stages protected by insects
column3: some as large as your craft
column4: and some even larger.

column1: What made Exed Exes stand apart from other shooters
column2: besides the high resolution graphics for its time
column3: and the detailed use of parallax scrolling to indicate depth
column4: was the fact that it was one of the earliest vertical shooters to allow for two player simultaneous play. Rather than waiting for one player to take his turn
column5: two players could enjoy the game at the same time
column6: and even work cooperatively to get further along in the game."

column1: 1191;exerion;exerion;"Exerion (c) 1983 Jaleco Company
column2: Ltd [Japan Leisure].

column1: ;Exerion is a vertical shooter that is operated with an 8 direction joystick and two fire buttons. The game's biggest features are the parallax scrolling which occurs in the background
column2: and the sensation of inertia that is applied to the motion of the ship. The ship is equipped with two kinds of weapons. You can fire the dual shot gun which can only release one pair of shots on the screen at a time
column3: but has an unlimited supply
column4: by tapping the first fire button. The single shot gun can fire a rapid stream of shots on the screen at one time by holding the second fire button down
column5: but it is limited in ammo according to the number of charges indicated on the bottom. Each weapon is best used in different situations
column6: in order to defeat the enemies which come flying down from the top part of the screen.

column1: Due to the inertia of the ship
column2: you must input any reverse in direction much sooner in order to cancel the ships momentum. This was not a common feature for similar games that came out around the same time
column3: so it distinguished Exerion from other shooters. Because the Famicom conversion was played on a horizontal screen
column4: the enemies appeared much closer to the player's ship
column5: which changes the feel of the game since you have to react to the enemies' location much sooner."

1197;exprraid;exprraidu;Express Raider (c) 1986 Data East Corp.
;The wild west-themed Express Raider is separated into two different game types; a sideways scrolling fighting sequence and a shooting sequence. The player controls a train robber
column2: or 'Express Raider'
column3: and must try to steal the bags of money from the moving locomotives.

column1: During the fighting sequence
column2: the Raider must fight the bank teller
column3: hit the coyotes and then jump onto the train before it speeds away. Once on the train
column4: he must fight his way past other enemies and avoid various projectiles
column5: such as bottles
column6: bullets and shovels full of coal. Players must be careful to duck under the low signs that come along as the train is travelling. Also
column7: once a train carriage is clear of enemies
column8: a bomb will appear between the current carriage and the next; players must quickly jump over to the next carriage before the bomb goes off
column9: otherwise the Raider will fall from the train and a life is lost. If the Express Raider manages to reach the train engine
column10: the loot will be captured and the game will then move on to the shooting sequence.

column1: In the shooting sequence
column2: the Express Raider rides a horse and must shoot at the enemies that appear from the windows of a train carriage. They will shoot back at the player and throw various objects. Players can hit the DUCK button to avoid the enemy attacks. A woman will appear at regular intervals offering the player a bag of money
column3: if the player shoots the woman
column4: a life is lost. After the shooting sequence has been completed
column5: the game will start over again with an increased level of difficulty."

1199;exterm;exterm;Exterminator (c) 1989 Gottlieb.
;A wholly abstract approach to the shoot-em-up genre in which one or two players take control of a disembodied
column2: digitized human hand and must kill the swarms of insects that have infested a street of houses.

column1: Exterminator is set in a street of houses and players must move from room to room in each property
column2: clearing each one of the infestation
column3: before moving onto the next house. Each player can initially only grab or 'thump' enemies (the latter for ground-based
column4: crawling insects)
column5: but a number of power-ups
column6: such as bug spray and somewhat bizarrely
column7: a laser firing finger can be collected to make progress a little easier."

column1: 1200;extrmatn;extrmatnu;"Extermination (c) 1987 Taito.

;A shoot'em up game.
1201;exvania;exvaniaj;Exvania (c) 1992 Namco.
;The queen of darkness
column2: Erinyes
column3: has kidnapped Princess Electra. The four heroes: Ward
column4: Emilio
column5: Charles
column6: and Karl embark on a quest to save the princess. They compete with each other to reach the Castle of Darkness and defeat Erinyes
column7: so one of them might be able to marry the rescued Electra and rule the land Exvania.

column1: The players must take up control of four medieval lords who are fighting for control of the land. They have to battle through eight different castles
column2: and try to gain control of each one. When one of the lords wins a battle
column3: he shall receive a medal - and once he has won three medals
column4: he will gain control of the current castle (which means that they can be up to six rooms long) and the game will proceed to the next castle. The gameplay is similar to that of Hudson Soft's Bomberman series
column5: the initial title of which was adapted by Irem for the arcade in 1991.

column1: The lords start out in the four corners of the screen and can only be killed by bombs
column2: but a strike from the whips will temporarily stun them. The objective is to trap the other lords with bombs and kill them or otherwise force them to walk into the path of an exploding bomb. Treasure chests are numerous in each room
column3: and can be broken with the whip. Each treasure chest contains a powerup such as speed shoes
column4: boomerangs
column5: extra bombs
column6: larger bombs
column7: and more.

column1: Every third room is a dragon room
column2: in which an enormous dragon is seen walking around freely. They come in three different colors (red
column3: green and black)
column4: and become stronger as the lords progress through each castle
column5: In later castles the dragons begin to breathe fire (which is just as lethal as a bomb) and attack the players in other ways. If a dragon is successfully killed
column6: powerups will appear all around him - and other enemies
column7: like blobs of slime and possessed skeletons
column8: appear as the castles progress. They cannot kill the players
column9: but can significantly stun them in various ways and become more numerous with each level. When the time is down to 40 seconds the text ""DANGER"" will appear on the screen and Death appears
column10: flying towards the lords and killing them on impact.

column1: When the time runs out
column2: an evil witch will electrify the room to kill all the surviving lords. The final room pits the winning player (the player who has won the most matches and who controls the most castles) against the final boss
column3: the witch
column4: who attacks with lightning spells."

column1: 1202;exzisus;exzisusa;"Exzisus (c) 1987 Taito Corp.
;Conversion Kit version. For more information about the game itself
column2: please see the original dedicated version.

column1: - TRIVIA -
There is a LOT of differences between each other
column2: possibly due to the various disparities between having full dedicated hardware and a simple software conversion kit running off of older and possibly weaker hardware:

column1: - A barrier upgrade exists in the dedicated version that does not appear at all in the conversion kit version. This allows the player to take several hits from enemies without dying.
- Many enemies in the dedicated version emerge from the background and move into the foreground. In the conversion kit version
column2: they just simply appear from the edges of the screen.

column1: - Almost ALL of the enemy patterns in each version are different. The dedicated board's enemy varation is a tad more scarce
column2: enemies frequently appear from the right
column3: while the conversion kit's enemies are a bit more varied in placement and design.

column1: - The conversion kit introduces a pickup canister that can be shot to obtain powerups. These do not appear in the dedicated version. In the dedicated version
column2: shooting a row of enemies à la Gradius will net you an upgrade instead.

column1: - To coincide with the removal of the background objects in the conversion kit
column2: the missile upgrade no longer fires into the background
column3: and instead will trail onto the ground horizontally
column4: making it more useful for taking out the laser turrets."

column1: 1203;eyes;eyes;"Eyes (c) 1982 Rock-Ola Mfg. Corp.
;The player controls a hat-wearing eyeball in a maze. As in Pac-Man
column2: the goal is to collect all of the dots to advance to next level
column3: but in Eyes you shoot the dots rather than eat them. Computer-controlled eyes chase and shoot at the player. Shooting a computer eye gives points and removes it from the level
column4: but it will reappear a short time later. Being shot by a computer eye is fatal.

column1: As the game progresses
column2: more computer eyes are added to levels and they take less time to shoot at the player. They also move faster."

1217;fantasia;fantasia;"Fantasia (c) 1994 Comad Industry Company
column2: Limited.

column1: ;Fantasia is a ""Qix""-style adult puzzle game modeled heavily after the Kaneko game ""Gals Panic!"". It features photographic images of both Japanese and western models. The objective is to reveal 80% of the silhouetted girl's image within the time limit while avoiding the enemies.
To complicate things
column2: there is a bar with a pointer at the top of the screen. If the pointer dips below a certain level (indicated by the change in color) the image will change to that of a monster. The pointer slowly creeps towards the monster side of the bar over time and moves dramatically towards the monster side whenever the player reveals a significant piece of the silhouette. Revealing the un-silhouetted part of the image moves the pointer back towards the girl side of the bar. If a round is completed while the monster's image is shown then the round must be repeated."

column1: 1225;fantzn2;fantzn2;"Fantasy Zone II - The Tears of Opa-Opa (c) 1988 Sega.

;Once again you control Opa-Opa, a pretty colored ship with wings on its side and must destroy the large creatures in each world before moving on to the next. Your task becomes difficult by other small creatures that happen to pass by. If you destroy a large creature, they will drop a dollar bill, which you can pick up and use at the shop to buy items and powerful weapons such as laser beams, x-way shots, and big wings. Another way to get money is to shoot certain kinds of enemies all in a row.
1226;fantzone;fantzone;Fantasy Zone (c) 1986 Sega Enterprises
column2: Limited.

column1: ;The Fantasy Zone is under attack by an army of ruthless
column2: yet undeniably cute
column3: alien enemies. A fearless space fighter by the name of 'Opa-opa' (a craft that is as cute as the game's enemies
column4: featuring wings and feet - the latter appearing whenever the player flies down to ground level at the bottom of the screen) must stop the alien invasion to restore peace to the Fantasy Zone
column5: as well as finding his missing father
column6: 'Opapa'
column7: in the process.

column1: Each level has a number of large
column2: enemy generating ships
column3: that produce a constant stream of enemies to attack the player. While the enemies the generators produce can either be shot or avoided
column4: the generators themselves MUST be destroyed. Once the generators are gone
column5: an end-of-level ship will appear that must be beaten to complete the level.

column1: Fantasy Zone is rendered with the surreal
column2: brightly coloured graphics that typify many Japanese videogames; with an equally abstract approach to in-game weapons: with that cartoon comedy staple
column3: the 'anvil'
column4: making an appearance."

column5: trees
column6: bridges
column7: through winter and summer seasons; over the Pacific--over a yacht
column8: tropical islands
column9: an aircraft carrier; and over Egypt--camels
column10: Pyramids
column11: the Taj Mahal
column12: the Sphinx
column13: through day and night landscapes. It's a complete global challenge with non-stop action over a continuously changing panorama below."

column1: 1230;fastlane;fastlane;"Fast Lane (c) 1987 Konami.
;In this driving/maze game
column2: you control a vehicle who must drive through the entire maze to progress. There is another vehicle who tries to stop you so to aid your progress
column3: you must drive through the beach ladies in order to gain power-ups which you can use on the other vehicle. These power-ups are as follows :

column1: JUMP - Allows you to either jump over the other vehicle or jump on top of it.
SHOOT - Allows you to fire a bullet at the other vehicle.
ATTACK - Allows you to charge into the other vehicle.
? - Can either be Option which fires forwards or Line which shoots vertically.  Both also help you complete the maze.
FLASH - Allows you to stun the other vehicle from any distance."
