During a trip to Southtown to attend the inauguration of a new branch of Pao Pao Cafe by former street fighter Richard Meyer

column6: a grade system that shows how well you perform in battle

1238;fcombat;fcombat;Field Combat (c) 1985 Jaleco Company
column2: Ltd [Japan Leisure].

column1: ;Field Combat is a 1985 arcade video game by Jaleco Company in which the player fights as a single commanding officer in a futuristic battlefield. The object of the game is to make it all the way to the end of the battlefield using the Genesis: a warship that can fire off missiles. While the player controls the blue forces
column2: the player must defeat the Red forces without dying in the process by either avoiding or shooting helicopters
column3: infantrymen
column4: and tanks. An interesting characteristic of the game is that it is possible to ask for reinforcements from an army which the player possesses by pressing both the A and B buttons at the same time. Whenever the player runs out of units to aid him in battle
column5: he can use his special weapon to ""absorb"" the enemies and add them to his army.

column1: The game used Richard Wagner's Ride of the Valkyries as its background music. There is also an enemy UFO like spaceship that
column2: when in battlefield
column3: attempts to grab and escape with a player friendly unit. It will also engage into air-to-air battle with a friendly helicopter."

column1: 1242;ffightj;ffightj;"Final Fight (c) 1989 Capcom Company
column2: Limited.

column1: ;Jessica
column2: the daughter of the city Mayor Mike Haggar has been kidnapped by the evil 'Mad Gear' gang. Set in the fictional Metro City
column3: Haggar rounds up two of his closest friends
column4: Guy and Cody
column5: and sets out to battle Mad Gear's gang members and ultimately rescue his daughter.

column1: 1 or 2 players choose to play as either Guy
column2: Cody or Haggar in this superb
column3: sideways scrolling beat-em-up. As well as the standard punch and kick moves
column4: each character also has a special attack. This move is powerful enough to fell several enemies at once
column5: but with the trade-off that each time a special attack is executed
column6: some of the player's energy is lost. Energy levels can be replenished by finding the food that lies hidden in certain crates and barrels. Some of the Mad Gear gang members will drop a weapon when they are felled. These weapons can then be picked up and used by the players.

column1: After the benchmark-setting ""Double Dragon""
column2: released by Technos in 1987
column3: Final Fight would become the standard-bearer of the scrolling beat-em-up genre. Featuring a large variety of distinctive
column4: well animated characters moving through colorful and detailed backgrounds
column5: and with a control system that is as intuitive as it is complex
column6: Final Fight is still considered to be the finest example of its kind."

1247;fghthist;fghthistuc;Fighter's History (c) 1993 Data East Corporation.

;Fighter's History is the first attempt of Data East to enter in competition with Capcom and its omnipresent Street Fighter II. Because the many similarities shared by the game with the Capcom masterpiece (like the character select screen
column2: the vs and winner/loser screens
column3: the controls and the design and moves of some characters)
column4: Fighter's History was at least simply stamped by most of the  players like another SFII clone
column5: and in this way remained ignored and obscured to the mass audience.

column1: Although time after
column2: the many beat'em up fans learnt to appreciate this maybe too underestimated fighting game
column3: especially for its combo system
column4: quite simple to execute even for those players not so able with timing and button pressing
column5: and for its fast gameplay: at this purpose most of the contribution was made by the updated version released in 1994
column6: Fighter's History Dynamite (known as Karnov's Revenge in USA and Europe) that made the gameplay more polished. Despite this at least Fighter's History never reached that great success that maybe Data East still tried to achieve.

column1: Players choose one of 9 international fighters and battle to be the best in the world. Every character has his ending sequence and his own stage. There are also two not-selectable bosses to challenge for reach the end
column2: and the last one of them is real surprising!"

;Fire One! was a player-versus-player or player-versus-computer submarine showdown.
The primary objective of the game is to find and destroy the enemy's submarine
column2: while avoiding the enemy's torpedoes. Through your virtual periscope you are free to launch one of your 8 torpedoes to take out any of the enemy's various ships for extra points. It takes some time to reload each torpedo tube
column3: so you must be judicious in how you plan your attacks.

column1: In addition to being able to control the left/right rotation of your periscope
column2: the game also features a submerge button which you can use to temporarily hide from the enemy. Holding this button down keeps you hidden but also keeps you out of the action
column3: allowing the enemy free reign over the seas."

column1: 1280;firetpbl;firetrapbl;"Fire Trap (c) 1986 Woodplace
column2: Incorporated.

column1: ;An abstract arcade game in which a single player takes on the role of a firefighter
column2: who must climb a burning building rescuing the people and animals who are trapped inside. As well as the fires
column3: the firefighter must also avoid or deflect (the latter with his extinguisher) a number of falling objects and debris
column4: including cars
column5: couches
column6: hammers
column7: chairs
column8: lamps
column9: stoves and refrigerators.

column1: Fire Trap is very similar
column2: gameplay-wise
column3: to Nichibutsu's 1980 classic
column4: ''Crazy Climber''. As the firefighter climbs the building
column5: he must use his fire extinguisher to put out the fires which include burning papers
column6: flame-gushing windows and moving fireballs. The fire extinguisher contains only a limited amount of water
column7: so must be used it wisely. Certain extinguished fires
column8: however
column9: reveal cannisters of extinguisher fuel to be collected. Other extinguished fires reveal bonuses and
column10: very occasionally
column11: springboards; which shoot the player higher up the skyscraper.

column1: The firefighter's ultimate aim is to reach the roof of the skyscraper and rescue a young woman who is trapped there. As the firefighter reaches the roof
column2: a giant fireball appears and circles the tower; this must be either avoided or extinguished. After the firefighter has rescued the woman
column3: he must fly down the building with his jet pack and extinguish any fires remaining on the building; before finally landing safely on the ground. The firefighter will then move on to another burning building to make another rescue attempt."

;A reconstructed sprite-ripped bootleg of Art of Fighting with all eight characters selectable in any mode. It has:
* FM music.

* No zooms.
* Poor AI.

* Ripped graphics but reprogrammed from scratch."
1286;fitter;fitter;"Fitter (c) 1981 Taito.

;The object of the game is for the player to maneuver his white robot in 1 of 4 directions within a maze, capture a red character robot as they move about the maze, and race to the center to change the 9 white balls located there to red. The player may only change one white ball to red at a time after he has captured a red robot, and must evade 4 chaser monsters in the process. Bonus point may be earned when capturing the elusive 'red king' that appears on the screen. Capture him and momentarily immobilize the chasers, but do not come in contact with the yellow robots--or your much-needed red robots will be changed to white and force you to change strategy. Play is over when the chasers have captured all of the player's robots. But, should the player be successful in changing all of the balls in the center to red, the pattern clears and a different challenge is presented. A 3x3 or 4x4 tri-colored pattern will appear at the bottom of the screen and a slightly different tri-colored cube of corresponding size will appear at the center of the screen. The player may earn bonus points by moving the directional arrow and rearranging the colors of the cube at the center of the screen to match the sample pattern presented at the bottom of the screen. The player is given 90 seconds to rearrange the cube as many times as he can. Action returns to the maze whether you win or lose the cube challenge. All in all, an exciting and challenging game where patience and skill are required.

column1: 1297;flyball;flyball1;"Flyball (c) 1976 Atari.

;This game is a very basic implementation of the game of baseball. The graphics are in black and white monochrome, and each side only has a single player (well the pitching team only has the pitcher, but several men can get on base at once). The game uses analog controls to simulate both pitching and hitting, so a smooth motion of the joystick will produce the best results. The pitcher is the only person on the field besides the base runners, so it is often best to make for one base further than the one you would have thrown the ball to (the pitcher has to run after the batter). The game only lasts for 1 or 2 innings (depending on how it is set), so each at bat really counts.

column2: Limited.

column1: ;Take off on a fantastic video trip. A voyage that simulates the thrills and skills of actual Hang Gliding. Players use the joystick to control Freddie
column2: but good timing and strategy is necessary to successfully negotiate invisible air currents
column3: wind direction and up and down drafts. This game has incredible visual impact for this time
column4: Freddie flies the skies over the Alps--over trains
column5: trees
column6: bridges
column7: through winter and summer seasons; over the Pacific--over a yacht
column8: tropical islands
column9: an aircraft carrier; and over Egypt--camels
column10: Pyramids
column11: the Taj Mahal
column12: the Sphinx
column13: through day and night landscapes. It's a complete global challenge with non-stop action over a continuously changing panorama below."

1302;foodf;foodf;Food Fight (c) 1982 Atari.

;The player, as Charley Chuck, must dodge all kinds of flying fruit and vegetables and try to eat an ice cream cone before it melts. How many ice cream cones can he eat? Your players will soon find out in this incredible video feast. As an ice cream cone melts on the other side of the screen, Charley Chuck just naturally has to go for it, But he must get past Oscar, Angelo, Jacques and Zorba, four chefs who unexpectedly pop out of holes, chase Charley Chuck and throw food at him. They all have different personalities and they're all out to stop Charley Chuck if he isn't fast enough. There are piles of tomatoes, peas, bananas, pies and watermelon Charley Chuck can use to defend himself from the persistent chefs. The player controls Charley Chuck with an analog joystick which allows 360 degree movement on the playfield, and a Throw button, used when Charley Chuck needs to throw food at one of the chefs.

1319;frogger;frogger;Frogger (c) 1981 Konami Industry Company
column2: Limited.

column1: ;Frogger is a 1- or 2-player game in which players move their frog from the bottom to the top of the screen. This is achieved by overcoming a number of hazards without getting run over or drowned.
The first half of the screen is a bi-directional flow of traffic including busses
column2: cars and racecars. Players must avoid these vehicles. Frogs can move safely with the flow of traffic to make their way to the second half of the screen
column3: which consists of a river with fast moving logs and sinkable turtles. Frogs must hop on the backs of the logs and the turtles to get to the home base at the top of the screen. At random times throughout the game play
column4: a lady frog will appear on a log. Bonus points are scored if the frog successfully hops on the back of the lady frog and escorts her safely home. A fly will also appear randomly in a home base. Bonus points can be scored if the frog hops in the home base when the fly is present. Sinking turtles also swiftly move across the river with the logs. If a frog is unsuccessful in hopping on a turtle's back
column5: the frog will sink and drown. Crocodiles
column6: snakes
column7: and otters also roam the moving river waiting to eat frogs on their way up to the home base. Players can hop on their back (except the snake
column8: whose touch is deadly)
column9: but they must avoid their open mouths. The frog must be lined up perfectly to enter one of the 5 home bases. Players must maneuver the frogs to their home base within the allotted time (60 beats on the timer).

column1: The frog can move vertically or horizontally by maneuvering the joystick. Players must maneuver the frog swiftly and precisely without getting run over
column2: drowned
column3: or eaten by the creatures that roam the flowing river. Avoiding traffic
column4: deadly snakes
column5: otters
column6: crocodiles
column7: and the treacherous diving turtles make game action stimulating in Frogger."

Before facing each opponent

column1: A strip sequence is shown every time the player wins a hand. Strip sequences consist of scrolling
column2: still images of the girl with limited animation of facial expressions. If a player depletes an opponents betting funds
column3: then the game will advance through all of the strip sequences for that opponent.

column1: Occasionally
column2: after defeating an opponent
column3: the player is given the opportunity to play a mini-game of high-low. The player is shown a tile and must guess if the next tile will be higher or lower than the tile shown.  If the player wins all three rounds
column4: he is given a cheat item.

column1: The player looses the game once all of his betting funds are depleted. Upon continuing the player keeps any unused cheat items and may buy more items from the store
column2: but all of the player's wins against the current opponent are wiped out."

1329;frontlin;frontlin;Front Line (c) 1982 Taito.

;Front Line is Taito America Corporation's action war game. Traveling through enemy territory the player must accomplish the ultimate mission or meet a violent end : capture the enemy fort and win total victory.
The journey begins slowly with the player armed with a gun (special Gun Control) and hand grenades. Quickly he becomes a target for enemy soldiers who also have guns and grenades. Moving faster
column2: he races past trees that hide the enemy who now unleash an ambush barrage of bullets and bombs. Even the ground he races over has been booby-trapped with land mines.

column1: If the player successfully makes it through this deadly obstacle course
column2: he meets an even greater challenge... the enemy is attacking with tanks! His gun now useless
column3: the player can stand and fight with grenades or leap into his own tank (special Tank button) and counter attack.

column1: The battle rages on all fronts as the player fights for his life
column2: racing for cover behind brick walls while outrunning grenades thrown by soldiers in fox holes. It's all-out war when the player jumps from his tank into a larger one with greater firepower.

column1: Now comes the final test of victory as the enemy's fort looms in sight. The player must leap from the tank and run through a hail of bullets to throw one final grenade. The white flag heralds total victory!"

1343;ga2;ga2u;Golden Axe - The Revenge of Death Adder (c) 1992 Sega.
;Like it's legendary prequel
column2: 1989's ""Golden Axe""; 'Revenge' is sideways scrolling beat-em-up set in a traditional fantasy world
column3: in which the evil 'Death Adder' has arisen to take over the lands. The game supports simultaneous four-player gameplay
column4: with each player taking on one of the game's characters. The four available characters are 'Sternblade' (a barbarian warrior)
column5: 'Dora' (a female centaurian)
column6: 'Goah' (a giant with a dwarf sitting atop his shoulders) and 'Little Trix' (an agile
column7: oriental-style warrior).

column1: As with 'Golden Axe'
column2: as well as standard weapon attacks
column3: each character has a special attack move that is activated by pressing both JUMP and ATTACK at the same time. Also
column4: double-tapping the joystick right or left will cause the player to charge and smash into opponents. At certain points during the game
column5: players will come across certain creatures and contraptions (such as dragons
column6: giant scorpions and catapults) which
column7: once the original occupier has been removed from the saddle
column8: can be mounted and ridden/utilized to attack the enemy.

column1: At certain points during a level
column2: as well as at the end of each level
column3: dwarfs appears carrying a sack on their back. Players can hit the dwarfs causing them to drop food and magic potions. During the course of the game
column4: players will also come across numerous trapped prisoners. These can be released by either opening their cages (by pulling a rope or similar) or hacking at their foot manacles.

column1: Unlike the linear level layout of its prequel
column2: 'Revenge' offers the player a branching route through the game
column3: adding to its variety and longevity."

1346;gaiapols;gaiapolsj;"Gaiapolis - Koganedaka no Ken (c) 1993 Konami.

column3: awesome character & enemy artwork designs
column4: a superb soundtrack and addicting hack & slash action with some RPG characteristics (characters & weapons level up
column5: plenty of magic spells & summons). If you enjoyed Taito's Cadash
column6: this game is for you!

column1: 1352;galag88b;galag88b;;
1353;galag88j;galaga88j;"Galaga '88 (c) 1987 Namco.
;Galaga '88 is an updated version of the old favorite
column2: ""Galaga""
column3: with more invaders and more player firepower. Galaga '88 gives players a chance to once again repel the invaders from the Galagan Kingdom. One or two players can try their hand at fighting the invaders. This time the Galagans have four more allies
column4: each with unique weapons and defenses that a player must overcome.

column1: By destroying special enemies or obstacles the player can get 'items'. When a player has two items
column2: they can warp to another dimension to confront more Galagan ships with new strategies. In the Challenging Stages (labelled in this game as 'That's Galactic Dancin')
column3: the player shoots down as many invaders as possible as the Galagans dance to a waltz
column4: tango
column5: march or jazz tune.

column1: The player selects single or dual ship power. The objective is to destroy all the Galagan foes in each of the 29 sectors of the galaxy
column2: with each sector more difficult than the last.

column1: Unique Features :
* More opponents. In addition to Boss
column2: Goei and Zako
column3: the original Galagan crew
column4: Don
column5: Nin
column6: Ban
column7: and Gan have been added. Each of the Galagans has a unique way of challenging the players.

column1: * Different types of ships. Players can choose single or dual ships (if the game option is set for dual and single). When the player retrieves a dual ship from the Boss's tractor beam
column2: it turns into a triple ship with ten times the power of a single ship.

column1: * Challenging Stages. In the 'That's Galactic Dancin' stages
column2: the Galagan invaders dance to a waltz
column3: tango
column4: Sousa march or jazz tune
column5: while the player shoots down Galagans to earn bonus points.

column1: * Warping to a new dimension. By destroying particular enemies or obstacles and capturing two of their items
column2: the player can warp to the next dimension.

column1: * Player challenge. Each dimension has different mix of Galagans with different strategies to be overcome.
* Win back captured ships. The player can win back ships captured in the Boss Galaga's tractor beam. When the player destroys the Boss
column2: the ships are released. If the player retrieves them
column3: the ships become dual ships if they were single and triple if they were dual.

column1: * High Score Mode. Upon completing a game
column2: a player can enter his initials if they are among the top eight scorers on the game."

column1: 1354;galaga;galagao;"Galaga (c) 1981 Namco.

;Galaga is a single-screen shoot-em-up in which the player controls a 'Fighter' spaceship and must defend the home planet against the on-coming hordes of alien invaders called ""Galagans"". The Fighter can only move left and right along the bottom of the screen.

Galagans fly onto the screen in a variety of formations before forming troop lines at the top of the screen. Once all troop lines are formed the Galagans separate and start attacking the player's Fighter in ones
column2: twos and threes. The top-line Boss Galaga need to be shot twice before they are destroyed.

column1: The Boss Galaga has a tractor beam that can capture the player's Fighter. A captured Fighter changes color from white to red and stays with that particular Boss until it is destroyed. The Fighter can be retrieved by destroying the Boss that captured it
column2: but players must be careful not to destroy the captured Fighter itself
column3: or that Fighter is lost. A rescued Fighter changes color back to white and links up with the player's current Fighter
column4: doubling its fire power.

column1: As players progress through each screen
column2: the speed and number of alien attacks increases. Alien formations also become more complex
column3: making the aliens harder to shoot.

column1: Bonus Fighters are awarded periodically throughout the game
column2: as players reach specific point values
column3: as dictated by the 'Bonus Life' dip switch setting. Each enemy ship also has an assigned point value (see Scoring below).

column1: The alien troop lines that form at the top of the screen are
column2: from top to bottom: Boss Galaga (in one row of four)
column3: Butterflies (red/white bug ships
column4: in two rows of eight
column5: directly below the Boss Galaga)
column6: and Bees (blue/yellow bug ships
column7: in two rows of ten
column8: directly below the Butterflies).

column1: In Stage 1
column2: the enemies do not drop bombs as they fly onto the screen. However
column3: they do so in most of the later stages.

column1: From Stage 4 onwards
column2: a squadron of special bonus enemies called ""transforms"" start appearing. They're called transforms because Bees will begin pulsating and move out of formation to change into these bonus enemies. They appear in the form of yellow scorpions in Stages 4
column4: and 6
column5: green 'Spy Ships' from ""Bosconian"" in Stages 8
column7: and 10
column8: and Galaxian Flagships in Stages 12
column10: and 14. After that
column11: the three different transforms are repeated in the same order. Transforms are always worthwhile targets because they are not very aggressive and are worth more than the other enemies. If all three transforms are destroyed
column12: extra bonus points will be awarded.

column1: Galaga also features CHALLENGING STAGES
column2: these consist of 40 Galagans that fly onto the screen in formations but do not drop any bombs. The object is to shoot as many of them as possible before they leave the play area. When an entire formation of eight Galagans is destroyed
column3: bonus points are added to the player's score. If all 40 aliens are destroyed
column4: players are awarded a special bonus of 10
column5: 000 points.

column1: Two new gameplay features Galaga introduced are :
1) Players are given the chance to double their fire power.
2) The game has a rapid fire (automatic firing) option
column2: whereby the player simply holds the FIRE button down and the space fighter continues to fire at the Galagan army in bursts of two missiles each."

column1: 1355;galaga3;galaga3a;"Galaga 3 (c) 1984 Namco.
;The general gameplay formula is the same as it was for both ""Galaxian"" and ""Galaga""
column2: with the player controlling a spaceship that moves along the bottom of the screen and fires up at the enemy formations at the top of the screen. Movement is not confined to left and right
column3: however
column4: as players can also move anywhere in the bottom half of the screen.

column1: The insectoid enemies fire down upon the player's ship
column2: and both individual and groups of enemies will break away from the armada to make attack runs on the player. Most of the Galagans can be killed with a single shot
column3: and shooting specific enemies will earn the player a tractor beam. This gives them the ability to capture one or more enemy ships; these prisoner ships will then sit alongside the player's ship and add to its firepower.

column1: Every few levels
column2: players will enter a 'Challenging Stage'
column3: where formations of enemy ships will fly in and out of the screen. Players must shoot them as many times as possible to try and spell out a word."

;Galaxian is a legendary single-screen shoot-em-up that took everything that made Taito's ground-breaking ""Space Invaders"" so good
column2: and improved upon it on every level. Each screen starts with a wave of multi-colored aliens moving left and right at the top of the screen; the aliens quickly break ranks and start dive-bombing the Galaxip (player's ship) - either in single units or in groups of 3 - dropping multiple missiles as they descend. All of the aliens need to be destroyed before the player can progress to the next wave.

column1: - CAST OF CHARACTERS -
Galaxip : This is the name of the ship which you control at the bottom of the screen.
Galaxian : These attacking aliens come in three varieties: blue
column2: purple
column3: and red. They begin in formation at the top of the screen and will occasionally swoop down to attack you before returning to their position in the formation.

column1: Flagship : At least two of these appear at the top of the formation at the start of each stage. They will swoop down to attack with one or two red Galaxians if any are nearby. If a flagship is one of the last enemies left of the screen
column2: it will run away and appear as a third Flagship at the start of the next stage."

;Galivan is a single player platform shoot-em-up in which the player takes on the roll of a 'Cosmo Police' officer who runs and jumps around a multi-directional scrolling cave system
column2: destroying or avoiding waves of constantly attacking robots
column3: aliens and alien ships.

column1: The player starts the game as an unarmed human
column2: whose only attacking options are kicking and punching
column3: but picking up a POW item encases the human in a robotic suit and arms the player with a laser gun.

column1: Collecting the blue POW items while in the suit awards the player with a powerful beam weapon for a limited time
column2: while the red POW item gives the player a three-shot cannon. POW items are dotted throughout the levels and can also be gained by shooting the blue robot aliens.

column1: The player's character has an energy bar that decreases whenever the player is hit. Should this fall below the halfway point
column2: the robot suit will be lost and the player will once again be an unarmed human.

column1: Collecting a POW item while in human form will restore the player's energy. If a POW is collected while wearing the suit
column2: however
column3: the player's energy will NOT be increased but their weapon will receive a power-up.

column1: The game's platforms are littered with springboards that fire the player high into the air when stepped on. Some platforms - often containing POW items - can only be reached via a springboard."

1380;galpani2;galpani2t;Gals Panic II (c) 1993 Kaneko.
;Gals Panic II is a ""Qix""-style adult puzzle game. The objective is to reveal 80% of the silhouetted girl's image within the time limit while avoiding the enemies.

There is a bar with a pointer at the top of the screen. If the pointer dips below a certain level (indicated by the change in color) the image will change to that of a monster. If a round is completed while the monster's image is shown then the round must be repeated. But unlike in the original
column2: the bar is unaffected by revealing the silhouetted and un-silhouetted parts of the image.

column1: After completing three rounds
column2: there is a break-out styled mini-game where the player may gain an extra life if he clears the blocks before the time limit."

column1: 1381;galpani4;galpani4;"Gals Panic 4 Yuu (c) 1996 Kaneko.

;Gals Panic 4 is a variant of the classic puzzle game qix where the player works to uncover the highlighted area of the play space to reveal a girl. Players select one of seven girls at the start of the game.  Each girl has three stages with each stage featuring a different background image to uncover. Players are given bombs to attack the enemies with and are rewarded with more bombs if they reveal a large section at one time. When a player reveals 80% of a girl the stage ends and the player is shown the entire background image. When a player reveals 100% of the girl in a stage
column2: he is rewarded with a 'Showtime' interlude.  Unlike in later games
column3: 'Showtime' sequences involve no nudity
column4: they just show the girl in a bikini. The 'Showtime' image is the same for each level featuring the girl.

column1: There is also a 2-player vs. game where both players work on separate images on a split screen and work to reveal their image first. When a player uses a bomb in this game
column2: instead of attacking the enemy
column3: it sends a sub-enemy to the other player's side."

To complicate things
column2: there is a bar with a pointer at the top of the screen. If the pointer dips below a certain level (indicated by the change in color) the image will change to that of a monster. The pointer slowly creeps towards the monster side of the bar over time and whenever the player reveals a significant piece of the silhouette.  Revealing the un-silhouetted part of the image moves the pointer back towards the girl side of the bar.  If a round is completed while the monster's image is shown then the round must be repeated.

column1: After every round there is a roulette game where the player can earn rewards or penalties that will take effect in the following round.
After winning three rounds against a girl
column2: the graphic becomes a photographic image of that girl."

;The third game in Namco's classic ""Galaxian"" series
column2: Gaplus picks up where 1981's ""Galaga"" left off. While maintaining the same classic 'look' of its predecessor
column3: Gaplus's graphics are a definite improvement over those of ""Galaga""; the game's increased color palette and subtle use of shading making the attacking aliens look rather more solid.

column1: Another enhancement over its prequel is in the addition of a player-acquired 'Tractor Beam'. In ""Galaga""
column2: only the enemies had access to the beam; enabling them to capture one of the player's 'Fighter' ships (the player then had to shoot the captor to release the Fighter). For the sequel
column3: however
column4: the player can now acquire the Tractor Beam. This is achieved by shooting one of the alien formation's 'generals' - a visibly more colourful alien than its comrades. The Tractor Beam will then activate for a limited time and any aliens the players captures (up to a maximum of six) will dock alongside the player's ship for enhanced firepower.

column1: One final yet important addition is in the movement of the player's ship. In previous installments
column2: the ship could only move left and right along the bottom of the screen; in Gaplus
column3: however
column4: the ship can now move UP the screen - although only to the halfway point. This is important as the alien's aggressive attack patterns will often see enemy craft swirling around the bottom of the play area.

column1: As with ""Galaga""
column2: Gaplus features regular 'Challenging Stages'
column3: with benign aliens swooping across the screen for the player to shoot as many times as possible
column4: in order to try and spell out a word and earn extra bonus points."

;Four selectable heroes scour dungeons and castles to defeat the evil monsters who would dare threaten the good people of their kingdom. Avoid the traps!

1408;gaun22p1;gaunt22p1;Gauntlet II (c) 1986 Atari Games.
;Gauntlet II is a direct sequel to the legendary maze-based fantasy themed shoot-em-up
column2: released a year earlier. Atari chose not to tinker with the core game-play mechanic to any great degree
column3: opting instead to enhance the already excellent multi-player action that had created such a stir upon the original game's release.

column1: As with its prequel
column2: up to four players once again take on the role of either 'Thor the Warrior'
column3: 'Thyra the Valkyrie'
column4: 'Merlin the Wizard'
column5: or 'Questor the Elf' and must play cooperatively as they explore and fight their way through the enemy-packed mazes
column6: collecting potions
column7: food and treasure as they searched for the exit that would lead them to the next dungeon.

column1: Changes to the sequel included the ability for players to play whatever character they wanted
column2: even if that character was already in play. Characters were now colour-coded and players would find themselves taking on the role of 'Blue Elf'
column3: 'Green Wizard'
column4: etc. New in-game speech was added to allow for the new player definitions.

column1: Other changes included the ability to 'bounce' shots off walls - known as 'Reflective Shots' - providing the correct potion was picked up. As well as new potions
column2: Gauntlet II also featured several new monsters. The most notorious of the new additions was the Fire-breathing Dragon that guards the exit to some dungeons. This powerful creature takes multiple hits to kill and defeating it would see the players rewarded with a permanent potion and a bag of treasure.

column1: Another notable addition was the 'It' monster: any player who was tagged by the creature would suddenly find that all of that level's monsters would ONLY chase the tagged player
column2: completely ignoring the presence of all other players. The only way to remove this curse was to tag another player
column3: thus making them 'it'.

column1: New level elements were also added to further increase variety. These included dungeons with entirely invisible walls
column2: magical walls (which changed into monsters or items when hit)
column3: stun tiles (which stunned any player that walked on them) and exits that flashed between functioning and non-functioning."

column1: 1410;gaun2pg1;gauntlet2pg1;;
1411;gaun2pj2;gauntlet2pj2;"Gauntlet (c) 1985 Atari Games.
;Gauntlet is a maze-based shoot-em-up for up to four players. Heavily influenced by classic fantasy conventions
column2: players take on the role of either Thor the Warrior
column3: Thyra the Valkyrie
column4: Merlin the Wizard
column5: or Questor the Elf and must play cooperatively as they explore and fight their way through the enemy-packed mazes. Competitive play is encouraged as players must fight for the limited amount of food
column6: treasure
column7: magic potions and power-up items that litter the dungeons.

column1: Each of Gauntlet's four characters have different strengths and weaknesses: Thyra has the strongest armour
column2: Thor is best at hand-to-hand combat
column3: Questor has the fastest speed and Merlin has the most powerful magic attacks. The object of the game is simply to survive as long as possible while exploring Gauntlet's mazes in search of treasure
column4: food
column5: magic potions and
column6: ultimately
column7: the exit that leads to the next dungeon.

column1: The potions - shown as blue bottles - that litter the levels offer either improved character abilities (such as 'speed' or 'extra shot power') or can be used as a 'smart bomb'
column2: destroying some or all of the on-screen monsters. Potions are also the only way to kill the game's 'Death' character that appears in many of the stages. Magic potions can be kept and used at the player's discretion by pressing 'Magic' button
column3: although each potion can only be used once.

column1: The first seven mazes are always the same
column2: but from level 8 onwards
column3: players will find themselves on any one of over a hundred different mazes. If players survive for long enough
column4: the mazes will be repeated in a different order. How long a player lasts depends upon the player's 'health' level. Health continually depletes as time progresses and further health is lost by contact with various monsters or their projectiles. Health can be replenished by consuming the food found in the mazes or by inserting more credits. The many treasure chests that litter the levels can be plundered for points
column5: and collecting treasure increases a player's score multiplier when two or more players are playing the game."

column3: 'Green Wizard'

column1: Other changes included the ability to 'bounce' shots off walls - known as 'Reflective Shots' - providing the correct potion was picked up. As well as new potions

column3: thus making them 'it'.

column1: 1433;gaxeduel;gaxeduel;;
1434;gberet;gberet;"Green Beret (c) 1985 Konami.
;Green Beret is a sideways-scrolling action/platform game set during the Cold War
column2: in which a US Special Forces Marine must infiltrate a Russian military base to save four POW's from being executed by firing squad.

column1: Initially
column2: the soldier is armed with only a combat knife
column3: but by killing the certain enemy troops
column4: players can obtain either a three-shot flamethrower
column5: a four-shot RPG
column6: or a three-pack of hand grenades.

column1: The Marine can jump or lie down to avoid the enemy bullets
column2: as well as climbing ladders to avoid enemies and projectiles
column3: as well as the flashing land mines that litter the levels. While it's possible to remain still in one area to rack up points
column4: if players take too long to proceed
column5: the game will start sending out tougher enemies and eventually a stealth-like bomber will appear to take out the player. There is also an unseen time limit that will kill off players if they take too long to complete the stage.

column1: The game has four stages in total: a missile base
column2: a harbour
column3: an air Base and a Siberian POW Camp. At the end of each stage the Marine will face a group of enemies specific to that stage: Stage 1 ends with a truckload of running and jump-kicking soldiers
column4: Stage 2 with a pack of fierce dogs and their handlers
column5: Stage 3 with three Gyro-copters and Stage 4 with a number of multi-shot flamethrower operators.

column1: The game is completed once the captives have been rescued at the end of the fourth stage
column2: after which the action starts over with an increased level of difficulty."

column1: 1436;gblchmp;gblchmp;"Global Champion (c) 1994 Taito America Corp.
;North American release. For more information about the game itself
column2: see the original Japanese release entry; ""Kaiser Knuckle"".

column1: In this version:
- Characters prologue/story removed.
- Some vocals said by the characters Kazuya
column2: Liza
column3: Li-Huan and Jim McCoy (after they win a round
column4: or before the fight begins) have been removed.

column1: - The portraits of Kazuya
column2: Liza and Li-Huan are different. Those were redrawn.

column1: - Super moves removed.
- The title screen is also different
column2: but strangely
column3: the letter K from both words in the Kaiser Knuckle logo can still be seen in some of Global Champion's backgrounds."

column1: 1437;gbusters;gbusters;"Gang Busters (c) 1988 Konami.

;An overhead shoot'em up where you play as a green-haired dude.
1438;gcpinbal;gcpinbal;Grand Cross (c) 1994 Excellent System.

;A futuristic video pinball game set in space where you use the 2 flippers to send the ball to many different enemies.
1439;gdarius;gdarius;G-Darius (c) 1997 Taito Corp.
;G-Darius literally added a new dimension to the highly regarded 'Darius' series
column2: with the introduction of fully 3D rendered backgrounds and enemies. Namco had already done the same with their Xevious series for ""Xevious 3D/G""
column3: released two years' earlier
column4: but G-Darius is generally regarded as the most accomplished of the two titles.

column1: G-Darius' game-play was also enhanced
column2: with the 'Capture Ball' system; this allowed the player to capture almost any enemy craft and use it against the game's other enemies. Captured enemies can either be detonated like a ''bomb''
column3: damaging all enemies nearby; or used to fire a special 'Alpha Beam'
column4: which cuts through everything but gold-colored objects and enemy bosses. Each boss is capable of firing its own version of this beam at the player; when both beams meet
column5: they will interrupt each other's path. Depending on how rapidly the player presses the Fire button
column6: one beam will grow and eventually overpower the others. The Capture ball was actually introduced in ""Darius Gaiden"" but was only used to a minimal extent."

column1: 1440;gdarius2;gdarius2;"G-Darius ver.2 (c) 1997 Taito.

;This version contains 3 buttons instead of 2 because one was entered for rapid fire, and the selection menu is added for difficulty once a coin is inserted.
1441;geebee;geebee;Gee Bee (c) 1978 Namco.

;A Pinball-flavored ball-and-paddle game.
1442;geebeeg;geebeeg;Gee Bee (c) 1978 Gremlin.
;- TRIVIA -
Gee Bee was released in October 1978."
1443;gekiretu;gekiretu;"Quiz Gekiretsu Scramble - Gakuen Paradise 2 (c) 1992 Face.

;A Japanese quiz game.
1444;gekirido;gekiridnj;Gekirindan (c) 1995 Taito Corp.
;Blast your way through different time periods in this vertical scrolling shoot'em up.
In 3195 AD
column2: scientists have developed a time-leap engine - but a mysterious entity known only as the Huge Boss has stolen it and used it to travel back in time and destroy 3000 years of mankind's history.

column1: Two people rise up to defeat him: Hokuto
column2: whose parents were murdered by the Huge Boss; and Shario
column3: to fulfill a last promise to her dead sister. Together they pilot their aircraft and chase the Huge Boss."

column1: 1445;gemini;gemini;"Gemini Wing (c) 1987 Tecmo.

;A vertically scrolling shooter. Destroy enemies and collect items, such as speed, that are stored in a tail behind your ship. Press the second button to activate them one by one in the order they were collected.
1446;genix;genix;Genix Family (c) 1994 NIX.
;A rip-off of Mitchell's ""Pang"" set in the Far-West."
1447;genpeitd;genpeitd;"Genpei Toumaden (c) 1986 Namco.
;Genpei Touma Den is a multi-genre birds-eye view action
column2: 2D side-scroller beat 'em up
column3: and 2D side-scroller platform arcade game that was released by Namco in 1986 only in Japan.

column1: The character controlled by the player is that of a real Japanese samurai
column2: Taira no Kagekiyo
column3: who fell at the Battle of Dan-no-ura at the end of the Genpei War in 1185. Over eight hundred years later he is resurrected and has to make his way over the Imperial Regalia of Japan - fighting other characters who actually existed such as Minamoto no Yoshitsune and Saito Musashibo Benkei on his travels
column4: as well as collecting the three sacred game items and defeating his arch-enemy Minamoto no Yoritomo.

column1: This game has three types of stages: Small Mode (standard)
column2: Big Mode (with large characters
column3: and usually boss fights)
column4: and Overhead Mode (like Small Mode
column5: but as the name suggests
column6: viewed from an overhead perspective). Most stages have torii (a gate) at the end of them
column7: which are used to transport the player to a different stage. Most of the Small Mode and Overhead Mode stages have multiple torii at the end of them
column8: which lead to different places on the map of the Imperial Regalia. Big Mode stages
column9: however
column10: only have one torii at the end of them. If Kagekiyo is unlucky enough to fall into a pit in any of the Small Mode stages
column11: he will end up in a non-standard Overhead Mode stage known as the ""Pit Stage"" (from which there are only two ways to escape - and one of these two does not always work).

column1: The game also features the Sanzu River
column2: the place believed in Japanese Buddhism to separate ""the current life"" and ""the afterlife""
column3: resembling the concept of the Underworld or Hell. Therefore
column4: mythological characters such as Emma-O
column5: God of the Underworld
column6: and Sun Goddess Amaterasu
column7: appear in this game (the former in the aforementioned ""Pit Stage"" and the latter in a non-standard Small Mode stage called the ""Bonus Stage"")."

1501;goldnaxa;goldnaxe;"Golden Axe (c) 1989 Sega.
;Golden Axe is a sideways scrolling beat-em-up set in a traditional fantasy world
column2: in which up to three warriors take up arms to rescue the kidnapped King and his Queen from the evil Death Adder.

column1: The game's three different playable characters are an Amazonian warrior named Tyris Flare
column2: a Barbarian hero named Ax Battler
column3: and a Viking dwarf named Gilius Thunderhead. Each character has a special attack move that is activated by pressing both JUMP and ATTACK at the same time. Also
column4: double-tapping the joystick right or left will make the character charge and smash into opponents.

column1: At certain points during the game
column2: players will come across enemies riding creatures (such as dragons). If the player knocks the original rider from the saddle
column3: the created can be mounted and used against the enemy.

column1: At certain points during a level
column2: as well as on the between-stage intermittent levels
column3: Thieves appear carrying a sack on their back. Players can hit the Thieves causing them to drop food and magic potions - the latter of which are used to create a special magical attack that damages or kills all on-screen enemies.

column1: Each of the game's heroes uses a different kind of magic: Ax Battler uses Earth magic
column2: Tyris uses fire magic and Gilius uses lightning magic. In addition: each player character also carries a different weapon: Tyris and Ax Battler both use swords while Gilius wields an axe.

column1: Golden Axe consists of 9 levels
column2: although only 5 of these are true levels as every 2nd stage is a short intermittent level featuring only the sack-carrying Goblins.

column1: Once Golden Axe has been beaten
column2: an end sequence is a scene of a video arcade
column3: in which the game's characters jump out of the arcade cabinet and chase the game's players out of the arcade and down the street."

column1: 1506;golgo13;golgo13;"Golgo 13 (c) 1999 Namco.
;A lightgun game in which the player
column2: armed with a semi-automatic sniper rifle takes on the role of the world's most lethal and highly paid assassin
column3: Duke Togo: Codename Golgo 13. Unlike other lightgun games Golgo 13 is very story driven and combines both 3-D and 2-D graphic elements.

column1: The player starts their career with a 100 percent accuracy rating and takes on various assignments. Each assignment begins with a 2D comic book storyline and although in Japanese they should still give the player some idea of the background story. The objective of the chosen assignment is then displayed together with the time limit
column2: target zone
column3: and available ammunition.

column1: At the end of each assignment the player is treated to on screen display of their performance. For each assignment successfully completed a large sum of cash is added to the player’s total
column2: plus an extra sum is awarded for hitting the target zone. If however the player fails to complete the objective or the timer reaches zero
column3: the player’s accuracy rating is reduced and the player is then moved on to choose the next assignment. The game is over when the player’s accuracy rating reaches zero.

column1: At the start of the player’s career
column2: 5 different assignments are available to choose from and can be completed in any order. Once all 5 assignments have been undertaken a new round of assignments becomes available. In total there are 4 rounds each consisting of 5 assignments
column3: with each round becoming progressively harder. The last round includes a special stage which can only be selected after all the assignments have been completed. Upon completion of the special stage the credits roll and the game ends. The player is then once again returned to the start of the game."

1510;goonies;goonies;Vs. The Goonies (c) 12/1986 Konami.
;A platform game based on the 1985 Steven Spielberg movie of the same name. The player takes control of Mikey and must explore a variety of caverns and rooms
column2: searching for the three keys needed to unlock the huge
column3: metal door that bars progress to the next level. The keys are hidden behind a number of doors which can only be removed by placing a bomb in front of them and blowing them open. Mikey's progress is hampered by the many enemies that roam the levels. The bombs needed to blow the doors appear when certain enemies are killed.

column1: A fellow 'Goonie' is trapped behind one of the doors on each level
column2: and can be rescued
column3: although this isn't necessary to progress to the next level. A catapult
column4: or 'slingshot'
column5: can also be found
column6: allowing Mikey to attack enemies from a safe distance."

column1: 1511;gorf;gorf;"Gorf (c) 1981 Midway.
;The player's goal is to defeat the Gorfian Empire and safeguard the future of mankind. Gorf is a single screen shoot-em-up in the classic ""Space Invaders"" mould
column2: the prime difference being that Gorf offers five distinct levels of shooting action. The levels are as follows :

column1: * Mission 1 - Astro Battles : The first mission is more or less a straight clone of ""Space Invaders""
column2: set against a sky-blue background. The player is protected by a glittering parabolic forcefield
column3: which is gradually worn away by enemy projectiles. The forcefield also works in BOTH directions
column4: and therefore must momentarily deactivate in order for the player's ship to fire out. To advance to the next mission
column5: the player must destroy all the invaders.

column1: * Mission 2 - Laser Attack : The other missions are all set in space. In this mission
column2: the player is faced with two formations each made up of five enemies. The formations are cross-shaped
column3: and at the bottom of each formation is a single laser gun. The laser guns fire a long
column4: dangerous yellow beam at regular intervals. At the same time
column5: the other enemies may break formation and attempt to divebomb the player. Destroying a laser gun causes the corresponding formation to break apart. To advance to the next mission
column6: the player must destroy all the enemies.

column1: * Mission 3 - Galaxians : This mission is a clone of ""Galaxian"". The player is faced with a swarm of galaxians
column2: which continually divebomb and shower the player with deadly projectiles. To advance to the next mission
column3: the player must destroy all the galaxians.

column1: * Mission 4 - Space Warp : A wormhole is situated in the middle of the screen out of which enemies ships emerge
column2: one at a time
column3: and spiral outward at increasing speed; whilst growing larger and flinging fireballs at the player. The Space Warp level would have an influence on Konami's superb ""Gyruss""
column4: released two years later. To advance to the next mission
column5: the player must survive a number of these enemies.

column1: * Mission 5
column2: Flag Ship : The final mission is a one-on-one confrontation with the alien Flag Ship itself. The Flag Ship is one of the earliest examples of the 'boss' enemy in mainstream video games. It is equipped with its own forcefield
column3: through which the player must blast in order to get a clean shot on the ship. It is also armed with a powerful fireball weapon. The player's weapon has a minor effect on the Flag Ship's hull
column4: and can only blast off tiny pieces of it. This adds to the player's problems
column5: as stray pieces of hull can destroy their ship. These pieces can be destroyed with a single shot. The only way to destroy the Flag Ship is to hit the glowing reactor at the heart of the ship
column6: either by first blasting away the hull to expose it
column7: or by managing to fire a shot directly into the tiny vent that leads to the reactor.

column1: Each time the Flag Ship is destroyed
column2: the player advances in rank. Initially
column3: the player begins with the rank of Space Cadet
column4: before moving on to Space Captain
column5: Space Colonel
column6: Space General
column7: Space Warrior
column8: and finally Space Avenger. The player's spaceship is equipped with a Quark Laser which allows the player to cancel a poorly aimed shot and fire another shot."

column1: 1513;gorkans;gorkans;"Gorkans (c) 1983 Techstar.

;In Gorkans, the player must use a four-way joystick to take control of a red flame-like character as he moves along blue lines (moving only forwards) and burns them away to collect flashing or spinning bombs for points before they explode. Gorkans must also watch out for the orange flames (which are palette-swapped versions of him) and also moving along the blue lines and burning them away - because if he ends up touching one of them (or unable to move given that he cannot retrace his steps), he will lose a life. If you are running out of space to go it is also possible to wait in one of the corners for the orange flames to burn themselves out. It is also possible to cut the orange flames off completely from Gorkans  and force them to move along particular lines by clearing out all the lines around the walls and leaving them with no option.
1514;gotcha;gotcha;Got-cha - Mini Game Festival (c) 1997 Dongsung Wonder Park.
1515;gotya;gotya;Got-Ya (c) 1981 Game-A-Tron.

;You are a 'Hand' and so are your enemies. Each hand can be Rock (A fist), Paper (Flat) or Scissors (2 fingers extended). Your job is to clear a maze of dots to move to the next level. If you touch an enemy and your 'hand' beats his (e.g. Paper beats Rock), you win, otherwise you lose your current turn.
1516;gowcaizr;gowcaizr;超人学園ゴウカイザー (c) 1995 Technos.
;(Choujin Gakuen Gowcaizer)
An anime style fighting game that takes place in the Year 2010 in Tron City. In this city
column2: there is a school for special students called the Belnar Institute. Isato Kaiza
column3: the hero of the story
column4: is a student at this school. He also possesses a stone called a Caizer stone which transforms him into a super human fighter named Gowcaizer. The story begins as a new student named Kyosuke Shigure arrives at the school seeking revenge against its president

column7: Kyosuke

1518;gradius;gradius;Gradius (c) 1985 Konami.
;A superb and demanding shoot'em up that shares - along with Irem's ""R*Type"" - the distinction of being a true innovator of its genre and
column2: again like R*Type
column3: completely revolutionized the humble shoot-em-up.

column1: Gradius' eye-catching graphics guaranteed gamer interest but it was the game's genius 'weapon upgrade' system that really made the difference. Never before could players actually CHOSE how to upgrade their ship. Destroying waves of enemies would often see the player reward with an 'orb' that could be picked up. The player could collect up to 6 orbs and could effectively 'buy' an upgrade from the 6 displayed at the bottom of the play area (speed-up
column2: bombs
column3: double
column4: laser
column5: multiple - which are orbs that follow the player's movements and add greater firepower - and a mystery 6th upgrade that is marked with an '?'). Game difficulty increases depending on how many power-ups the player has
column6: so it is sometimes advantageous to NOT power-up your ship too much."

column1: 1519;gradius2;gradius2;"Gradius II - GOFER no Yabou (c) 1988 Konami.

;The third game in Konami's renowned Gradius series; the prequel being ""Gradius [Model GX400]"" and a spinoff called ""Salamander [Model GX587]"". Gradius II strictly adheres to the shoot-em-up template set out by its hugely successful predecessor
column2: the game eschews the sideways/vertical scrolling alternate levels of Salamander and opts instead for Gradius sideways scrolling-only mechanic. This game is rightly considered to be one of the most demanding and difficult shoot-em-ups ever released."

column2: but more importantly
column3: the only way to pass a level is to shoot every enemy. The player knows when the enemy is overhead by looking at his shadow on the grid. Each red ball is worth 100 points. The green ball appears after catching 3 red balls & isworth 500 points. The crystal appears after catching 3 red balls
column4: a green ball and 3 more red balls. It is worth 1000 points and must be caught before it lands since it will not bounce

column6: making them hard to catch. The player has to avoid touching the bouncing enemies
column7: the charged tiles that flash after enemies land on them
column8: and the worm that moves horizontally across the tiles while charging them. There is a character named Igor that spits a sticky gum-like substance
column9: which turns the tile it lands on pink and causes Gridlee to move slow when walking on that tile. Also
column10: if there's one enemy left bouncing for a while as the player catches the

column1: balls
column2: the enemy eventually charges tile after tile
column3: which makes it dangerous for the player as the walking space is limited."

column2: a meteorite strikes the Galuga archipelago near New Zealand
column3: carrying with it a dormant alien lifeform. Two years later in 2633
column4: a terrorist organization of alien origin called Red Falcon takes over the island as part of their plot to invade the Earth. Bill Rizer and Lance Bean
column5: of the Contra unit
column6: are sent to the Oceania island to stop the evil threat.

column1: Gryzor is a hectic 1 or 2-player platform shoot-em-up featuring five stages. Three of the levels are standard side-scrolling platform levels
column2: while the remaining 2 are enemy 'bases'; 3rd person into-the-screen stages in which players must run down series of heavily defended corridors to reach and destroy an end-of-level boss
column3: before moving onto the next stage.

column1: Each player's character is equipped with a semi-automatic machine gun with an unlimited amount of ammunition and can jump
column2: move and fire in all eight cardinal directions. Players can also move and jump simultaneously while firing. Co-ordination of the character's movement is essential as a single hit from any enemy
column3: bullet
column4: or other hazard will instantly kill the player's character and also eliminate the current weapon from the player's inventory.

column1: As players fight their way through the enemy-packed levels
column2: additional weapons can be collected. If the player loses a life
column3: they will also lose any weapon power-up they were carrying. Available weapons are :

column1: * Machine gun [M] : Auto-fire.
* Spread gun [S] : Allows the player to fire five shots in an arc.
* Laser gun [L] : Will shoot a long laser that can take out many enemies in a row.
* Fire Ball [F] : A gun which fires small fireballs in a corkscrew pattern.
* Rapid-fire [R] : Increases the firing rate of the player's currently equipped weapon.
* Barrier [B] : Will make the player invincible for a few seconds.
The game's 5 levels and bosses are as follows :
Stage 1 : Jungle – Defensive Wall – (horizontal scrolling)
Stage 2 : Base 01 – Six turrets and alien eyeball – (3rd-person)
Stage 3 : Waterfall – Large Alien – (vertical scrolling)
Stage 4 : Base 02 – Six turrets and alien head – (3rd-person)
Stage 5 : Snow Field/Energy Zone/Hangar/Alien Lair – Alien Heart – (horizontal scrolling)"
1552;gseeker;gseeker;"Grid Seeker - Project Storm Hammer (c) 1992 Taito Corp.

;It is August 1999. In the skies over the Middle East, the second Persian Gulf War has begun. The early half of the 90's, the Persian Gulf War breaks out in the Middle East and prolonged fighting rapidly increases the rate of destruction of the world's natural resources. In 1999 this develops into a state of crisis where the effects of the war have resulted in an absolute shortage of reserves. Mistaken policies have resulted in the nation of the Middle East, suffering from shortages since the time of the original Persian Gulf War, taking military action against neighboring nations in an attempt to assure a supply of resources for themselves. Those nations which have managed to escape the fighting once again form a Multinational Force. Using the technology gained from research which had been done for a new type of nuclear reactor, they succeed in developing and producing GRID - a Gyrodrive Reactive Intercept Device. This is the start of Project Storm Hammer.
1553;gseekerj;gseekerj;Grid Seeker - Project Storm Hammer (c) 1992 Taito Corp.

;It is August 1999. In the skies over the Middle East, the second Persian Gulf War has begun. The early half of the 90's, the Persian Gulf War breaks out in the Middle East and prolonged fighting rapidly increases the rate of destruction of the world's natural resources. In 1999 this develops into a state of crisis where the effects of the war have resulted in an absolute shortage of reserves. Mistaken policies have resulted in the nation of the Middle East, suffering from shortages since the time of the original Persian Gulf War, taking military action against neighboring nations in an attempt to assure a supply of resources for themselves. Those nations which have managed to escape the fighting once again form a Multinational Force. Using the technology gained from research which had been done for a new type of nuclear reactor, they succeed in developing and producing GRID - a Gyrodrive Reactive Intercept Device. This is the start of Project Storm Hammer.
1554;gseekeru;gseekeru;Grid Seeker - Project Storm Hammer (c) 1992 Taito Corp.

;It is August 1999. In the skies over the Middle East, the second Persian Gulf War has begun. The early half of the 90's, the Persian Gulf War breaks out in the Middle East and prolonged fighting rapidly increases the rate of destruction of the world's natural resources. In 1999 this develops into a state of crisis where the effects of the war have resulted in an absolute shortage of reserves. Mistaken policies have resulted in the nation of the Middle East, suffering from shortages since the time of the original Persian Gulf War, taking military action against neighboring nations in an attempt to assure a supply of resources for themselves. Those nations which have managed to escape the fighting once again form a Multinational Force. Using the technology gained from research which had been done for a new type of nuclear reactor, they succeed in developing and producing GRID - a Gyrodrive Reactive Intercept Device. This is the start of Project Storm Hammer.

column3: which are worth 20 points each. The second stage
column4: which has a dotted orange line under the ship

1575;gumbo;gumbo;Gumbo (c) 1994 Min.

;Gumbo is a ""Columns""-style adult puzzle game featuring nude photographic and hand drawn images as a background to the playing field.  Columns of three blocks fall from the sky and the player can move the block left or right and shift the order of the blocks column falls. The objective is to match three or more blocks of the same type in vertical
column2: horizontal
column3: or diagonal rows in order to clear them from the play area. As the player clears more blocks the columns begin to descend at a more rapid rate.

column1: As time progresses entire rows of blocks are added to the bottom of the play area. Occasionally after clearing a set of blocks (and more often after setting off chains of removing blocks) the bottom row of blocks will be removed from the play area. If necessary
column2: the player can use a help which will change all of the blocks in the currently falling column into 'P' blocks. When the column lands on the stack of blocks
column3: whichever block it falls on will be cleared from the screen
column4: along with all blocks that match that block.  When the bottom row is removed from play a section is added to the progress bar at the bottom of the screen. When the progress bar is filled the stage is complete.

column1: After clearing a stage
column2: all of the remaining blocks are momentarily removed from the board and a bonus game begins.  In the bonus game the background image is broken up and shuffled around in a sliding puzzle game.  The progress bar at the bottom of the screen counts down the time left to return the tiles to their proper place and points are awarded for any extra time left after the game is completed.  Once the bonus game is over the background image is changed
column3: the blocks remaining from the previous stage are returned to the screen and the game continues.

column1: If the blocks reach the top of the screen where the columns are dropped from then the game is over.  Upon continuing all of the blocks are removed from play and the columns fall at the original speed."

1593;gunfronj;gunfrontj;Gun Frontier (c) 1990 Taito Corp.

;The year is 2120: Earthlings have spread beyond their galaxy and have started to colonize uninhabited planets in different solar systems. One such planet to be colonized was the Earth-like planet Gloria which happened to have an enormous natural supply of gold. This discovery became pivotal to Gloria's emigration
column2: so much that emigrators would be impoverished by the cost of reaching the planet. Because of this
column3: life on the planet thrived in a setting similar to the American Old West. Though poor
column4: the gold trade aided the Glorian's in advancing technology and knowledge
column5: so much that among the inhabitants lived talented inventors and engineers.

column1: However
column2: the Glorian's were not the only ones who were tempted by the planet's gold: Space pirates known as the Wild Lizards quickly invade Gloria and decimate the towns of the people and enslave those who survived in an attempt to deplete the planet's gold supply. Two inventors of Gloria who were a part of the planet's development teams decide to strike back at their invaders using two fighter jets in the shape of giant revolvers with plane wings.

column1: As far as vertical scrolling shooters go
column2: Gun Frontier is very standard. Players start with dual machine guns which are strengthened and multiplied by upgrades that come in the shape of US dimes taken from buffalo shaped enemies and every five dimes empowers the ship's guns. Players also start with a bomb supply which is upgraded to further destruction by collecting gold bars from destroyed ground forces. Once a player accumulates 25 bombs
column3: they are granted access to the Bomber Max
column4: the strongest of the player's bombs.

column1: The players can also pick up spinning coins with two different sides: a silver side and a gold side. If the player collects the coin on the silver side
column2: then the player merely gains another coin for their guns. However
column3: if the player collects the coin on the gold side
column4: then the player's guns and bomb supply is maximized to full power.

column1: A unique feature to the player's bombs is that the direction of the bomb's blast can be determined by the player's movement. If the player moves their plane to the lower right of the screen and launches their bombs
column2: then the direction the bomb will travel in the opposite direction the plane's movement. This feature can only be used however when a player has a large bomb count as only having one or two bombs will result in a small directionless explosion. Like most bombs in shoot 'em ups
column3: the bombs also work as a shield against enemy fire.

column1: The game uses a check-point system in which a downed single player will start off at the beginning of the check-point they died at.
Gun Frontier also employs an anti-autofire mechanism where the difficulty will max out by the second stage if the player is sustaining too fast of a fire rate."

;Each level is a maze of varying openness. Monsters spawn from colorful fires that must be extinguished to complete the level. The character can attack with three blasts of liquid before becoming empty. With each blast of liquid, the character moves faster and gets closer to being an empty outline with pink shoes. When empty the character is a shell of a sprite, but can move more quickly. Liquid is replenished by drinking (guzzling) from puddles. Occasionally, an alcoholic beverage will appear in the center of the screen. If the player picks up this beverage, liquid supply fills to maximum and the fires temporarily freeze.
1608;gwar;gwar;Guerrilla War (c) 1987 SNK.
;The country is struggling under the cruel domination of its evil King. The rebel guerilla leader and his comrades attempt to secretly land on shore. The King's military is waiting for them
column2: however
column3: and the players must fight their way inland to reach and destroy the King's palace stronghold.

column1: In this
column2: the pseudo-sequel to SNK's own superb ""Ikari Warriors"" (released two years earlier)
column3: players must once again shoot their way through a number of vertically scrolling levels
column4: all packed with large numbers of enemy soldiers
column5: gun emplacements and vehicles. Each level also contains a number of captured prisoners tied to wooden stakes
column6: and these can be rescued for extra points.

column1: The players' weapons have only a limited amount of ammunition and additional ammo/grenades must be picked up along the way. A number of gun upgrades can also be found. At various points in the game
column2: players can also enter unoccupied enemy tanks
column3: which provide increased firepower as well as resistance to enemy shots. Too many enemy hits
column4: however
column5: will eventually see the tank explode - this is proceeded by a warning flash to allow the player to exit the tank before the explosion occurs. Should the player be caught inside or near the tank when it explodes
column6: a life is lost.

column1: As with ""Ikari Warriors""
column2: Guerrilla War features full 360 degree gameplay with attacking troops appearing from all directions. The players' on-screen counterparts are able to rotate themselves accordingly."

column1: ;Gyruss is a single-player shoot-em-up in which the purpose is to fly through the solar system
column2: destroying waves of alien attackers
column3: before finally reaching Earth. Planets that must be passed before Earth is reached are Neptune
column4: Uranus
column5: Saturn
column6: Jupiter
column7: and Mars.

column1: It only takes two warps to reach Neptune
column2: but all of the others
column3: including Earth
column4: take three warps to get to. Each time the player reaches a planet
column5: they will be faced with a 'Chance Stage'
column6: a bonus stage in which players try to destroy as many aliens as possible to accrue points. After reaching Earth
column7: there is a Chance Stage
column8: followed by a very fast '3 Warps to Neptune' stage. After this
column9: the levels and the background music start over.

column1: Gyruss' superb gameplay
column2: in which the player ship rotates around the edges of the screen and fires 'inwards'
column3: is heavily influenced by Atari's 1981 classic
column4: ""Tempest"". While the design of the alien ships themselves is similar to those of Namco's also-legendary ""Galaga"" series."

column1: 1617;gyrussce;gyrussce;"Gyruss (c) 1983 Centuri
column2: Incorporated.

column1: ;For more information about the game
column2: please see the original Konami entry.

column1: - TRIVIA -
Gyruss was manufactured and released in April 1983 in the USA by Centuri under license from Konami."

Released in January 1986 in the USA."

1635;hangon;hangon;Hang-On (c) 1985 Sega.
;Hang-On is a superb point-to-point sprite scaling racing game in which the player takes control of a superbike and must race over five twisting circuits
column2: avoiding rival bikers and trying to reach the end of each stage before the time limit expires.

column1: Hang-On's handling and superb graphics were unlike anything seen before in the arcades and
column2: like many Yu Suzuki games that followed
column3: revolutionised the racing genre.

column1: The 5 stages of 'Hang-On' are :
Alps
Seaside
Grand Canyon
City Night
Circuit"
1636;hangonjr;hangonjr;"Hang-On Jr. (c) 1985 Sega.
;A cut-down version of its legendary parent
column2: 'Hang-On Jr' features similar gameplay to ""Hang-On""
column3: but is rendered in more primitive graphics due to the vastly inferior host hardware."

column1: 1637;harddrb5;harddrivb5;"Hard Drivin' (c) 1988 Atari Games.
;Slide into the contoured seat and adjust it to fit the length of your arms and legs. Put your feet on gas and clutch pedals and try the stick shift. Select manual or automatic transmission
column2: turn the ignition key and you're off!

column1: It’s the ride of your life. You feel the tires grip the road when you take a wide turn at high speed. You're alerted to the smallest change in the road by the feedback steering. You catch air as you fly the draw bridge and land on the down ramp. You control the car as it holds the road on the dizzying vertical loop.
Hard Drivin' might look like an arcade game but it drives like a real car. For the best lap times
column2: drive Hard Drivin' as if it were a real car. The main difference between Hard Drivin' and a real car is that Hard Drivin' is much safer to drive. A player can test the limits of the car and his skill with no risk of personal injury
column3: and follow a course that does not exist anywhere in the real world.

column1: After inserting the proper number of coins to start the simulator
column2: the player can select either an automatic or manual transmission. Turning the ignition key starts the simulator.

column1: Drivers can choose between the stunt track or the speed track by following the posted signs on the road. Each player has a certain (operator-selectable) amount of time to reach a checkpoint or the finish line. Crossing checkpoints and the finish line rewards the player with (operator-selectable) bonus driving time.
With Hard Drivin' a player can test drive a high-powered sports car on a real stunt course. He can jump a draw bridge
column2: negotiate a high-speed banked turn and drive a 360-degree vertical loop. These thrilling stunts
column3: among others
column4: provide the ultimate realistic driving experience.

column1: Or maybe high-speed driving is a particular player's type of excitement. He can 'put the pedal to the metal' and try to keep control around the corners
column2: weaving in and out of traffic while avoiding oncoming cars. All this
column3: and more
column4: await the player behind the wheel of Hard Drivin'.

column1: Players especially enjoy the unique instant replay feature on Hard Drivin'.  Every time a player crashes
column2: the simulator records and replays the crash sequence. Not only will the player find this entertaining
column3: but it is also informative. The instant replay shows the player exactly what he did wrong and why he crashed (If a player wants to skip the instant replay
column4: he can press the abort switch or turn the key when the replay starts).

column1: A skilled player finds the ultimate competition in the 'challenge' lap (or 'grudge match' as Atari Games likes to call it). The simulator remembers the path of the car driven by the best driver on record.  When a player beats the qualifying lap time
column2: he challenges the car of the past winner in a head-to-head race."

;Slide into the contoured seat and adjust it to fit the length of your arms and legs. Put your feet on gas and clutch pedals and try the stick shift. Select manual or automatic transmission
column2: turn the ignition key and you're off!

column1: It’s the ride of your life. You feel the tires grip the road when you take a wide turn at high speed. You're alerted to the smallest change in the road by the feedback steering. You catch air as you fly the draw bridge and land on the down ramp. You control the car as it holds the road on the dizzying vertical loop.
Hard Drivin' might look like an arcade game but it drives like a real car. For the best lap times
column2: drive Hard Drivin' as if it were a real car. The main difference between Hard Drivin' and a real car is that Hard Drivin' is much safer to drive. A player can test the limits of the car and his skill with no risk of personal injury
column3: and follow a course that does not exist anywhere in the real world.

column1: After inserting the proper number of coins to start the simulator
column2: the player can select either an automatic or manual transmission. Turning the ignition key starts the simulator.

column1: Drivers can choose between the stunt track or the speed track by following the posted signs on the road. Each player has a certain (operator-selectable) amount of time to reach a checkpoint or the finish line. Crossing checkpoints and the finish line rewards the player with (operator-selectable) bonus driving time.
With Hard Drivin' a player can test drive a high-powered sports car on a real stunt course. He can jump a draw bridge
column2: negotiate a high-speed banked turn and drive a 360-degree vertical loop. These thrilling stunts
column3: among others
column4: provide the ultimate realistic driving experience.

column1: Or maybe high-speed driving is a particular player's type of excitement. He can 'put the pedal to the metal' and try to keep control around the corners
column2: weaving in and out of traffic while avoiding oncoming cars. All this
column3: and more
column4: await the player behind the wheel of Hard Drivin'.

column1: Players especially enjoy the unique instant replay feature on Hard Drivin'.  Every time a player crashes
column2: the simulator records and replays the crash sequence. Not only will the player find this entertaining
column3: but it is also informative. The instant replay shows the player exactly what he did wrong and why he crashed (If a player wants to skip the instant replay
column4: he can press the abort switch or turn the key when the replay starts).

column1: A skilled player finds the ultimate competition in the 'challenge' lap (or 'grudge match' as Atari Games likes to call it). The simulator remembers the path of the car driven by the best driver on record.  When a player beats the qualifying lap time
column2: he challenges the car of the past winner in a head-to-head race."

column7: except on the bonus round where the player will just want to collect all the balloons that he can. The main intrigue here is getting past a blockade of Meowkies.

column1: The player controls are simple - Mappy can bounce in any of the four directions
column2: the only places he can land are the centres of the checkerboard squares (making for very few locations overall)
column3: and he will move at the same speed as the cats. If the player pushes the accelerator button and runs around
