column1: 1723;hopprobo;hopprobo;"Hopper Robo (c) 1983 Sega.
;Hopper Robo is a platform game in which the player must use a two-way joystick to take up control of a robot named Hopper Robo
column2: and a single button to make him jump. His objective is to collect the numbered boxes on each round in numerical order (the one he should collect next will flash)
column3: then drop them onto one of the two conveyor belts at the bottom of the screen. There are several kinds of enemy robots that guard some of the boxes; they all move in preset patterns and you will have to learn their movements in order to figure out the best moment to sneak past them. If any of them touch Hopper Robo he will die. He must also avoid other obstacles such as flying hammers and springs. To aid Hopper Robo
column4: there are springboards to reach higher platforms
column5: and pipes to slide back down. If Hopper Robo should run out of energy
column6: it will cost him a life - but when he clears a round
column7: his remaining energy will be awarded to the player
column8: as bonus points. There are eight unique levels
column9: after which the game loops indefinitely."

;Hot-Rod is a scrolling top-down racing game in which up to four players race each other over a variety of different surfaces on a selection of narrow
column2: twisting roads. Each player's vehicle has a fuel (gas) meter that constantly depletes as the race progresses. Extra fuel and bonus pick-ups are placed at regular intervals on each track and can be collected by driving over them. If a car runs out of fuel it is automatically disqualified from the race.

column1: During races the track scrolls to follow the current race leader. If the last-placed driver falls too far behind the leader and allows the scrolling area to catch up with them
column2: their car is automatically transported further up the track
column3: resulting in a fuel penalty.

column1: There are always four cars competing in each race
column2: with computer-controlled cars replacing any positions not filled by human players. Any driver finishing in the Top three is awarded bonus points
column3: with the amount determined on whether they finish 1st
column4: 2nd or 3rd. These points can be used to buy car upgrades in the garage shop that appears at the end of every race. The upgrades available are; engine
column5: tyre
column6: wing and bumper. These affect speed
column7: handling and durability. Particular attention should be paid to tyre choice
column8: as different tyres are suited to specific race surfaces
column9: with the next stage's surface being visible as the car enters the garage. Players can equip either a front or rear engine but not both at once. It is also impossible to have a spoiler and a rear engine equipped simultaneously.

column1: There are a total of 30 different tracks set across ten different environments
column2: including busy highways
column3: dirt roads
column4: a beach-side course
column5: a mountain course
column6: farmlands
column7: snowy terrain
column8: a desert
column9: a construction zone
column10: a shipyard and city streets. There are three races per environment with every third race ending with a victory ceremony in a stadium
column11: before play moves on to the next environment."

;Hunchback is a classic and much-copied platform game in which the player takes on the role of the eponymous bell-ringer
column2: Quasimodo
column3: in his quest to rescue the beautiful Esmeralda from the tower of the castle fortress.

column1: To reach Esmeralda
column2: Quasi must run and jump through a number of screens - each representing part of a castle wall - to reach the tower and complete his rescue. Each screen presents the player with a different set of platform-based obstacles. These range from spear-toting guards
column3: to ramparts and fiery chasms (the latter of which is cleared by carefully timed jumps onto and off a constantly swinging rope).

column1: Most of the game's screens also feature projectiles - in the form of fireballs and arrows - that must be avoided. These can appear from both the left and right-hand side of the screen and can be moving at one of two different heights and speeds. Some of the trickier screens contain more than one of these projectiles and contact with either a projectile or guard will result in Quasi falling from the castle wall
column2: resulting in the loss of a player life.

column1: To complicate matters further
column2: each screen must be completed within a strict time limit. This takes the form of an enemy guard climbing the castle walls; if the guard reaches the top of the wall
column3: he will walk towards Quasi to burn the Hunchback with his torch. If Quasi rings the bell before the guard has scaled the wall
column4: a bonus score is rewarded. If five screens are completed without a life being lost
column5: a 'Super Bonus' is awarded.

column1: A meter at the bottom left corner of the screen - displaying a cutaway of castle ramparts - shows Quasi's progress towards the tower and his beloved Esmeralda. Upon reaching Esmeralda
column2: players must complete a bonus screen - involving using moving ropes to collect bells from a series of platforms - to complete the rescue.

column1: Once completed
column2: the game starts over with a much higher level of difficulty and tighter time limits."

1753;hustle;hustle;"Hustle (c) 1977 Gremlin.

;HUSTLE is a 1- or 2-player video game which challenges players' reaction time as they attempt to build up a high score. The object of the game is to maneuver a moving arrow into targets which appear randomly on the screen. Each arrow is accompanied by a tail
column2: which can be used to block the opponent from scoring targets.

column1: TARGETS : The targets appear randomly on the playfield. The position of a target
column2: the value of a target
column3: the time a target stays on the screen
column4: and the time before a target appears are all unpredictable : There are never more than two targets on the screen at any time.

column1: To add to the unpredictability
column2: some targets appear with a value of ???. These are mystery targets
column3: and can have a value from -900 points to +900 points. Players go after the mystery targets at their own risk since the only way to determine whether or not a mystery target is positive or negative is to hit the target. Whenever a target is scored
column4: the game pauses while the appropriate player's score is tallied. Two distinctive sounds accompany the scoring
column5: depending on whether the target score is positive or negative. All non-mystery targets (which are all positive)
column6: and all mystery targets (which have positive values) are scored with an attention-getting warble sound. All mystery targets which prove to be negative are scored with a distinctive penalty sound.

column1: CRASHES : A crash (accompanied by a loud boom sound) occurs whenever a player hits anything other than a target. The three obstacles a player might hit are one of the screen boundaries
column2: the other player's tail
column3: or his own tail. Whenever a crash occurs
column4: the opponent scores 400 points PLUS all target values on the screen. If any mystery targets are on the screen during a crash
column5: their values are revealed
column6: and they are awarded to the opponent. All mystery targets whose values are revealed as the result of a crash are scored positive for the opponent.

column1: GAME SPEED : The game begins with the players moving at a moderate pace. Every time a target is scored
column2: the pace picks up slightly. After ten targets have been scored without a crash
column3: the pace stays at a maximum rate. Whenever a crash occurs
column4: the pace reverts to its initial moderate value
column5: and increases with each score
column6: as before.

column1: TAIL LENGTH : Whenever a crash occurs
column2: both players' tails grow longer. The game plays quite differently as it progresses. At the beginning of a game
column3: both players have short tails and are highly maneuverable. At this stage the game is a ""foot race"" to score the targets. As players crash and tails get longer
column4: a blocking strategy is added to the race for the targets. This constantly changing nature of the game is designed to provide long-lasting appeal
column5: and insure a long earning history.

column1: SINGLE PLAYER : HUSTLE has been designed to be just as exciting for one player as it is for two. A single player plays against himself
column2: and not against the computer.

column1: The single player game is initiated by simply pressing the ONE PLAYER START button instead of the TWO PLAYER START button after inserting a coin. The controls for one player are located on the right side of the control panel. The game plays the same as for two players
column2: with these exceptions :

column1: 1. There is a single arrow and tail
column2: instead of two.

column1: 2. Crashes are scored as PENALTY points
column2: with the same score as in the two player game. That is
column3: a crash scores 400 plus all on-screen targets into the PENALTY score.

column1: 3. At the end of the game
column2: the PENALTY points are subtracted from the player's score.

column1: The object of the single player game is to rack up as many points as possible. The game action is the same as the two player game
column2: with the lengthening tail and the accelerating pace."

column1: 1768;hyperspt;hyperspt;"Hyper Sports (c) 1984 Konami
;Hyper Sports is a multi-event sports game and is the sequel to 1983's seminal ""Track and Field"". As with ""Track and Field""
column2: the game supports up to four players and is controlled by two RUN buttons (renamed GO for this sequel) and one action - or UP - button.

column1: Tap GO and player will accelerate
column2: shoot or lift. Push UP and player will jump or shoot. The game offers seven different Olympic-based events
column3: and players must achieve qualification in each event in order to progress to the next. Game is over if you fail to qualify in an event.

column1: The seven events are :

1) Swimming-100M Freestyle : Use GO and UP buttons to regulate the speed and breath of swimmer. Tap GO button(s) to accelerate swimmer. Press UP button to allow swimmer to breath when 'breath' display appears on the screen. Swimmer will submerge if UP button is pressed any other time. Equal the computer's time for 3000 point bonus.
2) Skeet Shooting : Push either GO button to shoot. Shooting direction
column2: left or right
column3: coincide with GO button. Shoot clay within the red window to score. Consecutive hits expand the window
column4: in single increments
column5: to maximum. A miss will reduce the window to the smallest shape. 500-point clay appears after nine (9) consecutive hits. 1000 point clay appears after 19 consecutive hits. Hit all clays for a 'perfect' score.

column1: 3) Long Horse : Press and release either GO button to accelerate player
column2: push UP button at a proper position on the ramp to jump to the horse and again to lift from the horse. While in the air
column3: tap GO button(s) to control rolls and dismount pose. Points are decided on the number of rolls and dismount pose.

column1: 4) Archery : Press either GO button to randomly stop wind reel. Reel will automatically stop at random if GO button is not pressed
column2: wind reel displays wind direction and velocity (0 through 7 mph). Push UP button to shoot and hold to control angle.

column1: 5) Triple Jump : Tap GO button(s) to accelerate player. Press UP button at a proper position to hop
column2: step and jump.

column1: 6) Weight Lifting : Push GO button
column2: each time
column3: to advance to the next heaviest class
column4: once advanced
column5: backing up to a lighter class can not be made. Press UP button to elect weight class. Tap GO button(s) to lift the weight
column6: press UP button when bar bell flashes and continue tapping GO button(s) until the three judge indicators light up.

column1: 7) Pole Vault : Push either GO button and release. Press UP button to vault and release at proper position to clear the bar."

column2: Hyper Sports Special. Feel the thrill of competition as you test your Olympic skills against other world-class athletes. The Bronze is not enough

column1: Get pumped up to compete in the following events :
1) 100m Dash : Race against the other athletes as well as the clock. This is just a warm-up compared to the events to come.
2) Long Jump : Player dashes to the line
column2: leaps
column3: and propels his body as far as he is able. The player controls the speed and angle of the jump.

column1: 3) 400m Relay (Qualifying Heat) : Speed and timing are crucial in this event. Player must coordinate the baton hand-off perfectly for the best qualifying time.

5) 110m Hurdles : Player sprints down the track
column2: timing his jumps perfectly to clear all of the hurdles and reach the finish line in time.

column1: 6) Archery : This is a trial of the player's proficiency in using a bow and arrow. The player can decide the direction and force of the wind
column2: which will help in demonstrating his skill as a sharpshooter.

column1: 7) Javelin Throw : The player darts to the line and throws the javelin with all his might. The player controls the height of the javelin.
8) High Jump : Another test of speed and strength as the player runs to the line and hurls his body over the bar. The player can control his angle above the bar.

GO FOR THE GOLD!"

1799;indytem2;indytemp2;Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom (c) 1985 Atari Games Corp.
;The player takes on the role of action movie hero
column2: Indiana Jones
column3: in a game that takes place over 3 different zones; the mines
column4: a minecart chase and the temple. The first level features a number of platforms
column5: ladders and slides and Indy must free kidnapped children by finding their cages and whipping them open.

column1: The player must also keep an eye out for rattlesnakes and Thuggee guards. The second zone is a recreation of the infamous minecart chase in the movie and the player must guide Indy's cart to the bottom of the mine; keeping ahead of enemy carts and voiding traps and track-side enemies. The final area takes place in the temple itself and Indy must make his way to the altar and retrieve the Sankara stone. Indy must avoid guards and also flaming hearts thrown by the game's enemy boss
column2: Mola Ram.

column1: The player can choose to start the game on any one of 3 difficulty levels : easy
column2: medium and hard. These are selected at the beginning of the game by entering the corresponding door. Once all 3 Sankara stones have been collected
column3: Indy must work his way through a final mine and minecart section
column4: before making his escape on the rope bridge and facing Mola Ram once and for all. Playing the easy level will not include this level the first time Indy acquires all three stones. Instead
column5: a message will appear stating that Indy escaped on the rope bridge. The player is then returned to the game
column6: starting again on a more difficult mines level."

column1: 1810;intrepi2;intrepid2;"Intrepid (c) 1983 Nova Games.
;Intrepid is a game in which the player must use a 4-way joystick to take up control of a secret agent Intrepid whose objective is to enter an embassy
column2: find and retrieve a secret plan
column3: then escape as fast as he can. There are eight items that Spy 001 must find by looking around the rooms these doors lead to which are all worth 300 points when collected: a key (which unlocks the locked door on the fourth floor)
column4: a combination (which is needed to open the locked safe)
column5: an ID card (which allows Spy 001 to bypass the embassy's security systems without electrocution)
column6: a disguise (this allows Spy 001 to bypass the sentry
column7: without getting recognized)
column8: an umbrella (which allows Spy 001 to jump off the embassy roof without falling to his death)
column9: a wrench (which is to sabotage the elevator
column10: and trap the guards at the bottom of its shaft)
column11: a map (which shows the locations of the remaining items) and a pair of running shoes (which allow Spy 001 to move faster).

column1: If Spy 001 should fall down the elevator shaft
column2: get caught by the guards
column3: or get recognized by the sentry at the safe
column4: he'll lose a life. If he should jump off the roof before he's opened the safe (but after he's sabotaged the elevator)
column5: it is physically impossible for him to reenter the embassy. Should this happen
column6: the bonus timer shall immediately decrease to 0 and cost him a life. Once Spy 001 accomplishes his mission
column7: he'll proceed to his next mission which has more guards."

column1: 1822;invrvnga;invrvngedu;"Invader's Revenge (c) 1979 Zenitone Microsec.

;Invader's Revenge is a simple two-dimensional shooter. You control your fighter to defend your supply against an endless stream of alien invaders. Once you clear out one wave of 6 invaders, another wave comes in to take your fuel. After seven waves of alien invaders, you will then be given the chance to dock with your base to refuel. Of course, you have to navigate the hazards to get to your base. Your objective is simple, prevent the aliens from taking or destroying your fuel supply.

1826;irobot;irobot;I
column2: Robot (c) 1983 Atari.

column1: ;I
column2: Robot is a 3-D shoot-em-up in which the player controls the ""Unhappy Interface Robot #1984""; a servant robot who has become self-aware and decided to rebel against the all-controlling Big Brother and his ever-watchful 'Evil Eyes'.

column1: The game is set over a series of platform-based stages constructed from solid coloured blocks and to complete a stage
column2: players must ""eliminate the red zones"". This is achieved by moving the robot over all of a stage's red surfaces
column3: changing their colour to blue. The colour scheme - including target colour - changes every 26 levels
column4: however. So while the target colour is red for the first 26 screens
column5: it becomes yellow from Level 27
column6: blue from Level 53 and magenta from Level 79.

column1: In order to reach all of the platforms and surfaces
column2: the Interface robot will need to jump. This must be carefully timed
column3: however
column4: as jumping is not allowed under Big Brother's strict regime and his Evil eye - sitting atop a pyramid at the back of the playfield - will open at regular intervals to watch over the interface robot. Should the eye be fully open - indicated by it turning red - when the robot is mid-jump
column5: he will be spotted and destroyed
column6: costing the player a life.

column1: Once all of the coloured squares on a stage have been eliminated
column2: the enemy's shield is destroyed and the Interface Robot will need to be guided to a final
column3: previously inaccessible coloured square at the back of the playfield. The Evil Eye is then zapped and destroyed.

column1: Some levels feature different background elements that affect gameplay
column2: such as walls that must be shot and destroyed to reach coloured tiles
column3: or indestructible moving columns that intermittently block access to coloured tiles
column4: making timing difficult. There are also enemies to be shot or avoided
column5: including birds
column6: bombs and flying sharks.

column1: Once the eye has been beaten
column2: Interface Robot automatically jumps to the top of the pyramid and launches itself into space. A short inter-level ""Space Wave"" to the next stage follows. These stages feature polygonal objects hurling through space that must be either avoided or destroyed.

column1: Every third level contains a red pyramid that must entered once all coloured squares are eliminated. Once inside
column2: the Robot has one chance to collect as many bonus jewels as possible before destroying the Evil Eye. If the Robot is destroyed while inside the pyramid
column3: he is immediately thrust back into space. The player must then battle through three more levels and destroy a further three Evil Eyes before getting another chance to collect any high scoring pyramid jewels.

column1: After every fourth level
column2: the Space Wave stage features a battle with Big Brother himself
column3: shown as a huge
column4: disembodied polygonal head. Big Brother constantly spits cone-shaped projectiles from his mouth and every single one of these must be shot or they will collide with and kill the player.

column1: The head can be forced to rotate by repeatedly shooting the side of its face. If the head isn't facing the robot
column2: danger is minimized since he won't fire his cone-shaped projectiles when facing away. Players must simply survive this encounter for about 20 seconds
column3: after which Big Brother flies away and the next level begins.

column1: I
column2: Robot features 126 stages
column3: with 26 unique level designs. After level 26
column4: the designs repeat at a higher difficulty level and with an altered colour palette. The on-screen level counter is only two digits
column5: so levels 100–126 are displayed as 0–26 respectively. On passing level 126
column6: the player gets thrown back to a random earlier level.

column1: Once the game is underway
column2: pressing the one-player Start button will incrementally zooms the game's camera closer in to the action
column3: while the two-player Start button pulls it further back
column4: offering new viewing angles of the playfield. Closer camera angles result in higher score multipliers
column5: due to the increased difficulty of visibility. In later levels
column6: enemies known as ""Viewer Killers"" directly attack the player rather than the robot
column7: forcing players to either switch camera angles
column8: or move the robot to scroll the camera away from the Viewer Killers

column1: 'I
column2: Robot' was - in both technical and design terms - ahead of its time and the game featured many new and ground-breaking innovations that the games industry would later adopt. The most striking and obvious of these was the game's graphics. While 'I
column3: Robot' wasn't the world's first three-dimensional game
column4: it was the first to feature solid
column5: filled-polygon graphics
column6: as opposed to the wire-frame graphics adopted by earlier titles. The concept of players being able to switch viewpoints also appeared here first.

column1: The final innovation was 'Doodle City'. Instead of playing the game
column2: players could instead choose to use the game's colourful three-dimensional objects to draw pictures on the monitor screen. Doodle City lasts for three minutes per credit
column3: although players can switch back to playing 'I
column4: Robot' at any time. When switching back to the game

column6: with one life taken away for every minute in the ""Ungame"" mode."

1830;jack;jack;"Jack the Giantkiller (c) 1982 Cinematronics.

;This game plays a lot like ""Donkey Kong"" except that the controls are not quite as smooth. There are 5 screens to master if you want to help Jack in his mission. You do not get to play each screen at first
column2: they are added on as you progress through the game. The first time through the game skips from screen 1 right to screen 4.

column1: * The 1st screen is fairly simple
column2: you just have to climb to the top of the beanstalk. There are a few enemies
column3: but they can be defeated by simply tossing beans at them. You can find the beans scattered all around the stalk
column4: and picking one up adds one to your ammunition count (or two
column5: depending on the dip switch settings).

column1: * In the 2nd screen
column2: Jack manuevers through the clouds and attempts to cross the drawbridge into the castle
column3: but lions and birds stand in his way.

column1: * The 3rd screen has Jack climbing the castle stairway in a scene that was obviously inspired by ""Donkey Kong"". Avoid the cat and the mouse and you can make it to the top.
* On the 4th screen you have to jump from platform to platform until you reach the giant's lair. There will be several treasures
column2: grab the flashing one and try to make your escape.

column1: * The 5th screen is the first one again
column2: except that this time you are climbing down the beanstalk
column3: and you have falling rocks to dodge
column4: and the giant himself may even be after you (that one depends on the level).

column1: After making it back to your house you get to watch a little intermission before going after the next treasure. There are four different treasures altogether. The last one is the princess
column2: when you have her the giant himself will follow you down the beanstalk
column3: and you must chop it down to defeat him. After rescuing the princess the game starts over with increased difficulty."

column1: The ultimate aim of the game is to reach and destroy the Death Star and escape alive. Success is achieved by surviving an 'attack wave'
column2: which consists of four different scenes. Play switches between Endor and space-based scenes
column3: with each one putting the player in control of a different vehicle from the movie.

column1: The scenes are based on three distinct locations taken from the original movie. They are: The forest moon of Endor
column2: Attack on the Death Star
column3: and Space battle.

column1: * SCENE 1: Speeder Bike chase on Endor as Princess Leia. The goal is to reach the Ewok village alive.
* SCENE 2: Scout Walker chase on Endor as Chewbacca. The goal is to reach the shield generator.
* SCENE 3: Millennium Falcon attack on Death Star as Lando. The goal is to reach and destroy the Death Star power reactor.
* SCENE 4: Millennium Falcon escape from exploding Death Star. The goal is to escape the exploding Death Star.
* SPLIT SCENE: Play switches between scenes 2 and 3.
The scenes loop for as long as the player has lives remaining; although to increase variety
column2: the order in which they appear is randomised as play progresses. Each successive wave increases in difficulty."

;A mahjong game with 12 selectable player and opponent characters. At the start of the game the player selects his player character. Then, before every match the player selects his next opponent. Unlike in the original, Jan Jan Paradise, the player is allowed to select his character and opponent out of all 12 characters instead of just out of three characters at a time.  Each character features three different strip images and one animated strip sequence. When the player defeats an opponent, the final strip image of the opponent is replaced with the animated sequence. But unlike in the original, the player is shown the final still strip images of each character he has defeated in a 'gals collection', shown after the player's game is over. When the player loses he is treated to the booby-prize, all of the player character's strip images are shown excluding the animated sequence.

;The Play mode begins when either the 1-PLAYER or the 2-PLAYER START button is pressed. The Play mode ends when all of your performers have been eliminated. When this happens
column2: GAME OVER is written across the center of the monitor screen.

column1: ON THE SCREEN : The game is made up of groups of 5 sequences for each rack. When play begins
column2: all the performers run onto the screen and jump aboard their transport ship
column3: the Scarab. The Scarab then lifts off and heads for a point in space that is at the center of a grouping of five planets. (The song that is played in the background during this scene is 'Lights'.) Each group member's instrument is on a different planet.

column1: At the beginning of each sequence
column2: when a 2-PLAYER game has been selected
column3: the game tells which player is up.

column1: Also indicated in each sequence of each rack is the number of players (1 or 2)
column2: a running total of the player score(s)
column3: and the highest game score to date.

column1: PLAY BEGINS : From this point
column2: the player has approximately 10 seconds to decide which planet he wants to take the Scarab to (which performer’s instrument he wants to retrieve). The Scarab is guided to the planet of your choice by using the control stick to direct its movement.

column1: OBSTACLES : On each planet there are various obstacles that must be overcome in order for that particular performer to retrieve his instrument and make his way back to the Scarab.
1st PLANET - Microphone : Steve Perry must pass between the turnstiles without touching them
column2: get his microphone
column3: and shoot his way back to the Scarab. The background song for this scene is 'Don't Stop Believing'.

column1: 2nd PLANET - Bass : Here
column2: Ross Valory must leap onto the elevating pedestals
column3: timing his assent to grab his bass as it passes by him at the top of the screen
column4: and shoot his way back to the Scarab. The song played in the background here is 'Keep On Running'.

column1: 3rd PLANET - Keyboard : Here
column2: Jonathan Cain must leap the moving conveyor belt ridges without being touched to reach his keyboard and then must shoot his way back to the Scarab. The background song here is 'Stone in Love'.

column1: 4th PLANET - Guitar : With his jet pack
column2: Neal Schon must traverse the dangerous passages in this cavern to finally retrieve his guitar and then fight his way back to the Scarab. 'Chain Reaction' plays in the background here.

column1: 5th PLANET - Drums : Steve Smith must jump from drum-head to drum-head
column2: landing on all of them at least once in order to reach his drums. He then must shoot his way back to the Scarab. 'Wheel in the Sky' is the background song here.

column1: ALL INSTRUMENTS RETRIEVED : All the performers now move to a stage and give a performance of 'Separate Ways (Worlds Apart)'
column2: their latest hit blockbuster at the time of this game's release. They will play as long as Herbie
column3: the bouncer (controlled by the player)
column4: can keep the excited fans from overrunning the stage. When this happens
column5: play starts all over again in the next rack which will be more difficult to complete. The performers all have to retrieve their instruments again.

column1: SEQUENCES : Play ends in any particular sequence when one of 3 things happens.
a. The performer has a mishap and
column2: except for Steve Perry
column3: falls to the bottom of the screen. (A sample of 'Who's Crying Now' will play in the background.)

column1: b. The performer retrieves his instrument and shoots his way back to the Scarab.
c. The excited fans storm the stage (play advances to the next rack of 5 sequences).
PERFORMERS : When on each of the 5 planets
column2: the performer's movements are controlled by the control stick on the games control panel. They can basically move in any direction.

column1: MISHAP : Play will begin again (if you have reserve performers left) in space
column2: all performers are in the Scarab
column3: and the player has approximately 10 seconds to pick the next planet he wants to try.

column1: NOTE : You cannot pick a planet where the performer has already retrieved his instrument. These planets are indicated to the player by a wavey white ring around them.
If there are no more reserve performers left
column2: GAME OVER is written across the screen.

column1: SCARAB VEHICLE : The Scarab can move in any direction on the screen. Its movements are controlled by the control stick on the games control panel.
FIRE CONTROL BUTTONS : These control the rate of fire of your performer in; either left
column2: right
column3: up
column4: or down directions (certain performers can only fire in certain directions). There are 2-fire control buttons on the Upright models to allow both left and right handed persons to play the game easily.

column1: CONTROL STICK : By using the control stick you can position the Scarab/performer/bouncer at any location you desire on the screen.
BONUS PERFORMERS : These can be awarded to the player as he reaches or passes certain preselected point values. This feature is adjustable by the game's owner/operator.
GAME ENDS : When your last performer is eliminated. GAME OVER is written across the monitor screen."
1860;joust;joust;"Joust (c) 1982 Williams.

;Joust is a platform-based action combat game for one or two-players (with the two-player game offering either team-up OR head-to-head combat; the first time arcade gamers were given this choice) in which each player controls a knight riding on the back of a flying ostrich.

The object of the game is to progress through platform-based levels by defeating groups of buzzard-riding enemy knights. This is achieved by 'jousting'; both enemy and player knights carry a lance and must fly around the level (actioned by repeatedly hitting the 'Flap' button) trying to oust rival knights from their steeds by ramming them with the lance. This can only be achieved if the attacking rider is above the enemy knight when the lance connects. A collision of equal elevations results in the two knights bouncing off each other
column2: but if a player is lower than their enemy at the instant of contact
column3: they themselves will be knocked from their steed and lose a life.

column1: A defeated enemy will turn into an egg that falls to the bottom of the screen. This must be quickly collected by players as if the egg lands on a platform and isn't retrieved in time
column2: it will eventually hatch into another enemy knight that must be defeated again.

column1: Joust features three different types of enemy knights - Bounder
column2: Hunter
column3: and Shadow Lord - with each earning players different points values when defeated. A pterodactyl will appear after a predetermined time to hunt the players.

column1: Accurately navigating the player Knights can be initially quite difficult as control is strongly affected by both gravity and inertia. Players can lose a life by either being knocked from their steed by an enemy knight
column2: or by falling into the lava pit at the bottom of each level."

column1: 1861;joust2;joust2;"Joust 2 - Survival of the Fittest (c) 1986 Williams Electronics
column2: Incorporated.

column1: ;On the planet of the floating cliffs
column2: society calls upon its wing-mounted Gladiators to solve conflicts. You
column3: the Gladiator
column4: must enter the fray
column5: participating in a challenge of honor
column6: a Joust... where only the fittest survive!

column1: The legend of ""Joust"" continues in Joust 2. Players must solve the puzzle of what strategy will be most effective in dealing with the buzzards and other winged enemies on each of Joust 2's 35 different backgrounds.
The object of Joust 2 is to defeat all winged enemies by colliding with them. To survive a collision (joust)
column2: the Gladiator's lance must be higher.

column1: Defeating a Buzzard Enemy in a Joust causes release of an Egg. Eggs may be caught in the air or collected on landing areas for bonus points. Be Careful! Eggs falling into the Lava form into aggressive mutants
column2: while uncollected Eggs hatch into dangerous warriors.

column1: Danger lurks everywhere! Giant Statues come to life; Bats fall out of crystals embedded in the rocks; Lava Trolls and Water Monsters eat unsuspecting bird-mounts; Lightning fills the air; and Unbeatable? Pterodactyls patrol the skies. A gigantic Knight presides on several waves. You
column2: the Gladiator
column3: must destroy him! Hitting all four of his red pins explodes the Knight and all his servants.

column1: Gold Egg Feature : A Gold Egg may randomly appear on any wave. Collecting the Gold Egg before it hatches opens a window of awards in the background. To collect an award
column2: step on the red button above the window before a timer expires. Both players reap the benefits of the posted award
column3: which may include bonuses of 1
column5: 000 points
column6: 'super zapping' all enemies on the screen
column7: or even receiving an extra life.

column1: Prepare thyself for War!

Buy-In : Joust 2 is designed for action entertainment for one or two simultaneous players. Players who have started the game may continue where they left off by using the buy-in feature. When a player has used all of his lives
column2: he will hear : ""Wish to continue?"" A 10-second timer appears in the players score area to allow the game to continue by using a Credit
column3: or inserting a coin
column4: before the player presses the Start button.

column1: Level Selection : At the beginning of a game
column2: the player selects
column3: via the Flap button
column4: one of six different waves
column5: corresponding to the player's skill level. Then
column6: pressing the Start button begins the game. If the player wins the starting wave
column7: he receives an award of points
column8: approximating the scoring from preceding waves."

column1: The Pac character is once again pursued by four ghosts (Blinky

column3: Inky and Tim) in his quest to eat all of the dots in each maze. And
column4: as before
column5: numerous Power Pills litter the mazes that
column6: when eaten

column1: As with previous ""Pac-Man"" games
column2: intermissions are featured between certain levels. Jr. Pac-Man's intermissions are episodic in nature
column3: like those found in ""Ms. Pac-Man"". Jr. Pac-Man's story tells of the blossoming love between Jr. Pac-Man and a small ghost named Yum-Yum.

column1: Act I - Jr. Meets Yum-Yum : Jr. Pac-Man steps outside his home to play. He spots Yum-Yum beyond the fence in his yard and goes outside to meet her. Blinky
column2: hiding in the shadows
column3: comes out from hiding to catch Jr. However Ms. Pac-Man
column4: keeping a watchful eye over her child
column5: sees the commotion from her window and runs out to the yard to eat a Power Pill and chase both ghosts away while Jr. returns to the safety of home. This intermission is played after Round 1.

column1: Act II - The Gift : It seems that Jr. can't get the enchanting young ghost out of his mind
column2: so he proceeds to bring a balloon to her as a gift the next day. Excited to see her
column3: he meets her on a bridge and hands her the balloon
column4: when we catch a glimpse of Blinky lurking behind a bush. This intermission is played after Round 3.

column1: Act III - They Escape : Blinky moves from one bush to the another
column2: startling Yum-Yum into releasing the balloon. Blinky attempts to capture Jr. once and for all
column3: but once again
column4: Ms. Pac-Man comes to the rescue. Blinky chases her off to the left
column5: while Jr. Pac-Man and Yum-Yum escape to the right. Once alone
column6: they gaze in to each other's eyes and fall in love
column7: with hearts appearing all around them. This intermission is played after Rounds 5
column9: and 9."

- TRIVIA -
Released in October 1982
column2: this reworked version of ""Jungle King"" was the end result of a copyright infringement lawsuit filed against Taito by the estate of Edgar Rice Burroughs
column3: the creator of Tarzan.

column1: Here's what makes Jungle Hunt different from Jungle King:

* Music is played at the places where the Tarzan yell was originally heard - at the beginning of the game and at the end of the avalanche stage - the same music that plays upon completion of the river stage.
* The player character is a safari-suited jungle explorer clad in a pith helmet
column2: jacket
column3: and shorts
column4: instead of the Tarzan look-alike.

column1: * The life-lines that the player character swings on between the trees in the first stage are ropes instead of vines.
The original version of the game
column2: known as Jungle King
column3: featured a character who looked like the well known (and very much copyrighted) Tarzan. The character even sounded like Tarzan when he bellowed out the famous scream after finishing the boulder stage (and at the beginning of the game). So
column4: for legal reasons
column5: the name was changed to 'Jungle Hunt' and the player character was changed to resemble a classic safari-suited jungle explorer complete with the standard issue pith helmet
column6: jacket
column7: and shorts. The bellowed scream at the end of the boulder stage was also entirely removed
column8: replaced by the music from the end of the river stage.

column1: A Jungle Hunt unit appears in the 1983 movie 'WarGames'.
Michael Torcello holds the official record for this game with 1
column3: 220 points.

column1: MB (Milton Bradley) released a board-game based on this video-game (same name) in 1983."
1879;junglek;junglek;"Jungle King (c) 1982 Taito.
;Jungle King is a jungle adventure game where players take on the role of Jungle King
column2: a Tarzan-like jungle man
column3: who is going in search of his Jungle Princess
column4: who has been kidnapped by a pair of barbaric cannibals.

column1: Jungle King has four stages
column2: each with its own unique scenarios
column3: so each stage could be considered a separate game in its own right.

column1: It is noticable that this game scrolls from right to left
column2: while the vast majority of scrollers go from left to right
column3: although most people probably wouldn't even notice that.

column1: Jungle King's gameplay is very similar to that of Activision's ""Pitfall""
column2: a classic arcade game released on many home computer and console formats of the time.

column1: The game's stages are as follows :
* The first stage
column2: which may have been the best stage in the game
column3: is set in a forest with a series of swinging vines. Players must use the JUMP button to move from right to left across the vines
column4: while avoiding the monkeys that can send Jungle King falling to the ground. This level is easy to master
column5: but players must time their jumps carefully to make it to the next vine.

column1: * The second stage is set under a jungle river. Players must guide Jungle King through a river infestest with alligators and crocodiles. This stage features a 'breath meter' that must be carefully watched to avoid drowning (players simply swim up to the surface to get more air). Jungle King is armed with a knife with which he can stab the crocs and gators
column2: but this can only be done when their mouths are not fully open.

column1: * The third stage is an avalanche with boulders rolling down a hill. The player simply uses the joystick to control Jungle King's climbing speed up the hill
column2: and the JUMP button to leap over rolling boulders until they reach the end of the stage.

column1: * The fourth and final stage has the player guiding Jungle King through a cannibal village. Jungle King must jump over the cannibals while their spears are down
column2: and eventually make his way towards his Jungle Princess
column3: who is being lowered into a pot to be boiled for supper.

column1: On completion of the game
column2: players are rewarded with a short 'I Love You' ending
column3: and then the game begins again with increased difficulty."

column1: Kaiser Knuckle was Taito's answer to Capcom's Street Fighter II during the fighting game trend of the 90s. Despite showing highly detailed and unique content in the arcades
column2: it didn't catch enough attention to become a success and was never ported to home consoles.

column1: A unique feature is that this was the first and only fighting game to feature five different strength for basic punches and kicks.
Another unique feature are power zones
column2: these are activated when landing a special move when a character's Power (Crush in the Japanese version) meter is full. Power zones contain electricity or fire that can help improve a character's special move. Stage backgrounds can also be destroyed by the combat
column3: getting hit fills the Power meter and when a special move connects when it is full
column4: it greatly damages the background walls and can unlock the fire or electric zones found in levels."

;Karnov is a 2-D, platform style game. You control Karnov through 9 scenes. Each of these scenes gives you piece of a map (except the first scene). Get all the pieces of the map and you get to the treasure. Your journey won't be easy though. You will be going through some rough environment such as towns, forests, oceans, and caves. To further make your travels a hazard, different enemies attempt to end Karnov's life prematurely and prevent him from getting to the treasure. To aid Karnov in his adventures, he has certain items that he can draw from his inventory. In addition, there are other items that can make Karnov a potent foe of those wishing to harm him. You must complete each scene in order to advance to the next scene. All in a days work of a hearty explorer.

column3: this time ported in the Neo Geo MVS Hardware. In this new version of the original game several changes and improvements were made to enhance the gameplay: now the battles are faster and more technical
column4: with the usual friendly combo system that makes the fight so spectacular. There are also some powerful hidden moves added for most of the characters. Even the graphic was slightly enhanced
column5: with a nice color palette and some wonderful backgrounds (especially Zazie's).

column1: The game actually suffered from the reputation to be a 'SFII clone' given by the general opinion from the first episode. Thanks to this new chapter of the saga
column2: which was particularly appreciated by the Neo Geo fans because it is one of the rare 'SFII style' beat'em ups on the Neo Geo this changed.

column1: A really nice and classical beat'em up
column2: still worthy to be played
column3: especially for the real fans of the 2-D beat'em up."

column1: 1915;kbash;kbash;"Knuckle Bash (c) 1993 Toaplan Company
column2: Limited.

column1:
;3 wacky characters go after the Bulls and others who would dare threaten the peace of the city!
1916;kchamp;kchamp;Karate Champ (c) 1984 Data East USA.

;A seminal 1-on-1 fighting game set over the course of a karate tournament, Karate Champ was the first game of its type and would influence every game of the fighting genre that followed. Karate Champ's control system utilised a somewhat awkward dual joystick control system, with simultaneous joystick manipulation required to execute even the simplest of kicks.

1921;kicka;kickc;Kick Man (c) 1981 Midway Mfg. Co.

Priestess Sayo-chan must repel ghosts in order to rescue Seven Lucky Gods!

column2: Sayo-Chan must travel to the ghost village and defeat the enemies who are determined to stop her rescuing the Gods."

1932;killcom;killcom;Killer Comet (c) 1980 Centuri.

;An early shooter. You goal is the destroy the invading ships around the screen. You can only fire upwards.
1933;kingbalj;kingballj;King & Balloon (c) 1980 Namco.

;The player controls two green men (likely soldiers in the king's army) with an orange cannon that fires at squads of descending balloons. You must protect the King and prevent him from being captured and carried away by one of the balloons. Unlike most shooter games
column2: the player's cannon can be hit and destroyed any number of times; it is the King that must be protected. The game ends when the king is carried away three times."

1937;kinst;kinst14;Killer Instinct (c) 1994 Midway Mfg. Co.
;10 genetically engineered fighters engage in 1-on-1 combat in a tournament arranged by the sinister 'Ultratech'
column2: the organization behind the genetic creation of the fighters. The tournament soon turns into a battle for survival.

column1: Each player starts the game with 2 energy bars
column2: which represent the amount of health each player has for the entire game. Once the first bar is depleted
column3: the player falls
column4: gets up and starts to use the second energy bar. A voice will subsequently announce either 'Round Two' or 'Killer Instinct!'. The player who wins the first round gets to keep their remaining energy
column5: and still has the second bar to use in future fights. This gives an advantage to the player who wins the first round.

column1: Killer Instinct introduced incredibly complex combos to the fighting genre
column2: as well as including the Fatalities and Humiliations made famous by Midway's ""Mortal Kombat"" Series."

column1: 1938;kinst2;kinst2;"Killer Instinct 2 (c) 1996 Midway Mfg. Co.
;A great sequel of the previous game include new features and new characters.
The plot follows on where the first installment left off. Eyedol's death at the hands of Orchid accidentally sets off a time warp
column2: transporting some of the combatants back in time and allowing the Demon Lord Gargos to escape from Limbo.

column1: Now
column2: trapped 2000 years in the past
column3: the warriors that survived Killer Instinct
column4: along with several new faces
column5: fight for the right to face Gargos in combat. Each character that survived the journey from the first game has a corresponding background story
column6: while new characters on this installment are native inhabitants of this past time period. Some fighters
column7: like T.J. Combo who survives from the original
column8: just want to get home. Others
column9: like new character Tusk
column10: want to bring an end to Gargos and his reign of evil. This time there is no tournament or prize money
column11: just a fight to the finish with the fate of the future hanging in the balance."

column1: 1939;kirameki;kirameki;"Kirameki Star Road - Intro Club (c) 1997 Taito.

;Kirameki Star Road is a music trivia game for one or two players where the player assumes the role of a music talent scout. At the start of the game the player chooses one of three girls to promote as a new music idol.  The object of the game is to listen to a piece of popular music and select the correct musician or title for the song before the timer runs out. After getting a set number of questions right
column2: the player will be rated on their performance and will be shown how the girls popularity is advancing within certain demographics.

column1: At each new stage the player gets to pick the genre from which the music selections will be pooled from and also gets to see the selected girl in a new costume. In the first stage the girl is scouted in her school uniform
column2: the second stage involves a swimsuit audition
column3: and later stage costumes are decided by the genre of music selected for that stage.

column1: At certain stages in the game
column2: the player is treated to a mini-game instead of the usual trivia.  Stage three is a dance stage
column3: where the player is shown a combination of joystick and button moves and must then repeat them from memory.  Stage six is a photo shoot stage
column4: where the player must attempt to frame the girl in a series of photos as the camera quickly shifts around. And Stage eight requires the player to shake off nosy tabloid paparazzi.

column1: Each mistake in the trivia or mini games leads to a lost life.  The game is over once a player looses all their lives."
1940;kirarast;kirarast;"Ryuusei Janshi Kirara Star (c) 1996 Jaleco.

;Ryuusei Janshi Kirara Star is a strip mahjong game with a space-anime theme and very extensive animation. The game features three girls with two strip sequences each. The game allows the player to select the first opponent
column2: but following opponents are played in sequence.

column1: As a unique feature
column2: not every winning hand played by the player will lead to a strip sequence. Lesser winning hands will instead add time to a quiz game that can be played between hands. The game will display how many seconds of playtime the player has earned for the quiz game and the player can select whether to attempt the quiz sequence
column3: or skip ahead to the next hand and earn a longer time limit.

column1: Correct answers given during the quiz game will remove panels placed over the girls image. If the player removes all of the panels before the timer runs out then the next strip sequence will be revealed. Failing this
column2: if the player correctly answered any questions during the quiz sequence they will be awarded a cheat item for use in the next hand.

column1: The game is over when a player runs out of betting funds."
1941;kittenk;kittenk;"Kitten Kaboodle (c) 1988 Konami.
;Export release. Game developed in Japan. See The original Japanese release entry
column2: ""Nyan Nyan Panic""
column3: for more information about the game itself."

column1: 1942;kiwame;kiwame;"Pro Mahjong Kiwame (c) 1994 Athena.
;(Fu'un - Super Tag Battle)
2-on-2 tag team battle with 10 selectable characters with huge sprites to challenge King Leo and the powerful shaman Jyazu. Very fast-paced and fun!"
1945;klax;klax;"Klax (c) 1989 Atari Games.
;The tiles klank end over end down the ramp. Catch them on the paddle
column2: or they fall in the pit. Flip them from the paddle into the bins
column3: matching the same-colored tiles horizontally
column4: vertically
column5: or diagonally. Each line of colored tiles is a Klax. When you've made a Klax
column6: you hear a fanfare. When you complete a wave
column7: the crowd cheers. Let a tile fall in the pit
column8: and you hear a scream as it falls in. If you fail to complete a wave
column9: the crowd is disappointed. Stay alive
column10: complete the waves and don't drop any tiles!

column1: Catch the tiles as they come to the end of the ramp on the paddle. Flip a tile into a bin by pressing the start/flip button. Pull the joystick forward to increase the speed of the closest tile as it klanks down the ramp. Push the joystick back and toss the top tile on the paddle back on the ramp and gain a little time.
The paddle can hold up to five tiles. As long as the green light is on below the paddle
column2: you can pile more tiles on the paddle. When the red light appears
column3: you must flip at least one tile in a bin or toss it back on the ramp before you can collect any more tiles. You can flip tiles into a bin as long as the green light is on below the bin.

column1: To succeed in Klax
column2: make points and also complete each wave. Create a horizontal
column3: vertical
column4: or diagonal row of at least three tiles (just like in tic-tac-toe) in the bins to make a Klax and make points. You receive the most points for diagonals
column5: less for horizontals and the least for verticals. When you create a Klax
column6: the tiles in the Klax disappear to make room for more tiles in the bins.

column1: Each wave has a different task to be completed
column2: which is shown on the To Go Meter. This task could be making a certain number of Klaxes or points or surviving a certain number of tiles. Complete the task before too many tiles drop in the pit and you complete the wave. When you complete a wave
column3: you receive bonus points for the tiles remaining on the ramp
column4: on the paddle
column5: and any empty spaces in the bins. If you fail
column6: you can start again at the same wave.

column1: Klax does not have a clock for you to race against
column2: but as your playing time increases
column3: the tiles klank down the ramp faster and faster.

column1: Waves : When you first enter the game
column2: you can start at wave 1
column4: or 11. Wave 1 teaches you how to play the game and use the controls. At every fifth wave you can choose to play the next wave
column5: the fifth wave beyond
column6: or the tenth wave beyond.

column1: Klax has five different types of waves and more than five different backgrounds. There are five waves per level
column2: and one hundred waves to complete.

column1: Each time you begin a wave
column2: the To Go meter shows what kind of Klaxes or how many points you need to accumulate to complete the wave. The different types of waves are :

column1: * Klaxes To Go
column2: which are the easiest. Just create Klaxes horizontally
column3: vertically or horizontally. Create enough Klaxes to complete the wave before you drop too many tiles in the pit.

column1: * Tiles To Go requires you to survive a certain number of tiles. Create Klaxes in any of the three ways to collect points and to clear the bins to hold more tiles.
* Points To Go requires you to make a certain number of points. Create Klaxes to collect points but make diagonals
column2: four- or five-of-a-kind Klaxes
column3: and simultaneous Klaxes for higher points.

column1: * Diagonals To Go requires you to create diagonals. Create Klaxes in any way to collect points; but only the correct number of diagonals will complete the wave.
* Horizontals To Go requires you to create horizontals. Only horizontal Klaxes will complete the wave; but you can create Klaxes vertically and diagonally to collect points.
You see several kinds of information on the screen. These are the :
* To Go Meter which continuously calculates the number of Klaxes
column2: tiles
column3: points
column4: diagonals or horizontals still required to complete the wave. The number depends on the type of wave you are playing.

column1: * Drop Count
column2: which shows the number of dropped tiles. The drop count is continuously calculated. When the number of tiles dropped is reached
column3: the wave is over.

column1: * High Score
column2: which shows the highest score to date
column3: regardless of the number of continues that player had.

column1: * Wave Indicator
column2: which shows what wave you are playing."

The paddle can hold up to five tiles. As long as the green light is on below the paddle
column2: you can pile more tiles on the paddle. When the red light appears
column3: you must flip at least one tile in a bin or toss it back on the ramp before you can collect any more tiles. You can flip tiles into a bin as long as the green light is on below the bin.

column1: To succeed in Klax
column2: make points and also complete each wave. Create a horizontal
column3: vertical
column4: or diagonal row of at least three tiles (just like in tic-tac-toe) in the bins to make a Klax and make points. You receive the most points for diagonals
column5: less for horizontals and the least for verticals. When you create a Klax
column6: the tiles in the Klax disappear to make room for more tiles in the bins.

column1: Each wave has a different task to be completed
column2: which is shown on the To Go Meter. This task could be making a certain number of Klaxes or points or surviving a certain number of tiles. Complete the task before too many tiles drop in the pit and you complete the wave. When you complete a wave
column3: you receive bonus points for the tiles remaining on the ramp
column4: on the paddle
column5: and any empty spaces in the bins. If you fail
column6: you can start again at the same wave.

column1: Klax does not have a clock for you to race against
column2: but as your playing time increases
column3: the tiles klank down the ramp faster and faster.

column1: Waves : When you first enter the game
column2: you can start at wave 1
column4: or 11. Wave 1 teaches you how to play the game and use the controls. At every fifth wave you can choose to play the next wave
column5: the fifth wave beyond
column6: or the tenth wave beyond.

column1: Klax has five different types of waves and more than five different backgrounds. There are five waves per level
column2: and one hundred waves to complete.

column1: Each time you begin a wave
column2: the To Go meter shows what kind of Klaxes or how many points you need to accumulate to complete the wave. The different types of waves are :

column1: * Klaxes To Go
column2: which are the easiest. Just create Klaxes horizontally
column3: vertically or horizontally. Create enough Klaxes to complete the wave before you drop too many tiles in the pit.

column1: * Tiles To Go requires you to survive a certain number of tiles. Create Klaxes in any of the three ways to collect points and to clear the bins to hold more tiles.
* Points To Go requires you to make a certain number of points. Create Klaxes to collect points but make diagonals
column2: four- or five-of-a-kind Klaxes
column3: and simultaneous Klaxes for higher points.

column1: * Diagonals To Go requires you to create diagonals. Create Klaxes in any way to collect points; but only the correct number of diagonals will complete the wave.
* Horizontals To Go requires you to create horizontals. Only horizontal Klaxes will complete the wave; but you can create Klaxes vertically and diagonally to collect points.
You see several kinds of information on the screen. These are the :
* To Go Meter which continuously calculates the number of Klaxes
column2: tiles
column3: points
column4: diagonals or horizontals still required to complete the wave. The number depends on the type of wave you are playing.

column1: * Drop Count
column2: which shows the number of dropped tiles. The drop count is continuously calculated. When the number of tiles dropped is reached
column3: the wave is over.

column1: * High Score
column2: which shows the highest score to date
column3: regardless of the number of continues that player had.

column1: * Wave Indicator
column2: which shows what wave you are playing."

2002;krull;krull;Krull (c) 1983 Gottlieb.
;The left joystick controls the movement of the player character
column2: Colwyn. He can be moved in any one of eight directions. The right joystick controls the movement of the player's weapon
column3: the glaive. It can be thrown in any one of eight directions. Four glaives can be in flight at one time and will return to Colwyn with a boomerang-type action. The one and two player select buttons are also located on the panel.

column1: Krull consists of five subgames :
1. The Mountain Game.
2. The Swamp Game.
3. The Fortress Game.
4. The Hexagon Game.
5. The Beast Game.

The player must accomplish a task in each of the five games with eight levels of difficulty in each. All eight levels can be reached in one task based on the time spent performing that task (amount of time spent on that subgame). The total number of lethal characters on the screen at one time increases as the levels increase.
FROM THE SKY WILL COME THE BLACK FORTRESS. FROM THE FORTRESS WILL COME THE SLAYERS
column2: TO DEVOUR THE PLANET OF KRULL. THEN SHALL A GIRL OF ANCIENT NAME BECOME QUEEN
column3: AND THE KING SHE CHOOSES SHALL RULE THE PLANET.

column1: The planet Krull is threatened by the Beast. His army of Slayers has brought terror to the land. Colwyn must stop this terror and save the land and its people. On the day Colwyn is to wed the Princess Lyssa
column2: the Slayers
column3: army of the Beast
column4: kidnap her to become the Beast's bride. Colwyn must reach the Black Fortress and reclaim his Princess. He who marries the Princess shall be king. The Beast must not be allowed to rule the planet.

column1: A prophet acquaints Colwyn with the magical properties of the glaive
column2: a five-bladed sword
column3: which Colwyn must acquire. To accomplish this task
column4: he must climb the mountain and collect the five individual blades of the glaive in order to assemble the weapon. The blade is picked up by touching Colwyn to the blade. Boulders are fatal and must be avoided. The weapon joystick is not utilized in this subgame. The player is awarded 1
column5: 000 points for each blade picked up. Points are also awarded for placing Colwyn in a dangerous position in front of one or more boulders.

column1: During his travels to discover the Black Fortress
column2: Colwyn comes upon an army of eight men that he befriends and recruits to help him in his quest to destroy the Beast so that Krull can be safe from his evil.

column1: With no intentions of losing his newly acquired bride without bloodshed
column2: the Beast orders an army of Slayers to stop Colwyn and his friends. Forging through the quicksand-riddled swamps
column3: Slayers materialize from the soil and Colwyn prepares for battle. In the second subgame
column4: Colwyn must save as many friends as possible while killing all of the Slayers. The friends are saved by touching them and the Slayers are destroyed by the glaive. The Slayers themselves and their spears must be avoided. The game begins with eight friends. The number of friends saved is the number of friends carried over into future subgames. The friends can eliminate the Slayers with hand-to-hand combat but can also be destroyed themselves. Receiving three blows either by hand-to-hand or by the Slayers spear is fatal to the friends. The subgame ends when there are no longer any friends to save and all of the Slayers have been eliminated. Avoid quicksand
column5: as it slows Colwyn's attack. Each friend saved awards 1
column6: 000 points (maximum 8
column7: 000 points) and 100 points for each Slayer the player eliminates.

column1: After days of travel
column2: Colwyn and his men have found the Black Fortress in the Iron Desert where many dangers await them. While attempting to lead his men through the dangerous narrow passageways that lead to the Fortress
column3: Slayers materialize once again in a second attempt to stop Colwyn's struggle. In this third subgame
column4: Colwyn must pick up all of his friends and deposit them safely into the hexagon while again combating the Slayers. The total number of friends in this subgame is equal to the total number of friends saved in Subgame 2. This subgame concludes when all of the friends have been delivered to the hexagon. The player is awarded 1
column5: 000 points for each friend delivered to the hexagon
column6: 100 points for each Slayer he destroys and 100 points for each Slayer remaining when the last friend is delivered to the hexagon.

column1: Victorious in battle
column2: Colwyn must now attempt to release his friends from the hexagon. Unlike entry
column3: exiting the hexagon is a struggle deservant of its own merit. Once again Colwyn must call upon the power of the glaive. Release of his friends is accomplished by throwing the glaive at the front wall while it is black only. Any glaive striking the wall while it is not black will stick in the wall until the wall becomes black. The Slayers
column4: of course
column5: attempt to stop Colwyn's efforts. In his own attempt for survival
column6: Colwyn must fight them off and avoid their spears. The subgame ends when the last black wall is broken through and the friends have escaped. The player is awarded 100 points for each Slayer he puts an end to
column7: 100 points for each Slayer remaining when the friends are set free and 1
column8: 000 points for the first black wall destroyed
column10: 000 points for the second
column12: 000 points for the third and 4
column13: 000 points for the fourth.

column1: Now inside the Black Fortress
column2: Colwyn secedes from his friends in order to rescue the Princess Lyssa. He finds her in a large cave carefully guarded by the Beast. He knows that the only way to reclaim his bride and conserve the planet is to forge into battle with the Beast. In the fifth subgame
column3: the player moves Colwyn towards the Princess in order to reach her. As he progresses
column4: the Beast attempts to stop him by throwing fireballs at him. The fireballs must be avoided or destroyed by the glaive. If not destroyed
column5: the fireballs will ricochet off of the walls. Destroying a fireball awards the player 100 points multiplied by the number of fireballs in flight. The Beast is momentarily stunned when hit with a glaive and awards the player 100 points. The Beast cannot be destroyed and the player must avoid touching him. When Colwyn reaches the Princess
column6: his friends
column7: following the pandemonium of the battle
column8: appear and chase the Beast off
column9: awarding 1000 points per friend. The total number of friends in this subgame is equal to the total number of friends saved in Subgame 2."

column1: - TRIVIA -
Kung-Fu Master was released in December 1984 outside Japan. Originally known in Japan as as ""Spartan X"".

Licensed to Data East for US manufacture and distribution. Kung-Fu Master was the first game that Irem licensed to Data East and was also the first of two genre-defining fighting games released by Data East that year; the other being 'Karate Champ'
column2: the world's first one-on-one fighting game.

column1: A bootleg of this game was released by O.K. corp. in 1985.
Mike Sullivan holds the official record for this game with 1
column3: 040 points.

column1: - TRIVIA -
Kung-Fu Master was released in December 1984 outside Japan. Originally known in Japan as as ""Spartan X"".

Licensed to Data East for US manufacture and distribution. Kung-Fu Master was the first game that Irem licensed to Data East and was also the first of two genre-defining fighting games released by Data East that year; the other being 'Karate Champ'
column2: the world's first one-on-one fighting game.

column1: A bootleg of this game was released by O.K. corp. in 1985.
Mike Sullivan holds the official record for this game with 1
column3: 040 points.

2012;kuniokub;kuniokunb;Nekketsu Kouha Kunio-Kun (c) 1986 Technos.
;The original side-scrolling beat-em-up from Technos. Kunio
column2: a tough guy from Nekketsu High School
column3: stands up for his bullied friend Hiroshi against the numerous gangs that are tormenting his life. Each stage begins with one of the gang's members beating up Hiroshi
column4: followed Kunio chasing after the attackers.

column1: The game uses a 2-way attacking
column2: in which one button attacks to the character's left and the other to his right. Techniques includes a basic punch combo
column3: a back kick
column4: a collar grab and even a jump kick. The player can also run by pushing the joystick left or right twice.

column1: The game is comprised of 4 stages
column2: each with their unique set of enemy characters:

column1: Stage 1 - Set on a train platform. The enemies are a gang of students from the neighboring school of Hanazono. Some of the enemies are armed with sticks. Their boss is Riki
column2: Kunio's rival.

column1: Stage 2 - Set on a harbor in Yokozuka. The enemies are a gang of bikers called the Yokohama Funky. The first wave of enemies will attempt to run Kunio down with their bikes. After knocking down all the bikers
column2: the enemies on the sidelines will enter the playing field to attack the player. Their boss is Shinji.

column1: Stage 3 - Set in a dark alley
column2: the enemies are a gang of girl students from the Taiyou Academy. The boss is Misuzu
column3: a giant lady.

column1: Stage 4 - The first half of the stage is set in a parking lot
column2: where a group of four hitmen working for the Sanwa Club will attack Kunio with their knives. Unlike other enemies
column3: they can kill the player off with one hit. After defeating the four hitmen
column4: the player will enter the Sanwa building where he will encounter three more hitmen and their boss
column5: Sabu."

;In Lady Bug you guide a lady bug through a Pac-Man style maze, eating dots, and avoiding enemy insects. You lose a life if you run into a skull or get eaten by an enemy insect. ;Lady killer is an adult
column2: puzzle game featuring eight sexy women.  The objective of the game is to dive and leap through the surface of the play area to reveal the image of the girl underneath.

column1: At the start of each level the player gets to select which girl he wants to reveal.  Her image is then shown and is then covered by the game board.  Then the level begins. The player must move to avoid the enemies while attempting to flip the tiles on the board by diving and surfacing through them.  Flipped tiles often reveal power-ups to help the player. The player is killed any time he touches or is shot by an enemy
column2: but the player can kill enemies by flipping a tile that the enemy is standing on. Enemies will re-spawn until the level is completed. The level is completed once all of the tiles have been removed.

column1: Each girl features five states of undress and four stages. During gameplay
column2: the girl's silhouette remains visible through the surface of the game play area and while her state of dress changes between stages
column3: her pose and silhouette will remain the same. Each girl also has a special stage featuring a mini-game of a sliding tile game or a number selecting game. After completing the final stage for each girl
column4: the player is shown an erotic scene for that girl and the player must wiggle the joystick left and right to advance the scene.

column1: The game is over when the player has lost all of his lives.  Upon continuing the player restarts the level he is currently on."

column1: ;Taking place in the year 2012 in an alternate galaxy
column2: Last Duel involves the struggle between two planets Mu and Bacula. On planet Bacula
column3: a strong warrior tribe known as the Galden rose to immense military power and conquered all of the societies on the planet. Unsatisfied with conquering just one planet
column4: the Galden decided to conquer a neighboring terrestrial planet
column5: Mu. Using advanced bioships
column6: star fighters
column7: and motor vehicles
column8: the Galden invaded Mu
column9: destroying many of its cities and taking the planet's ruler Queen Sheeta hostage. The remaining royal guards of Mu are deployed in space fighters that can transform into cars to rescue the queen and crush the Galden forces.

column1: The player alternates each level between using car and space ship. The vehicle has two main attacks one of which varies depending on the form the vehicle took. In car mode
column2: the vehicle can jump over pot holes and enemies. While in ship mode
column3: the vehicle can perform a barrel roll
column4: making it temporarily invincible.

column1: The player can select Power-Ups that including a large
column2: slow firing laser
column3: a twin-shot
column4: a wide shot and options that provided side attacks. Speed-Ups were only available in ship mode. Every driving section is timed and if the player is unable to reach the boss on time
column5: they will lose a life. However
column6: the moment the player encounters the boss
column7: the timer will be removed."

2048;lazercmd;lazercmd;"Lazer Command (c) 1976 Meadows Games.

;You have an overhead view of a maze with two sides, the sides mirror each other. The left side of the screen is yellow, and the right side is green. On each side are fifteen tanks. The object is to blow up all of the opposing players tanks (or as many as you can before the timer runs out). You can only control one tank at a time, you can move them around and blast your opponents tanks (getting the active one is usually a good idea). When you get blasted, your tank vanishes, and you must move a little blip over to another tank to resume play (this blip is invisible unless it is against a wall). You can also leave your tank and head for another one by pressing the second button. This is just a great strategic title, it holds up even today. It is really worth playing if you like that sort of thing. Just be aware that this is a two player only title, so you will need a friend to play against.
2049;lbowling;lbowling;League Bowling (c) 1990 SNK [Shin Nihon Kikaku].
;A colourful and playable ten-pin bowling game for 1 to 4 players
column2: offering a choice of three scoring methods : 'Regulation'
column3: 'Flash' and 'Strike 90'.

column1: The game begins with players selecting either a right or left-handed bowler
column2: before choosing what weight they want their bowling balls to be. Once the match starts properly
column3: Power and Direction meters will appear and players must use both their judgement and timing to select and execute the desired bowl. Timing is key as players are only allowed twenty seconds to make each shot.

column1: The 'Strike 90' mode awards players ninety points for a strike and sixty points for a spare. In the 'Flash' game mode
column2: the points flash across the lane as the players throw the ball. Should they succeed in knocking down the standing pins
column3: the points that are displayed at the time the pins are struck will be added to the players' scores."

2068;lemnangl;lemnangl;Mahjong Lemon Angel (c) 1990 Home Data.
;Mahjong Lemon Angel is a strip mahjong game based on the late-night TV
column2: adult anime ""Lemon Angel.""  The game features the three main characters from the series
column3: Shima Erika (17)
column4: Emoto Miki(17)
column5: and Sakurai Tomo (16) with each girl appearing in one introductory sequence and five strip sequences apiece.

column1: At the start of the game the player has the option to start with 10
column2: 000 betting points for one credit or 30
column3: 000 for two credits.  After making this choice
column4: the player gets to select the first opponent.  After every winning hand

column6: the player advances to the next girl.  Game play continues until all strip sequences have been revealed or the player runs out of betting funds."

column1: 2069;leprechn;leprechn;"Leprechaun (c) 1982 Tong Electronic.

;The player controls a sleuth running through a forest, trying to get a Leprechaun's pot of gold. The pot of gold is randomly placed on the screen. When the pot of gold is touched, the player is taken to the next level. The Leprechaun chases the sleuth through the forest, trying to catch him. If he is caught, the player loses a life and starts over from the beginning of the level. After all lives are lost, the game ends. Should the Leprechaun reach the pot of gold first, it is then relocated to another forest. By touching the trees, the player's score increases, as does the value of the pot of gold. After each level and after every 30 seconds the Leprechaun's speed increases.

column1: 2075;liberat2;liberatr2;"Liberator (c) 1982 Atari.
;The Liberator controls consist of a trackball
column2: fire button
column3: and shield button. The player controls a coordinated attack from four star ships at the corners of the screen. The primary target of the attack are enemy bases on a rotating planet in the center of the screen. The trackball is used to move a cross-shaped cursor. The fire button fires a missile at the cursor's location from your closest ship. The shield button is used to activate force fields around the ships. The shield can only take four hits each round
column4: and the count is shared between all ships.

column1: At the beginning of each level
column2: the player is flying through outer space and spaceships fly on screen from the left and right and leave in an arc. They try to ram into your ships. Note that shields do not work during this stage.

column1: After this stage
column2: the player is taken to a view of a rotating planet. The most prominent enemies are red flashing missile bases. They shoot missiles
column3: fireballs
column4: and star balls at your ships. The enemy bases can also detach from the planet
column5: turn into satellites
column6: and orbit the planet while shooting missiles. Once all missile bases are destroyed
column7: the player moves onto the next level. At higher levels
column8: there is the white master base. It is very intelligent
column9: and it can change the direction or speed of the planet rotation to avoid getting hit."
