column1: 2079;liblrabl;liblrabl;"Libble Rabble (c) 1983 Namco.
;At first glance
column2: the gameplay resembles Taito's Qix. The player controls two ""arrows""
column3: one red (Libble) and one blue (Rabble) with a line strung between them. The object is to wrap the line around poles and surround Mushlins and enemies with it. The player can either close the loops themselves (worth more points for the Mushlins) or move both arrows to the same edge of the screen. The player clears a ""season"" when he or she harvests all the Mushlins.

column1: Along the way
column2: various enemies will appear and try to stop the player. The most common are four little hooded critters (Hobblins)
column3: which start each season in the corners. If the player catches them in a loop
column4: they will be sent to the top of the screen for a short period of time. Other critters such as fireballs (Killers)
column5: sparks (Changers)
column6: and Demons will also appear. These can be killed by closing a loop around them. Sometimes
column7: scissors-like enemies (Shears) appear
column8: and if they cross the player's line
column9: they cut it. If the player's line is ever cut by Shears or Demons
column10: a new one is instantly made: directly between the two arrows.

column1: Every so often when the player closes a line
column2: a detector goes off indicating that the area that has been closed off has a treasure chest somewhere. To actually uncover the chest
column3: the player must surround a small enough area which covers just the chest
column4: and no other possible hiding places. The game guides the player along that step
column5: first by challenging them to uncover a chest at the start of the game (and then by revealing the locations of the chests for the first two seasons). When the player actually uncovers a chest
column6: six bonus creatures (Topcups) will pop out
column7: then make for the edges. The player must corral them with the line and then close the loop to score the bonus for them: they mean bonus letters. If the player manages to complete a bonus word
column8: the season is automatically cleared out and the player moves to a bonus stage where they must try to uncover and collect chests (to collect a chest
column9: the player needs to close a loop around an opened chest) within a time limit.

column1: The player loses a life if any of the assorted critters touch one of the arrows or if he or she runs out of time (the border is the player's timer
column2: and he or she can boost the time by looping Mushlins and plants)
column3: and the player gains an extra life at 40
column12: 000 and 1
column14: 000 points by default. After the 100th season
column15: the season counter will stop at 99
column16: similar to how Namco's Galaxian and King & Balloon's round indicators would stop after 48 rounds."

column1: 2085;lizwiz;lizwiz;"Lizard Wizard (c) 1985 Techstar.

;The player must use an eight-way joystick to take control of the Lizard Wizard, whose mission is to help free the people who are caught within the planet Zyfus. The Lizard Wizard does this by shooting the rocks that fly out of that erupting volcano at the bottom of the screen which will burst into flames if he misses them and get eaten by the dragon-like lizards for their fire. As the prisoners emerge from the volcano, the Lizard Wizard must also rescue them from the planet by taking them to the platforms on the surface. The player must also face Spydors on certain levels, which must be killed before they reach the surface.

column4: was terrifying people all over the country. One day the princess 'Kiri'
column5: a daughter of the lord
column6: was kidnapped by the Corps. In order to save her from them
column7: a number of militia were sent to the Corps' Headquarters
column8: but none of them ever returned. Then one young man headed for the Corps' Headquarters to save the princess. His name 'Kage'
column9: a ninja from Iga Village."

column1: 2090;llander;llander;"Lunar Lander (c) 1979 Atari.
;Lunar Lander is a 1-player coin-op electronic game that simulates landing a manned spaceship on the moon. Various video-display phrases indicate score
column2: time elapsed during this landing mission
column3: fuel units consumed
column4: altitude above the moon
column5: and horizontal and vertical speed. The fuel consumption and both speed readings are important for the player to determine how to land the craft. Realistic engine rumble and crash sounds accompany game play. A high beep warns of an almost-depleted fuel supply
column6: whereupon players can add coins to automatically extend the game and 'fill up' their fuel tanks. Depending on the quality of the landing or the crash
column7: various messages are displayed on the screen.

column1: Game play begins with engine rumble and the lander drifting towards the bottom
right corner of the screen. Horizontal and vertical speeds are constantly displayed
column2: including two arrows to show horizontal and vertical directions of travel. Altitude is measured in distance above the surface of the mountain - not above 'sea level'. The screen also shows time in actual seconds
column3: representing time elapsed in the current mission.

column1: The operator can select from four different settings for fuel units - 450
column3: 750 or 900 fuel units per coin (free play is also available). As the lander module flies over the landscape
column4: it approaches the mountains and a landing site. At a certain point near the mountains
column5: the game 'zooms in' for a close-up view of everything on the screen.

column1: If the player realizes the speed is too fast and the landing looks hopeless
column2: he or she can press the ABORT button on the control panel. This will give the lander extra thrust and make it fly upwards at top speed. The abort feature does consume 120 to 180 fuel units
column3: though
column4: as a disincentive to overusing it. If the ABORT button is pressed too late
column5: however
column6: a crash cannot be avoided.

column1: The four levels of mission difficulty are determined by the player and can be changed at any time during the game or the ready-to-play mode. The differences between the four are printed on the mission select panels and are self explanatory
column2: except perhaps rotational momentum. This feature causes the lander to tumble around when either ROTATE button is pushed. The longer either button is held down
column3: the faster the lander module will spin in that direction. The player gains control of the lander by pressing the other ROTATE button for the same amount of time."

;As the player begins his flight into Adventure-Land

;An evil wizard is causing terror in a faraway land. Only you, a brave legendary warrior has the strength and courage to face him and his powerful demons in order to restore peace. Features colourful graphics, a cool soundtrack and excellent 'hack & slash' action. Fans of fantasy action games will love it! :)
2107;losttmbh;losttombh;Lost Tomb (c) 1982 Stern Electronics.
;A shoot-em-up set in an ancient
column2: South American pyramid
column3: in which the player must explore a large number of single rooms in the search for treasure. Each room is filled with enemy creatures that must be killed or avoided. The player is equipped with a limited amount of whips and must collect as many items of treasure as possible.

column1: The player is presented with options throughout the game
column2: depending upon which rooms they wish to enter. Once a path is chosen
column3: players must pick up treasures
column4: kill all the monsters in their way
column5: find the key and exit the room as fast as they can; avoiding the potential of setting off an earthquake. Upon exiting a level
column6: the player is presented with a hallway which shows a number of doorways allowing access to any one of several different rooms. This allows players to pick their own route through the game
column7: but the decision which room to tackle next must be taken quickly as players must reach their chosen room quickly or risk being attacked by a flock of screeching birds.

column1: The player's character is armed with an eight-way firing gun (in a similar fashion to Williams' 1982 classic
column2: ""Robotron""). In addition to the gun
column3: the player is also equipped with three whips
column4: which can be used to either kill attacking creatures or to knock down any walls that bar the player's progress. Players are given the opportunity to purchase additional whips at the interludes between levels; this is done by inserting an extra credit into the arcade machine and pressing the relevant button.

column1: Treasure must be constantly collected in order to stay alive."

;Two jet-pack wearing marines must battle a powerful enemy force that has seized and inhabited their home planet - now known as 'Dust World' - and restore the planet to its former name of 'Earth'.
Lost Worlds' gameplay features multi-directional shooting
column2: with the Marines being able to rotate through 360 degrees
column3: allowing players to fire in any direction. When killed
column4: enemies drop 'Zenny Coins' which can be used to upgrade weapons and player health at the shops that appear at the halfway point of each level. Forgotten Worlds features superb graphics and ingenious enemy design
column5: and was converted to many different home formats."

column1: 2110;lotlot;lotlot;"Lot Lot (c) 1985 Irem Corp.

;In Lot Lot, you directly control one arrow and indirectly control another which follows after your original arrow with a (roughly) 4-second delay. When you press the button, any balls on the compartment that one arrow points to are immediately swapped with the contents of the compartment that the other arrow points to. The goal of Lot Lot is to get as many tiny balls (which resemble Pachinko balls) out of grid compartments and down into point slots in order to achieve a designated score, and advance to the next round.
2111;lottofun;lottofun;Lotto Fun (c) 1987 H.A.R. Management.

;Lotto Fun is a 'ping pong balls in a blower' type lottery game.
2112;lrescue;lrescue;Lunar Rescue (c) 1979 Taito.

;Lunar Rescue is a combination 2-D simple flight simulator and 2-Dimensional shooter. You start the game by floating within your mother ship. You then either must release your lander or after a pre-determined period of time, the mother ship will forcibly eject it. You first have to navigate through six rows of asteroids to make it to one of the landing platforms. You have six platforms initially but each landing will eliminate one since there is one platform per astronaut you have to rescue. On your return trip up, the screen changes and now you have saucers trying to destroy you with laser fire. Again, you will either have three or six rows of saucers depending if there are meteors in the area. You then must successfully land in the docking bay of the mother ship to get credit for a successful rescue of one astronaut.

column1: ;Taking place in the year 2012 in an alternate galaxy
column2: Last Duel involves the struggle between two planets Mu and Bacula. On planet Bacula
column3: a strong warrior tribe known as the Galden rose to immense military power and conquered all of the societies on the planet. Unsatisfied with conquering just one planet
column4: the Galden decided to conquer a neighboring terrestrial planet
column5: Mu. Using advanced bioships
column6: star fighters
column7: and motor vehicles
column8: the Galden invaded Mu
column9: destroying many of its cities and taking the planet's ruler Queen Sheeta hostage. The remaining royal guards of Mu are deployed in space fighters that can transform into cars to rescue the queen and crush the Galden forces.

column1: The player alternates each level between using car and space ship. The vehicle has two main attacks one of which varies depending on the form the vehicle took. In car mode
column2: the vehicle can jump over pot holes and enemies. While in ship mode
column3: the vehicle can perform a barrel roll
column4: making it temporarily invincible.

column1: The player can select Power-Ups that including a large
column2: slow firing laser
column3: a twin-shot
column4: a wide shot and options that provided side attacks. Speed-Ups were only available in ship mode. Every driving section is timed and if the player is unable to reach the boss on time
column5: they will lose a life. However
column6: the moment the player encounters the boss
column7: the timer will be removed."

2152;maglord;maglord;Magician Lord (c) 1990 Alpha Denshi Company
column2: Limited.

column1: ;Magician Lord is a side-scrolling platform shoot-em-up in which players take on the roll of a wizard called Elta - the last Magician Lord - on his quest to save his homeland from the evil Gul-Agieze
column2: who plans to resurrect the God of Destruction using 8 tomes of mystical power.

column1: Elta has to jump
column2: shoot and climb his way to the end of each of the game's 8 levels where he must beat a servant of Gal
column3: along with one of Gal's sinister boss creations. To complete the game Elta must reach the final stage and defeat Az Atorse himself. If the player takes too long to complete a stage
column4: Elta will be harassed by an invincible monster.

column1: Elta's primary form of attack is a weak but fast-moving energy projectile that can fired in one of four directions
column2: but by collecting the special coloured orbs that ocassionally appear
column3: he can transform into a different form
column4: making him more powerful and giving him new attacks.

column1: These are the six different forms that Elta can assume by picking up the colored orbs:
* Dragon Warrior: In this form Elta attacks by breathing fire; a continuous short-range attack that
column2: unlike the standad attack
column3: can also be aimed diagonally.

column1: * Waterman: The Waterman-form attacks with water grenades – blue bubbles of water that burst upon touching the ground and form into water pillars. The attack can hit several times for additional damage but only covers a small area.
* Poseidon: A more powerful version of the Waterman
column2: Poseidon shoots wide waves of water that travel along the ground for several hits. It does severe damage and causes enemies to freeze and shatter on impact. While very powerful
column3: this form moves very slowly.

column1: * Shinobi: The Shinobi-form gains increased agility and attacks with powerful magical arcs of fire which are wide but slow-moving.
* Samurai: While limited in range
column2: the Samurai-form is the only form that can attack through walls
column3: shields or even multiple enemies
column4: using a boomerang-like energy attack that does heavy damage.

column1: * Raijin: The Raijin-form gives Elta's jumping ability a big boost as well as a unique attack that creates a continuous electrical field around his body."

2154;magmax;magmax;"Mag Max (c) 1985 Nichibutsu.

;Mag Max is a horizontally scrolling shoot-em-up in which a single player takes control of the 'Maxcraft' hover-ship and must battle their way through an packed enemy installation to find and destroy the invading alien 'Dragonia' fleet.
The action takes place both above and below ground and transporters appear throughout the game that allows the Maxcraft warp between the two as players search for the three-headed 'Dragonship'.
At various points the player will come across robot components - either a torso
column2: a pair of legs or a plasma gun - and collecting these will eventually see the player's hover-ship become a towering robot
column3: vastly increasing its firepower in the process.

column1: If the Maxcraft takes an enemy hit when additional components are attached
column2: a component is lost. If the ship is hit when only in basic form
column3: however
column4: a life is lost."

- TRIVIA -
The official Italian distributor of Atari Arcades
column2: f.lli Bertolino s.r.l.
column3: moved a legal attack against Sidam
column4: and won. Many code fragments stored in ROM of ""Asterock""
column5: Missile Storm and other Sidam clones was identical to those contained in Atari originals' memory. Sidam changed the coin accept and sound routines
column6: to get rid of copyrighted Atari POKEY chip. Sidam called this a 'coincidence'; moreover
column7: the Italian legislation did not mention directly the computer programs as copyrighted materials like songs and books. However
column8: the court sentenced about the 'intellectual property' of programs - this was an important sentence in Italian legal history - and Sidam was convicted of copyright violation."

2167;majest12;majest12j;Majestic Twelve - The Space Invaders Part IV (c) 1990 Taito Corp.
;The third sequel to Taito's seminal ""Space Invaders""
column2: Majestic Twelve leaves the classic Invaders game-play intact
column3: but adds a slew of new alien invaders and power-ups to the mix. This
column4: together with the vastly improved graphics that introduce colorful new backdrops - some of which scroll vertically in a similar fashion to the star-field in Namco's ""Galaxian"" - ensure that Majestic 12 is a worthy sequel to the legendary original.

column1: The original game's flying saucer still makes an appearance
column2: but instead of merely awarding bonus points when shot - as in the original game - it now drops a power-up pod for the player to retrieve. Power-ups include shield
column3: faster shots
column4: a laser (activated with the second button) and a giant butterfly
column5: which freezes the invaders for a limited time.

column1: One of the game's most memorable features was the 'Cattle Mutilation' bonus screen
column2: in which the player must protect a heard of cattle from a number of fast-moving saucers
column3: intent on stealing the animals. If a cow is snatched; the player must shoot the relevant saucer to free it; being careful not to actually shoot the cow itself. The '91 incarnation also introduced 'bosses' to the series for the first time; giant
column4: screen-filling aliens that required several shots to kill.

column1: Another major difference to the previous games in the series is that if an invader reaches the bottom of the screen
column2: the player will simply lose a ship (in the original
column3: the game would end once an alien had landed). Also
column4: the player's ship now comes equipped with a shield that can withstand several hits. The shield's strength is depleted every time it takes a direct hit from one of the invaders
column5: and too many hits will result in the shield disappearing altogether. A direct hit on an un-shielded ship will result in the loss of a player life."

The player takes on the role of Sir Arthur the knight

column1: Arthur must run and jump through six horizontal and 8-way scrolling levels in his bid to rescue the kidnapped princess. Arthur is initially armed with throwable lances

column4: flaming torches

column6: bats
column7: demons and other assorted satanic minions that Sir Arthur has to face.

column1: Each of the six end-of-level gates is guarded by one of Satan's generals; huge
column2: end-of-level guardians who must be defeated before the player can finally reach the Goblin King and rescue the princess."

column1: 2176;maketrax;maketrax;"Make Trax (c) 1981 Williams Electronics
column2: Incorporated.

column1: ;- TRIVIA -
This is the U.S. version of ""Crush Roller""
column2: released in November 1981 by Williams
column3: under license from Kural Samno. For more information about the game itself
column4: please see the ""Crush Roller"" entry.

column1: Make Trax has a protection chip
column2: Crush Roller doesn't. The code between the two is nearly identical
column3: except that everywhere the protection code is located
column4: code has been replaced with a couple of bytes to return the correct value and several NOP instructions (which do absolutely nothing).

column1: When you run the game for the first time
column2: the default highscore table (FAR OUT PLAYERS) is empty (everything is set to 0 except the nickname which is set to KRL).

column1: Tom Carver holds the official record for this game with 2123840 points."

;A mass prison breakout has occurred and the prison warden has been kidnapped in this sideways scrolling shoot-em-up from Konami. The player controls a lonely police officer whose job it is to kill the hordes of escaped convicts and
column2: eventually
column3: rescue the kidnapped warden. Each level also has a number of civilian hostages that also roam the levels and need to be rescued.

column1: The player begins the game with only a pistol
column2: but two extra weapons
column3: in the form of a bazooka and a tear gas gun
column4: can be collected. The 'Weapon Select' button cycles through the player's weapons via a display at the bottom of the screen. When the desired weapon is highlighted
column5: pressing the Fire button will select and fire the desired weapon.

column1: Hostages will randomly run across the screen and can be rescued by running into them. Should the player accidentally shoot a hostage

;Export version by Bally/Midway for North America. Game developed in Japan by Namco. For more information about the game, please see the original Namco version entry.
2187;mappyj;mappyj;Mappy (c) 1983 Namco.
;You are Mappy
column2: the brave mouse policeman. Mappy's mission is to retrieve all of the stolen treasure from the Mewkies cat gang. They've stashed all of the loot in their leader's mansion which contains several floors
column3: and numerous trampolines that the Mewkies like to use to travel between stories. Mappy must keep away from the cats and collect all items in the house before moving on to the next house. If Mappy is caught by a cat
column4: he loses a life. Mappy also loses a life if he crashes to the floor by breaking through a trampoline or falling into a pitfall. When all of Mappy's lives are lost
column5: the game is over.

column1: Houses have six floors
column2: and some houses in later rounds have an attic. Mappy gets to the different floors by jumping on a trampoline. Mappy can jump three times on a trampoline
column3: but the fourth time will break it. Once Mappy moves onto a floor
column4: he can jump on the trampoline another three times.

column1: When Mappy jumps on the trampoline
column2: he will go to the top floor of the house unless you push the joystick left or right to move him onto a particular floor. You can move Mappy onto a floor as he's on the way up
column3: but not on the way down.

column1: Nyamco
column2: the boss cat
column3: does not chase Mappy. Instead he moves around in a zigzag pattern. He also like to hide for a few seconds behind a treasure.

column1: The cats are very sneaky and
column2: if given half a chance
column3: will try to corner Mappy at the end of one of the platforms or to trap him on one of the floors he must use to get to the treasures he's after.

column1: The cats have no defense mechanisms of any kind. But they cannot be permanently eliminated either. As soon as Mappy puts one cat out of commission
column2: another cat appears somewhere else in the house.

column1: However
column2: in an emergency
column3: you can slow one cat down for short periods of time. This is accomplished by having Mappy throw open a standard door in the cat's face to knock him down and stun him. When hit by the door
column4: the cat will be stunned for several seconds. When he is disabled like this
column5: Mappy can walk right by him and not get caught. To temporarily eliminate more than one pursuer at a time
column6: Mappy must catch them in the microwaves emitted when opening power doors - the thick flashing doors that flicker with different colors.

column1: As your skill level increases
column2: the number and direction of pursuers coming at you at any one time and the speed with which they move
column3: is gradually increased; plus
column4: their pursuit patterns become more and more devious while their overall accuracy is highly improved.

column1: Bonus lives are awarded to you periodically throughout the game as you reach or pass certain preselected point values ('Extra Lives' dip switch).
Once all the treasure in the house has been retrieved
column2: you move on to the next house.

column1: A bonus round is awarded to you after the 2nd house
column2: and after every 3rd house thereafter
column3: i.e. in after the 6th
column4: 9th
column5: 12th
column6: 15th
column7: etc. houses. In the bonus rounds
column8: you score extra points by popping balloons. Using the trampoline
column9: jump to pop as many balloons as possible in the fewest number of moves. The bonus round ends when the music ends. If you die during a bonus round
column10: the bonus round ends there
column11: but the number of lives remaining is not affected.

column1: - CAST OF CHARACTERS -
Mappy (""Micro Police"") - This is you
column2: our hero and defender of justice
column3: the police-mouse who is on the case to recover the stolen loot from the enemy cats.

column1: Nyamco (""Boss The Big Bit"") - Does not chase Mappy
column2: but moves around the house in a zig-zag fashion

column1: Mewkies (""Naughty Folks"") - This gang of smaller cats chases and tries to catch Mappy.
Gosenzo - This appears when Mappy moves throughout the house for a long period of time without retrieving any stolen items. Once it appears
column2: Mappy has no chance of escaping.

column1: Doors - When Mappy is directly in front of a door
column2: press the Door button to open the door. Doors open in the direction of the doorknob. Mappy cannot go through a closed door; you must open it to go through.

column1: Power Doors - These flicker with different colors and are thicker than the ordinary doors. When you press the Door button
column2: the door opens and sends a microwave that flushes away Mappy's feline pursuers. There are four power doors in each house."

column1: 2188;marble;marble;"Marble Madness (c) 1984 Atari Games Corporation.

;Marble Madness is an abstract maze game for one or two players. The game's goal is to guide a small glass marble over a three-dimensional maze and reach the finish line before the level's timer has expired. Any seconds that remain on the timer when the finish line is crossed are carried over to the next level.
As well as having to negotiate the marble over treacherous walkways and ramps
column2: numerous obstacles and unfriendly creatures will try to slow the marble's progress or knock it over the edge of a platform
column3: wasting yet more precious seconds until a replacement marble appears. The two-player game has players competing to reach the goal first.

column1: Marble Madness features six different mazes."
2189;marble2;marble2;"Marble Madness (c) 1984 Atari Games Corporation.

;Marble Madness is an abstract maze game for one or two players. The game's goal is to guide a small glass marble over a three-dimensional maze and reach the finish line before the level's timer has expired. Any seconds that remain on the timer when the finish line is crossed are carried over to the next level.
As well as having to negotiate the marble over treacherous walkways and ramps
column2: numerous obstacles and unfriendly creatures will try to slow the marble's progress or knock it over the edge of a platform
column3: wasting yet more precious seconds until a replacement marble appears. The two-player game has players competing to reach the goal first.

column1: Marble Madness features six different mazes."

column1: 2196;mariojp;marioj;"Mario Bros. (c) 1983 Nintendo.
;Mario Bros. is a superb
column2: single-screen platform game in which the legendary ""Mario Bros.""
column3: Mario and Luigi
column4: must try to rid each level of a number of pests that have infested the waterworks : Shellcreepers (turtles)
column5: Sidesteppers (crabs that need to be hit twice) and Fighterflies (flies that can only be attacked when they touch a platform).

column1: Players can jump upwards to hit the platform above them
column2: which will 'flip' any enemies on the above platform onto their backs. The prone enemies can then be kicked into the water to remove them. A 'POW' button also appears on a number of screen; this can be 'butted' by a player
column3: causing all on-screen enemies to flip onto their backs; as well as destroying any enemy fireballs that may be around. Each POW can only be used a maximum of three times.

column1: As well as the game's enemies
column2: players are also hampered by the huge amount of inertia that comes into play when controlling Mario or Luigi. This is due to the low degree of traction that exists between the Mario brothers and the platforms. On later phases
column3: ice appears on the platforms reducing the amount of traction even further. As the game progresses
column4: water droplets hang below the platforms and freeze into deadly icicles
column5: which will eventually break off and fall."

;Each player (up to 2 people may play at a time, 2-player mode is more fun), controls a little geometric shape. Each player starts at opposite sides of the maze. The object is to get to the point where the other player started, before they get to where you started. You use a joystick to guide your 'character' through the maze. The game is time based, and you score a point for each maze you beat faster than your opponent (or the computer player if you are going solo). The factory setting is for a 90 second game, but this is operator adjustable. The graphics are done in monochrome white on black. With no detail on anything. The maze walls are only a pixel thick, while the characters themselves (simple shapes), are not much bigger. The mazes are not stylized in anyway. They look exactly like the kind of maze you would do with a paper and pen.
2221;mazerbla;mazerbla;Mazer Blazer (c) 1983 Stern Electronics.
;The object of the game is to prevent the attacking aliens from working through the maze and entering your ship. Each time an alien enters your ship
column2: you lose a life.

column1: There are 14 different types of aliens in Mazer Blazer. Each level will have 1 or 2 different types of aliens that present the player with constantly changing levels of difficulty. The screen is divided into 4 colors. The colors determine the point value of the object (see Scoring section for more details).
Shoot the aliens using the rapid fire Mazer Blaster. The farther from the ship you shoot the aliens
column2: the higher the poin value awarded.

column1: The walls of the maze are in 2 different colors; grey and orange. Orange walls are indestructible
column2: while the grey walls can be shot away either by the nasties on the screen or your Mazer Blaster. Shooting the grey walls leaves gaps in the maze ans makes it easier for the aliens to reach their ship
column3: and lowers your wall bonus.

column1: After each level is a Timed Bonus Rack. There are 8 aliens per bonus rack.. Shoot the aliens as fast as possible for a maximum bonus. The aliens seen in the bonus rack will be the alien encountered in the next maze level.
In every maze is the freeze target (located at the lower center of the screen). The freeze target
column2: when hit
column3: momentarily stops the movement of the aliens on the screen."

;A 1-on-1 fighting game in which players choose from 10 different wrestlers and take to the ring to try and defeat their larger-than-life opponents. Each wrestler has an assortment of moves
column2: including his own special 'super slam'. The object of the game is to win and defend the championship by pinning or putting a submission hold on your opponent.

column1: There are 2 different game modes to select and play : Single Match or Tag Team 'Battle Royal'. In Single Match
column2: players choose to be one of eight wrestlers including 'Mike Hagger'
column3: 'Alexander The Grater'
column4: 'El Stingray'
column5: 'King Rasta Mon'
column6: 'Titanic Tim'
column7: 'Gunloc'
column8: 'Biff Bolshevik' and 'The Great Oni' ('Jumbo Jack' and 'The Scorpion' cannot be selected in this game).

column1: Once a wrestler has been selected
column2: players will compete in a world-wide tournament against the other 9 wrestlers (including 'Jumbo Jack' and 'The Scorpion') in respective matches. In each match
column3: players must defeat each of their respective opponents by a pinfall
column4: count-out or submission in order to proceed to each of the following matches. Once all opponents are defeated
column5: the winner will be crowned champion and players will have to face all opponents again to defend their title.

column1: In Tag Team 'Battle Royal'
column2: players can choose to play as any 2 of the 10 wrestlers for their tag team
column3: including 'Jumbo Jack' and 'The Scorpion'. Here
column4: the player and his or her partner have to eliminate both of the 2 wrestlers on the opposing tag team
column5: in order to win the match and proceed to the next. During these matches
column6: if the player is eliminated before his or her partner is
column7: the match will be declared no contest and it will be a draw.

column1: During each bout in this game
column2: metal buckets and/or glass bottles will sometimes be thrown into the ring which can be picked by the players' wrestler(s) and used as weapons against their opponents."

;At the end of the 21st century, war and hunger disappear on the earth, and humankind go on very well. On such occasion, it occurred to humankind that mysterious disappearances of women rise in waves in many places in the world. column1: 2241;megamn2a;megaman2a;;
2242;megatack;megatack;"Megatack (c) 1980 Centuri.
;SINGLE PLAYER GAME

The game-play sequence in MEGATACK consists of 4 or 5 turns (operator selectable) each of which lasts as long as the player can skilfully maneuver his spacepod to avoid destruction. When he loses a spacepod
column2: the GIP message reappears
column3: accompanied by the GIP sound
column4: and displays the number of spacepods left. After the last spacepod is destroyed
column5: the game-over sound is heard and the game-over message is displayed.

column1: Assuming a (4) pod game
column2: play begins with player-scores (00000) and at the top and the (3) best scores displayed across the bottom Eight (8) monsters appear in the upper portion of the screen and move towards the bottom
column3: while dropping their bombs. The player uses his joystick control to move his spacepod across the bottom of the screen. The spacepod will start with the number (4) in the center and the number will decrease each time a spacepod is destroyed so that the number (1) will be in the center on the last round.

column1: As the spacepod is moved across the bottom of the screen the player fires his laser energy-beams towards the left
column2: right
column3: and straight-up accompanied by an echoing laser sound effect. The laser beams have unlimited range
column4: covering the entire play-field
column5: and each spacepod has an unlimited number of shots. The (3) laser beams are fired simultaneously. Each fire-button must be released and pressed again to fire a second shot. Also
column6: there is a slight ""reload"" delay so that beams cannot-be fired too rapidly.

column1: Whenever a laser beam strikes a monster or a bomb
column2: it explodes with a visual flash and an audio blast. If a monster is blasted
column3: the player is awarded a 'kill' and his score is increased by the appropriate score (per the scoring menu when a bomb is blasted
column4: no points are scored.

column1: When a spacepod is hit by a bomb
column2: it explodes with a growing flash and a reverberating blast. When the spacepod gets too close to a monster
column3: the monster jumps up and sporadically devours it while growling and burping
column4: if a monster reaches the bottom
column5: it bounces across the bottom in an attempt to devour the spacepod.

column1: When all the monsters in a given round have been destroyed the screen will turn into a starfield
column2: and small space rings will appear
column3: which if not shot at
column4: hit
column5: and destroyed will grow in size. If any one (1) ring is allowed to reach a predetermined size
column6: it will de-activate the spacepods laser gun
column7: which during these rounds only fires straight up
column8: lift the spacepod off the bottom of the screen
column9: absorb it and then disappear (shrinking in size)
column10: thus ending the round. The next round begins with the next wave of monsters. This starfield round occurs between every wave of monsters
column11: and if the player is successful in destroying all the rings the next wave of monsters will then appear.

column1: When the spacepod is finally destroyed either by being absorbed
column2: hit by a bomb or devoured by a monster the round is over and the video image returns to the GIP display flashing player (1) up and displaying the remaining spacepods the screen then goes black again and this time the pod with the number (3) in the center appears at the bottom of the screen and play continues as before.

column1: During play there are always (8) monsters (max) on the screen
column2: however the monsters attack in waves of 25
column3: after each multiple of 25 kills the starfield or space ring round will appear with each ring worth the same score as the monsters were worth in the previous screen display. The monsters that reappear after each space ring round are a new shape
column4: and color and score more points
column5: and drop a different color bomb
column6: any monsters left at the end of a round will reappear at the beginning of the next round. At the beginning of the game the action is rather moderate to allow new players an opportunity to develop a 'feel' for the game. In each succeeding wave of monsters
column7: the bombs begin to fall at an increased rate and the monsters motions are increased.

column1: All of these features combine to make MEGATACK satisfying for the novice
column2: challenging for the expert
column3: and profitable for the operator.

column1: TWO-PLAYER MODE
The play of MEGATACK in a two-player game is identical to single-play with the players alternating turns. On the Upright Version
column2: the players use one common set of controls. On the cocktail version there are two sets of controls on opposite sides of the table. The computer activates control alternately between player 1 and 2 and flip-flops the screen image so that it is oriented to the player in control.

column1: The GIP message
column2: which appears after each turn
column3: clearly indicates which player is up by flashing it in the player's color. This also allows time for the players to position themselves at the controls
column4: but is brief enough to avoid unnecessary ""dead-time"". The use of two different player-colors eliminates any confusion as to which player is in control."

2253;metalb;metalb;Metal Black (c) 1991 Taito Corp.
;Earth is under attack from an alien race from the 'Nemesis' region of space
column2: and human civilisation now stands on the brink of collapse. The invaders have utilised energy molecules - known to earth scientists as 'Newalones' - to create powerful beam weapons with which to attack Earth. In response
column3: Earth's scientists have developed the 'Black Fly' project; a powerful space craft that utilises the same Newalone molecule technology of the alien aggressors.

column1: Metal Black is a very playable sideways scrolling shoot-em-up which manages to feel different to other games in the genre
column2: due to the fact that it lacks a a player-definable weapon power-up system. Instead of collecting items that provide extra speed
column3: different weapons etc. players must collect the clusters of 'Newalone' molecules that float around each level. These molecule clusters will gradually increase the player ship's firepower.

column1: As long as the Metal Black ship has sufficient firepower
column2: players can activate the 'Beam Weapon'
column3: which generates a powerful energy beam that destroys everything it comes into contact with. The Beam Weapon will only last for a few seconds and its use will reduce the ship's energy levels. Once the Beam weapon de-activates
column4: Metal Black will have vastly reduced firepower for its forward-firing laser cannon. Players must once again collect the Newalone molecule clusters to build up the ship's firepower."

;Metal Clash is a futuristic fighter game for one or two players. In one player mode

column1: The player pilots his robot around the screen destroying enemy robots using punches and kicks. Flying saucers can be destroyed for a life energy boost.  Items in the background can be destroyed for points. After defeating a set number of enemies the stage's boss will appear. The boss is more powerful than regular enemies
column2: and has his own life energy bar shown on screen. Some of these bosses can be disarmed of their powerful weapons (such as guns and energy shields) which the player can equip and carry on into further levels.

column1: When hit by enemies
column2: the player will lose energy and will drop any weapons that he has equipped. When the player's life energy is completely depleted he will lose a life. The game is over once all of the player's lives are lost.  The game features no continues.

column1: 2261;metrocra;metrocrsa;"Metro-Cross (c) 1985 Namco.

;A single player runs through a number of futuristically-themed levels, avoiding obstacles - Coca-Cola cans, barriers, green floor tiles (which slow the player's progress), holes etc. - and attempt to reach the finish line before the tight time limit expires. Progress is aided by springboards - which allow the player to jump over obstacles - and a skateboard, which is unaffected by the green tiles that otherwise slow the player's progress. Bonus points can be earned by kicking the static drinks cans that can be found throughout each level.

2277;mia;mia;M.I.A. - Missing in Action (c) 1989 Konami.
;M.I.A. is a direct sequel to 1985's 'Green Beret' and
column2: like it's predecessor
column3: is a horizontally scrolling jump and shoot game for one or two players. Special forces soldiers must penetrate several enemy-packed combat zones to reach a POW compound.

column1: Upon reaching the compound
column2: the player must infiltrate and rescue the POWs held there
column3: before escorting them safely through a final enemy-packed level to the rescue helicopter that awaits at the end.

column1: Unlike 'Green Beret'
column2: the two-player game in M.I.A. sees both players fighting side-by-side
column3: instead of the alternate approach of the original game.

column1: The game consists of six stages;
* War-torn battlefield
* Airstrip
* Jungle
* Rail Yard
* PoW Base
* Escort the PoW's to the Helicopter
The first four stages are presented in random order and may also be ""mirrored""
column2: so players battle right-to-left instead of left-to-right. This vastly increases variety to the game and adds replay value. The PoW and helicopter stages are always the last two stages. At the end of each level
column3: the players must fight off a flurry of enemy troops and destroy gun emplacements and watch towers. Certain sections of each stage offer players a different route
column4: with both platforms and underground tunnels that can be utilized and explored.

column1: As with 'Green Beret'
column2: players start each level carrying only a combat knife. Specific enemy troops carry weapons which are dropped when the soldier is killed and can be picked up by the players. The weapons are always carried by soldiers wearing red uniforms
column3: and range from an assault rifle
column4: grenades
column5: a flame-thrower or a bazooka. Players can carry more than one weapon and can cycle through them as needed. Each collected weapon has only a limited supply of shots.

column1: After rescuing the PoW's on the sixth stage
column2: players must escort as many of the escapees as possible to a waiting helicopter
column3: and must get at least one PoW safely aboard the chopper to complete the mission and start a new set of stages."

column1: 2280;midres;midres;"Midnight Resistance (c) 1989 Data East.
;One or two players take on the role of two commando brothers whose entire family has been kidnapped and must be rescued. The game's eight large
column2: eight-way scrolling levels are made up of platforms
column3: ledges and ladders; each populated both with enemy soldiers and with intricate
column4: imaginatively designed enemy machinery.

column1: In a gameplay mechanic first introduced in SNK's 'Ikari Warriors'
column2: players can rotate their guns through 360 degrees
column3: allowing them to target and fire in all directions.

column1: Some enemies
column2: when killed
column3: will drop a red key; collecting these keys allows players to upgrade their weapons at the shop that awaits at the end of each level. A maximum of six keys can be carried at any one time."

column1: 2283;miexchng;miexchng;"Money Idol Exchanger (c) 1997 Face.

;Handling money has never been so much fun! This incredibly original puzzle game lets you take control of  hilariously designed characters in a cute Japanese superhero theme and boggle your mind with a puzzle system reminiscent of the Magical Drop games but with a tricky-to-master coin handling twist. Good graphics with lots of funny animations (the intro is indeed a joy to behold!), cool pop music & lots of challenge make this game a true gem to behold!

column1: 2287;mikiehs;mikiehs;"High School Graffitti Mikie (c) 1984 Konami Industry Company
column2: Limited.

column1: ;- TRIVIA -
High School Graffitti Miki is an alternate version of the Konami game ""Mikie"". Aside from the noticeably different decor in the homeroom (all right
column2: it's only the blackboard)
column3: there are several MAJOR differences in this MUCH harder version. Hearts that were normally in glass cases are stacked as piles of three hearts (you only have to time the last heart for Perfects). Furthermore
column4: you can't headbutt in this version
column5: you have to yell
column6: which temporarily stuns enemies EXCEPT FOR your homeroom teacher
column7: who cannot be stopped except by thrown items. Yelling is also much shorter range than headbutting
column8: making timing crucial. Not a version for the weak-reflexed. Most importantly though is that if you take too long in a room
column9: the Classroom teacher can throw what looks like either a necklace or dentures at you. On the plus side
column10: you recover faster from a yell than a headbutt (less lag time) and enemies don't speed up as fast as they do in the other romsets (unfortunately
column11: it seems as though the homeroom teacher will speed up on his own in this romset)."

column1: 2288;mikiej;mikiej;"Shinnyuushain Tooru-Kun (c) 1984 Konami.
2289;milliped;milliped;Millipede (c) 1982 Atari.
;Millipede is a 1- or 2-player game with a color raster-scan video display. The game action takes place on a playfield filled with mushrooms
column2: flowers
column3: and deadly DDT bombs. The player tries to destroy a variety of insects that drop from the top of the screen or enter from the sides of the screen
column4: most of them to attack the player. The player controls a bow-shaped vehicle called the Archer. The object of the game is to shoot and destroy as many objects as possible for a high point score
column5: before the player's lives are all used up.

column1: Player control consists of a Midi Trak-Ball control and a FIRE button. The Archer is moved by rotating the Midi Trak-Ball control. The Archer can be moved in all directions
column2: but only within the bottom fifth of the screen. However
column3: the Archer must move around mushrooms
column4: flowers
column5: and DDT bombs
column6: since these are fixed and not 'transparent' objects. Pressing the FIRE button causes the Archer to emit an arrow that travels upward. The Archer may fire one or many arrows (by holding down the FIRE button constantly). But only one arrow will appear on the screen at a time.

column1: A player may start a game at an advanced level of play and receive bonus points for starting play at that level.

Game play begins with a playfield of randomly placed mushrooms and DDT bombs. A Millipede enters at the top center of the screen and starts snaking its way across the screen. The Millipede changes direction when it runs into a fixed object in the playfield (mushroom
column2: DDT bomb
column3: or flower)
column4: or when it reaches the side boundaries of the playfield.

column1: When a segment of the Millipede is shot
column2: it is destroyed and a mushroom appears where that segment was shot. When shot
column3: the Millipede breaks into two smaller Millipedes
column4: each with its own head. When a Millipede reaches the bottom of the screen
column5: it starts back up
column6: but remains within the area of the Archer (the bottom 5th of the screen).

column1: If a Millipede reaches the bottom of the screen without being shot
column2: it releases its tail. This tail changes into a new head. Also to provide the player a challenge
column3: if a Millipede is still alive when it reaches the bottom
column4: new heads will enter the screen almost at the bottom of the sides. More of these heads will appear as time progresses.

column1: An attack wave is complete when all Millipede segments are destroyed. The screen then scrolls down one line. At the 9th attack wave
column2: when the Millipede with only four segments enters from the top of the screen
column3: the screen will scroll down every two seconds. The only way a player can stop the scrolling screen is to shoot a DDT bomb or destroy the entire Millipede.

column1: It takes four shots to destroy a mushroom. After the fourth attack wave of each wave cycle
column2: the entire playfield of mushrooms changes. Some mushrooms die and new mushrooms grow where there were none before. A mushroom next to a DDT bomb becomes poisoned (See Tips and Tricks below for complete details).

column1: When a Millipede runs into a poisoned mushroom
column2: two things happen: its head changes color
column3: and it changes direction and falls vertically to the bottom of the screen.

column1: DDT bombs explode when hit by an arrow. Any object near the bomb is engulfed by the explosion. Insects are worth three times their normal point value if they are destroyed by the explosion.
Spiders appear in any round. They move in a random pattern on the bottom third of the screen. As the player's score increases
column2: the range of the Spider decreases
column3: until it is confined to the bottom fifth of the screen. Also
column4: more Spiders enter as the game progresses. A Spider destroys any mushroom or flower it moves over. Depending on a special option switch setting
column5: the Spider moves slowly until a player reaches a specific score
column6: and then it speeds up. If the Archer and a Spider collide
column7: both are destroyed.

column1: When a Millipede with fewer than eleven segments appears
column2: an Earwig enters the screen from either side
column3: moving at a relatively slow speed. As the player earns more points
column4: the Earwig's speed increases. If an Earwig passes over a mushroom
column5: it poisons the mushroom.

column1: When a Millipede with fewer than ten segments appears
column2: a Dragonfly enters at the top of the screen. The Dragonfly moves in a zig-zag pattern and its speed increases as the player's score increases. As the Dragonfly moves
column3: it leaves a trail of mushrooms behind.

column1: When a Millipede with fewer than nine segments appears
column2: a Mosquito enters at the top of the screen and flies in a diagonal pattern. The Mosquito's speed increases as the player's score increases. When a Mosquito is destroyed
column3: the screen scrolls up one row.

column1: Beetles appear randomly after the first wave. They enter from the sides of the screen near the bottom
column2: travel down to the bottom of the screen
column3: and walk at least half way across the bottom. Then the Beetle travels up and exits at the side of the screen. If a Beetle passes over a mushroom
column4: the mushroom changes into a flower. Flowers cannot be destroyed by the Archer's arrows. Depending on a dip switch setting
column5: the number of Beetles appearing on the screen and the speed of the beetles increase as the player's score increases. When a Beetle is destroyed
column6: the screen scrolls down one row.

column1: Bees may fall from the top of the screen during any round. As the Bee falls
column2: it leaves a trail of mushrooms behind. The Archer must hit a Bee twice to destroy it; the first shot just speeds it up.

column1: An Inchworm may appear when a Millipede with fewer that eleven segments appears. The Inchworm travels from one side of the screen to the other side. It moves slowly until the player's score reaches 80
column2: 000 points. Then it speeds up. If the Archer destroys the Inchworm
column3: all insects will slow down for about three and one-half seconds.

column1: After a Millipede of one
column2: three
column3: five
column4: seven
column5: or eleven segments has been destroyed
column6: an insect bombing raid occurs. A raid may have only Bees
column7: Dragonflies
column8: Mosquitoes
column9: or a mixture of all three."

column1: 2290;millpac;millpac;"Mill Pac (c) 198? Valadon Automation.
;Rare French hack of ""Centipede"".
- TRIVIA -

'Mill' is an abbreviation for 'Mille' which translates from French as 'Thousand'. 'Pac' is the reference for the ""Pac-Man"" characters. 'Mill Pac' is also a pun for 'Mille-Pattes' which translates from French as ...""Millipede""!
Valadon Automation was founded by Alain Valadon."
2291;mimonkey;mimonkey;"Mighty Monkey (c) 1982 Universal Video Games.
2292;mimonsco;mimonsco;Mighty Monkey (c) 1982 Universal Video Games.
2293;mimonscr;mimonscr;Mighty Monkey (c) 1982 Universal Video Games.
2294;minasan;minasan;みなさんのおかげさまです! (c) 1991 Monolith Crporation.
;(Minasan no Okagesama Desu! Dai Suguroku Taikai)
A difficult mahjong game with very odd characters and board game elements."
2295;minefld;minefld;"Minefield (c) 1983 Stern Electronics.
;A horizontal tank shooter game
column2: with great atmosphere Parallax scrolling background.

column1: The mid-day heat is rapidly becoming unbearable as the supply helicopter lowers your battle tank on to edge of the desert. You have a whole day's travelling ahead
column2: 90 miles across the seemingly endless desert
column3: until you reach the target of your mission - the enemy's desert fortress. Only after you have managed to destroy it
column4: will it be safe for the transport helicopter to collect you and send you on another full-scale mission.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: the going across the desert is not easy. Your tank has run out of super-missiles and you must replenish your armoury from the stockpiles on the way. If you don't collect enough you will not be able to destroy the forts and the enemy base
column3: which is so well protected you need three missile hits to put it out of action. However
column4: you have unlimited supplies of shells for your heavy duty gun that can fire in all directions.

column1: To add to your diffículties
column2: the enemy have buried deadly mines all over the desert floor which you must avoid at all costs
column3: or lose a tank. Once you are on your way
column4: the enemy
column5: knowing of your mission
column6: keep sending all manner of war machines to try and stop your journey. You must take action against them all
column7: and avoid their bombs. After 60 miles of hazardous travel night arrives
column8: and the enemy use this opportunity to try and confuse you by sending a varied mixture of attackers under cover of darkness
column9: Beware
column10: some of them are robot controlled and will try and crash into your tank.

column1: Good luck in your mission-the reward is high. A spare tank every 30.000 points and a chance to record our initials on the tank coomander's roll of honour."
2296;mineswpr;mineswpr;"Minesweeper (c) 1977 Amutech.
;This game was two player only
column2: you must have a real live person to play against
column3: or else the other players boat will head directly for the bottom wall
column4: which doesn't make for a very interesting game. Each player moves their little boat around leaving a solid line of mines behind them. All moves are made on an invisible grid
column5: so you can only turn at 90 degree angles. To win you must last longer than your opponent before hitting something (first person to hit something loses). One good strategy is to try and box your opponent in to a small section of the screen
column6: and then just move carefully until they crash. Pushing backwards on the stick will cause you to crash into your own mines
column7: so avoid that at all cost.

column1: The game was controlled with buttons rather than joysticks (this was cheaper to produce
column2: and most of the other similar games of the time used buttons as well). Inserting a coin started the game at once. Both players got to play for a single coin. The game ended after one player chalked up six wins
column3: but this was operator adjustable down to as low as three. The operator can also turn the sound on and off with internal switches as well."

column1: 2297;minferno;minferno;"Inferno (c) 1977 Meadows Games.
2298;minigol2;minigolf2;Sente Mini-Golf (c) 1985 Bally Sente.
2299;minigolf;minigolf;Sente Mini-Golf (c) 1985 Bally Sente.

column2: Limited.

column1:
;Japanese ninja game featuring 12 stages.
2302;missb2;missb2;Miss Bubble II (c) 1996 Alpha Co.
;Miss Bubble II is an adult bootleg of ""Bubble Bobble"".  It features 100 single screen levels with photographic semi-nude images for backgrounds.  The background changes every three levels.
The player takes on the role of one of two yellow and green colored mice. Armed only with the ability to blow bubbles and jump
column2: the objective is to trap and kill all of your enemies within the bubbles to advance to the next stage. The bubbles can also be used as temporary platforms
column3: to help the mice reach previously inaccessible areas of a level. If a player is touched by an enemy then the player dies.

column1: Any trapped enemies who are not killed quickly enough will turn red and escape their bubble prison. These angry enemies are much faster than before
column2: making them harder to kill. Enemies also become angry if players are taking too long to complete a level. Defeated enemies are turned into bonus fruit items that can be collected for points.

column1: On many levels
column2: special bubbles appear such as water filled bubbles appear. These can be burst by players to release their contents and destroy enemies. The water bubble releases a torrent of water that will quickly flow down the platforms to the bottom of the screen. Any enemies caught in the flow are killed.

column1: Bubbles containing letters also appear. The aim is to collect the letters needed to spell the word along the side of the screen.
Once the player loses all of his lives the game is over.  Upon continuing
column2: all remaining enemies return to their un-angered forms."

column1: 2303;missile;missile2;"Missile Command (c) 1980 Atari.

;Missile Command is a 1- or 2-player game with a color monitor. The game depicts an Armageddon-style war in which players defend their missile bases and cities with antiballistic missiles (ABMs). The enemy - the game computer - launches incoming waves of attack missiles. These weapons may be either individual missiles or multiple independently-targed re-entry vehicles (MIRV)
column2: which unleash branching attack missiles. In addition
column3: the enemy occasionally launches missiles from a fast-moving 'killer' satellite or from bombers. The enemy also launches smart bombs that usually avoid explosions.

column1: Players receive varying numbers of points for intercepting attack missiles
column2: for having unused ABMs still in their bases' arsenals
column3: and for having their cities undamaged after a missile wave.

column1: The game begins when either Start pushbutton is pressed. The game ends when the player's last city is destroyed.
The three bases - Alpha
column2: Delta and Omega - each have ten ABMs ready to be fired. Players must be careful to fire the ABMs more or less evenly from among those bases
column3: because no more ABMs are granted until the screen resets in preparation for a new wave of attack missiles. If an enemy missile strikes a city or base
column4: the colorful buildings or base will change to the solid color of the landscape.

column1: The game continues until all cities are destroyed. Missile Command has no operator-selectable fixed time length. Thus a highly skilled player can play longer than the novice.
During the second wave
column2: a 'killer' satellite and/or bomber will appear on the screen
column3: moving quickly and launching attack missiles at the bases and cities. Players get bonus points for shooting down the satellites or bombers.

column1: The general approach for getting high point scores is fairly quickly discovered : try to launch your ABMs when the enemy missiles have just appeared at the top of the screen. Then they are clustered together
column2: where one ABM can usually destroy several enemy missiles. In the later
column3: more advanced waves
column4: players can lay out a blanket of explosions.

column1: You start the game with a certain number of cities depending on the 'Cities' dip switch (4
column4: or 7 cities; the default is 6)
column5: and can have no more than 6 cities in play at one time. If the dip switch is set to starting with 7 cities
column6: the 7th city will be treated as a bonus city after at least one city in play has been destroyed.

column1: You earn a bonus city every time you score a certain number of points ('Bonus City' dip switch
column2: the default is 10000). You don't see your bonus cities until they replace destroyed cities at the beginning of the next wave.

column1: - CAST OF ELEMENTS -

Anti-Ballistic Missiles (ABMs) : The defensive missiles you launch to protect your cities. Each missile base contains 10 ABMs per wave. If any missile base is struck by an attack missile or smart bomb
column2: the remaining stock of ABMs for that wave are destroyed
column3: and the missile base is rendered useless until the next wave. You receive bonus points for every ABM you have remaining at the end of each wave.

column1: Targeting crosshair : Aim your ABMs quickly but carefully. Use the trackball to move the targeting crosshair to where you want the next ABM to go
column2: then press any Launch Control button to fire the ABM. The ABM will explode where the crosshair was positioned when the Launch Control button was pressed.

column1: Cities : There are six cities in total on the screen at one time
column2: three on either side of the Delta Base. If one enemy missile or smart bomb manages to strike a city
column3: that city will be wiped out. When all cities are destroyed
column4: the game is over.

column1: Alpha Base : The missile base on the bottom left corner of the screen. Press the leftmost Launch Control button to launch an ABM from the Alpha base.
Delta Base : The missile base in the bottom center of the screen. Press the middle Launch Control button to launch an ABM from the Delta base.
Omega Base : The missile base on the bottom right corner of the screen. Press the rightmost Launch Control button to launch an ABM from the Omega base.
NOTE: The Alpha and Omega bases launch ABMs at a slower speed than the Delta base
column2: so you must plan further ahead when launching ABMs from those bases.

column1: Attack Missiles : Their only aim is to destroy your cities and missile bases. Every missile wave starts off with a hailstorm of attack missiles. They never deviate from their path. They may
column2: however
column3: turn into MIRVs.

column1: MIRV : Surprise! There is no warning when an attack missile turns into an MIRV (with multiple warheads). Think fast. Each new missile that the MIRV unleashes is carefully targeted.
Killer Satellite : A mean-looking satellite that travels across the sky at a mid-level altitude and fires attack missiles. First appears in Wave 2.
Bomber : A big slow-moving target that flies across the sky at a mid-level altitude
column2: but watch out! It fires attack missiles. First appears in Wave 2.

column1: WARNING: If you destory a bomber or killer satellite before they deploy their attack missiles
column2: you may see their attack missiles added to the downpour. An existing attack missile may also turn into an MIRV.

column1: Smart Bomb : Smart enough to avoid most explosion clouds from your ABMs. Your ABM must explode next to one in order to destroy it. You can also squeen it between two explosions to destroy it. First appears in Wave 5.
'LOW' Warning : As soon as there are only three ABMs left in a missile base
column2: the game displays the word 'LOW' underneath that base
column3: and a warning signal sounds. Heed the warning."

column1: 2304;missile2;missile1;"Missile Command (c) 1980 Atari.

;Missile Command is a 1- or 2-player game with a color monitor. The game depicts an Armageddon-style war in which players defend their missile bases and cities with antiballistic missiles (ABMs). The enemy - the game computer - launches incoming waves of attack missiles. These weapons may be either individual missiles or multiple independently-targed re-entry vehicles (MIRV)
column2: which unleash branching attack missiles. In addition
column3: the enemy occasionally launches missiles from a fast-moving 'killer' satellite or from bombers. The enemy also launches smart bombs that usually avoid explosions.

column1: Players receive varying numbers of points for intercepting attack missiles
column2: for having unused ABMs still in their bases' arsenals
column3: and for having their cities undamaged after a missile wave.

column1: The game begins when either Start pushbutton is pressed. The game ends when the player's last city is destroyed.
The three bases - Alpha
column2: Delta and Omega - each have ten ABMs ready to be fired. Players must be careful to fire the ABMs more or less evenly from among those bases
column3: because no more ABMs are granted until the screen resets in preparation for a new wave of attack missiles. If an enemy missile strikes a city or base
column4: the colorful buildings or base will change to the solid color of the landscape.

column1: The game continues until all cities are destroyed. Missile Command has no operator-selectable fixed time length. Thus a highly skilled player can play longer than the novice.
During the second wave
column2: a 'killer' satellite and/or bomber will appear on the screen
column3: moving quickly and launching attack missiles at the bases and cities. Players get bonus points for shooting down the satellites or bombers.

column1: 2306;mizubaku;mizubaku;"ミズバク大冒険 (c) 1990 Taito Corp.
;(Mizubaku Daibouken)
Mizubaku Daibouken is a cute and colourful single-player scrolling platform game from the same stable that brought the classics ""Bubble Bobble""
column2: ""The New Zealand Story"" and ""Rainbow Islands"" to the gaming world.

column1: The game features 'Hipopo the Hippo'; a strange Platypus-Hippopotamus hybrid who must fight his way through a large number of enemy-packed levels in search of his missing girlfriend - rescuing other Hippo-like creatures that await trapped at the end of each level.
Hipopo is armed with magical water globes that can be thrown at enemies to trap them. Once trapped
column2: the enemies can then be kicked to kill them. Enemies left unkicked will soon free themselves and return to their pursuit of Hipopo. Holding down the fire button increases the size of the globes and power-ups can also be picked-up that increases the globe size further still.

column1: The level design makes full use of the game's water-based theme
column2: with moving platforms
column3: collapsible floors
column4: boats and water-wheels all making an appearance. Small plants also appear on certain levels that can be ""watered""
column5: causing them to grow and form new platforms. Some plants are hidden and only appear when an area is watered. These usually contain doors to secret rooms and areas.

column1: At the end of every 2nd or 3rd stage
column2: Hipopo must defeat a large end-of-level guardian. Once the guardian has been defeated
column3: two doors will appear
column4: allowing players to choose which route they wish to take next."

2336;mjsikakb;mjsikakb;Mahjong Shikaku (c) 1988 Nichibutsu.

;Mahjong Shikaku is an adult mahjong game with a date theme. The objective of the game is to get through your date with your girlfriend with the end goal of reaching a hotel. Interfering with that goal are the various girls in the game
column2: who each attempt to thwart your efforts by challenging your skills at strip mahjong.

column1: At the start of the game
column2: the player chooses a name and then his date begins.  At various date spots the player is stopped by one of five girls
column3: who throws herself at the mercy of your mahjong skills. The player must defeat each girl before moving on in his date.

column1: Throughout the course of the matches the player gains energy as shown by fire icons on the right hand side of the screen. When the player is 'fired up' he has better luck in the hands he is dealt so it is possible to make better winning hands. Even so
column2: each girl has unlimited betting funds so the player must defeat each one three times
column3: no matter how good of a hand the player has.

column1: Each girl features two mandatory strip sequences
column2: and the player gets to choose one of four options for the final strip sequence.

column1: The player can lose a match and still continue right where he left off so long as he still has betting funds remaining.  But if his betting funds are depleted then the game is over."

2344;mk;mk;Mortal Kombat (c) 1992 Midway.
;Mortal Kombat
column2: first in the Mortal Kombat series
column3: is a 1-on-1 fighting game featuring a cast of seven different characters. Mortal Kombat took ideas from Capcom's seminal Street Fighter II
column4: such as the game's special moves and projectiles. It also introduced a cast of photo-realistic digitized fighters for players to fight either as or against.

column1: Mortal Kombat characters list:
JOHNNY CAGE
KANO
RAIDEN
LIU KANG
SCORPION
SUB-ZERO
SONYA BLADE
Battles are fought over the best of three rounds. At the end of a battle
column2: a voice instructs the winner to 'Finish Him/Her!' and players have only a couple of seconds to try and execute their character's 'fatality'
column3: which sees the winner killing the loser in a spectacular and grisly fashion."

2346;mk2chal;mk2chal;Mortal Kombat II Challenger.. (c) 199? Unknown.
;This hack of MKII have:
* Faster Uppercuts.
* Jax has a faster Face Smash.
* Jax's Face Smash has Liu Kang's sound FX.
* Cages Shadow Kick goes twice as far.
* Cage has full time Red Shadow moves.
* Multiple Dead Pool Fatality (Normal Uppercut will knock the person in
column2: then you can continue to hit them while they're in the acid).

column1: * Play against Noob Saibot after 6 wins.
* Play Pong on battle 16 instead of 250.
* Fight Smoke whenever you catch the 'Toasty' guy (not just the portal stage).
* Play against Jade after 4 wins.
* More difficult fight ladder that often begins with Kintaro or a hidden character.
* All of the secret characters can appear on the fight ladder.
* Super extended time to perform fatalities."
2347;mk2r14;mk2r14;"Mortal Kombat II (c) 1993 Midway Mfg. Co.
;Mortal Kombat II is a direct sequel to the 1992 original featuring new fighters (increasing the character roster from 7 to 12) and improved graphics.
As with its predecessor
column2: MKII's matches are divided into rounds
column3: with victory awarded to the first player to win two rounds. At the point of defeat
column4: the losing fighter will become dazed and the winner is given the opportunity to execute a 'finishing move'.

column1: Some of the standard fighting moves (moves shared by all characters) have now been expanded or enhanced. A crouching punch has been added and the 'roundhouse kick' is more powerful and now knocks opponents across the screen. Also
column2: the difference in hit boxes between high and low kicks is now more marked.

column1: Additionally
column2: returning characters gain new special moves and MKII marks the first appearence of multiple Fatalities - as well as additional
column3: non-lethal finishing moves - in the series. In addition to the Fatalities of its predecessor
column4: MKII offers 'Babalities' (turning a defeated opponent into a crying baby)
column5: 'Friendships' (a non-malicious interaction
column6: such as dancing or giving a gift to the defeated opponent) and stage-specific Fatalities (the winner uppercutting their opponent into an abyss below
column7: spikes above
column8: or a pool of acid in the background).

column1: Each character still shares generic attributes - speed
column2: power
column3: jump height and airtime - albeit with differing hit boxes. The sequel drops the points system of its prequel in favour of a consecutive win tally."

2352;mk3;mk3;"Mortal Kombat 3 (c) 1995 Midway Mfg. Co.

;Succeeding in taking over the Earth realm, Shao Kahn takes all the human souls on Earth as his own. To stop the Outworld realm from totally merging with the Earth realm, a few Earth warriors were chosen to have their souls protected from Shao Kahn in order to defend the Earth realm in a new Mortal Kombat tournament. 14 digitized characters fight to overthrow Shao Kahn and his Centaur lieutenant Motaro.

2355;mkeibaou;mkeibaou;Mahjong Keiba ou (c) 1993 Nichibutsu.

;Mahjong with a rather original horse racing theme.
2356;mkla1;mkla1;Mortal Kombat (c) 1992 Midway.
;Mortal Kombat
column2: first in the Mortal Kombat series
column3: is a 1-on-1 fighting game featuring a cast of seven different characters. Mortal Kombat took ideas from Capcom's seminal Street Fighter II
column4: such as the game's special moves and projectiles. It also introduced a cast of photo-realistic digitized fighters for players to fight either as or against.

column1: Mortal Kombat characters list:
JOHNNY CAGE
KANO
RAIDEN
LIU KANG
SCORPION
SUB-ZERO
SONYA BLADE
Battles are fought over the best of three rounds. At the end of a battle
column2: a voice instructs the winner to 'Finish Him/Her!' and players have only a couple of seconds to try and execute their character's 'fatality'
column3: which sees the winner killing the loser in a spectacular and grisly fashion."

column1:
;In the 25th century, Mars is home to millions of immigrants. This is because Earth was going to be overcrowded, and thus the colonization of a terraformed Mars was the only solution. The problem is, at some point, an unknown source of energy, located in the south pole, is discovered by the local government. All of a sudden, a declaration of independence arrives on Earth. What's going on? The Earth fleet goes to reveal it, with the new 'Mosquito fighters' acting as intruders...
2365;mmaze;mmaze;Marchen Maze (c) 1988 Namco.

;The player take control of a girl named Alice who walks over scrolling platforms, through nine different isometric worlds and she must knocks enemies over the edge with her bubble blower, while collecting various powerups along the way. Holding the fire button down generates bigger bubbles. The enemies attack shooting marbles at her, that can make she fall over the edge unless they are avoided or jumped over.
2366;mmcamera;mmcamera;Mahjong Camera Kozou (c) 1988 Miki Syouji.

;A mahjong game with women stranded in far-off places. Of course, you see sexy photographs of them if you beat them.

;An adult mahjong game with a race car theme.
The maximum bet per hand is three credits."

2370;mnchmobl;mnchmobl;Munch Mobile (c) 1983 Centuri
column2: Inc

column1: ;A weird driving game with a car that has long arms that reach out to grab a variety of edible items that appear along roadside.
The object is to drive safely down the road. Pick up enough fuel to stay alive while avoiding other vehicles that go by
column2: grab as many bonus objects as possible including apples
column3: cherries
column4: bananas
column5: acorns
column6: live fish and money
column7: and park your car in the garage. Driving while trying to pick up the goodies is difficult and you can crash very easily on the narrow roads. The pace of the game is frustrating because the hands move slowly while the car itself moves really fast
column8: especially in the later rounds. If one of your hands hits a tree or any other foreign object in its quest for food
column9: the car winces in pain for a few moments until it can use its hands again.

column1: You can get a bonus for putting used-up food into garbage cans. Grabbing fish which leap out of surrounding rivers is a safe bet
column2: but most other bonuses are placed
column3: so you can crash if you try to grab them. The best strategy is only to go for the fuel
column4: since the car is a big gas guzzler and you can also get a bonus for leftover fuel at the end of the drive."
