;A girl must shoot monsters and escape from a burning building. The game starts at preschool and ends at a wedding chapel where she is to collect items and get married, only for the game to begin again.
2378;monkeyd;monkeyd;Monkey Donkey (c) 1981.
;This game is a bootleg of ""Crazy Kong - Part II"". It uses a different color scheme than the original."
2379;monsterb;monsterb;"Monster Bash (c) 1982 Sega.
;MONSTER BASH is a fascinating cartoon theme game featuring colorful graphics in three exciting scenes of hunt-and-hide adventure. Light-hearted
column2: suspenseful music and audio sounds add to the fun
column3: and heighten player interest and intrigue.

column1: DRACULA'S HOUSE
The player-hero of the game is LITTLE RED
column2: a wily
column3: red-headed boy who chases Dracula throughout his five-story haunted house. Up and down staircases and through Warp Doors leading to secret passageways
column4: Little Red zaps defending bats while attempting to light candles in certain rooms. When a candle is lit a Magic Sword is energized with mystical powers. Little Red must touch the flashing Magic Sword to gain SuperZap power... only a SuperZap will defeat the sly Dracula.

column1: FRANKENSTEIN'S CASTLE
Little Red enters the eerie castle of the hulking Frankenstein. He pursues Frankenstein around his six-story castle while avoiding the fierce Wolfmen.  The tricky Wolfmen can be zapped
column2: but be careful
column3: they can duck under the zap and attack Little Red. Fewer candles are now available to be lit. Warp doors to secret passageways can be used only when they flash. Special jump-down zones allow Little Red to jump down several levels at once
column4: eliminating any Wolfmen in the way as he descends
column5: but Frankenstein can only be defeated with a SuperZap.

column1: CHAMELEON MAN'S GRAVEYARD
The greatest challenge yet... to dispatch the sneaky Chameleon Man and his horde of Spiders.  Entering the spooky graveyard
column2: Little Red finds that only one candle is available for lighting which is found in a crypt guarded by giant Spiders. Chameleon Man changes his color to match that of the background and thus becomes invisible. Little Red must pass over one of the Color-Change Spots to change the background color making Chameleon Man visible again. Chameleon Man can do away with Little Red with a flick of his long tongue. Chameleon Man can only be done in with a SuperZap."

column1: 2380;montecar;montecar;"Monte Carlo (c) 1980 Atari.
;Atari's Monte Carlo is a 1-player video game that simulates driving in a grand prix race. Various video-display phrase indicate score
column2: time elapsed ('FUEL')
column3: speed and which track was selected at the beginning of the game (eight different ones ranging from easy to hard). Players drive the grand prix car through the streets
column4: while spectators observe from the side. Bales of hay
column5: cola stands
column6: trees
column7: and bushes also line the roadway.

column1: Four computer-controlled cars provide challenge : they pass the player's car at high speed and may cause it to skid or even crash. However
column2: the computer cars are not unfailable and may also skid or crash occasionally. Realistic engine revving
column3: screeching tires and crash sounds accompany game play."

2387;moonbase;moonbase;Moon Base (c) 1979 Nichibutsu.
;A licensed sequel to the legendary ""Space Invaders"". Moon Base's gameplay is virtually identical to the original game
column2: with the player once again moving a laser base back and forth along the bottom of the screen
column3: shooting endless waves of aliens marching downwards towards the player. Once again flying saucers can be shot for extra points.

column1: Some minor enhancements over the original include the wave number now being indicated on the player's laser bases
column2: and the inclusion of the infamous 'color cellophane overlay'
column3: added to give the impression of coloured alien sprites."

column1: 2388;mooncrgx;mooncrgx;;
2389;mooncrs2;mooncrs2;"Moon Cresta (c) 1980 Nichibutsu.
;Moon Cresta is a 1 or 2-player game in which players may compete for highest score against the game computer. Each time a player is hit by an alien
column2: the game switches to his opponent's sequence.

column1: The object is to destroy as many of the descending aliens as possible. To accomplish this the player is given a three stage multi-fire Warship. He begins with the first stage
column2: firing a single laser at the enemy. If he is successful in eliminating the first 4 sets of aliens
column3: he is given an opportunity to dock his first stage onto the second within a specific time limit (the sooner he unites the stages
column4: the higher is his awarded score).

column1: Once docked
column2: the stages combine their firing power
column3: so the first (1 laser) adds to the second (2 lasers) giving the player a total of 3 usable lasers as the game continues.

column1: The player then must face 2 more sets of aliens and a shower of meteors
column2: after which he has a chance to dock again
column3: this time uniting with the third stage for a combined fire power of five lasers. If he is able to defeat the last two sets of aliens intact
column4: the entire sequence begins again. The game continues with increasing difficulty until the entire warship is destroyed. When the warship is hit the player continues with whatever stages remain. If his score reaches 30
column5: 000 he is awarded a free game and his score continues to accumulate."

2396;moonwalk;mwalk;Michael Jackson's MoonWalker (c) 1990 Sega.
;Based on the movie of the same name
column2: Moonwalker is a scrolling
column3: isometric beat' em up in which Michael Jackson (1958-2009)
column4: along with his chimp Bubbles
column5: attempts to save children and defeat the evil 'Mr. Big'. During each round
column6: the player must defeat each and every one of Mr. Big's henchmen and the deadly enemy machines that patrol the levels. This is achieved either by shooting them with Michael Jackson's 'magical energy'
column7: or by using his Dance Magic - the game's equivalent of a smart bomb. Some enemies take only one shot to defeat whereas others take several shots before they are destroyed. The longer the player holds down on the fire button
column8: the greater the amount of magical energy Michael can inflict. At the start of each round
column9: the player is given 2 dance magic smart bombs. Towards the end of each round
column10: Michael's pet chimpanzee
column11: Bubbles
column12: will be seen moving about. If Michael touches Bubbles
column13: he will turn into a powerful robot (the 'Moonwalker' of the game's title). After Michael has become Moonwalker
column14: he will be able to shoot lasers and fire missiles. Michael must defeat every boss enemy at the end of each round in order to proceed to the next.

column1: Each player's Michael Jackson character looks identical but wears a different colour : white (left player)
column2: red (middle player)
column3: and black (right player)."

2402;moremorp;moremorp;"More More Plus - Puzzle Express (c) 1999 SemiCom.

;More More Plus is the sequel to ""More More"" with much improved graphics and the addition of three more games. The game features a collection of 20 different mini-games to challenge the player's skill. Unlike the previous game
column2: players can now select any of the 20 games at any time. If the player successfully meets the challenge in the mini-game then he can continue to play. If the player achieves an ""excellent"" rating in four games then they will receive an extra life.  The game is over once the player has lost of their lives."

column1: 2403;mosaic;mosaic;"Mosaic (c) 1990 Space.
2404;mosaica;mosaica;Mosaic (c) 1990 Fuuki.
;- TRIVIA -
Manufactured by Fuuki under license from Space."
2405;mosyougi;moshougi;"将棋の達人 Master of Shougi (c) 1995 SNK.

;(Shougi no Tatsujin - Master of Shougi )
2406;motofren;motofrenmd;Moto Frenzy (c) 1992 Atari Games.
2407;motorace;motorace;MotoRace USA (c) 1983 Williams Electronics
2408;motos;motos;Motos (c) 1985 Namco.
;The object of the game is to bump your enemies - space bugs - off the solar base using Motos
column2: your ship. When you bump all of them off
column3: you move to the next base or round. If Motos is knocked off the base
column4: you lose one life. The game is over when you lose all your lives.

column1: You can collect Power parts and Jump parts lying on the solar base by simply having Motos touch them. The collected parts will be displayed in the lower left corner of the screen and you can use them in the next round. Motos can be outfitted with no more than seven power parts; the more power parts added
column2: the more powerful Motos is. However
column3: Motos can only be outfitted with only one jump part per round. With a jump part
column4: Motos can jump over two squares by moving the joystick in the desired direction and pressing the Jump button. One jump on a square cracks the square and a second jump in the same spot makes a hole in the solar base.

column1: You can outfit Motos with these parts in the Power Parts or Jump Parts screen displayed at the beginning of each round. Select the number of parts you want by moving left and right with the joystick
column2: and lock them in place by pressing the Jump button. You can use the selected parts for one round only; they will not be available in subsequent rounds.

column1: Linger too long on the playing field and Shooting Stars will begin to fall periodically onto the solar base. The Stars are aimed at Motos
column2: and when they miss they crack a square or break a hole in the solar base (like they do to the base behind the Motos logo in the attract mode's title sequence).

column1: - CAST OF CHARACTERS -
* Motos - The protagonist of the game. This is you.
* Power Parts - These give Motos extra bumping power. Motos can be equipped with a maximum of seven Power parts at a time.
* Jump Parts - These give Motos the ability to jump over the gaps in the playfield. Motos can only be equipped with one jump part at a time.
* Red Pupa (First appears in Round 1) - Weighs in at 380 kg (838 lbs) and travels 20 km/h (12.4 mph).
* Blue Pupa (First appears in Round 2) - Weighs in at 380 kg (838 lbs) and travels 20 km/h (12.4 mph).
* Polar (First appears in Round 2) - Weighs in at 400 kg (882 lbs) and travels 20 km/h (12.4 mph).
* Spirus (First appears in Round 4) - Weighs in at 2
column2: 900 kg (3.2 tons) and travels at 40 km/h (24.9 mph).

column1: * Fire Bug (First appears in Round 7) - Weighs in at 3
column2: 800 kg (4.2 tons) and travels at 45 km/h (28.0 mph).

column1: * Mega (First appears in Round 9) - Weighs in at 7
column2: 500 kg (8.3 tons) and travels at 10 km/h (6.2 mph).

column1: * Taitorian (First appears in Round 11) - Weighs in at 4
column2: 100 kg (4.5 tons) and travels at 55 km/h (34.2 mph).

column1: * Fire Bee (First appears in Round 13) - Weighs in at 3
column2: 200 kg (3.5 tons) and travels at 70 km/h (43.5 mph).

column1: * Lady Bug (First appears in Round 17) - Weighs in at 5
column2: 120 kg (5.6 tons) and travels at 60 km/h (37.3 mph).

column1: * Black Pupa (First appears in Round 18) - Weighs in at 400 kg (882 lbs) and travels 20 km/h (12.4 mph).
* Beetle (First appears in Round 18) - Weighs in at 5
column2: 800 kg (6.4 tons) and travels at 55 km/h (34.2 mph).

column1: * Giga (First appears in Round 29) - The heaviest of all enemies. Weighs in at 13
column2: 400 kg (14.8 tons) and travels at 20 km/h (12.4 mph).

column1: * Beecon (First appears in Round 2) - Scores you points whether Motos or an enemy bug bumps it off the solar base.
* Nabicon (First appears in Round 3) - Most of these unleash Blue Pupa at regular intervals.
* Shooting Stars - They fall periodically onto the solar base if you take too much time in a round. They are aimed at Motos and when they miss
column2: they crack square or break a hole in the solar base."

column1: 2409;mouja;mouja;"Moujya (c) 1996 Etona.
;A cross between ""Money Puzzle Exchanger"" and ""Puyo Puyo""."
2410;mouser;mouser;"Mouser (c) 1983 UPL.
2411;mouserc;mouserc;Mouser (c) 1983 UPL.
2412;mpangj;mpangj;Mighty! Pang (c) 2000 Mitchell.
;Mighty! Pang is the fourth game in the superb Pang series. While the artistic design has been drastically changed
column2: Mighty! Pang retains the same gameplay of its predecessors. The game features three modes of play: panic
column3: tour and expert modes.

column1: Tour mode is the standard mode of play featuring 57 stages. The player goes on a tour of the world
column2: popping balloons and picking up power-ups. Each location on the tour features a number of stages which feature a new background of a famous tourist attraction. Each stage is cleared by popping all of the balloons within that stage.

column1: Expert mode is a mode for advanced players.  Play is broken up into stages like in tour mode but the stages are much more difficult.

Panic mode is a basic one-stage mode of play where new balloons continuously fall from the sky. The single stage is a basic one with no platforms or barriers. Some of the smallest balloons will flash and shooting these balloons will pause all of the balloons in place for a short duration of time."
2413;mpatrol;mpatrol;"Moon Patrol (c) 1982 Irem.
;The player controls a moon buggy
column2: viewing it from the side
column3: that travels over the moon's surface. While driving it must avoid obstacles such as craters and mines. The buggy is also attacked by UFOs from above and tanks on the ground.

column1: - CAST OF CHARACTERS -

PLAYER CHARACTER - MOON BUGGY : Your vehicle across the rugged lunar terrain is a specially designed moon buggy. It comes with six wheels on three specially mounted axles that contain especially absorbent shocks which allow the buggy to glide across the uneven landscape of the moon. The wheels of the buggy can be utilized to create short hops
column2: which allow the buggy to jump over pits and other hazardous obstacles that can't be removed in time. It is also equipped with a roof mounted gun for anti-air fire and a forward mounted cannon. The anti-air gun can fire up to four bullets on the screen at one time
column3: while the cannon can only project one bullet at a time. The buggy is destroyed by impact with an obstacle
column4: getting hit by alien craft bombs
column5: or falling into a lunar pit.

column1: ENEMIES ON THE GROUND :
1) Craters and Rocks - Throughout the course of driving on the moon
column2: you will encounter natural terrain obstacles that you must overcome. Nothing more can be done about craters than jumping over them. Most craters are spaced out
column3: but a few come in rapid succession of one another
column4: so jumps must be timed carefully. In addition to craters
column5: you will come across rocks on the landscape. Most rocks are easily dispatched with one shot from your cannon. Sometimes
column6: two rocks occur back to back. If you're fast enough
column7: you can destroy them both. Otherwise
column8: you may opt to jump over the pair. Small rocks lie below the height of your cannon fire. They can only be destroyed if the shot from your cannon detonates near the rock. Otherwise
column9: the shot will sail harmlessly over the rock. When in doubt
column10: jump over the rocks to be safe.

column1: 2) Land Mines - These small objects which flash white and red make their first appearance after point J in the beginner course. Like pits
column2: they can not be destroyed and must be jumped over. They tend to occur in rapid succession
column3: so it is recommended that you travel no faster than regular speed until you are an expert player. When two mines are approximately two moon buggy lengths apart
column4: it is important to jump over the first one considerably early so that you don't land on the second
column5: and have enough time to jump off the ground before you reach it.

column1: 3) Boulders - At certain points along your patrol
column2: the elevation of the moon's surface rises. The first such occurrence is between points P and Q in the beginner course. While you are driving uphill
column3: it is not uncommon to encounter boulders rolling down towards your buggy. Like rocks
column4: these boulders can be rendered harmless with your cannon. Even the small boulders present little challenge thanks to the incline of the surface elevating them to the level of your cannon. But be prepared for a difficult jump if too many come at you at once and you don't have enough time to destroy them all.

column1: 4) Tanks - These first appear after point U in the beginner course. They are stationary
column2: and typically fire one bullet at a time in your direction. Their bullets and the shots from your cannon cancel each other out
column3: so you must immediately fire again in order to hit the tank. Any delay on your part will result in the tank firing once more
column4: preventing you from destroying the tank before you reach it. Tanks can be jumped over if necessary.

column1: 5) Rocket Cars - The first of these appears after point A in the champion course. It will trail behind you until it is ready to strike. Stay fast
column2: and don't do anything until it begins to approach you. When it is half-way between you and the edge of the screen
column3: jump up and let it sail underneath you. Fire as soon as you land to destroy it for 500 points.

column1: 6) Space Plants - A strange type of vegetation exists on the moon
column2: favouring to make their homes in the craters of the lunar surface. They bob in and out of the craters in an effort to catch whatever they can grab. These space plants first appear shortly before point H in the champion course. A shot from the cannon is enough to render the space plant harmless
column3: but the crater must still be leaped over. Attempting to leap over a crater that still contains a space plant can be a dangerous gamble if not timed perfectly.

column1: ENEMIES IN THE AIR
Alien Craft : There are three types of craft that the enemy employs when trying to defeat you from overhead. They all appear in groups ranging from two to five.
1) Regular Craft - These weave back and forth dropping bombs on the buggy. The bombs can be destroyed with your anti-air gun
column2: but they make difficult targets. If this craft is left on the screen for too long in later levels
column3: it may fly down to collide with your buggy.

column1: 2) Elliptical craft - These behave nearly identical to the regular craft. They drop bombs on you with increasing accuracy. The long you remain at a particular speed
column2: the better their shots will get
column3: so make sure to mix your speed up in order to confuse them. Sometimes
column4: you can jump at the last minute and avoid getting hit if the bomb is about to hit the back of your buggy.

column1: 3) Tri-orb craft - This craft
column2: made of three circles bound together
column3: is the deadliest of them all. Rather than dropping normal bombs at the buggy
column4: they pitch terrain deforming grenades at the path ahead of you. You must watch the trajectory of their small flashing grenades and anticipate when you might need to jump as a result of the newly formed pit left by their grenade's impact with the ground. Like the bombs
column5: the grenades can be shot
column6: but they are even harder to hit."

column1: 2414;mpatrolw;mpatrolw;"Moon Patrol (c) 1982 Williams Electronics
column2: Incorporated..

column1:
;Export version by Williams Electronics for North America. Game developed in Japan by Irem. For more information about the game itself, please see the original Irem entry.
2415;mplanets;mplanets;Mad Planets (c) 1983 Gottlieb.

;In Mad Planets, the player takes control of a spaceship and must attempt to destroy a series of Earth-like planets which emerge from the center of the screen and rapidly move towards the player's ship - increasing in size as they do so. Destroying all of the planets in a round before the they reach their full scale will see the player awarded with bonus points. Fully-grown planets are orbited by a number of small moons, which, if destroyed, cause the planet to go 'mad' - turning red and making a beeline for the player's ship. The game also includes bonus rounds in which stranded astronauts can be rescued for additional points.
2416;mplanuk;mplanetsuk;Mad Planets (c) 1983 Gottlieb.

;In Mad Planets, the player takes control of a spaceship and must attempt to destroy a series of Earth-like planets which emerge from the center of the screen and rapidly move towards the player's ship - increasing in size as they do so. Destroying all of the planets in a round before the they reach their full scale will see the player awarded with bonus points. Fully-grown planets are orbited by a number of small moons, which, if destroyed, cause the planet to go 'mad' - turning red and making a beeline for the player's ship. The game also includes bonus rounds in which stranded astronauts can be rescued for additional points.
2417;mp_gaxe2;mp_gaxe2;Golden Axe II (c) 1993 Sega.
;Not long after the malign reign of the Death Adder has ended
column2: another evil rises. The peace of the land has again been threatened
column3: this time by 'Dark Guld'
column4: who was supposed to be imprisoned but apparently is not. He has instead now gotten his hands on the Golden Axe
column5: and is using it for his own nasty purposes
column6: and with his minions is causing much chaos.

column1: So once more
column2: Ax-Battler
column3: the fierce barbarian; Tyris-Flare
column4: the fearless Amazon; Gilius Thunderhead
column5: the ferocious dwarf
column6: rise up to deal with the oppression
column7: with their might and magic
column8: and recover the Golden Axe."

column1: 2418;mp_sonic;mp_sonic;"Sonic The Hedgehog (c) 1993 Sega.
2419;mrdo;mrdo;Mr. Do! (c) 1983 Universal.
;Mr. Do! is a colourful and addictive maze game in which the player takes on the role of the eponymous Mr. Do
column2: a circus clown
column3: who must clear each level of either cherries or monsters. The game's single screen levels are made up of tunnels surrounded by a colourful
column4: soil-like substance. This soil can be dug through to create new tunnels
column5: allowing Mr. Do to escape his enemies and to reach the many cherries that litter the levels. A number of apples are also scattered around each level
column6: and Mr. Do can push them along tunnels (to block and/or kill monsters) or can tunnel beneath them to drop them onto the heads of any pursuing enemies. Mr. Do himself can also be killed by a falling apple.

column1: Mr. Do is armed with a 'Powerball' that can be fired down a tunnel
column2: it will then bounce around the tunnels until it either returns to Mr. Do
column3: or comes into contact with
column4: and kills
column5: one of the level's monsters. The Powerball regenerates immediately the first time you use it
column6: but takes longer each time it is used to return to your hands. As each level progresses
column7: the monsters themselves start to dig tunnels of their own in their pursuit of Mr. Do. Monsters can also push the apples.

column1: Each screen has a doorway through which the monsters enter the level. Once all of the monsters have appeared
column2: the doorway will turn into a 'prize'
column3: (ice cream
column4: biscuits
column5: etc.). If Mr. Do collects the prize
column6: the 'Alphamonster' and his three 'Muncher' henchmen will appear. The Alphamonster may be in the EXTRA box at the top of the screen or be moving around the screen. The Alphamonster and the Munchers cannot be easily crushed under apples because they tend to eat them. They can be killed individually with the Powerball or by killing the Alphamonster itself
column7: at which point any remaining Munchers will turn into apples.

column1: After every three levels
column2: there is a brief intermission in which a tune is played and a large
column3: animated Mr. Do appears
column4: together with some of the game's monsters. The time to complete each level and the preferred method (monsters
column5: cherries
column6: Alphamonsters
column7: or Diamond) is shown. The paths in the first level resemble a 'D'
column8: after this each level's tunnels resemble a digit
column11: '4' etc.) up to '0' for level 10.

column1: A level can be completed any one of several different ways : either by collecting all of the on-screen cherries; by killing all of the monsters
column2: by completing the EXTRA box
column3: or by collecting the diamond. The latter appears only very occasionally ('Special' awards an extra credit)."

column2: Limited.

column1:
;A highly addictive puzzle game in which the player must drill down through an endless onslaught of blocks, attempting to get blocks of the same colour to touch and subsequently make them disappear. 'Undergrounder' bonuses can be picked up for bonus points and air capsules must be collected to restore the player's ever-diminishing air supply.
2424;mrdrilr2;mrdrilr2;Mr. Driller 2 (c) 2000 Namco
column2: Limited.

column1: ;Same as ""Mr Driller""
column2: except now a 2-player game. Anna Hottenmeyer joins Susumu Hori as the world is in peril once again."

column1: 2425;mrdu;mrdu;"Mr. Du! (c) 1982.
2426;mrflea;mrflea;The Amazing Adventures of Mr. F. Lea (c) 1982 Pacific Novelty.

;A four part game where you get Mr. F. Lea where he wants to go (on the back of some lush, tasty dog, of course). You run through lawns and across highways, on the tails of other dogs, and up a hill to get to your destination. Occasionally you even make a run for a dog's head.
2427;mrgoemon;mrgoemon;Mr. Goemon (c) 1986 Konami.
2428;mrheli;mrheli;Mr. Heli no Daibouken (c) 1987 Irem.

;As Mr. Heli in this horizontally scrolling shoot'em up, your mission is to rescue the planet. Clear 6 zones in all, including floating green islands, moving rock beds, underground clock towers, etc.! The incidents which occur one after another are all caused by the psychic power of the muddy. The enemies you encounter on your way are pretty tough. Keep sharp watch for them though they look cute. This is an exciting airfight game with the charm of a cartoon.
2429;mrjong;mrjong;Mr. Jong (c) 1983 Kiwako.

;A puzzle game.
2430;mrkougar;mrkougar;Mr. Kougar (c) 1984 Artic Electronics (ATW).

;The game involves Mr. Kougar having to eat all the dots on the screen. The dots are distributed on several moving platforms, which also are the favorites places of the Banalets, the Kougar's enemies. Touching one of the several eggs on the screen will turn Mr. Kougar invincible and will let a fairy out. The fairy will kill any enemies it touches on it's way to the top of the screen or will free a Banalet, adding one more enemy for Mr. Kougar to defeat.

column1: 2460;msisaac;msisaac;"Metal Soldier Isaac II (c) 1985 Taito Corp.
2461;msjiken;msjiken;Mahjong Satsujin Jiken (c) 10/1988 Nichibutsu.

2463;mslug;mslug;Metal Slug - Super Vehicle-001 (c) 1996 Nazca.
;A scrolling 'run-and-gun' platform game for one or two players
column2: Metal Slug is a humorous parody of war and specifically of World War II and the Nazis.

column1: The game features six enemy-packed levels
column2: referred to as 'missions'. Players start the game armed only with a pistol
column3: but extra weapons can be picked up and used for greater firepower. Also
column4: at certain points during a level players will find an unused 'Super Vehicle-001' - or Metal Slug - tank which can be entered and driven. The Metal Slug is slow-moving but has very powerful weapons. If the Slug takes too many hits it will break down and start to flash
column5: the player must then quickly exit the vehicle before it explodes. The enemy troops also have vehicles at their disposal
column6: such as tanks
column7: boats and helicopters.

column1: The levels are littered with bearded hostages who
column2: when rescued
column3: award players with either points bonuses (in the form of medals) or weapon power-ups. Available weapons are Heavy Machine Gun
column4: Flame Shot
column5: Rocket Launcher and Shotgun. Hand grenades are also available.

column1: Each level ends with at least one large enemy 'Boss' vehicle that takes many hits to destroy. Once the boss has been destroyed
column2: bonus points are awarded for each prisoner rescued. Further bonus points are awarded if the player's Metal Slug vehicle has survived the boss battle."

column1: 2464;mslug2;mslug2;"Metal Slug 2 - Super Vehicle-001/II (c) 1998 SNK [Shin Nihon Kikaku].
;The heroes of Metal Slug
column2: Marco and Tarma
column3: are called into action once again to take on the might of General Morden and his armies in this
column4: the first of several sequels to the superb 1996 original. This time
column5: however
column6: Morden has acquired a number of powerful allies to aid him in his evil schemes
column7: some of which are not even human. The 2 brave soldiers are called upon to deal with this threat once again
column8: aided by members of the newly founded 'Sparrow Squad'
column9: Fio and Eri.

column1: Metal Slug 2 improved on much of what made the first game great; featuring more enemies
column2: larger bosses
column3: more weapons
column4: more vehicles
column5: more hostages
column6: more surprises and more humour than its illustrious predecessor. The occasional moments of slowdown that blighted the first game are still present
column7: however."

column1: 2465;mslug3;mslug3;"Metal Slug 3 (c) 2000 SNK.

;The heroes of the first 2 games return once more to do battle with the ever-present General Morden and his vast army. The third game of the series places a greater emphasis on defeating hulking boss characters than the 2 previous outings. Metal Slug 3 also introduced multiple routes through most levels
column2: vastly increasing the replay value of the game. For example; on the first level the player reaches a point where they can either continue over land
column3: or enter a small submarine and head down into the ocean depths
column4: where they will be faced with a variety of huge
column5: deadly sea-dwelling creatures.

column1: Metal Slug 3 introduced a number of new elements that have a direct effect on the player's character - similar to the 'mummification' of the second game. The first of these is the 'fatty' affect : should the player pick up too much food (fish
column2: for example) their character will morph in an obese version of itself. This doesn't have any detrimental effect on performance and is included purely for reasons of humour. Another effect is the now infamous 'Zombiefication'; should the player's character be attacked by a Zombie
column3: he or she will become Zombie until they are either killed
column4: or pick up a first-aid
column5: which will restore the player's character back to human form. Movement while in the zombie state is slow and restricted but the player is armed with what can perhaps be best described as the 'Zombie Vomit'; a huge arc of blood that can be used to destroy oncoming enemies. A second Zombie attack while the player's character is in a Zombie state will result in the player losing a life."

column1: 2466;mslug3n;mslug3h;;
2467;mslugx;mslugx;"Metal Slug X - Super Vehicle-001 (c) 1999 SNK.
;Originally released to improve upon some of the problems the previous Metal Slug game (""Metal Slug 2 - Super Vehicle-001/II"") had
column2: most notably its notorious slowdown
column3: this update also implemented several changes to beef up the gameplay
column4: such as new enemies
column5: a different end boss layout and a number of new weapons and secrets. The result is a better game and one of the finest chapters in this series."

column1: 2468;mspacmab;mspacmab;"Ms. Pac-Man (c) 1981 Midway.
;In this
column2: the first proper sequel to Namco's legendary pill eating maze game
column3: players must once again run around a number of mazes
column4: eating all of the pills that are scattered throughout. The ever-present ghosts (Blinky
column5: Pinky
column6: Inky and Sue) return to hamper the player's progress. The infamous 'Power Pills' are also present and correct
column7: with four appearing in each maze.

column1: Namco introduced a number of changes and enhancements over the original game. The first difference is in the main character. For the first time in video-game history
column2: the game's lead character was female. Ms. Pac-Man is almost identical to the original character with two main differences; she wears a bow in her 'hair'
column3: and is also wearing lipstick.

column1: Another change from the original is that the bonus fruit items are no longer static but now move randomly around the mazes.
Ms Pac-Man features four different maze layouts
column2: which alternate every two to four rounds :

column1: The first maze is only encountered in Rounds 1 and 2
column2: and has 220 dots and 4 Power Pills. There are two sets of tunnels in this maze equidistant from the center of the maze. You must clear this maze two times before moving on to the next maze.

column1: The second maze is only encountered in Rounds 3
column3: and 5
column4: and has 240 dots and 4 Power Pills. There are two sets of tunnels in this maze; one set in the lower half
column5: and the other set at the very top. You must clear this maze three times before moving on to the next maze.

column1: The third maze is first encountered in Round 6 and has 238 dots and 4 Power Pills. Unlike all other mazes
column2: there is only one set of tunnels in this maze
column3: slightly above the center of the board. You must clear this maze four times before moving on to the next maze.

column1: The fourth and final unique maze is first encountered in Round 10 and has 234 dots and 4 Power Pills. There are two sets of tunnels in this maze
column2: directly next to one another in the middle of the maze. The turns at the entrance to the tunnels change the usual immediate accessibility of the tunnels and should be taken in to account. You must clear this maze four times before moving on to the next maze.

column1: After Round 13
column2: the game alternates every four rounds between the third and fourth mazes.

column1: Finally
column2: the ghosts' movement patterns are also completely different from those of the original game.

column1: As in the original game
column2: intermission scenes will be played after certain rounds. Ms. Pac-Man's intermissions tell the story of how Pac-Man and Ms. Pac-Man met
column3: fell in love
column4: and had a baby. Ms. Pac-Man's intermissions are also preceded by a sign and a title. 3 intermissions are present :

column1: 1) Act I - They Meet : Pac-Man
column2: the star of the original game
column3: enters the screen being chased by Inky while Ms. Pac-Man enters from the other side being chased by Pinky. As the two of them are about to collide
column4: they quickly move upwards
column5: causing Inky and Pinky to collide. Pac-Man and Ms. Pac-Man face each other at the top of the screen
column6: and a heart appears above them. This intermission is played after Round 2.

column1: 2) Act II - The Chase : Pac-Man and Ms. Pac-Man are seen giving each other a playful chase. One chases the other in one direction
column2: and they take turns alternating who chases who and in what direction. After three turns
column3: they chase each other twice more at a faster speed. This intermission is played after Round 5.

column1: 3) Act III - Junior : Pac-Man and Ms. Pac-Man anxiously await the arrival of a stork
column2: who flies overhead with a bundle. As the stork is about to pass over them
column3: he releases the bundle
column4: which drops to the ground in front of Pac-Man and Ms. Pac-Man
column5: and opens up to reveal a baby Pac. This intermission
column6: which is played after Rounds 9
column8: and 17
column9: would later serve as the introductory sequence to ""Jr. Pac-Man"".

column1: No intermission is present between rounds after the 18th one."

2470;mspacmat;mspacmat;"Ms. Pac Attack (c) 1981.
;Basically this game is ""Pac-Man""
column2: with a few minor differences. The major difference is that the ghosts have fewer restrictions on their movement
column3: making them more formidable. Also adding to the challenge are the different mazes and the fact that the fruit no longer stays in one place
column4: but moves in
column5: out and around the maze. Fortunately there is a power pellet in each corner that (usually) turns the ghosts blue for a period of time
column6: allowing you to eat them for points.

column1: The main difference being the order of levels has been changed. As in the regular ""Ms. Pac-Man"" game
column2: the maze turns invisible at a certain point. However
column3: in Ms. Pac Attacks
column4: this point is reached much earlier - at about the 144th screen instead of the 255th."

column1: 2474;mswordj;mswordj;"Magic Sword - Heroic Fantasy (c) 1990 Capcom Company
column2: Limited.

column1: ;The land has been cast in darkness by Drokmar
column2: who has been corrupted by the Black Orb; an artefact that promises immortality to anyone who comes under the influence of the orb's powerful sorcery. Two warriors set out to fight their way through fifty levels of platform beat-em-up
column3: in order to destroy the orb - which lies at the top of the Dragon Tower - and free their lands.

column1: Treasure chests litter the levels which
column2: when smashed open
column3: release treasure items
column4: magic power-ups
column5: keys
column6: food and weapons. As players fight their way through the levels
column7: they will come across a number of trapped prisoners. As long as the heroes are carrying keys
column8: prisoners can be released who will then fight alongside the players
column9: with each prisoner possessing their own unique attacks. Weapons and power-ups can be picked up to aid players in their quest and food can be found and eaten to increase player health.

column1: As the players ascend the tower
column2: they will be granted new magical weapons after each boss they defeat. The player's weapons are affected by a 'magic bar' that charges over time. When fully charged
column3: the weapon has a powerful ranged attack
column4: but when not charged only a close attack is produced. A magical staff will grant increased range attack ability. A magical blast may be generated by pressing the Attack and Jump buttons at once
column5: but costs health.

column1: There are multiple paths in the game
column2: and two separate endings. Hidden doors can be used to skip levels when found - usually by attacking a wall or a particular spot."

column1: 2532;myqbert;myqbert;"Q*bert (c) 1982 Gottlieb.

;The object of the Q*bert game is to change the color of the top of the cubes to the Destination Color indicated at the upper-left corner of the screen (below Player 1's score) by hopping onto them. When all the cubes in the pyramid have been changed to the Destination Color
column2: the screen will advance to the next round
column3: with the player-controlled Q*bert character starting back on the top cube. At the beginning of each level
column4: there will be a short demonstration cycle with Q*bert hopping around four cubes to explain to the player the play action of each level. Each level consists of four rounds. The current level number and round number is displayed at the upper-right corner of the screen (below Player 2's score in a 2-player game).

column1: Gameplay starts with Q*bert appearing at the top of the pyramid. The joystick will move Q*bert from cube to cube by hopping in any of four diagonal directions. Q*bert can move anywhere on the pyramid
column2: but jumping off will kill him. Hopping onto a rotating disk will take Q*bert back to the top of the pyramid. In the first two rounds of play
column3: Q*bert will have to avoid touching the red and purple balls. These deadly objects drop randomly onto the second-from-the-top row of the pyramid and bounce downwards. The red balls will fall off the bottom
column4: but the purple ball will stop at the bottom and hatch into Coily
column5: the snake which chases Q*bert. To get rid of Coily
column6: lure him to the edge
column7: then jump unto a disk. The disk will take Q*bert back to the top and Coily will fall off
column8: awarding 500 points and clearing the board of all other 'nasty' characters.

column1: Starting at the third round of play
column2: other 'nasty' characters come into play. The green characters or objects are safe to hop onto and will award points. All other 'nasty' characters are deadly to touch. In the third round the red balls will stop falling
column3: but two purple characters named Ugg and Wrong Way will appear at the lower portion of the pyramid and travel sideways and upwards (Ugg is the one with the snout moving from right to left on the right face of the cubes
column4: and Wrong Way is the one with the big eyes moving from left to right on the left face of the cubes). They will not chase Q*bert
column5: but will move randomly to get in Q*bert's way. In the third round and every round after
column6: based on an internal timer
column7: a green ball will appear and bounce down from the top of the pyramid. Hopping Q*bert onto the green ball will award 100 points
column8: and freeze all the 'nasty' characters on the screen for a few seconds
column9: but 'Q*bert' will still be able to move to complete the color changes.

column1: During the fourth round of play
column2: two green characters named Slick and Sam will appear
column3: based on the internal timer (Slick is the one wearing shades; Sam does not wear shades
column4: otherwise their function is identical). They will drop onto the second-from-the-top row of the pyramid and hop randomly downwards. If they hop onto a cube that Q*bert has already changed the color of
column5: the cube will change to a different color to thwart Q*bert. Hopping Q*bert onto Slick or Sam will stop them and award 300 points.

column1: Throughout the remaining rounds
column2: all the characters and objects will appear in random combinations with increasing speed.

column1: To add variety to the game
column2: the Flying Discs will change positions every round
column3: and in the higher levels the number of Flying Discs will change.

column1: During Level 2
column2: the play action will increase in difficulty from changing the cubes to one color
column3: to changing the color of the cubes twice. This means that each cube would have to be hopped on twice to change the pyramid to the Destination Color
column4: completing the Round.

column1: Starting at Level 3 and for all remaining rounds
column2: and levels
column3: the play action will become more difficult. The object remains to change the cubes to the Destination Color
column4: but if Q*bert hops on any cube
column5: that cube will change color. So even if the cube has already been changed to the Destination Color
column6: it will change again.

column1: Here is a rundown of how all the colors change :
Legend :
S - Starting Color
I - Intermediate Color
D - Destination Color
LEVEL 1 : When Q*bert jumps on S or I
column2: it changes to D. When he jumps on D
column3: it stays at D (NOTE : During the fourth round
column4: when Slick/Sam jumps on D
column5: it changes to I).

column1: LEVEL 2 : When Q*bert jumps on S
column2: it changes to I. When he jumps on I
column3: it changes to D. When he jumps on D
column4: it stays at D.

column1: LEVEL 3 : When Q*bert jumps on S
column2: it changes to D. When he jumps on D
column3: it changes back to S. Q*bert must start again.

column1: LEVEL 4 : When Q*bert jumps on S
column2: it changes to I. When he jumps on I
column3: it changes to D. When he jumps on D
column4: it changes back to I. Q*bert must start again.

column1: LEVEL 5 : When Q*bert jumps on S
column2: it changes to I. When he jumps on I
column3: it changes to D. When he jumps on D
column4: it changes back to S. Q*bert must start again.

column1: LEVELS 6-9 : Same color pattern as Level 5. The difference is the increased speed of Q*bert and the 'nasty' characters.
There are also bonus points awarded at the end of each round for successfully completing the round. The bonus for the completion of the 1st round is 1
column2: 000 points. This Bonus will progressively increase each Round by 250 points to a maximum of 5
column3: 000 points at Level 5."

column1: 2533;mysticm;mysticm;"Mystic Marathon (c) 1984 Williams.

;The object of Mystic Marathon is to guide an elvish looking goblin in some sort of overland race. In most arcade games if you made a mistake you would lose a life, but in Mystic Marathon making a mistake, any mistake, simply meant it was impossible to win the race. Bump into something, oops, can't win. Choose the wrong path, can't win. Press jump at the wrong time, can't win.

2537;mystwarr;mystwarr;Mystic Warriors - Ikari no Ninja (c) 1993 Konami.
;Mystic Warriors is a horizontally-scrolling platform beat-em-up for up to four players
column2: in which the evil 'SKULL' organisation has taken over the world and driven its terrified civilians into hiding. Five Ninja warriors set about destroying SKULL and freeing the World from its grip.

column1: Mystic Warriors features five selectable characters
column2: one of which is shown being kidnapped by SKULL once players have made their character choices. What follows is eight levels of platform 'run-and-gun' action
column3: with an end-of-level boss waiting at the end of each stage.

column1: Players are armed with both Shuriken throwing stars and with a sword for close encounters. Numerous boxes are scattered throughout the levels (or are being carried by enemies)
column2: all of which contain bonus items such as weapon power-ups or energy-replenishing food. Other power-ups include an invulnerability shield (known as the ""Shinobi Shield"") which lasts a few seconds and a ""Smart Bomb"" power-up
column3: which destroys all on-screen enemies. Some boxes also contain points-giving items
column4: such as bags of money
column5: jewellery and gold."

column1: 2539;nam1975;nam1975;"NAM-1975 (c) 1990 SNK [Shin Nihon Kikaku].
;One or two players take control of 2 machine-gun carrying Vietnam vets who must shoot their way through a number of sideways scrolling
column2: Vietnam-themed levels. the players shoot into the screen and aiming is achieved via the use an on-screen target
column3: which each player directs to lock on to the various enemy troops and vehicles. Players can run and somersault to avoid the incoming enemy fire.

column1: A number of more powerful weapons - such as grenades and flame throwers - are often dropped by the enemy and can be picked up and used. Bonus points are also revealed in this fashion.
Nam-1975 is a blatant plagiarism of TAD Corp's ""Cabal""
column2: released in September 1988. Cabal is easily the more accomplished of the two games."

column1: 2540;nametune;nametune;"Name That Tune (c) 1986 Bally Sente.

;The game itself was an almost exact translation of the 1980s incarnation of the gameshow. It was all colors and text, and the only animation in it was a little hand that played notes on a piano. The interface had to be simple, as they used up all the ROM space on the different songs.

column1: ;NARC is a graphically violent one or two-player side-scrolling shoot-em-up in which players take on the role of ""Narcs""; futuristic police officers whose duty it is to either arrest or kill drug dealers
column2: junkies and attack dogs as players fight to crush the criminal empire known as K.R.A.K.

column1: The Narcs have both machine guns and rocket launchers at their disposal and players can also pick up (confiscate) discarded drugs and money to earn extra points. These are totaled up at the end of each level. On many stages a special colour-specific 'Keycard' needs to be found before players can progress to the next section of the level.
Narc's stages are as follows:
* The Junkyard
* K.R.A.K. Street
* The Bridge
* Sunset Strip
* Skyhigh's Nursery
* Downtown
* Red Level 1
* Blue Level 2
* Mr. Big's Office
* Inner Sanctum
* Jackpot!"

2549;naughtya;naughtyba;Naughty Boy (c) 1982 Jaleco.
;A maze/shooting game.
On this fun game the player controls a naughty boy who goes through the forest and must defend himself throwing rocks at monsters to destroy them. The longer you hold down the fire button
column2: the farther your character can throw rocks. The boy must avoid a variety of monsters and obstacles while attempting to make it to the top of each level and proceed on to the next. There are a number of flags at the top of each level on a fortress that must be destroyed in order to proceed to next level.

column1: Occasionally
column2: there is a bonus round where your character fly back and forth at the top of the screen in a hot-air balloon in an attempt to drop rocks down upon a big monster that is running at the bottom of the screen to hit directly over his head. There is a fuel gauge that determines when the bonus round will end."

column1: 2570;nebulbee;nebulbee;;
2571;nebulray;nebulray;"Nebulasray (c) 1994 Namco.
;NebulasRay is a vertically scrolling shoot'em up for one or two players. Civil war has broken out in the Austral star system
column2: with the militaristic 'Master Forces' ousting the ruling government and looking to seize control of the entire system.

column1: Taking on the role of resistance fighters
column2: players must battle through waves of enemy ships across 6 levels
column3: before finally reaching and destroying the 'Master Fortress'. As well as forward-firing weapons
column4: each player ship also carries a limited number of powerful bombs that inflict much greater damage on the enemy than the standard weapons. Initially
column5: each player ship is armed with only 3 bombs.

column1: Numerous weapons and power-ups can be picked up during play
column2: each of which can itself be powered-up:

column1: * WIDE SHOT - Increases shot width. 5 levels available.
* GAIN POWER - Increases destructive power. 5 levels available.
* SPEED UP - Increases player ship speed. 5 levels available.
* BOMB - Extra bomb. Maximum of 7 can be carried.
* FOUR-BARREL PHOTON - Powerful Photon torpedoes. Time-based.
* HOMING LASER - Powerful lasers that automatically target enemies. Time-based.
* LIGHTING BURST - Powerful short-range lightning burst. Time-based.
* DEFLECTOR - Shield to protect player ships. Time-based.
* EXTRA POINTS - Pick up for 3000 points.
Visually
column2: NebulasRay employs complex sprite rotation and scaling techniques - as well as multi-layered parallax scrolling - to create impressive and highly detailed graphics with a true sense of depth."

2583;neogeo;neogeo;Neo-Geo MVS (c) 1990 SNK Corp.

;A cartridge-based arcade system board. The MVS stands for Multi Video System, and as its name suggest, offers owners the ability to put up to six different arcade titles into a single cabinet, a key economic consideration for operators with limited floorspace. With its games stored on self-contained cartridges, a game cabinet can be exchanged for a different game title by swapping the game's ROM-cartridge and cabinet artwork.

column1: 2588;newpuc2;newpuc2;"Newpuc2 (c) 1980 Kamiya.

Newpuc2 is a hack of ""PuckMan"". It has :
* Intermissions from the original ""PuckMan"" between each maze.
* A 'slot machine' every 3 mazes which determines which type of maze (invisible/visible) will come up next.
* There are two maze variants :
The first is a visible blue maze with five exits on each side and a modified maze layout from the original ""PuckMan"".
The second maze is invisible except for the borders and the dots
column2: but has a slightly different layout than the visible maze and has only three exits on each side.

;Night Striker is a 3-D shoot-em-up rendered with fast moving
column2: sprite-scaled graphics. Players must guide an armoured hover car through a number of scrolling levels - destroying waves of enemies in the process - in an attempt to rescue a scientist who has been kidnapped by a terrorist organization. A large guardian awaits players at the end of each level
column3: with each one taking several hits to destroy.

column1: Instead of having a set number of lives
column2: the player's vehicle is equipped with a shield that depletes whenever the player is hit by enemy fire or has collisions with either enemies or scenery. The player's shields are recharged at the end of every level.

column1: Night Striker takes its influences from many landmark games of the sprite scaling genre
column2: all of which are Sega releases. The basic shoot-em-up gameplay is similar in style to both 1985's ""Space Harrier"" and 1987's ""Thunder Blade"". Some of the game's levels resemble those of 1988's ""Galaxy Force II"" as well as ""Thunder Blade""
column3: while the game's level structure - a 'pyramid' of levels that allows players to chose their own route through the game with the use of end-of-level forked roads - is borrowed from the 1986 classic
column4: ""Out Run""."

;Naughty Mouse, also known as Woodpecker, is a platform arcade game where the player must take control of Naughty Mouse, who must make it from his own house at the bottom of the screen to his girlfriend's house at the top. There are several differently colored woodpeckers that hatch from the large eggs positioned on the left and right sides of the screen, which set out to stop him. The player has a single button with which to make Naughty Mouse jump over them. Some of the ladders may also become electrified after Naughty Mouse has climbed them, forbidding him to go back down them again on pain of death. Once he has reached his girlfriend's house, he will receive the stage's remaining time as bonus points and proceed to the next stage. The main difference between Naughty Mouse and Woodpecker is the color palettes, and stage arrangements.

2649;numanath;numanath;Numan Athletics (c) 1993 Namco.
;An athletics game featuring 8 tournaments :
Interceptor
A real life missile defense style-contest as missiles are being launched from a ship
column2: and you must use your mystical powers to stop the oncoming missiles. The outside buttons (1 & 3) make you step to the left or right
column3: and the middle button is fire. Failure to hit the missile results in you being blown up. If you select Sharon from France
column4: most of her clothes would disappear except for the bottom part of her suit.

column1: Niagara Jumps

The final competition in the tournament. It is also considered to be the most difficult competition in the game. Very similar to the Triple Jump competition in the Olympics. The object is this contest is to make it across the falls. Alternately press buttons 1 and 3 to build up speed
column2: then press button 2 three times. If you don't time yourself properly
column3: you will sink and drown and you will go down the steep falls.

column1: Nonstop Rock Chop
You must smash as many rocks as you can before time runs out. Rapidly press buttons 1 and 3 alternately until the gauge is full
column2: then press button 2 to smash the rock.

column1: Numan Sniper
In this contest
column2: monsters will jump out of the sea from three different locations. Your object
column3: destroy them. Press buttons 1
column4: 2 or 3 varying by their location to shoot.

column1: Scud Toss

Just as in the Javelin competition in the Olympics. Played on a ""Track and Field""-like field with an only exception -- a missile. Rapidly and continuously press the two run buttons and then push and hold the middle button to set the angle of which you would throw the missile. Again
column2: like Interceptor
column3: if you select Sharon -- then again if she is faulted
column4: she will be missing most of her clothes.

column1: Tower Topper
Here you are expected to climb up to the building rooftop with the fastest time possible. Press button 2 repeatedly to scale the side of a building. If you press it too early -- you won't move
column2: but if you press it too late -- you will fall off.

column1: Turbo Dash

Much like the 100m Dash in the Olympics -- only the core elements have slightly changed. You are racing against a drag racer and another player. Press the two outside buttons (1 & 3) in alternate fashion until your RSI (or 'special speed') sets in.
VS. Express

Very similar to a familiar scene in the Superman comic books. You must stop the oncoming train using your magical powers and send it in the opposite direction backwards. Press button 2 to stop the train
column2: then hammer the outside buttons to build up power before bunging it back down the track. If you don't time this right -- the train will run you over."

;In his never ending quest for adventure and excitement
column2: man invented off-road racing. These races were then brought before the masses by converting huge sports stadiums into dirt and mud obstacle courses in which off-road 'Ironmen' battled for top honors.

column1: Now the Leland Corporation brings this fast moving
column2: hard driving sport to the video game arena.

column1: Ironman Ivan Stewart's Super Off-Road is stadium off-road racing at it's best. One to three players are asked to test their dirt track skills against the best dirt truck driver in the world.
Contestants compete on eight different tracks with a total of 16 configurations and these courses are packed with enough jumps
column2: bumps
column3: hills
column4: and holes to challenge even the most skillful driver.

column1: Winning drivers earn 'cash' prizes
column2: and use this 'cash' to 'buff out' their machines. At the end of each race
column3: players take their trucks to the 'Speed Shop' to buy better shocks
column4: tires
column5: engines
column6: and higher top speed. They can also buy nitro packs to help them blast over the jumps and through the mud.

column1: The 'Convert-a-Credit' feature allows drivers to add to their winnings by using credits as 'cash'. Each additional quarter
column2: when converted
column3: becomes $200
column4: 000 in game 'cash' and this additional 'cash' may be used for purchases in the 'Speed Shop'."

column1: 2662;offtwalc;offtwallc;"Off The Wall (c) 1991 Atari Games Corp.
;Off the Wall is an arcade game produced by Atari and released in North America in 1991. A modern remake of Breakout
column2: this game introduces many new gameplay features to the bat-and-ball genre
column3: and it incorporates some elements from Pong as well. It supports up to three players simultaneously (though most cabinets only support two)
column4: and the game's graphics include many backgrounds modeled after modern abstract art.

column1: The objective of Off the Wall is to score as many points as possible by destroying square blocks in a never-ending series of levels. The player controls a paddle using an analog knob or a joystick (depending on the machine configuration). The paddle moves along one edge of the playfield
column2: and a ball flies around the playfield and bounces off the walls and the paddle. When a ball hits a block
column3: the block disappears (unless it is indestructible). A square exit is placed on the screen
column4: and directing the ball into this exit causes all remaining blocks on the screen to self-destruct
column5: awarding bonus points and advancing the player(s) to the next level.

column1: The ball occasionally splits in two (in multiplayer games
column2: three balls may be on the screen at once)
column3: and the player can put spin on the ball
column4: causing it to move in a curved trajectory. The player loses a life when the last ball on the screen moves past the player's paddle
column5: though in some circumstances
column6: the game gives the player a second chance. The game is over when the player has lost all of his or her lives.

column1: As levels progress
column2: the game introduces new features that make the game more complex and challenging. These features include blocks that move randomly or in circles
column3: various powerups
column4: indestructible blocks and bombs
column5: blocks that parachute or fly in to replace destroyed blocks
column6: objects that change the ball's speed and trajectory
column7: and guns that can shrink the players' paddles. Depending on the number of players in the game
column8: some levels may be skipped due to the exit being along one player's edge of the playfield. In multiplayer games
column9: a bonus round occurs periodically where players compete directly against one another in an exact clone of Pong. The winning player earns an extra life."

column1: 2663;offtwall;offtwall;"Off The Wall (c) 1991 Atari Games Corp.
;Off the Wall is an arcade game produced by Atari and released in North America in 1991. A modern remake of Breakout
column2: this game introduces many new gameplay features to the bat-and-ball genre
column3: and it incorporates some elements from Pong as well. It supports up to three players simultaneously (though most cabinets only support two)
column4: and the game's graphics include many backgrounds modeled after modern abstract art.

column1: The objective of Off the Wall is to score as many points as possible by destroying square blocks in a never-ending series of levels. The player controls a paddle using an analog knob or a joystick (depending on the machine configuration). The paddle moves along one edge of the playfield
column2: and a ball flies around the playfield and bounces off the walls and the paddle. When a ball hits a block
column3: the block disappears (unless it is indestructible). A square exit is placed on the screen
column4: and directing the ball into this exit causes all remaining blocks on the screen to self-destruct
column5: awarding bonus points and advancing the player(s) to the next level.

column1: The ball occasionally splits in two (in multiplayer games
column2: three balls may be on the screen at once)
column3: and the player can put spin on the ball
column4: causing it to move in a curved trajectory. The player loses a life when the last ball on the screen moves past the player's paddle
column5: though in some circumstances
column6: the game gives the player a second chance. The game is over when the player has lost all of his or her lives.

column1: As levels progress
column2: the game introduces new features that make the game more complex and challenging. These features include blocks that move randomly or in circles

column8: some levels may be skipped due to the exit being along one player's edge of the playfield. In multiplayer games
column9: a bonus round occurs periodically where players compete directly against one another in an exact clone of Pong. The winning player earns an extra life."

;While similar to most vertical scrolling shooters
column2: Omega Fighter is unique in its gameplay
column3: level and enemy focus: rather than flying through multiple levels

column1: There are two weapons that the player picks up
column2: and if the player picks up a different powerup
column3: it will always reset to its lowest level:

column1: (I) - Ion Laser: Shoots straight
column2: pick up more to increase damage at a cost of decreasing length. Ideal for close combat.

column1: (W) - Wide Shot: Shoots bullets in wider range when collecting more of them. Ideal for taking enemies from afar but deals less damage.
There are also two items that are pressed by the bomb button
column2: and players may pick up to two of them:

column1: Silver - Activate to slow down everything on screen. Useful to dodge bullets and getting closer for higher score.

column2: score depends on closeness to player prior to using the item."

column1: You begin your training with a small number of droid ships in the first wave of attackers and gradually build your skill until there is a maximum number of 12 attacking droid ships per wave. These attaching ships not only move independently and fire at you
column2: they also drop two different kinds of space mines to block your path and your shots at them.

column1: As your skill level increases
column2: the speed with which the droid ships attack is gradually increased and their shots at you become more accurate.

column1: Bonus ships are awarded to you periodically throughout the game as you reach or pass certain preselected point values. Each enemy ship and mine has a point value.
The object of the game is to survive as long as possible while destroying as many attacking droid ships and space mines as you can. As you do this
column2: each following wave of attackers will be harder to destroy."

;Operation Wolf 3 is a light-gun controlled shoot-em-up in which a terrorist organization known as 'SKULL' has taken over an island and are armed with nuclear missiles. Two agents
column2: codenamed 'Hornet' and 'Queen Bee' (players one and two respectively) are dispatched by the United Nations taskforce
column3: 'Federation for Freedom'
column4: and must take down the SKULL organisation and disarm the nuclear missiles.

column1: Unlike the limited ammo found in the first game in the series
column2: players now have unlimited ammo. As long as the trigger is squeezed
column3: weapons will fire on full automatic. Once the ammo meter is depleted
column4: the rate of fire decreases sharply. When the trigger is released
column5: the meter instantly refills. Players can also carry a limited supply of grenades
column6: although only three bombs can be carried at any one time
column7: as opposed to the nine of the first game. As players progress through the stages
column8: various power-ups can be found
column9: such as stronger weapons and extra grenades.

column1: A bonus round appears after every second stage. This consists of a shooting gallery and players must hit as many targets as possible to earn bonus points.
The game's five stages are:
* Warehouse
* Expressway
* Wasteland
* The Tower of Them (Missile silo)
* Final stage - A nuclear missile has launched and must be destroyed mid-flight."

2690;orbit;orbit;Orbit (c) 1978 Atari.
;GAME LEVELS. The game level can be selected at the beginning of the game or after game select button has been pressed. Press the buttons from 1 to 10.
BEGINNER: Instant start/stop when pressing forward. Level Options :
1. Slow (Starship and Shells)
2. Medium (Starship and Shells)
3. Fast (Starship and Shells)
INTERMEDIATE: Accelerates to full speed when forward pushbutton pressed. Partial breaking when forward pushbutton released. Level Options :
4. Slow (Starship and Shells)
5. Fast (Starship and Shells)
EXPERT: Acceleration to full speed when forward pushbutton pressed. Level Options:
6. Fast shells (Shells only)
7. Slow (Starship and Shells)
8. Medium (Starship and Shells)
9. Fast (Starship and Shells)
SUPER EXPERT: Same as Expert
column2: with a strong gravity option. Level Options :

column1: 10. Fast (Starship and Shells)
GAME OPTIONS: These toggles can be selected at any time during play by pressing the buttons from 1 to 8.
1. Bounce Back - Sets boundaries around perimeter of the TV monitor screen. Example: Starship immediately reverses direction after reaching boundary. Normally perimeter boundaries do not exist.
2. Negative Gravity - Sun radiates gravity outward to perimeter boundaries of the TV monitor screen. Normal sun state radiates positive gravity (positive gravity is inward toward the sun).
3. Zero Gravity - Sun does not radiate gravity.
4. Black Hole - Invisible sun with any selected gravity.
5. Space Stations - Two space stations orbit around sun. Each player is designated a specific space station on which he may land for repairs
column2: fuel and shells. When player starship touches opponent's station it is immediate annihilation.

column1: 6. Unlimited Supplies - Unlimited fuel and ordnance (fire power).
7. Stars - Remove stars from playfield.
8. Strong Gravity - Unusually strong positive gravity."

;A platform 'versus' shoot'em up in which either one player (playing against the computer) or two players (playing against each other) attempt to destroy each other by any means necessary. The levels themselves are interesting and varied
column2: with airships
column3: planes etc. providing a detailed and highly interactive backdrop in which the players do battle. That interactivity is increased further with the introduction of destructible sections which
column4: when blown up
column5: can often open up new areas or rooms. Each level is littered with a variety of weapons that can be picked up and utilized by the player(s). Graphically
column6: Outfoxies employed superb sprite scale and rotation techniques that elevated the already fun gameplay still further. The aeroplane level
column7: for instance
column8: dips and sways
column9: bringing problems of inertia and gravity to the platform action. Also; the in-game camera zooms in and out of the level
column10: depending on how far away the two opponents are from each other. Playable characters range from a monkey to a pair of psychotic school children
column11: with each character choice offering the player different aptitudes (the monkey can jump higher
column12: for example). A fun enough game in one-player mode
column13: Outfoxies really came into its own when two human protagonists took part."

column1: ;Out Run is a ground-breaking racing game in which the player drives a red Ferrari Testarossa through a number of colourful European locations
column2: trying to reach each end-of-level checkpoint before the tight time limit expires.

column1: Each of the game's stages is packed with civilian traffic that must be carefully avoided
column2: as players try to negotiate the game's twisting
column3: hilly roads.

column1: At the end of every stage players are presented with a fork in the road
column2: allowing them to chose which route they wish to take next. This was not the first time this feature had appeared (Tatsumi's 1983 racer
column3: TX-1
column4: was the first to introduce forked roads).

column1: As well as being able to choose routes
column2: players could also - via the game's ""in-car radio"" - choose one of three different catchy tunes to listen to while driving. The songs are 'Magical Sound Shower'
column3: 'Passing Breeze' and 'Splash Wave'."

column1: 2721;p47;p47;"P-47 - The Phantom Fighter (c) 1988 Jaleco.
;P-47 is a two-dimensional
column2: scrolling shooter type of game. You play as the pilot of a P-47. Your mission is to basically destroy as many of the enemies as you possibly can. This means eliminating as many air and ground units as you can. You will be going through four missions (each being broken up into two parts) and at the end of each of these parts is an enemy boss for you to tangle with. Although you have unlimited ammunition
column3: the enemy will make you pay for the invasion into their homeland. You will be able to accomplish this with various power-ups and also a second player (if they buy in). Your mission won't be easy but it is necessary so you can secure both the skies and ground for our troops.

column1: The game is broken up into four missions. Within these four missions
column2: there are 2 parts. One part involves going over land and the other part has you either going over water or being up in the air. Regardless of which part you are on
column3: you will still have to deal with the same basic things. After part two of mission four
column4: the missions will repeat again with mission one."

2728;pacland;pacland;Pac-Land (c) 1984 Namco.
;Pac-Land is a horizontally-scrolling platform game set in the cartoon world of the game's title. A fairy has lost her way and needs Pac-Man to help her get back to her home of Fairyland. Pac-Man
column2: with the fairy safely hidden beneath his hat
column3: must run and jump through the colourful world until he reaches and enters the magical door to Fairyland. Upon being rescued
column4: the fairy gives Pac-Man a pair of magical shoes for his trip back home. These enable him to jump wherever he wants
column5: without the need for a platform to jump from. This effectively means Pac-Man can 'sky-jump' back home if he so wishes.

column1: Directional buttons make Pac-Man walk left and right and it's possible to make him run by tapping the desired directional button twice. Pac-Man is pursued by his ever-present enemies in the form of five ghosts - Pinky
column2: Inky
column3: Blinky
column4: Clyde and Sue. Pac-Man must avoid the ghosts and other deadly objects that populate the levels. As with previous games in the series
column5: a small number of 'Powerpills' appear. Eating a Powerpill makes Pac-Man temporarily invincible and turns the ghosts purple and vulnerable to being eaten. On some stages
column6: Pac-Man must use a springboard to jump over large ponds by leaping from the springboard and rapidly moving left and right while in the air.

column1: The game's stages are called 'trips'
column2: with players able to start on any one of the first five. Each trip made up of four rounds (three rounds to reach Fairyland and one round to return home) with a short interval between each one. The objective in all trips is to get the fairy safely back to Fairyland then return home to Pac-Man's family. The majority of the trip involves moving from left to right
column3: avoiding various obstacles such as the enemy ghosts
column4: water spurts and quicksand traps. The journey home
column5: however
column6: scrolls right to left.

column1: Each stage must be completed within a set time limit and if the player runs out of time before finishing a round
column2: Sue (the purple ghost) will speed up considerably and kill Pac-Man. At the end of each round
column3: players are awarded bonus points based on how much of the time limit remains. On each stage
column4: cherries and other items can be collected for extra points. There are a total of 8 different trips in the game
column5: totalling 32 levels. After the 8th trip
column6: the 9th trip is a repeat of the 5th trip
column7: with level 33 effectively being level 17
column8: with an increased difficulty level."

column1: 2729;pacland2;paclandj;"Pac-Land (c) 1984 Namco.
;Pac-Land is a horizontally-scrolling platform game set in the cartoon world of the game's title. A fairy has lost her way and needs Pac-Man to help her get back to her home of Fairyland. Pac-Man
column2: with the fairy safely hidden beneath his hat
column3: must run and jump through the colourful world until he reaches and enters the magical door to Fairyland. Upon being rescued
column4: the fairy gives Pac-Man a pair of magical shoes for his trip back home. These enable him to jump wherever he wants
column5: without the need for a platform to jump from. This effectively means Pac-Man can 'sky-jump' back home if he so wishes.

column1: Directional buttons make Pac-Man walk left and right and it's possible to make him run by tapping the desired directional button twice. Pac-Man is pursued by his ever-present enemies in the form of five ghosts - Pinky
column2: Inky
column3: Blinky
column4: Clyde and Sue. Pac-Man must avoid the ghosts and other deadly objects that populate the levels. As with previous games in the series
column5: a small number of 'Powerpills' appear. Eating a Powerpill makes Pac-Man temporarily invincible and turns the ghosts purple and vulnerable to being eaten. On some stages
column6: Pac-Man must use a springboard to jump over large ponds by leaping from the springboard and rapidly moving left and right while in the air.

column1: The game's stages are called 'trips'
column2: with players able to start on any one of the first five. Each trip made up of four rounds (three rounds to reach Fairyland and one round to return home) with a short interval between each one. The objective in all trips is to get the fairy safely back to Fairyland then return home to Pac-Man's family. The majority of the trip involves moving from left to right
column3: avoiding various obstacles such as the enemy ghosts
column4: water spurts and quicksand traps. The journey home
column5: however
column6: scrolls right to left.

column1: Each stage must be completed within a set time limit and if the player runs out of time before finishing a round

column3: players are awarded bonus points based on how much of the time limit remains. On each stage
column4: cherries and other items can be collected for extra points. There are a total of 8 different trips in the game
column5: totalling 32 levels. After the 8th trip
column6: the 9th trip is a repeat of the 5th trip
column7: with level 33 effectively being level 17
column8: with an increased difficulty level."
