column1: 2733;pacmanbl;pacmanbl;"Pac-Man (c) 1981 Unknown.
2734;pacmania;pacmania;Pac-Mania (c) 1987 Atari Games Corp.
;Export version by Atari for North America. Game developed in Japan by Namco. For more information about the game itself
column2: please see the original Namco version entry.

column1: In this export version
column2: gameplay begins with the opportunity for players to level select among one of three playfield worlds : Block Town
column3: Pac-Man's Park or Sandbox Land. With Block Town being the easiest and Sandbox Land being the hardest
column4: players are accordingly rewarded for selecting and completing the challenges in this mode.

column1: - TRIVIA -
Pac-Mania was released in December 1987 in North America by Atari Games under license from Namco.

column2: 412 units were produced by Atari. The selling price was $1

column1: In this Atari 'Export' version :
- The first Block Town only has one level
column2: instead of two.

column1: - The first Pac-Man's Park
column2: Sandbox Land
column3: and Jungly Steps Worlds only have two levels each
column4: instead of three.

column1: - Common has been renamed 'Funky'.
- Grey Common has been renamed 'Spunky'.
- The Top Ten Score List has been added and will let you write initials
column2: before continuing.

column1: - The ""Pac-Mania"" Logo has Pac-Man
column2: Pinky
column3: and Blinky circling around the logo in the Atari version
column4: whereas the Namco version does not.

column1: - A 'Stage Select' feature has been added.
- Items are placed differently from the original Namco version.
- Courage Bonus would activate once you got past Block Town.
- There is a total of 19 levels in the game
column2: instead of the Namco version's 23 levels."

column1: 2735;pacmanij;pacmaniaj;"Pac-Mania (c) 1987 Namco
column2: Limited.

column1: ;Pac-Mania is a 1- or 2-player game in which the player maneuvers Pac-Man through a world of 3-D mazes. He's back in action... but with a new twist
column2: BOUNCE power! Ready for a new generation of Pac-Man players
column3: he can't wait for the chance to show off his new aerial maneuvers to the crowd! The ""boss"" ghost Blinky has recruited the talents of two new ghosts
column4: Common and Grey Common. Sue from ""Ms. Pac-Man"" also returns to the scene. Pac-Man must use his speed and cunning to outwit these annoying pests.

column1: Pac-Man now faces new challenges as he enters the worlds of Block Town
column2: Pac-Man's Park
column3: Sandbox Land
column4: and Jungly Steps. Fortunately for Pac-Man
column5: he has the help of two 'special items' - a green and red power pill. The green pill adds temporary speed
column6: and the red awards double points for eating ghosts. It's a whole new ball game for Pac-Maniacs!

column1: The player's main objective is to eat all dots and power pills in the mazes while avoiding persistent ghosts. Using the new BOUNCE button
column2: players can bounce their way over the ghosts to avoid being caught. But two new ghosts have been added to insure that Pac-Man doesn't have it too easy. In fact
column3: Common and Grey Common can also bounce in the air like Pac-Man. Fortunately
column4: these rivals of Pac-Man are only found in the later levels
column5: and can only jump in the Sandbox Land and Jungly Steps mazes.

column1: During play
column2: the appearance of fruit and green/red power pills will trigger the bell. This alerts players immersed in the game who might otherwise miss these valuable items. A green power pill awards extra speed; it is good until a yellow or red power pill is eaten and expires or a game life is lost. Red power pills award double points for eating ghosts
column3: and continue to do so until a game life is lost.

column1: An optional continue feature is offered to allow players to continue their progress without having to start back at the beginning. It's a great way for Pac-Maniacs to learn and practice strategies without having to restart games from the beginning. Bonus thresholds are offered at various score values
column2: and are adjustable."

column1: 2736;pacmod;pacmod;"Pac-Man (c) 1980 Midway Mfg. Co.

column3: ""Puckman [Upright model]""."

column1: 2737;pacnchmp;pacnchmp;"Pac-Man & Chomp Chomp (c) 1983 Namco.
;An alternate version of ""Pac & Pal""
column2: featuring Chomp Chomp in place of the original 'Pal'
column3: Miru. Chomp Chomp is Pac-Man's dog from the Hanna-Barbera Pac-Man cartoon. Pac-Man also had a cat in the cartoon
column4: by the name of Sour Puss.

column1: - SERIES -
1. Pac-Man (1980)
2. Ms. Pac-Man (1981)
3. Super Pac-Man (1982)
4. Pac-Man Plus (1982)
5. Jr. Pac-Man (1983)
6. Pac-Man & Chomp Chomp (1983)
7. Pac-Land (1984)
8. Pac-Mania (1987)"
2738;pacnpal;pacnpal;"Pac & Pal (c) 1983 Namco.

;Pac-Man has a new friend named Miru, but she tries to steal stuff and take it to the ghost pen. Pac-Man now not only has to collect the stuff lying around the board, but he must also watch Miru to make sure she doesn't take the stuff for her own use.
2739;pacnpal2;pacnpal2;Pac & Pal (c) 1983 Namco.

;Pac-Man has a new friend named Miru, but she tries to steal stuff and take it to the ghost pen. Pac-Man now not only has to collect the stuff lying around the board, but he must also watch Miru to make sure she doesn't take the stuff for her own use.
2740;pacplus;pacplus;Pac-Man Plus (c) 1982 Bally Midway.

;The ghosts are the same, if their edible forms are changed. The maze is familiar, if a bit off in color. The prizes in the center are a bit different. Be careful, however : Pac-Man may eat a power pill and find that Blinky, who is right in front of the energizer for him to immediately eat, is still red, and now Pac-Man is dead. Also, you might want to try eating the ghosts after eating the center prize. They'll return to their normal forms shortly after turning visible.
2741;paddle2;paddle2;Paddle 2 (c) 1988.
;Bootleg/hack of Taito's ""Arkanoid""."
2742;paddlema;paddlema;"Paddle Mania (c) 1988 SNK.

;- TRIVIA -
This game is a bootleg of ""Crush Roller"". For more information about the game
column2: please see the ""Crush Roller"" entry.

column1: Careful when going through the 'bridges' in this version as the fish are able to reach up from above or below to kill your character."
2744;pairs;pairs;"Pairs - Featuring The Giffy Girls (c) 1994 Strata Group
column2: Incorporated.

column1: ;This is the classic memory game played with a deck of cards laid out in a 6x10 grid. You begin by selecting a card
column2: it turns over
column3: and then you try to select another card that matches. If both of your cards match
column4: then they are both taken away (and a bit of the picture is revealed underneath them). If they don't match
column5: then they are flipped back over and you must try again. The number of chances you have is kept track of with hearts at the top of the screen
column6: you get an extra heart each time you guess correctly
column7: and you lose a heart each time you guess incorrectly. Matching pairs also adds time to the timer. If you lose all of your hearts or the timer runs out then it is game over.

column1: At the start of each stage (and upon every continue) a few cards are set face-up for your advantage. Also
column2: each stage features two joker cards (represented by the current girl's head-shot). When a joker card is selected
column3: the next card selected removes all remaining cards with the same value.

column1: During game-play
column2: the background image is shown in gray-scale and any nipples or pubic hair shown in the image is covered over with a band-aid sprite.  Once the stage is completed
column3: these bandages disappear and the image is shown in full-color.  Once all of a girl's stages are completed
column4: the player is shown all of the backgrounds for that girl.

column1: The game has 8 different women to choose from
column2: and there are four stages for each woman (the pictures get naughtier at each stage). Once all 32 of those stages are completed
column3: you get to play several bonus stages that have pictures of several women together. This is a really fun game
column4: despite its obvious adult trappings."

;Taking on the role of a Roman emperor, replete with white robe and olive leaf head ornament, the player must make his or her way from the top left of the screen to the bottom right, via careful navigation of a variety of poles and moving platforms. Enemies can push the player character into fires or over the edge of platforms if they are not carefully avoided.

2751;pang3j;pang3j;"Pang! 3 - Kaitou Tachi no Karei na Gogo (c) 1995 Mitchell.
;The second sequel to the superb 1989 original
column2: Pang! 3 retains the same gameplay of its predecessors but adds vastly improved graphics and a choice of three difficulty levels; Beginner
column3: Normal and Panic. On both the 'Normal' and 'Panic' skill levels
column4: players can choose from 4 different playable characters; each possessing different strengths and weaknesses
column5: such as a double harpoon or quick shots. On the beginner level
column6: players can only use the Mexican character.

column1: Another notable difference is in the game's use of backdrops : instead of the world landmarks of the first two games
column2: Pang! 3 features classical works of art in the form of paintings and sculptures."

2754;pangpoms;pangpoms;Pang Pom's (c) 1992 Metro.

;A colourful static-screen platform game in which players must burst all of the balloons on the screen to advance to the next stage. A number of balloons reveal prizes and bonus points.
2755;panic;panic;Space Panic (c) 1980 Universal Company
column2: Limited.

column1: ;Influential computer game designer and writer Chris Crawford calls Space Panic ""the granddaddy of all platform games""
column2: as it predates Nintendo's Donkey Kong (from 1981) which is often cited as the original platform game. Space Panic lacks Donkey Kong's jump mechanic - the main character instead digs holes in the platforms into which he must lure the aliens. He must then hit them to knock them out of the hole and off the screen. In later levels
column3: two or more holes must be lined up vertically in order to dispose of the aliens. There is also a limited supply of oxygen."

column1: 2762;paperboy;paperboy;Paperboy (c) 1984 Atari Games.
;Paperboy is a one or two-player game in which the objective is to deliver Newspapers to the Paperboy's customers from Monday through to Sunday.
Each game begins with ten customers and ten non-customers. Paperboy's customers live in the brightly coloured houses
column2: while non-customers live in dark coloured houses. To deliver to a customer
column3: the player must throw a paper either into the customer's mailbox
column4: or onto their front porch. Failure to deliver a paper to a customer results in the loss of that customer for the next day. Any damage done to a customer's property also results in the loss of that customer. Losing all ten of Paperboy's customers will get him fired and the game is over. However
column5: on any day in which all customers have their papers successfully delivered
column6: one of the non-customers will re-subscribe.

column1: Non-customers' houses and yards are loaded with targets at which to throw your extra papers (windows
column2: lamps
column3: statues
column4: etc.). Hitting these targets earns points for the ""Breakage Bonus""
column5: which is displayed at the top center of the screen. The total Breakage Bonus is awarded to the player at the end of each day (or at the end of the game-whichever comes first).

column1: If Paperboy loses a customer
column2: that customer's house will be dark coloured the next day. As a non-subscriber
column3: this house now presents more targets at which to throw newspapers for building up the Breakage Bonus. At the start of each day
column4: a map of Paperboy's route is displayed to indicate subscriber and non-subscriber houses. This helps to remind players of what customers they may have lost on the previous day and the location of remaining customers.

column1: Paperboy can carry a maximum of ten papers at a time
column2: but can restock his supply by riding over paper bundles placed here and there on his route. A paper supply indicator is displayed underneath the player's score.

column1: While making his deliveries
column2: Paperboy must avoid collisions with all stationary objects and other characters moving about the neighborhood. To avoid collisions
column3: Paperboy can ride his bike anywhere - on the sidewalk
column4: in the street
column5: or into front yards. A collision with anything results in the loss of a life.

column1: In addition to the obstacles
column2: non-subscribers are hostile towards Paperboy and will attack him and try to knock him down. If Paperboy damages a subscriber's property
column3: that character may also attack. So the more customers that are lost
column4: the more hostile the neighborhood becomes toward Paperboy.

column1: At the end of each delivery day
column2: players have a chance to sharpen their skills by guiding Paperboy through the Paperboy Training Grounds. This obstacle course is filled with various targets at which to throw newspaper
column3: as well as ramp jumps to be negotiated. This is a bonus round and no lives are lost for failing to reach the finish line."

column2: Paperboy must avoid collisions with all stationary objects and other characters moving about the neighborhood. To avoid collisions
column3: Paperboy can ride his bike anywhere - on the sidewalk
column4: in the street
column5: or into front yards. A collision with anything results in the loss of a life.

column1: In addition to the obstacles
column2: non-subscribers are hostile towards Paperboy and will attack him and try to knock him down. If Paperboy damages a subscriber's property
column3: that character may also attack. So the more customers that are lost
column4: the more hostile the neighborhood becomes toward Paperboy.

column1: At the end of each delivery day
column2: players have a chance to sharpen their skills by guiding Paperboy through the Paperboy Training Grounds. This obstacle course is filled with various targets at which to throw newspaper
column3: as well as ramp jumps to be negotiated. This is a bonus round and no lives are lost for failing to reach the finish line."

column1: 2765;paradise;paradise;"Paradise (c) 1994 Yun Sung.
;Paradise is a rip-off of ""Gals Panic!"" but features photographic images of nude western models during gameplay instead of drawn Asian nudes."
2766;parodisj;parodiusj;"Parodius Da! Shinwa kara Owarai e (c) 1990 Konami.
;Created as a parody of Konami's own superb and challenging ""Gradius"" series of shoot-em-ups
column2: Parodius Da! acquired its own identity and would spawn sequels of its own. It maintained the same intuitive power-up system of ""Nemesis""
column3: ""Salamander"" et. al. but adopted a graphical style that was entirely its own; something that becomes evident at the very start of the game when players can chose to pilot either a penguin or an octopus rather that the traditional Gradius ship. Parodius' eccentricity and unique humour is further demonstrated soon after the game begins; as players face such enemies as a giant belly-dancing woman and a half-cat/half-boat creature."

2790;pbobble;pbobble;Puzzle Bobble (c) 1994 Taito Corp.
;The first in the hugely successful puzzle series from Taito
column2: Puzzle Bobble is a game for 1 or 2 players in which the aim is to clear each play area of the colored bubbles that litter it. This is achieved by firing bubbles up the screen - with the angle of trajectory dictated by the player - at the clusters of static colored bubbles that litter each play area. The aim is to forms chains of like-colored bubbles
column3: thus making them disappear. At regular intervals
column4: the bubbles will drop one row down the screen
column5: making life more difficult for the players. The game is over when the bubbles reach the very bottom of the play area.

column1: In the 1-player game there are thirty rounds to complete
column2: whereas in the 2-player Vs. mode
column3: the winner is the player who clears their play area first. The addictive yet straightforward game-play mechanic ensured that the ""Puzzle Bobble"" games would be the most successful of their genre since Russian programmer
column4: Alexey Pajitnov's legendary ""Tetris"" was unleashed upon the gaming world in the late 1980s."

2799;pclubj;pclubj;Print Club Vol. 1 (c) 1995 Atlus.

;Print Club is a small photo booth found at video game arcades in Japan. The Print Club machines produce these small photo stickers (about 2.5 x 2 cm, slightly smaller than a postage stamp) which feature a large variety of superimposed frames which compliment the subject's faces. You just pay 300 yen, stand in front of a video monitor which shows your face, choose the desired frame, pose for the photo, then wait for a sheet of 16 photo stickers which the machine spits out in about a minute. The image quality is not so high (this is probably part of the charm), but the sticker is so small that it really doesn't matter. People affix the stickers on personal articles like notebooks, cell phones, etc. But mainly, school girls collect them to show friends.

2860;penbros;penbros;Penguin Brothers (c) 2000 Subsino.

;A multi-screen platform game in which one or two players (either co-operatively or competitively) control a cute penguin fighting against the game's equally cute enemies. The idea is to destroy all of the on-screen enemies; once this a done
column2: a circular key will appear; the player must pick the key up
column3: whereupon they will be teleported to another screen which represents the second part of the stage. This screen has a silver doorway; the player must carry the key to the door - avoiding or destroying the on-screen enemies - to complete the level.

column1: Playing as a loose cross between Taito's ""Bubble Bobble"" and Irem's ""Bomber Man""
column2: each player's penguin is armed with bombs which are used to destroy the game's enemies
column3: as well as obstructions - such as walls etc. - and barrels; the latter often revealing hidden bonuses that can be collected. Players must be careful to avoid blowing themselves and each other up when the bombs detonate.

column1: Each level contains one or more 'rotating' platforms
column2: allowing travel between upper and lower platforms. Players and enemies can stick to the underside of a rotating platform
column3: then rotate it through 180 degrees to reach the platform above them. The opposite applies to reach a lower platform."

column1: 2861;pengo;pengo;"Pengo (c) 1982 Sega.
;Pengo the Penguin is the eponymous star of Pengo the video game. The basic layout of Pengo is akin to that of Namco's legendary ""Pac-Man""; featuring
column2: as it does
column3: a top down
column4: single screen
column5: maze-like arrangement. Pengo's enemies
column6: the Sno-Bees
column7: are also similar to Blinky
column8: Pinky
column9: Inky
column10: and Clyde - the ghosts that pursued Pac-Man; not least because Sno-Bees also come in four different varieties
column11: each represented by a different color.

column1: One aspect that distinguishes Pengo from the Namco classic is that the Maze itself is a wholly interactive environment. Each section of wall is represented as a block of ice
column2: which can be pushed onto the Sno-Bees to destroy them. The Sno-Bees themselves will destroy the ice blocks as they move around each level
column3: so speed is of the essence. Some of the blocks are 'Diamond blocks' which cannot be destroyed
column4: and can be re-used by Pengo.

column1: The outer wall of each level can also be utilized; if the player pushes against the wall when a Sno-Bee is next to it
column2: the Sno-Bee will be temporarily stunned
column3: allowing Pengo to move in for the kill."

column1: 2866;penta;penta;"Penta (c) 1982 Unknown [Italy].
;Penta the Penguin is the eponymous star of Penta the video game. The basic layout of Penta is akin to that of Namco's legendary 'Pac-Man'; featuring
column2: as it does
column3: a top down
column4: single screen
column5: maze-like arrangement. Penta's enemies
column6: the Sno-Bees
column7: are also similar to Blinky
column8: Inky
column9: Clyde etc. - the ghosts that pursued Pac-man; not least because Sno-bees also come in four different varieties
column10: each represented by a different colour.

column1: One aspect that distinguishes Penta from the Namco classic is that the Maze itself is a wholly interactive environment. Each section of wall is represented as a block of ice
column2: which can be pushed onto the Sno-bees to destroy them. The Sno-bees themselves will destroy the ice blocks as they move around each level
column3: so speed is of the essence. Some of the blocks are 'Diamond blocks' which cannot be destroyed
column4: and can be re-used by Penta.

column1: The outer wall of each level can also be utilised; if the player pushes against the wall when a Sno-bee is next to it
column2: The Sno-bee will be temporarily stunned; allowing Penta to move in for the kill."

column1: 2867;pepper2;pepper2;"Pepper II (c) 1982 Exidy.
;Despite its name
column2: there was no predecessor named Pepper or Pepper I. The gameplay is similar to the game Amidar by Konami and Stern.

column1: There are four mazes per level in Pepper II. Each maze has exits leading to 3 other mazes. All four mazes must be filled to advance to the next level. To fill in a maze
column2: the player maneuvers ""Pepper"" around different segments of the maze. As Pepper travels
column3: he leaves a ""zipper"". Once he encloses or ""zips"" a segment
column4: it fills in and points are awarded. If Pepper backtracks on an uncompleted segment
column5: it unzips.

column1: The character ""Pepper"" is an angel. There are two types of enemies that must be avoided: ""Roaming Eyes"" and the "" Whippersnapper"" who unzips all uncompleted
column2: zipped segments by moving over them. Pepper's one defense is to enclose an area containing a pitchfork ""energizer""
column3: which turns him into a devil for approximately four seconds. At that time he can go after all Roaming Eyes for points. At the same time
column4: the Whippersnapper freezes. There are four pitchforks in the corners of every maze. A deluxe energizer is located in the center of each maze. This energizer alternates between being a pitchfork and a halo symbol. If Pepper encloses the middle area when the energizer is a halo
column5: the Whippersnapper will disappear from the maze.

column1: Points are made for enclosing a segment
column2: consuming a pair of roaming eyes when energized by the pitchfork (similar to Pac-Man)
column3: obtaining prizes
column4: completing a maze
column5: and completing 4 mazes. A bonus turn is awarded at 40
column11: 000 points
column12: depending on the dip switch settings.

column1: Each maze also contains a prize in one of the segments. The player must enclose the area it appears in to gain the prize and points
column2: and then the prize is shown beneath the maze."

column2: controlling the game's hero
column3: a rat called Peter; must rush around a platform-filled screen collecting a variety of objects to take back to Peter's nest. These objects include bottles
column4: watches
column5: hats
column6: balls
column7: and cans.

column1: A number of enemy creatures hinder the player's progress; these include rats
column2: cats
column3: dogs
column4: bats and owls. There are 3 different levels to play through; a junkyard
column5: a sewer and a tree.

column1: As well as the objects that must be collected and taken to Peter's nest
column2: additional objects can also be collected and thrown to stun attacking animals. Flying animals that have been stunned can be ridden around the screen for a short period of time. A round ends when all the desired objects have been collected and placed in the nest. Successive rounds add more objects and enemies
column3: as well as changing the patterns of the shortcuts."

column1: 2874;pettanp;pettanp;"Pettan Pyuu (c) 1984 Sun Electronics.
2875;pfghtj;pfghtj;Pocket Fighter (c) 1997 Capcom.
;A superb
column2: abstract and humorous fighting game featuring miniaturized renditions from several Capcom fighting games; including the legendary ""Street Fighter"" series
column3: as well as ""Darkstalkers"" and the little-known ""Red Earth"".

column1: During a bout
column2: players will be able to release coloured gems from successful attacks against their opponent
column3: as well as from wooden chests that regularly appear. Collecting these gems will 'power-up' the player's character
column4: giving them more powerful attacks. There are two bars and three sub-bars in the interface. The two main bars are the life bar and the super bar; the first indicates the player's health and the second their ability to throw super combos. The Super Bar itself can be filled up to nine levels
column5: allowing players to execute more super combos. Each super combo has a level assigned to it
column6: and it uses Super Bars depending on it.

column1: The 3 sub-bars show the level of 3 of each player's special moves. Each character has at least three special moves
column2: as shown in the sub-bars
column3: and each of these corresponds to a color. Some characters have one or two additional Special Moves that aren't affected by sub-bars. Each time a player shoots their opponent
column4: gems pop out of him or her
column5: and the attacker can take them to power up their own special moves according to the colors.

column1: There are 4 buttons : PUNCH
column2: KICK
column3: SPECIAL
column4: and TAUNT. The Special button is a chargeable move that cannot be blocked and upon impact drops gems in the opponent's possession. More gems will be dropped depending on how much the player charges the attack. Holding Down
column5: Forward or no direction at all when using the Special button will cause a specific gem color to drop from the enemy. Holding Back along with the Special button allows for a defense that is specific against the unblockable Special attacks. Other kinds of attacks do no damage when blocked
column6: and unlike most 2-D fighting games
column7: this includes special and super moves.

column1: Pocket Fighter also features Flash Combos in which a player can execute a combo by pressing the KICK or PUNCH button after they have hit their opponent using the PUNCH button for a total of 4 hits. Flash Combos will usually cause a player's fighter (except Ryu) to change into various costumes during the sequence
column2: and perform a powerful attack in the end. This final hit is usually the hardest in the sequence to connect with. These costumes range from uniforms (such as traffic cops or schoolgirls)
column3: to swimsuits
column4: and even cameos of other Capcom characters. For example
column5: Chun-Li may turn into Jill Valentine from the Resident Evil series
column6: while Felicia may turn into Mega Man or other Darkstalkers characters not playable in the game.

column1: The commands are also very easy compared to the Street Fighter series
column2: thanks to SPECIAL button. By doing a motion (for example : qcf or hcf) and pressing the Special Button the fighter will launch his or her super combo.

column1: In addition to the usual punches
column2: kicks and fireballs
column3: each character has a couple of very abstract yet powerful 'special' attacks; which can range from the player producing a huge mallet (Ken)
column4: to standing on a podium and motioning a bicycle race through the opposing fighter (Chun Li)."

column1: 2880;phantasm;phantasm;Phantasm (c) 1991 Jaleco.

;Talk about lousy days! During a walk with your girlfriend you are ambushed by unknown guys who take your girl away and shoot you dead! Now, as a wandering spirit with the ability to possess almost anybody you come across, you are summoned by your girlfriend's father and given a mission to save her from the mysterious crime syndicate that holds her hostage so that you can rest in peace. Features colourful cartoony graphics, decent music & sound effects, lots of variety (since you can possess any enemy except bosses!) and classic platform action.

2883;phelios;pheliosj;Phelios (c) 1989 Namco.
;A great vertical shoot'em up game based on Greek mythology.
The player controls the sun god Apollo who is riding of his winged horse Pegasus flying through ancient Greece on a mission to rescue his sister Artemis the goddess of the moon
column2: from the clutches of the fiend Typhon. Shoot all enemies like harpies and skeletons along with goblins and colossal enemy bosses.

column1: Pressing the fire button makes his sword fire a tiny shot
column2: while holding it down charges the sword
column3: firing a bigger fireball upon release. Even the smallest enemies take multiple hits
column4: so the standard shot is of little use."

column1: 2884;phoenix;phoenix;"Phoenix (c) 1980 Amstar.
;Phoenix is a classic vertical shoot-em-up in the mould of Taito's ""Space Invaders"" and Namco's ""Galaxian""
column2: but takes the concept further with the introduction of progressive stages of play (instead of simply repeating a single playfield over and over with an increasing difficulty level).

column1: The player pilots a lone ship that can only move left and right along the botton of the playfield and fire upwards. The ship can also utilize a temporary 'Force Field' to protect it from missiles and birds. Any birds that that collide with the Force Field are destroyed. The Force Field only lasts for two seconds
column2: but then cannot be used again for another five seconds.

column1: There are five attack waves to each round of play.
The first wave begins with a formation of sixteen birds attacking the player's ship. They drop missiles and dive at the ship in an effort to destroy it.
The second wave is a variation of the first
column2: only with a different enemy attack pattern.

column1: The third wave begins with pattern of eight eggs that hatch into blue Phoenix birds that then attack the player's ship. These birds can be destroyed by rocket fire from the ship. If the rocket hits the bird on center
column2: the bird is destroyed. If the rocket hits the bird to the left or right of center
column3: only that wing of the bird is destroyed. The wing will regenerate itself if the bird is not quickly destroyed.

column1: The fourth wave is similar to the third
column2: only with two banks of eggs instead of one.

column1: The fifth and final wave is the attack of the Space fortress mothership; a huge mothership piloted by a purple-coloured Alien Queen who sends down waves of small birds to attack the player's ship
column2: as well as launching missiles from the mothership itself. The Alien Queen is protected by a barrier that must be shot several times before both the Queen and the mothership are destroyed.

column1: Once the mothership has been destroyed
column2: the game starts over with an increased level of difficulty.

column1: The additional gameplay elements seem to be at the expense of hardware performance. Despite having more basic graphics than ""Galaxian""
column2: Phoenix's ships move in a very mechanical fashion compared to the smooth
column3: nicely animated movements of Namco's classic."

2927;pleiadbl;pleiadbl;Pleiads (c) 1981 Tehkan.
;Pleiads is a 2-D
column2: space shooter style game. With its many interesting visual and audio effects
column3: this game is sure to challenge the most avid player.

column1: Each round of play includes 4 different stages. With the onset of the melodious background tune
column2: the first stage of play begins.

column1: Against a backdrop of planets and twinkling stars
column2: the Earth City must be protected from sixteen attacking Martians. These Martian attackers have the ability to transform from flying Martians
column3: to walking Martians
column4: or to UFOs. The walking Martians build barriers across the Earth City. These barriers must be destroyed.

column1: The Earth Spaceship can be maneuvered right and left. With the use of the 'warp' button
column2: it can be randomly relocated when necessary. These
column3: plus a backup of stationary defense weapons
column4: aid in protecting the Earth City and Spaceship
column5: as well as in destroying the Martian Attackers. When all but the two final Martians have been destroyed
column6: a tone of dusk shades the Earth City. As these two attackers meet their end
column7: the Earth Spaceship ascends into space to meet the challenge of Stage II.

column1: In this second stage of play
column2: the Earth Spaceship encounters eight Space Monsters. To destroy these Monsters
column3: they must be hit in the direct center. When a Space Monster with burning wings is destroyed
column4: up to 400 points can be added to your score. When all the Space Monsters have been destroyed
column5: the Earth Spaceship prepares for Stage III.

column1: In this third stage of play
column2: the Earth Spaceship is confronted with the Martian Space Battleship and its unseen forces. This Martian Battleship contains five closed chambers
column3: each protected by a rocket flame. Each chamber opens periodically at random
column4: to release a defending reserve of Martian attackers. When a flame below an open chamber is extinguished
column5: point value of the Martian Space Battleship increases. This enemy ship can be destroyed by either eliminating all sixteen Martian attackers
column6: or by extinguishing all five rocket flames. When the Martian Space Battleship finally explodes
column7: the Earth Spaceship moves on to Stage IV.

column1: This last stage of play begins with an emergency signal
column2: SOS
column3: SOS
column4: SOS
column5: AT ONCE RETURN TO EARTH. The Earth Spaceship is now ready to be guided on its journey
column6: through a landing corridor
column7: back to its home base. The Earth Spaceship must be carefully maneuvered around other spaceships in order to avoid destruction. Clearing flags will add bonus points to your score. When the Earth Spaceship has been safely maneuvered to its arrival target
column9: 000 points will be added to your score
column10: while bursts of fireworks greet your arrival and signal the beginning of a new round of play."

column1: 2940;polepos;poleposj;"Pole Position (c) 1982 Namco.
;Pole Position is a 1-player game using a color raster-scan video display. Game action takes place at the Fuji Speedway in Japan. The country around the speedway consists of green meadows
column2: hills
column3: and snow-capped Mt. Fuji.

column1: The player drives a Formula-1 race car on the track. The first objective of the game is to finish the qualifying lap as quickly as possible. If the player beats the clock
column2: he or she qualifies for the race. If not
column3: he or she drives out the remainder of the time along the qualifying course.

column1: As a qualifier
column2: the player is ranked according to his or her qualifying lap time
column3: from the 1st (pole) position to the 8th. The second objective of the game is to race against the clock and other cars to finish the specified number of laps ('Nr. of Laps' dip switch setting; 3 laps is the default) of the race as fast as possible and to achieve the highest score possible. The player earns points for passing cars
column4: driving on the track
column5: and finishing the race with time remaining. He or she is rewarded with an extended-play lap for completing the first lap within a certain amount of time (depending on the 'Extended Rank' dip switch setting).

column1: The game starts with the player's car behind the starting line and a certain amount of time
column2: in seconds ('Game Time' dip switch setting; the default is 90 seconds)
column3: will be on the clock. The player's car must finish the qualifying lap within a certain amount of time (which varies depending on the 'Practice Rank' dip switch setting) to be in the race. If the player does not qualify
column4: his or her car continues on the track until the 'Game Time' elapses.

column1: If the player has qualified
column2: just before the race begins
column3: the player's car (flashing on the screen) is placed at the starting line with seven other cars. The position of the car depends on the position earned during the qualifying lap. (The player's car is always place at the 8th position in the attract mode.)

column1: The starting lights flash from red to green
column2: and the race begins. Racing hazards are other racing cars
column3: sharp turns
column4: road signs
column5: and water puddles. (All of these hazards except for water puddles are also present on the qualifying lap.) As the race progresses
column6: more cars appear on the track. If the player's car hits another car or a road sign
column7: it is destroyed in an explosion. The player's car reappears in a few seconds and the race continues. Driving through water puddles or off the track slows down the player's car.

column1: Racing into the first turn
column2: the player must let up on the accelerator slightly to make the corner. Road signs flash along the side of the track. Depending on how well the player manipulates the controls
column3: he or she can either roar through the hairpin turns like a champion or spin out in a flaming crash. He or she jockeys for position with the other racers
column4: while keeping his or her eye on the clock at the top of the screen. When time runs out
column5: the race is over. If the player has beaten the racing lap time and has seconds remaining
column6: the remaining seconds are added to the extended lap time
column7: which varies depending on the 'Extended Rank' dip switch setting.

column1: The top score achieved by a player appears at the top of the screen. The time allotted for the lap is displayed under the top score. Increasing lap time (in seconds and hundredths of a second) and the speed of the car appears last."

column1: ;Pole Position II is a 1-player game using a color raster-scan video display. Game action takes place at four different raceways - the Fuji Speedway in Japan
column2: the Test Track (an oval track like Indy)
column3: the Seaside Speedway (with the Long Beach Pike in the background)
column4: and the Suzuka Speedway in Japan. The unique and picturesque scenery around each raceway adds exciting realism to each race!

column1: The player drives a Formula-1 race car on each track. The first objective of the game is to finish the qualifying lap as quickly as possible. If the player beats the time
column2: he or she qualifies for the race. If not
column3: he or she drives the remainder of his time along the qualifying course.

column1: As a qualifier
column2: the player is ranked according to his or her qualifying lap time
column3: from the 1st (pole) position to 8th. The second objective of the game is to race against the clock and other cars to finish the specified number of laps ('Nr. of Laps' dip switch setting; 3 laps is the default) of the race as fast as possible
column4: and to achieve the highest score possible. The player earns points for passing cars
column5: driving on the track
column6: and finishing the race with time remaining. The player is rewarded with an extended-play lap for completing the first lap within a certain amount of time (depending on the 'Extended Rank' dip switch setting).

column1: To start play
column2: the player must first insert the correct number of coin(s) for a game (according to the coin dip switch settings
column3: 1 coin/1 credit is the default for both 'Coin A' and 'Coin B' dips). The player then turns the steering wheel until the track he or she wants to drive on is highlighted in white. The game starts when the player steps on the accelerator. The player's car will appear behind the starting line and a certain amount of time
column4: in seconds ('Game Time' dip switch setting; the default is 90 seconds)
column5: will be on the clock. The player's car must finish the qualifying lap within a certain amount of time (which varies depending on the 'Practice Rank' dip switch setting) to be in the race. If the player does not qualify
column6: his or her car continues on the track until the 'Game Time' elapses.

column1: If the player has qualified
column2: just before the race begins
column3: the player's car (flashing on the screen) is placed at the starting line with seven other cars. The position of the car depends on the position earned during the qualifying lap. (The player's car is always placed at the 8th position in the attract mode.)

column1: The starting lights flash from red to green
column2: and the race begins. Racing hazards are other racing cars
column3: sharp turns
column4: water puddles
column5: and road signs. (All of these hazards except for water puddles are also present on the qualifying lap.) As the race progresses
column6: more cars appear on the track. If the player's car hits another car or a road sign
column7: it is destroyed in an explosion (Pole Position II adds flying debris to the visual effect). The player's car reappears in a few seconds and the race continues. Driving through water puddles or off the track slows down the player's car even more than in the original ""Pole Position"".

column1: Experience will teach the player which turns on which tracks require slight steering (because they're banked) and which turns require fast and forceful steering. The player jockeys for position with the other racers
column2: while keeping his or her eye on the clock at the top of the screen. When time runs out
column3: the race is over. If the player has beaten the racing lap time and has seconds remaining
column4: the remaining seconds are added to the extended lap time
column5: which varies depending on the track and the 'Extended Rank' dip switch setting.

column1: The top score achieved by a player appears at the top of the screen. The time allotted for the lap is displayed under the top score. Increasing lap time (in seconds and hundredths of a second) and the speed of the car appear last. Each track has its own separate high score list."

column1: 2952;pompingw;pompingw;"Pomping World (c) 1989 Mitchell Corp.
;One or two players control safari-suited characters armed with harpoon guns
column2: who must destroy the numerous different-sized balloons that litter each stage. When hit by a harpoon
column3: the balloons break down into smaller fragments
column4: in a similar fashion to Atari's 1979 classic
column5: ""Asteroids"".

column1: Players can only fire the harpoon guns virtually upwards
column2: but can move left and right
column3: as well as climbing the ladders that appear on many of the levels. Each of the game's fifty levels is played against a backdrop of one of seventeen famous world landmarks. All balloons must be destroyed before players can advance to the next screen.

column1: The game's levels each contain a different layout of blocks. While most of these are permanent fixtures
column2: some disappear when shot
column3: while others reveal hidden bonuses. Food item bonuses occasionally appear that can be collected for bonus points.

column1: Player start each stage armed with only a single-shot harpoon
column2: but some balloons
column3: when popped
column4: release special weapons that drop down to the bottom of the screen. Players then have a few seconds to collect the power-up before it disappears. Available power-ups are:

column1: * A twin harpoon that allows two shots at once.
* A grappling hook that will stay attached to the ceiling or block for a short period of time.
* A rapid-fire gun.
Other non-weapon bonuses include:
* A force field.
* An hour-glass that slows the balloons' movement.
* A clock that freezes the balloons for a short time.
* An extra life.
* Dynamite
column2: that will pop all remaining balloons down to their smallest size."

column1: ;The player takes on the role of a bow-and-arrow welding pig who must protect her piglets from the pack of hungry wolves ballooning up or down the cliff face. The pig is suspended in a winch-controlled cage and must move vertically up and down
column2: shooting the balloons and sending the wolves plummeting to the ground. Any wolves she misses will
column3: having safely reached the ground
column4: climb a ladder to try and bite her. Also
column5: if any of the wolves reach the ground
column6: more piglets will be captured by them. Mother Pig must try to kill as many wolves as possible without letting them reach the ground.

column1: On the second level
column2: the wolves use balloons to float upwards to the top of a high cliff. If enough of them reach the cliff
column3: they will push a huge boulder down onto Mother Pig's cage. After this level has been completed
column4: the piglets who have been captured are rescued and the game starts over with increased difficulty.

column1: There is also a bonus round where Mother Pig will attempt to eliminate as many wolves on ascending balloons as possible by throwing as few slabs of meat as possible for a maximum bonus score."

column5: of course

column3: Swee'Pea
column4: the Sea Hag
column5: and her vulture Bernard. The game's three levels are the dock scene
column6: the street scene and the shipboard scene. These repeat with increasing difficulty."

column1: 2969;popnpop;popnpop;"Pop'n Pop (c) 1998 Taito.
;Pop'n Pop is a puzzle game using balloons. This is not only a puzzle game blended with a shooting invaders style game.

Move the player character with the joystick and change the position and release the balloons upwards using the 2 push buttons. Line up 3 or more of the same color balloons to pop them and clear the round by bursting all the balloons.
Many bosses appear using a variety of tricks to impede your progress.
There are 3 game modes.
- Puzzle Mode: Play by yourself or with another person to challenge the computer.
- VS CPU Mode: Play against the computer by yourself.
- 2 Player VS Mode: Play against your opponent with your selected characters."

2986;prehisle;prehisle;Prehistoric Isle in 1930 (c) 1989 SNK.
;Prehistoric Isle in 1930 is a horizontally scrolling shooting game developed by SNK and released in arcades in 1989.
Ships have been mysteriously disappearing in the vicinity of the Bahamas for years. Now
column3: the United States government sends an expedition to the area in a flying boat to determine the cause. As they survey the ocean
column4: the expedition comes across an uncharted landmass which they dub ""Greenhell Isle"" and launches two reconnaissance biplanes to take a closer look. As they investigate the island
column5: the biplanes come under attack by dinosaurs and other life forms that were thought to have become extinct millions of years ago.

column1: The player takes control of a biplane armed with a forward-firing machine gun. It can also be equipped with an option weapon pod that can be rotated clockwise around the craft. The option's attack changes depending on where it is currently positioned:
* When directly above or below the plane
column2: the option fires energy waves that reflect back upon contact with a surface.

column1: * When diagonally above the plane
column2: the option fires balls of energy that bounce off surfaces at a 45 degree angle.

column1: * When diagonally below the plane
column2: the option drops bombs.

column1: * When directly in front of the plane
column2: the option replaces the default machine gun with its own flame cannon.

column1: * When directly behind the plane
column2: the option deploys aerial mines."

3013;psychos;psychos;Psycho Soldier (c) 1987 SNK.

;Psycho Soldier is a 1986 release by SNK. It is a side-scrolling shooter featuring two-player simultaneous play. The major character is a girl named Athena. She fires blasts of psychic energy as her main weapon. She can collect orbs which she can control telepathically. These orbs protect her from some projectiles and can also be launched at targets. The orbs will explode on impact. Her companion, a boy named Kensu, can help her with his own powers. Together they clean up a ruined city full of monsters and mutants.

;A great fighting game with eight selectables characters.
The plot takes place in the year 2010
column2: where selected individuals are blessed with the power of psychic abilities. All people imbued with this power are called ""Psychiccers"" and uses a specific element such as fire
column3: ice or gravity in fighting.

column1: Time after Psychiccers are shunned by normal people because of their unnatural abilities and that most cases turn violent and deadly. All of that changes one day when a mysterious corporation known as ""NOA"" appears and offers Psychiccers a place in their company. Headed by a man named Keith Evans
column2: the corporation seeks to create a perfect utopia for Psychiccers and that they'll eliminate anyone who stands in their way.

column1: Challenging NOA's ambition is a small independent group known as ""Anti-NOA"" and that one of its members
column2: a young American Psychiccer named Burn Griffiths
column3: seeks to confront and stop his old friend Keith from going through with his extreme plans of creating a Psychiccer-only world."

column4: aiming for a specific toy from a shelf
column5: and shooting at objects that move across the screen or rush towards the player.

column1: Your 'judgement' is based on your shooting accuracy in some games

3018;puckman;puckmanb;Puckman (c) 198? Unknown

;This final bootleg/hack upright model was a complete fake, but there were a lot of them. They seemed to use converted Namco cabinets, painted white, and were decorated with very strange looking sideart that showed Puckmen and ghosts that looked nothing like the ones on any other Puckman/Pac-Man products. (Since when has Puckman had green frogs legs?) The marquee had an odd Puckman logo in yellow and orange, along with a picture of the blue ghost and the strange 'frog legged' Puckman.
3019;puckmana;puckman;Puckman (c) 1980 Namco.

;Puckman is the seminal and hugely influential arcade game in which the player guides the legendary Puckman around a single-screen maze eating dots. Puckman is constantly pursued in his task by four colored ghosts. Each ghost has its own unique personality and behavioural patterns and a single touch from any of the ghosts results in Puckman losing a life. When all of Puckman's lives are lost
column2: the game is over.

column1: Power pills are situated in each corner of the rectangular maze and eating one of these makes Puckman temporarily invincible; the four ghosts also change to dark blue in color and can now be eaten by Puckman. But watch out...a flashing blue ghost indicates that the power pill is about to wear off and the ghosts are about to transform back to their former selves again. Once Puckman eats a blue ghost
column2: this 'skinned' ghost then becomes visible as a pair of eyes only
column3: will return to the ghost pen in the middle of the maze
column4: regenerate into its former self
column5: and return to the maze to continue its pursuit of Puckman.

column1: Each maze contains 240 dots and 4 power pills
column2: and all must be eaten to complete the level; whereupon the entire sequence begins again with an increased level of difficulty (the action increases in speed and power pills decrease in effectiveness).

column1: Twice in every level
column2: a bonus fruit or prize item will temporarily appear in the middle of the maze below the ghost pen. Puckman can eat these bonus items to receive extra points. Also
column3: there is an escape tunnel on each side of the maze that Puckman can use to escape any ghosts that are currently closing in on him. The ghosts can also use the tunnel
column4: but take longer to pass through it than Puckman
column5: making escape a little easier.

column1: Between certain rounds
column2: funny intermissions will be played featuring Puckman and the ghosts in funny situations. Three intermissions are present:

column1: 1) The red ghost chases Puckman across the screen and off the side. Then he re-appears running in the opposite direction
column2: having turned blue
column3: followed by a giant Puckman! This intermission is played after Round 2.

column1: 2) The red ghost is again chasing Puckman
column2: but this time he rips his red sheet on a nail on the ground
column3: and we can see his pink body under the sheet! This intermission is played after Round 5.

column1: 3) The red ghost chases Puckman across the screen once more
column2: this time with his sheet sewn. They disappear at the left side and then the ghost reappears coming back the opposite direction. This time he is bare and drags his sheet behind him. This intermission is played after Rounds 9

column1: No intermission is present between rounds after the 18th one."

column1: 3022;pulirula;pulirula;"PuLiRuLa (c) 1991 Taito Corporation.
;PuLiRuLa is a six-level
column2: sideways scrolling beat-em-up for 1 or 2 players that defies any logic in either its theme or its graphical approach; that places the players in a dream-like world populated by armies of strange and bizarre creatures.

column1: PuLiRuLa's plot centres around the world of 'Radishland'. Each of Radishland's six towns is kept running smoothly with the aid of a giant key
column2: which is necessary to keep the world's 'time-flow' moving. The key is stolen by a mysterious enemy and the timeflow is disrupted. Players must fight their way through waves of increasingly abstract enemies in their quest to recover the key and restore time to Radishland.

column1: To aid players in their quest
column2: they are each armed with a magical stick
column3: with which they can hit and defeat the game's abstract enemies. Players are also armed with a limited number of smart bombs
column4: capable of killing multiple enemies. The smart bombs are as visually unique as the rest of the game; taking the form of such things as a herd of running animals
column5: a purple dancing blob-like man or a man in a giant microwave oven who captures and cooks any on-screen enemies. When killed
column6: the enemies disappear and an animal or townsperson is released from inside the creature."

column1: 3024;pulsar;pulsar;"Pulsar (c) 1981 Sega.

;Pulsar is a multi-directional shooter where the player must use a four-way joystick to direct a small white tank around changing mazes with a single button to make it fire shots at enemies. The yellow enemies move along the edges of the walls
column2: while the green enemies move randomly and the red enemies bounce off the edges of the walls - and they all move faster
column3: fire faster
column4: and increase in point value
column5: with every round. You should also watch out for ""force-field"" walls - they will kill your tank if it gets caught in one. If you shoot the Pulsar
column6: it will explode into six enemies.

column1: You will also have to collect the colored keys to open the numbered locks at the bottom of the maze - you will receive a double-points bonus if you do it in numerical order
column2: but regardless of whether you opened those locks in numerical order or not
column3: you will always receive a bonus for how much fuel you have left at this point. You will receive extra fuel when you kill enemies and open locks; running out will kill you."

column1: 3025;pulstar;pulstar;"Pulstar (c) 08/1995 Aicom.

;An accomplished and graphically superb sideways scrolling shoot-em-up that borrows many of its visual and gameplay elements from all three games in Irem's legendary ""R*Type"" series; including the Beam weapon and R-type's infamous pod attachment. Unlike ""R*Type""
column2: however
column3: Pulstar's pod cannot be detached from the front of the ship and merely acts as a shield to protect the player's ship.

column1: Pulstar consists of eight challenging levels
column2: with the player able to start the game on any one of the first four."

column1: 3026;punchout;punchouta;"Punch-Out!! (c) 1984 Nintendo.
;The player assumes the role of a green-haired boxer
column2: who must fight his way through six increasingly larger-than-life boxers to earn the title of 'Champ' in this superb 1-on-1 fighting game.

column1: During matches
column2: the player's boxer is viewed from behind as a wire-frame (so the player's opponent can be seen). Players must time their punches
column3: dodges and blocks in order to defeat the opposing boxer.

column1: The player's opponents are each rendered as humorous cartoon-like caricatures - adding much to the game's atmosphere - and each boxer fights in a slightly different style
column2: forcing players to adapt to their strategy. The top monitor is used for statistics while the bottom one is used to display the actual fight."

column1: 3028;punishrj;punisherj;"The Punisher (c) 1993 Capcom Company
column2: Limited.

column1: ;The Punisher is a side-scrolling beat-em-up based on the Marvel Comics character of the same name
column2: in which one or two players take on the role of either 'The Punisher' or 'Nick Fury' and must battle through six dangerous locales filled with violent criminal gangs
column3: leading to a final confrontation with criminal mastermind
column4: 'The Kingpin'.

column1: As well as the standard punch and kick moves
column2: each character also has a special attack. This move is powerful enough to fell several enemies at once
column3: with the trade-off that each time a special attack is executed
column4: some of the player's energy is lost. Energy levels can be replenished by finding food that lies hidden in some of the background objects that litter the levels.

column1: Many enemies carry weapons
column2: such as axes
column3: baseball bats
column4: swords and knives and should players manage to knock these from the enemies' hands
column5: the heroes can pick up the weapons and use them against the enemies. In keeping with their comic book counterparts
column6: each player character also carries a handgun; this only comes into play when confronted with gun-wielding enemies
column7: at which point the players' guns are drawn automatically. Once the gun-carrying enemies have been killed
column8: the players' guns are automatically re-holstered.

column1: A large and powerful gang boss awaits the heroes at the end of each stage. The five gang bosses are Scully
column2: Guardroid
column3: Bonebreaker
column4: Bushwacker and Guardroid 2. The sixth and final level takes place in The Kingpin's lair
column5: ending with a showdown with the criminal mastermind himself."

Players can hinder their opponent by forming Puyo combinations; a successfully formed chain removes some some of the player's Puyos and causes 'junk' Puyos to fall into the opponent's play area. As these Junk Puyos are transparent
column2: they cannot be used to form a chain and can only be destroyed when a nearby chain is created."

column1: 3039;puyosun;puyosun;;
3040;puzlclub;puzlclub;"Puzzle Club (c) 1990 Namco.

;Puzzle Club is a sliding block puzzle video game. The objective of each stage is to make every row in the puzzle show matching animated icons before the timer reaches zero. Once a row is matched that row is shifted to the bottom of the puzzle.  Once all of the rows are matched the stage is completed and the players score is tallied.

There is a 'young' mode and 'adult' mode that is selected at the start of the game. The 'young' mode features icons and characters from the pac-man series.  The 'adult' mode features standard slot game icons. The 'adult' mode also features a bonus stage between regular stages
column2: featuring a sliding puzzle with the animated image of a girl lifting barbells. If the player solves the puzzle within the short time limit he is awarded extra bonus points."

column1: 3041;puzldama;puzldama;"Taisen Puzzle-dama (c) 1994 Konami.

;Taisen Puzzle-Dama is a puzzle game and series by Konami.  It features gameplay very similar to Sega's ""Puyo-Puyo"" games.  'Coins' drop in sets of two's from the top of the screen and players must form chains of three or more same colored coins to make them disappear.

The game is set up as a two player versus style game with CPU opponents for the single player game.  Clearing multiple chains at a time sends locked coins to the other side.  These locked coins are enclosed in clear boxes which are removed when a nearby coin is cleared from the screen.  This can set off more chains which adds to the strategy of the game.
If the coins get stacked up to the top of the screen then the player loses the game.  Upon continuing the player will restart the same match."
3042;puzloopj;puzzloopj;"Puzz Loop (c) 1998 Mitchell.
;Puzz Loop is a puzzle game for one or two players in which different coloured marbles continually roll down a spiral path towards a central goal line.

Players control a rotating cannon situated at the center of the spiral and must stop the line of marbles from reaching the goal by shooting matching coloured marbles into the line. If three or more marbles of the same colour are matched
column2: they will disappear.

column1: In addition to standard marbles
column2: bonus marbles occasionally appear that will
column3: for example
column4: temporarily slow down the rate the marbles' advance
column5: or cause all marbles of a certain colour to be destroyed. Also
column6: providing there is a clear line of sight
column7: unwanted marbles can be fired straight out of the play area to prevent them from adding to the advancing line.

column1: All marbles must be destroyed to complete a level. The game is over once the marbles are pushed over the goal threshold."

3048;puzznic;puzznicj;"Puzznic (c) 1989 Taito Corp.
;This is a puzzle game in which the aim is to move symbol-bearing blocks onto identically-symboled blocks in order to eliminate them. Blocks can only be moved left or right
column2: or dropped downwards.

column1: The order in which the blocks are eliminated needs careful planning
column2: as it's sometimes necessary to destroy three blocks at a time
column3: or use blocks as bridges for other blocks. Some puzzle screens have moving background blocks that act as elevators
column4: making careful timing essential.

column1: Should the player make a mistake and destroy or move the wrong blocks
column2: each puzzle screen allows for a set number of 'retries' (depending on the dipswitch settings). A retry resets all tiles to their original positions.

column1: The game consists of eight levels
column2: with each level consisting of four separate puzzle screens. Once a level has been completed
column3: players can chose which level to tackle next. This translates into 36 separate puzzle screens to be completed in any one game
column4: chosen from a total of 144 puzzle screens
column5: giving the game much replay value."

;The Gougetsuji clan of Kurokos had finally found a new master after Otane Gougetsuji finally defeated the former leader, her older sister Oume. Unfortunately Otane has now disappeared! So a new tournament is called out in order to quickly find a new clan leader. All the fighters from the first tournament have returned as well as some eager (... and strange!) newcomers. Featuring some of the funniest parodies of famous fighting games, a cool soundtrack an tons of new moves making it a way better game than its predecessor, there is no doubt that only the strongest will survive this battle!
3052;pyros;pyros;Pyros (c) 1987 Taito America Corp.

;Two youngsters, Pyros and Erika, unexpectedly strayed into a wonderland called Wardner's Forest. Upon entering the magical forest, the young girl was changed into a crystal ball by an evil warlock called 'Wardner', the ruler of the forest, and brought to a secret place deep inside the woods. The brave young Pyros armed with only a magic flame as a weapon sets out to rescue his female companion from the clutches of the evil Wardner and bring her safely home. Join him in his adventurous search through the magical forest to save his friend and to break Wardner's spell over the enchanted forest and all the inhabitants.

3056;qbert;qbert;Q*bert (c) 1982 Gottlieb.

;The object of the Q*bert game is to change the color of the top of the cubes to the Destination Color indicated at the upper-left corner of the screen (below Player 1's score) by hopping onto them. When all the cubes in the pyramid have been changed to the Destination Color
column2: the screen will advance to the next round
column3: with the player-controlled Q*bert character starting back on the top cube. At the beginning of each level
column4: there will be a short demonstration cycle with Q*bert hopping around four cubes to explain to the player the play action of each level. Each level consists of four rounds. The current level number and round number is displayed at the upper-right corner of the screen (below Player 2's score in a 2-player game).

column1: Gameplay starts with Q*bert appearing at the top of the pyramid. The joystick will move Q*bert from cube to cube by hopping in any of four diagonal directions. Q*bert can move anywhere on the pyramid
column2: but jumping off will kill him. Hopping onto a rotating disk will take Q*bert back to the top of the pyramid. In the first two rounds of play
column3: Q*bert will have to avoid touching the red and purple balls. These deadly objects drop randomly onto the second-from-the-top row of the pyramid and bounce downwards. The red balls will fall off the bottom
column4: but the purple ball will stop at the bottom and hatch into Coily
column5: the snake which chases Q*bert. To get rid of Coily
column6: lure him to the edge
column7: then jump unto a disk. The disk will take Q*bert back to the top and Coily will fall off
column8: awarding 500 points and clearing the board of all other 'nasty' characters.

column1: Starting at the third round of play
column2: other 'nasty' characters come into play. The green characters or objects are safe to hop onto and will award points. All other 'nasty' characters are deadly to touch. In the third round the red balls will stop falling
column3: but two purple characters named Ugg and Wrong Way will appear at the lower portion of the pyramid and travel sideways and upwards (Ugg is the one with the snout moving from right to left on the right face of the cubes
column4: and Wrong Way is the one with the big eyes moving from left to right on the left face of the cubes). They will not chase Q*bert
column5: but will move randomly to get in Q*bert's way. In the third round and every round after
column6: based on an internal timer
column7: a green ball will appear and bounce down from the top of the pyramid. Hopping Q*bert onto the green ball will award 100 points
column8: and freeze all the 'nasty' characters on the screen for a few seconds
column9: but 'Q*bert' will still be able to move to complete the color changes.

column1: During the fourth round of play
column2: two green characters named Slick and Sam will appear
column3: based on the internal timer (Slick is the one wearing shades; Sam does not wear shades
column4: otherwise their function is identical). They will drop onto the second-from-the-top row of the pyramid and hop randomly downwards. If they hop onto a cube that Q*bert has already changed the color of
column5: the cube will change to a different color to thwart Q*bert. Hopping Q*bert onto Slick or Sam will stop them and award 300 points.

column1: Throughout the remaining rounds
column2: all the characters and objects will appear in random combinations with increasing speed.

column1: To add variety to the game
column2: the Flying Discs will change positions every round
column3: and in the higher levels the number of Flying Discs will change.

column1: During Level 2
column2: the play action will increase in difficulty from changing the cubes to one color
column3: to changing the color of the cubes twice. This means that each cube would have to be hopped on twice to change the pyramid to the Destination Color
column4: completing the Round.

column1: Starting at Level 3 and for all remaining rounds
column2: and levels
column3: the play action will become more difficult. The object remains to change the cubes to the Destination Color
column4: but if Q*bert hops on any cube
column5: that cube will change color. So even if the cube has already been changed to the Destination Color
column6: it will change again.

column1: Here is a rundown of how all the colors change :
Legend :
S - Starting Color
I - Intermediate Color
D - Destination Color
LEVEL 1 : When Q*bert jumps on S or I
column2: it changes to D. When he jumps on D
column3: it stays at D (NOTE : During the fourth round
column4: when Slick/Sam jumps on D
column5: it changes to I).

column1: LEVEL 2 : When Q*bert jumps on S
column2: it changes to I. When he jumps on I
column3: it changes to D. When he jumps on D
column4: it stays at D.

column1: LEVEL 3 : When Q*bert jumps on S
column2: it changes to D. When he jumps on D
column3: it changes back to S. Q*bert must start again.

column1: LEVEL 4 : When Q*bert jumps on S
column2: it changes to I. When he jumps on I
column3: it changes to D. When he jumps on D
column4: it changes back to I. Q*bert must start again.

column1: LEVEL 5 : When Q*bert jumps on S
column2: it changes to I. When he jumps on I
column3: it changes to D. When he jumps on D
column4: it changes back to S. Q*bert must start again.

column1: LEVELS 6-9 : Same color pattern as Level 5. The difference is the increased speed of Q*bert and the 'nasty' characters.
There are also bonus points awarded at the end of each round for successfully completing the round. The bonus for the completion of the 1st round is 1
column2: 000 points. This Bonus will progressively increase each Round by 250 points to a maximum of 5
column3: 000 points at Level 5."

column1: 3058;qbertqub;qbertqub;"Q*bert's Qubes (c) 1983 Mylstar Electronics.
;The object of Q*bert's Qubes is to jump around diamond formation of 25 cubes and rotate them so that one or more rows of cubes match the shown target cube (a tic-tac-toe) while avoiding the meltniks
column2: the rat and the purple guys. Jumping on anything green is safe
column3: catching the turtle slows down enemies for a short time and catching the freeze ball freezes enemies for a short time.

column1: Each level has four rounds and a bonus round and there are 11 levels...
Level 1 : get 1 tic-tac-toe
column2: cubes only have 2 colors

column1: Level 2 : get 1 tic-tac-toe
column2: cubes only have 3 colors

column1: Level 3 : get 1 tic-tac-toe
column2: cubes have 6 colors from this point on

column1: Level 4 : get 2 tic-tac-toes
Level 5 : get 3 tic-tac-toes
Level 6 : get 1 tic-tac-toe
column2: matched target cubes can be rotated

column1: Level 7 : get 2 tic-tac-toes
column2: matched target cubes can be rotated

column1: Level 8 : get 3 tic-tac-toes
column2: matched target cubes can be rotated

column1: Level 9 : get 4 tic-tac-toes
Level 10 : get 3 tic-tac-toes
column2: matched target cubes can be rotated

column1: Level 11 : get 3 tic-tac-toes
After this levels 9-11 repeat indefinitely."

3064;qix;qix;Qix (c) 1981 Taito Corp.

;The objective of Qix is to claim a certain proportion of the playing field as your own. At the start of each level, the playing field is just a large, empty rectangle, containing the Qix - a stick-like entity that performs peculiar, erratic motions within the confines of the rectangle. The player controls a small marker that can move around the edges of the rectangle. To claim an area of the screen, the player must detach from an edge and draw Stix within the rectangle. Stix are simply lines traced out by moving the marker. When the marker traces out a closed shape, the area enclosed by the shape becomes solid and has been claimed. The player may draw either Fast Stix, which appear blue when solid, or Slow Stix, which appear red. Slow Stix take longer to draw, but are worth twice as many points. Once the player has claimed an area, the marker can safely move along the border of that claimed area. To complete a level, the player must claim 75% or more of the rectangle's area.

column1: The object of the game is to destroy an army of robots that have taken over an Earth colony satellite station. Each level has a boss character that must be destroyed. Upon its death it releases a door key that must be used to exit the level. Weapon and character power-ups can be collected to aid players in their task.
Due to its potential for four-player shoot-em-up gameplay
column2: Quartet's gameplay feels vaguely similar to (though by no means as accomplished as) Atari's 1985 classic
column3: ""Gauntlet""."

column1: 3116;racedrb1;racedrivb1;"Race Drivin' (c) 1990 Atari Games Corp.
;Race Drivin' includes all of the innovative game features that made ""Hard Drivin'"" the industry's first true driving simulation game
column2: plus many more new features :

column1: Improved Handling - Faster microprocessor and more efficient software code provides a now imperceptible lag time between control input and screen graphic response. Race Drivin' feels even more like a real car!
New Tracks - The Super Stunt track will challenge even the best ""Hard Drivin'"" stunt racers. New tests of skill include a corkscrew loop
column2: a jump loop
column3: and a full pipe.

column1: The autocross track with a built-in pace car provides feedback to hone competitive driving skills. The vector-drawn pace car is actually a recorded view of the player's best lap.
Buddy Race - 2-player sequential race in which the computer records the performance of Player 1
column2: and Player 2 races head-to-head against the first player and the clock.

column1: Linked Race - Install a simple cable between two simulator cabinets
column2: adjust game options
column3: and the buddy race becomes a true head-to-head competition.

column1: Select a Car - Players can select from several different sports cars to suit the race track chosen. The Race Drivin' cars are modeled after the performance features of several well-known sports cars. Each car has its own handling characteristics of off-the-line quickness
column2: top speed
column3: and cornering."

column1: 3133;racinfrc;racinfrcu;"Racin' Force (c) 1994 Konami.

;An excellent sports cars racing game, featuring a pre-rendered graphics for the cars and utilizes voxels graphics for the 3D playfield and great sounds, in which the player competes against computer cars or versus mode via linked game up to eight players, also feature with four Grand Prix tracks to choose and a day and night driving.
3134;rackemup;rackemup;Rack 'Em Up (c) 1987 Konami.

;A vertical pool game where you can play either 9-ball or rotation.
3135;racoon;raccoon;Raccoon World (c) 1998 Eolith.
3136;radarscp;radarscp;Radar Scope (c) 1979 Nintendo.
;As captain of the Sonic Spaceport
column2: players must defend their station against enemy spaceships called Gamma Raiders
column3: which attack with vengeance and swiftly retreat to formation. The object of the game is to destroy 48 enemy Gamma Raiders before there is total disintegration of all the Spaceports on the player's side.

column1: Players can counterattack with the Rapid-Fire Laser Blaster which zooms the lasers over the three-dimensional-esque field of curving vectors
column2: while it intercepts enemies. The lower on the radar screen that you destroy a Gamma Raider
column3: the more points will be earned. If exploding decoys damage the Sonic Spaceport
column4: the Laser Blaster's firing speed will reduce. The Laser Blaster's ""Damage Meter"" will light up as damage is incurred and when fully illuminated
column5: will weaken the Laser Blaster's offensive powers. To reverse this
column6: the players must attack and destroy all remaining Gamma Raiders.

column1: Players are given a wide range of flexibility in controlling the difficulty levels of the game. Extra Spaceports are awarded at 7
column7: 000 points
column8: as determined by the players. The initial number of Spaceports may also be pre-programmed at 3
column10: 5 or 6. When the required number of spaceships is destroyed
column11: players receive an extra point bonus."
