column2: Limited.

column1:
;This Ver. II of Soul Edge has improved graphics and new selectable characters.
3736;spacbatt;spacbat2;Space Battle (c) 1980 U.S Billiards.

;You pilot an arrowhead-shaped vessel at the bottom of the screen, facing off against four different types of enemies. Certain enemies drop 'space soldiers' when shot, if these make it to the bottom of the screen, they will try to 'spear' your ship from behind.
3737;spacbeam;spacbeam;Space Beam (c) 1979 Irem.

;You and another cannon are duelling each other over a field of alien ships. As the ships thin out, you become more exposed (so does your enemy, but the computer has better reflexes than you). Can you outlast, or outmaneuver your opponent?
3738;spacduel;spacduel;Space Duel (c) 1982 Atari.
;Space Duel is a 1- or 2-player game with a color X-Y video display. This display
column2: with its 3-color guns and higher voltage
column3: has the same technology that was used in previous Atari black-and-white X-Y displays. However
column4: the screen now displays dazzling color and unique visual effects in a spectacular multi-dimensional video display.

column1: Space Duel offers players a choice of 4 different game versions. One player can control a fighter or a space station. Two players
column2: playing at the same time
column3: can control fighters or a space station. The game offers players 12 different targets (7 split when hit)
column4: and 18 different waves. At the beginning of each wave
column5: objects enter from the screen edge. The player(s) then tries to shoot and destroy the objects. The wave ends when all the objects are destroyed.

column1: The play mode begins with the first wave. In the space station game
column2: two ships appear near the center of the screen. The ships are joined together by a 'fuse'. In the fighter game
column3: the red ship appears above the red controls. The green ship appears above the green controls. A sound is heard any time a ship appears on the screen.

column1: A ship may fire as many as four shots on the screen at one time. However
column2: if a ship is damaged
column3: it may fire only one shot on the screen. Also the ship is slower to react. In space stations
column4: a second hit to either ship destroys that ship. Then
column5: the fuse between ships starts to burn
column6: and the other ship explodes.

column1: In the fighter game
column2: players may shoot each other without losing a life. Instead
column3: the ship blinks and disappears. After a period of time
column4: the ship reappears in a different location. If one player loses all of his ships before the other player
column5: his last ship returns to the screen as a damaged ship. It is possible to earn a bonus ship while damaged.

column1: Shields protect a ship from all saucer shots and collisions. Shields wear out with time or if hit by targets. Space stations have more than twice as much shield energy as fighters.
In the first wave
column2: spinners enter and break into two smaller pieces when shot. Each piece splits into two smaller pieces when shot again. Each of these pieces is destroyed when shot. Other targets split apart in the same manner.

column1: At the end of each wave
column2: a bonus wave begins and a low humming sound is heard. BONUS LEVEL
column3: and the number of points for that level
column4: flash on the screen. A box appears at the screen edge and ships cannot leave that boundary. Fuzzballs
column5: stars and saucers enter and attack the player. A fighter
column6: when shot by the other player
column7: either just before or during the bonus wave
column8: will not reappear until the next wave. The bonus wave ends when all targets are destroyed
column9: or the humming sound reaches its highest pitch.

column1: Other targets enter as the game progresses. When the number of targets is less than the wave number
column2: or it no splitting targets have been hit in some time
column3: saucer enters and shoots at targets and ships. The saucer shots become more accurate as play continues. Saucers may also enter as a pair. They shoot at
column4: but do not destroy
column5: each other. Anything caught between them will be shot. Each time the pair goes across the screen
column6: the distance between them increases.

column1: A player's ship may be destroyed by a shot or collision. Game play ends when all ships are destroyed."

;Space Invader's clone.

column1: 3743;spacecr;spacecr;"Space Cruiser (c) 1981 Taito.

3744;spacedem;spacedem;Space Demon (c) 1980 Fortrek.
3745;spacedx;spacedx;Space Invaders DX (c) 1994 Taito Corp.
;A modern and fitting tribute to Taito's 1978 seminal shoot-em-up
column2: ""Space Invaders"".

column1: There are now 3 different game modes to choose from. These include a faithful recreation of the legendary original - available in both upright and cocktail versions - and replete with a simulation of the infamous ""coloured plastic overlay"" that was used to add the impression of full colour graphics to the original game.
The 2 remaining game modes are 'Versus'
column2: with simultaneous split-screen 2-player action
column3: and ""Parody""
column4: which features characters and graphics from other well-known Taito games
column5: such as ""The New Zealand Story""
column6: ""Bubble Bobble"" and ""Liquid Kids"". Despite the graphical changes
column7: the Parody version plays identically to the original game
column8: and all modes retain the original
column9: legendary sound effects."

column1: 3748;spacefb;spacefbe2;"Space Firebird (c) 1980 Nintendo.

;Space Firebird is a one or two player game in which players are attacked from all sides by highly maneuverable Firebirds. Players can move space ship left or right and shoot a rapid-fire laser at attacking Firebirds. A special Warp Mode allows the space ship to escape danger and fire at the flock of aliens.
FIREBIRDS
The space Firebirds are a unique set of adversaries. There are three different birds
column2: the Emperor
column3: Eagle and Gull
column4: which fly together in complex looping formations
column5: firing and attacking from all directions. The player must keep track of the laser hits because each bird has a different resistance level to hits. The fearless Emperor is destroyed by four hits
column6: the Eagle with two hits and the soaring Gull with one hit. The Eagle also has a deadly bomb which is launched at the space ship. Extra points are scored by hitting the bomb before it explodes. The bomb when hit
column7: scatters into deadly shrapnel. To avoid the flying shrapnel
column8: the bomb must be hit from directly underneath.

column1: SPACE SHIP

The space ship can be moved right or left to evade attacking Firebirds. Depressing the fire button enables the space ship to shoot its laser at approaching Firebirds. Players receive 3 (adjustable) space ships per play.
WARP MODE
Activate warp mode to escape impeding danger or to strike out at approaching birds. There is only warp mode per space ship. When activated
column2: the space ship is launched into space with a force field around it that deflects enemy fire. In warp mode
column3: Firebirds can be eliminated by ramming into them or by firing at close range.

column1: If all Firebirds are destroyed
column2: the player moves into a new battle sequence that increases in difficulty. One new space ship is awarded for a score of 5
column3: 000 (adjustable) points. Game ends when all space ships are destroyed."

column2: France
column3: EUR].

column1: 3751;spacefev;spacefevo;"Space Fever (c) 1979 Nintendo.

;The Earth is under attack from alien invaders. Shoot them out of the sky before they land. Space Fever is Nintendo's take on the ""Space Invaders"" franchise. The game is almost identical in terms of how it plays. The alien craft are arranged in rows and they slowly move left and right across the screen. When the row reaches the edge
column2: the ships drop down a row and move in the opposite direction. As you shoot more enemies the speed will increase
column3: as will the number of enemy bullets. You have four blocks above you that absorb the enemy shots until they are worn through
column4: and being hit by an enemy shot will cost you a life. Sometimes a UFO will fly along the top of the screen and can be hit for Bonus points.

column1: There are three different game modes for 1- or 2-player games :
Game A - There are two 'blocks' of aliens that move in opposite directions to each other.
Game B - The aliens move as one 'block'
column2: but they only appear one row at a time.

column1: Game C - The same as ""Space Invaders"" - all the aliens move as one 'block' in the same direction."
3752;spacefrt;spacefrt;"Space Fortress (c) 1981 Century Electronics.
3753;spacegun;spacegun;Space Gun (c) 1990 Taito Corp.

;As a member of a special Search And Rescue unit. you (and an optional friend) are told to investigate an S.O.S. distress signal that was sent from a space station. what you don't know is that a group of vicious aliens have taken the colonists hostage. luckily for you, you're armed with a plasma pulse gun and four sets of grenades that are quite special (aside from the common grenade that explodes, some will freeze, incinerate, and even slice and dice the aliens).
3754;spaceint;spaceint;Space Intruder (c) 1980 Shoei.

;Space Invader's clone.
3755;spaceod;spaceod2;Space Odyssey (c) 1981 Sega.
;PLAY INSTRUCTIONS :
1. Destroy attacking UFO-s for points.
2. Round ends after seven sectors.
3. Faster ship speed awards higher bonus at end of round.
4. Extra points awarded for passing through gaps blown in targets.
5. Passing over black hole momentarily disables ship.
6. Avoid meteors. They are indestructible
7. Bonus ship awarded for outstanding play.
8. Point values increase with each round.
Good luck."

3761;spacewr3;spacewr3;Space War Part Three (c) 1979.
;Pirate release of Space Invaders. Items which make this game unique:
* Spaceship's design is different.
* Numbers in the bunker to denote rack number.
* The occasional timed round
column2: with a bonus plus a splash screen for finishing the rack.

column1: * Invaders change shape as you finish off more racks.
* When you finish off the first rack
column2: the game asks you for your name. Afterwards
column3: it shows what you input in place of the SCORE1 or SCORE2 above your score."

column1: 3762;spacezap;spacezap;"Space Zap (c) 1980 Midway.
;A multi-directional space shoot'em up game.
The space colony is in danger his defense base is being attacked by a alien threat it comes in four differents quadrants and their attacks are devastating
column2: quickly use the cannon to destroy them and release the base of the hostile threat must be quick because time passes
column3: the enemy increases the intensity and speed of attack and can exploit its base you must avoid this
column4: you must using your control skills at win the mission and defend your base."

column1: 3763;spacfura;spacfurya;"Space Fury (c) 1981 Sega.
;This game is a rather simple alien blasting shoot-em-up. It uses almost industry standard vector controls
column2: which are four buttons
column3: Left Rotate
column4: Right Rotate
column5: Thrust
column6: and Fire. You begin the game in the center of four strange looking shapes. These shapes are both level selects and upgrades. Run into one of them and it will add itself to your ship
column7: and then you get to do the level associated with it. Each level is different mainly because you have wildly different shot patterns on each one. But all of them are the same when it comes to your objective. What you have to do is blast all the spaceship parts before they can form into dangerous enemy spaceships. Blast them all
column8: and you get to select a new level and watch a little interlude where the alien taunts you with his evil computer voice.

column1: PLAY INSTRUCTIONS :

;A pinball game featuring 4 boards :
1. On the Carnival Board
column2: there are two ways to work towards the goal : knocking out the drop targets on the upper board
column3: or hitting the button targets that light the word 'Rhythm' on the lower part of the main board.

column1: 2. On the Border Board
column2: the 'INPUT' button targets in the center upper part of the board are the ones to hit to work your way towards your goal.

column1: 3. On the Monster Board
column2: you must complete 7 different target areas
column3: each one referring to a body part : 2 roll-throughs for arms
column4: two holes for eyes
column5: two sets of targets for legs and the top rollovers work towards the 'head'.

column1: 4. On the Sniper Board
column2: you knock down the 'LOAD' drop targets
column3: then shoot the Shot Bonus button target when lit. You do this 6 times to reach your goal.

column1: As you go follow through on the game
column2: the warp shots let you see how far you've gone in your quest to finish each board. The fewer clothes each girl has
column3: the further you have gone on that board. Once the women are topless
column4: you've done all you can on that board."

;The objective is to roll the coin to the bottom of the screen and through the hole at the bottom by tilting the coin's platform. It seems simple, but is super addictive and really fun to play with a group of people.

;Spectar
column2: released by Exidy in 1980
column3: is the follow-up of ""Targ"". Gameplay is apparently unchanged
column4: you control a vehicle called Whummel into a 9x9 grid maze
column5: chasing down
column6: and being chased by
column7: the alien invaders. Targs have evolved into the more dangerous Rammers
column8: and Spectars appears more often
column9: shooting at player's ship.

column1: You use a 4-Way joystick to guide your vehicle in the maze
column2: and a pushbutton to shoot at enemies. Up to 2 players can alternate in gameplay.

column1: The most noticeable difference from his predecessors is that to complete a level you can now collect all the gems in the maze
column2: in a ""Pacman""-like game or destroy all of the Rammers (like in ""Targ""). Rammers and Spectars continue to appear from flashing pods
column3: so you cannot rest and plan your course easily
column4: or you will be overwhelmed by the alien force.

column1: Graphic is highly improved compared to his predecessor : The maze now has barricades that must be avoided or can be used as a shielding against the enemies
column2: and has ten environment settings
column3: changing from the 'square-block town' of Targ to a city
column4: a forest
column5: a lunar landscape and many more. The enemies too are smarter and faster
column6: and the fact that they go on spawning from the pods makes the game a even more frenzy challenge."

;In Speed Freak you drove an extremely fast car along a lonesome road. The idea was simply to drive as fast as you can without crashing. The game was time based, you could crash as much as you wanted, but points were scored for driving as fast and as far as you could without crashing. Your view of the action was from behind the hood of the car, but slightly above what an actual driver would see, kind of like you were sitting on the roof instead of inside the car. Obstacles were mainly oncoming cars (which was always the same one), and police roadblocks. The off-road scenery was limited to stick figure cows, hitchhikers, and the occasional cactus.

;In Spelunker - which means 'cave-diver' - a caver has to work his way down through a number of multi-directionally scrolling caves - each one deeper underground than the last - in his bid to find the mythical 'World of Wonders'. To do this
column2: the spelunker must find the exit to each cave
column3: so he can move on to the next and get closer to his goal.

column1: Spelunker is a platform game
column2: and each tricky cave is filled with enemies - such as bats and ogres - and traps. Ladders
column3: ropes
column4: lifts and the obligatory minecarts must be used to reach other platforms and sections of the cave.

column1: To aid him in his difficult quest
column2: the Spelunker carries a gun and can shoot short-range fireballs at his enemies to stun or kill them. Numerous bonus items can be collected
column3: such as bombs to destroy any rocks block his route
column4: keys to open locked doors and potions to boost the caver's ever-decreasing energy meter. Treasure chests also litter each cave
column5: and can be opened for bonus treasure items."

column1: 3803;spf2xj;spf2xj;"Super Puzzle Fighter II X (c) 1996 Capcom Co
column2: Limited.

column1: ;Super Puzzle Fighter II X is a puzzle game for one or two players based upon Capcom's legendary ""Street Fighter"" and ""Vampire"" series of fighting games.
Super Puzzle Fighter II X's gameplay is reminiscent of Sega's superb 1992 puzzle game
column2: ""Puyo Puyo"" with players taking on the role of one of the famous Street Fighter characters
column3: represented visually between the two play areas in the middle of the screen. The aim is to manipulate falling coloured gem blocks
column4: matching the colours to gems already in the play area; before finally destroying them with orbs of a like colour.

column1: Gems can only be eliminated by coming into contact with a 'Crash Gem' of the same colour. This eliminates all adjacent gems of that colour
column2: setting up the potential for huge chain reactions.

column1: As gems are eliminated
column2: garbage blocks called 'Counter Gems' will drop into the opponent's playfield; these will eventually become normal gems
column3: but only after they count down to zero (most Counter Gem countdowns start at '5' and are reduced by one each time a new pair of gems is dropped on that board)
column4: until that time they cannot be eliminated by normal means. The only way to eliminate Counter Gems before they become normal gems is to place a Crash Gem of that colour nearby so it eliminates at least one normal gem. If this is done
column5: all Counter Gems immediately adjacent to the Crash Gem will be taken out as well.

column1: Additionally
column2: gems of the same colour that form squares or rectangles (of at least two blocks tall and wide) in the pit become a giant Power Gem of that size and color; eliminating these as part of a combo increases the number of Counter Gems that would otherwise normally appear on the opponent's board.

column1: The only other type of piece to appear is a diamond
column2: which eliminates all the normal
column3: Power
column4: Counter and Crash gems of whichever colour gem it lands on. This
column5: too
column6: will cause Counter Gems to appear on the opponent's board.

column1: Whenever a player destroys a number of blocks
column2: their on-screen Street Fighter counter-part will be shown attacking the opponent character. The fighting move used is dependent on both the colour and number of blocks the player has destroyed.

column1: The available in-game characters
column2: and games from which they are taken (based on first appearance) are :

column1: * Ryu (""Street Fighter"")
* Ken (""Street Fighter"")
* Chun-Li (""Street Fighter II - The World Warrior"")
* Sakura (""Street Fighter Zero 2 [CP-S II No. 15]"")
* Morrigan (""Vampire - The Night Warriors [CP-S II No. 05]"")
* Donovan (""Vampire Hunter - Darkstalkers' Revenge [CP-S II No. 09]"")
* Lei Lei (""Vampire Hunter - Darkstalkers' Revenge [CP-S II No. 09]"")
* Felicia (""Vampire - The Night Warriors [CP-S II No. 05]"")
Hidden characters:
* Gouki (""Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge [CP-S II No. 03 Bis]"")
* Dan (""Street Fighter Zero [CP-S II No. 11]"")
* Devilotte (""Cyberbots - Fullmetal Madness [CP-S II No. 10]"")"

column1: 3808;spiero;spiero;"Super Pierrot (c) 1987 Universal.
;Whoo hoo
column2: this game is nothing but dot eating fun. You play the game one screen at a time
column3: and each screen will be covered with dots
column4: baddies
column5: and will have a few logs thrown in to boot. What you are trying to do is either eat all the dots
column6: or kill all the monsters. There are two basic kinds of enemies (plus a few more that will sometimes escort the bonus letters). The first kind is a sort of green clam
column7: these are slow moving and pose little danger to Mr. Do. But the second kind is fairly dangerous
column8: it is a purple cartoon snake
column9: and it will make quick rolling attacks at Mr. Do!
column10: you must dodge these
column11: as your powerball is ineffective against a rolling snake. Both enemy types will sometimes transform into a purple sightless unicorn if they manage to remain alive long enough
column12: shoot the unicorns as soon as they appear
column13: because you cannot outrun them over long distances.

column1: Mr. Do! has two things to defend himself with. The first is the superball
column2: he starts out carry this
column3: simply toss it at an enemy
column4: and they will vanish (you can also bounce the superball off of walls for a higher score). Your superball regenerates as you eat dots and fruit
column5: and it is often a good idea to use it as soon as it regenerates (to take out yet another baddie). Your other weapon is the logs that are scattered around the game board. Simply push them
column6: and they will roll down the screen
column7: taking out anything in their path (including Mr. Do! if you are dumb enough to get in their way).

column1: You leave a line behind you as you walk
column2: when you meet your own line (creating a box)
column3: any dots inside the box will be upgraded to cherries
column4: while cherries upgrade to apples
column5: which upgrade to lemons
column6: which finally upgrade to pineapples. You don't have to do any of this fruit upgrade stuff at all
column7: but is the best way to rack up a lot of points. You can collect letters to spell EXTRA to get a free man (just like all the other ""Mr. Do!"" games)."

column1: 3818;spnchotj;spnchoutj;"Super Punch-Out!! (c) 1984 Nintendo.
;Super Punch-Out!! is an update of the superb boxing game
column2: ""Punch-Out!!""
column3: featuring five new larger-than-life opponents. The player once again assumes the role of a green-haired boxer who must fight his way up through five boxers to earn the title of 'Champ'.

column1: As with the original game
column2: the player's boxer is viewed from behind with his torso rendered with wire-frame graphics (allowing the player's opponent to be easily seen). Punches
column3: dodges and blocks must all be well-timed in order to defeat the opponent.

column1: Both the player and the opponent have stamina meters displayed at the top of the screen. These decrease when either boxer takes a punch and boxers will get knocked down if their stamina meter runs out completely. Faster knockdowns will cause the fallen boxer to recover less stamina upon getting up; the same happens if a boxer is knocked down by a knockout punch.
Thanks to the refined roster of new and hugely distinctive enemy fighters
column2: Super Punch-Out!! is considered to be an improvement over the first game."

column1: As with the original game
column2: the player's boxer is viewed from behind with his torso rendered with wire-frame graphics (allowing the player's opponent to be easily seen). Punches
column3: dodges and blocks must all be well-timed in order to defeat the opponent.

column1: Both the player and the opponent have stamina meters displayed at the top of the screen. These decrease when either boxer takes a punch and boxers will get knocked down if their stamina meter runs out completely. Faster knockdowns will cause the fallen boxer to recover less stamina upon getting up; the same happens if a boxer is knocked down by a knockout punch.
Thanks to the refined roster of new and hugely distinctive enemy fighters
column2: Super Punch-Out!! is considered to be an improvement over the first game."

;In this game you control a race car on a semi-circular track. You are looking down on the action from above. Your only goal is to drive around the track as many times as possible
column2: and as fast as you can. There will be four cars on the track at all times (the computer lets you know that 'Grey cars drive automatically').You control the white car
column3: while the computer controls a black car and two grey cars. The game will rate you at the end
column4: you can get rated Granny
column5: Rookie
column6: or Pro
column7: and getting a score over 250 points will extend the game an extra 30 seconds. The game has several different tracks available
column8: and they change randomly throughout the game (they literally change while you are still driving). This is different than the original ""Sprint 2""
column9: which allowed you to select your track manually. The graphics are simple black and white with two shades of gray thrown in for good measure. They are simple
column10: but they get the job done."

column1: 3825;sprint2;sprint2;"Sprint 2 (c) 1976 Kee Games.

;In this game you control a race car on a semi-circular track. You are looking down on the action from above. Your only goal is to drive around the track as many times as possible, and as fast as you can. There will be four cars on the track at all times (the computer lets you know that 'Grey cars drive automatically'). Player one controls the white car, while player two (if present), controls a black car. The game will rate you at the end, you can get rated Granny, Rookie, or Pro, and getting a score over 250 points will extend the game an extra 30 seconds. The game has several different tracks available, and you can select them with a button at the start of a match. The graphics are simple black and white with two shades of gray thrown in for good measure. They are simple, but they get the job done.

3829;sprint8;sprint8;Sprint 8 (c) 1977 Atari.

;In this game you control a race car on a semi-complicated track. You are looking down on the action from above. Your only goal is to drive around the track as many times as possible, and as fast as you can. There will be eight cars on the track at all times. With the computer controlling cars for missing players. The sheer number of cars can make this game a little confusing. All the cars have minor variations to set them apart from the others, but are similar enough that you simply cannot look away from the track for a second. If you are used to the other Sprint games, you will find that this one is a bit different, the graphics are slightly higher in resolution, and the tracks are much more complex, and have a different look to them, not to mention the fact that this version adds a brake pedal that was absent in the other Sprint titles. The game has several different tracks available, and you can select them with a button at the start of a match. The graphics are simple black and white with two shades of gray thrown in for good measure. They are simple, but they get the job done. The game will rate you at the end, you can get rated Granny, Rookie, or Pro, and getting a score over 250 points will extend the game an extra 30 seconds.
3830;sprint8a;sprint8a;Sprint 8 (c) 1977 Atari.

The game has several different tracks available, and you can select them with a button at the start of a match. The graphics are simple black and white with two shades of gray thrown in for good measure. They are simple, but they get the job done. 3835;spyhunt;spyhunt;Spy Hunter (c) 1983 Bally Midway Mfg. Co.
;Spy Hunter is an action/driving game. It places the player as the driver of a G-6155 CIA Prototype Interceptor sports car. The object of the game is to travel the freeways and waterways
column2: hunting down and destroying as many enemy vehicles as possible
column3: all the while not harming civilian vehicles. The view is top-down and the screen scrolls vertically underneath the player's car.

column1: The game begins with the player driving the G-6155. Soon
column2: the player starts to encounter enemy vehicles which try to force the player's car off the road and crash. Each enemy vehicle has its own special feature
column3: such as tire slashers or bulletproof armor.

column1: Points are scored for driving on the road and for destroying enemy vehicles. There is a lead-in time when the player has an endless supply of cars. After this time expires
column2: the player will lose a life each time the car crashes. Extra cars can be earned with high scores. The first extra car is earned at a default value of 30
column3: 000 points
column4: but this value can vary depending on settings.

column1: The player must be careful to avoid harming civilian vehicles on the road. There are three types: blue automobiles
column2: pink automobiles
column3: and motorcycles. Hurting these vehicles causes scoring to stop briefly
column4: during which time the player's score reads 'NO POINTS'.

column1: Initially
column2: the only weapon the player's car has available is a dual front-mounted machine gun which has an endless supply of ammunition. Early on
column3: these guns and the player's driving skill are his only weapons against the enemy cars. The player can also attempt to force or ram the enemy cars off the road. Eventually the player encounters an ally
column4: the weapons van. After the player drives past the weapons van parked on the side of the road
column5: the van accelerates past the player's car and positions itself in front of it and drops a ramp. The player can then drive up the ramp to enter the back of the van. The van then pulls to the side of the road and deploys the spy car equipped with a new weapon. A symbol atop the weapons van indicates which type of special weapon it carries. The player is not obligated to use the weapons supplied by the van. Also
column6: if uninterested
column7: the player can simply ignore the van and drive past it.

column1: There are three special weapons in all and they can all be equipped simultaneously. The special weapons consist of an oil slick
column2: a smoke screen and missiles. Each special weapon has a limited number of uses. The smoke screen and missiles can each be used three times. The special weapons are activated via dedicated buttons on the steering wheel. Once the weapons ammo is depleted or before
column3: the car can be refitted with a new supply from the weapons van.

column1: There are six enemies in all
column2: each with their own special characteristic :

column1: * 'Switchblade' or 'Never To Be Trusted' cars have tire slashers. Knives pop out of this car's tires and can force the player's car to crash if they touch his tires.
* 'The Road Lord' or 'Bulletproof Bully' cars have bulletproof armor plating; machine guns are ineffective against these cars.
* 'The Enforcer' or 'Double Barrel Action' is a limousine with a shotgun-toting thug who shoots at the player's car.
* 'The Mad Bomber' or 'Master Of The Sky' is a helicopter which drops bombs. This enemy can only be destroyed with missiles.
* 'Barrel Dumper' is a boat which drops lethal explosives into the water.
* 'Doctor Torpedo' is a boat which shoots torpedoes at the player's ship.
Occasionally a message appears on screen that says 'Bridge Out - Detour on Left'. Then the player must drive his car into a boathouse located alongside the road
column2: otherwise he will crash into the water and lose a life. After driving through this house
column3: the player's car is turned into a speedboat on a river
column4: with enemy boats which try to destroy the player. In this area
column5: if the player uses the oil slick
column6: the boat instead issues a line of fire which destroys any ship directly behind the player. In this area
column7: occasionally the river splits; the left side continues the river
column8: the right side causes the player to drive through another house where the boat is changed back into the car.

column1: Later in the game the player gets a warning that there are 'Icy Roads Ahead'
column2: then the player enters an area that has a white road which is very slick. The icy roads section eventually ends and goes back to normal roads. Icy roads occur again on and off during the rest of the game."

column1: 3843;srdarwin;srdarwin;SRD - Super Real Darwin (c) 1987 Data East Corp.
;SRD: Super Real Darwin is a vertical scrolling shooter arcade game developed and published by Data East. It is the sequel to Data East's 1986 arcade game
column2: Darwin 4078. The player takes control of a small fighter ship capable of mutating into different shapes. The ship's appearance will change with upgraded weapons as the player obtains more powerups.

column1: The story starts on the planet Lakya where the technologically advanced inhabitants of the planet unwittingly unleash the planet's life force known as Evol. As the released Evol drifts from planet Lakya
column2: it is received by the inhabitants of the nearby planet Cokyo; the people of Cokyo initiate the Shlohe project
column3: a plan to use their captured Evol to develop advanced biologic ships and weapons to invade planet Lakya. The inhabitants of Lakya retaliate the Cokyo invasion by using their own evolving fighter ships."

3846;srmp2;srmp2;Super Real Mahjong PII (c) 1987 Seta.
;Super Real Mahjong Part II is the second game in the Super Real Mahjong series.  Super Real Mahjong Part II introduces strip sequences to the game
column2: featuring one beautifully animated opponent with six strip sequences.

column1: Super Real Mahjong Part II begins with your female opponent taking off her sweater so she can get down to a serious game of mahjong. The tiles are mixed up
column2: the wall is set up
column3: the players build their hands
column4: and the game begins. Every time the player wins a hand
column5: his opponent strips off a piece of clothing. Every time the player loses a hand
column6: she puts a layer of clothing back on. Should the player reveal all six strip sequences
column7: gameplay will continue and with every win
column8: the last strip sequence will replay. Only when the player runs out of betting funds will the game be over. The game features no continues."

column1: 3847;srmp3;srmp3;"Super Real Mahjong Part 3 (c) 1988 Seta.

;Super Real Mahjong Part 3 is a strip mahjong game featuring two girls with 5 strip sequences each.  Super Real Mahjong Part 3 featured newly designed sprites for the tiles and game play and was the last game to feature sprite animations of the player's hands in the Super Real series. Part 3 also introduced continues to the series.

The player begins the game playing against Kasumi Serizawa.  With every winning hand the opponent removes an article of clothing.  With every loss she puts a piece of clothing back on.  When the player clears all of Kasumi's strip sequences she introduces the player to her older sister
column2: Miki
column3: and gameplay continues in the same fashion.  If the player loses all of his funds then the game is over."

column1: 3848;srmp4;srmp4;"Super Real Mahjong PIV (c) 1993 Seta.
;Super Real Mahjong Part IV is a strip mahjong game featuring three girls with five strip sequences each
column2: plus 3 extra girls with one strip sequence each. Once again
column3: the fourth game in the Super Real Mahjong series has redesigned the game tiles and from part IV on
column4: all of the hand animations are completely removed from the game. Part IV also has greatly enhanced the quality of the animation and expanded its use in storytelling and strip sequences.

column1: The gameplay is standard for this series.  With every winning hand the opponent removes an article of clothing. With every loss she puts a piece of clothing back on. When the player clears all a girl's strip sequences
column2: the next girl is introduced and the game continues. The girls have unlimited betting funds so each strip sequence must be won separately. If the player loses all of his funds then the game is over.

column1: If the player defeats all three regular opponents then the bonus game begins.  The bonus game features three extra girls with one strip sequence each. The difficulty is increased for the bonus game and once the bonus game starts there are no more continues."
3849;srmp4o;srmp4o;"Super Real Mahjong PIV (c) 1993 Seta.

column1: The gameplay is standard for this series.  With every winning hand the opponent removes an article of clothing. With every loss she puts a piece of clothing back on. When the player clears all a girl's strip sequences
column2: the next girl is introduced and the game continues. The girls have unlimited betting funds so each strip sequence must be won separately. If the player loses all of his funds then the game is over.

column1: If the player defeats all three regular opponents then the bonus game begins.  The bonus game features three extra girls with one strip sequence each. The difficulty is increased for the bonus game and once the bonus game starts there are no more continues."

;Sanrin San-Chan is a fast-moving maze-chase game in which the player takes on the role of a tricycle-pedalling child out collecting flowers
column2: while trying to avoid collisions with the numerous enemies giving chase.

column1: Most of the maze paths are separated into two lanes
column2: with a springy elastic fence separating them. This fence is the key to playing the game
column3: as players can jump into it
column4: allowing them to squeeze past oncoming enemies in the same lane. Also
column5: enemies on the opposite side of the fence can be sent flying from the track. Solid blocks also feature
column6: and these can be pushed into enemies to destroy them.

column1: Special bonus rounds feature after stages two
column2: six
column3: ten and fourteen. These rounds are platform-based
column4: with the player trying to collect as many items of fruit as possible before heading up to the highest platform
column5: to meet up with a friendly elderly lady who is waiting there. 'Fruit' and 'Happy' bonuses are then awarded."

column1: 3858;ssf2j;ssf2j;"Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers (c) 1993 Capcom Company
column2: Limited.

column1: ;The fourth game in the SFII series featured all new graphics
column2: redone sounds
column3: and above all
column4: four characters new to the series. Here is a full list of changes from previous SFII games:

column1: * New title screen with new music.
* Completely new portraits for all characters. M. Bison ('Vega' in Japan) now has a winged-skull on his hat instead of a star.
* New endings for the bosses. The last part of Chun Li's ending is also modified
column2: letting the player choose whether she should now live a normal girl's life or continue being a detective.

column1: * Vega ('Balrog' in Japan) no longer climbs the fence on his stage prior to doing his 'Flying Barcelona Attack' or 'Izuna Drop' moves. He now just jumps to the edge of the screen and jumps off
column2: as he does in the other stages.

column1: * Voice samples for all characters and announcer re-recorded with different actors. Each character now have their own unique voice so there is no more shared voice samples (e.g. the male 'KO' scream).
* Background music playback is handled differently. The background music will play continuously from Round 1 to Round 2 until a character causes the KO sign to flash on Round 2
column2: which will trigger the 'Heavy Damage' version of the music. From Round 3 onward
column3: the music is played in the same format as in previous SFII games.

column1: * Four completely new stage backgrounds with new background music to accompany the New Challengers.
* Color schemes for the twelve original stage backgrounds have changed once again :
1) Ryu stage: The sky is now near evening
column2: and the moon is now white with a touch of light blue.

column1: 2) E. Honda stage: The walls are now light blue
column2: and the big picture (excluding the sun) is now red-orange.

column1: 3) Blanka stage: The vine where the snake is coiled is now light green
column2: and people to the right have changed a bit. The river behind the village is now a clear blue.

column1: 4) Guile stage: The sky is back to daytime
column2: the canopy on the jet is now clear
column3: and the people in the background are now dressed in blue. The symbol on the ground is back to blue
column4: but the missile linings are still red.

column1: 5) Ken stage: The tugboat has been replaced with a yacht
column2: the two guys on the top now wear orange clothes and white clothes. On the bottom
column3: the first person now wears a green shirt and has gray hair
column4: the second person now wears white t-shirt and yellow pants
column5: the third person now has long hair and wears white top and pink skirt
column6: the fourth person now wears light blue shirt and orange pants
column7: and the guy in the trenchcoat and hat is now replaced by a new person in blue shirt and navy blue pants.

column1: 6) Chun Li stage: The sky is now sunset
column2: the two customers now wear orange
column3: the meat store's roof is now green with its sign back to red
column4: the guy holding the chicken now wears blue
column5: the ""Shanghai Friend Corridor"" sign is now red-orange with yellow letters
column6: the guy to the right now wears green pants
column7: and the water sign is now blue.

column1: 7) Zangief stage: The stage floor is now green
column2: and the area to the left is back to red. In addition
column3: the fence on the left foreground is now lowered a bit.

column1: 8) Dhalsim stage: The curtains and stone floor are now green
column2: and the carpet is back to red.

column1: 9) Balrog ([JP] M. Bison) stage: While the stage floor is still purple
column2: the 'Las Vegas' on the floor is now yellow. The car to the left is now blue
column3: and the car to the right is now green. The guy throwing the confetti at win/lose now wears yellow
column4: the guy next to the car to the left now wears purple and the guy next to the guy throwing the confetti has been redesigned.

column1: 10) Vega ([JP] Balrog) stage: The stage floor now shows off a green hue
column2: and the fence now comes crashing down at the start of the fight.

column1: 11) Sagat stage: Buddhist statue is still gold
column2: and now it's sunset. In addition
column3: a big city is now visible in the distance.

column1: 12) M. Bison ([JP] Vega) stage: The sky is now back to daytime
column2: and the guys sitting Indian style praying (and stands up angrily after breaking a big statue) are now dark-skinned. The roof of the palace is now red with green trim
column3: and the linings on the giant bell that were previously red are now black."

column1: 3860;ssf2jr2;ssf2jr2;"Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers (c) 1993 Capcom Company
column2: Limited.

column1: ;The fourth game in the SFII series featured all new graphics
column2: redone sounds
column3: and above all
column4: four characters new to the series. Here is a full list of changes from previous SFII games:

column1: * New title screen with new music.
* Completely new portraits for all characters. M. Bison ('Vega' in Japan) now has a winged-skull on his hat instead of a star.
* New endings for the bosses. The last part of Chun Li's ending is also modified
column2: letting the player choose whether she should now live a normal girl's life or continue being a detective.

column1: * Vega ('Balrog' in Japan) no longer climbs the fence on his stage prior to doing his 'Flying Barcelona Attack' or 'Izuna Drop' moves. He now just jumps to the edge of the screen and jumps off
column2: as he does in the other stages.

column1: * Voice samples for all characters and announcer re-recorded with different actors. Each character now have their own unique voice so there is no more shared voice samples (e.g. the male 'KO' scream).
* Background music playback is handled differently. The background music will play continuously from Round 1 to Round 2 until a character causes the KO sign to flash on Round 2
column2: which will trigger the 'Heavy Damage' version of the music. From Round 3 onward
column3: the music is played in the same format as in previous SFII games.

column1: * Four completely new stage backgrounds with new background music to accompany the New Challengers.
* Color schemes for the twelve original stage backgrounds have changed once again :
1) Ryu stage: The sky is now near evening
column2: and the moon is now white with a touch of light blue.

column1: 2) E. Honda stage: The walls are now light blue
column2: and the big picture (excluding the sun) is now red-orange.

column1: 3) Blanka stage: The vine where the snake is coiled is now light green
column2: and people to the right have changed a bit. The river behind the village is now a clear blue.

column1: 4) Guile stage: The sky is back to daytime
column2: the canopy on the jet is now clear
column3: and the people in the background are now dressed in blue. The symbol on the ground is back to blue
column4: but the missile linings are still red.

column1: 5) Ken stage: The tugboat has been replaced with a yacht
column2: the two guys on the top now wear orange clothes and white clothes. On the bottom
column3: the first person now wears a green shirt and has gray hair
column4: the second person now wears white t-shirt and yellow pants
column5: the third person now has long hair and wears white top and pink skirt
column6: the fourth person now wears light blue shirt and orange pants
column7: and the guy in the trenchcoat and hat is now replaced by a new person in blue shirt and navy blue pants.

column1: 6) Chun Li stage: The sky is now sunset
column2: the two customers now wear orange
column3: the meat store's roof is now green with its sign back to red
column4: the guy holding the chicken now wears blue
column5: the ""Shanghai Friend Corridor"" sign is now red-orange with yellow letters
column6: the guy to the right now wears green pants
column7: and the water sign is now blue.

3888;sspring1;ssprintg1;Super Sprint (c) 1986 Atari Games.
;Like ""Championship Sprint""
column2: released the same year
column3: Super Sprint is an updated version of the old Atari Sprint series; with added the ability to allow players to upgrade their vehicles as the game progresses. Upgrades are won by collecting wrenches that appear once per track. After a player has collected four wrenches
column4: they will be presented with an upgrade screen; giving them the opportunity to choose better traction
column5: increased top speed
column6: faster acceleration
column7: or a faster helicopter. The only discernible difference between this and ""Championship Sprint"" is the addition of brand new tracks."

column1: 3895;ssrdrabd;ssridersabd;"Sunset Riders (c) 1991 Konami.
;Sunset Riders is a superb sideways scrolling shoot-em-up for one to four players set in America's Wild West. Four sharpshooter bounty hunters (Steve
column2: Billy
column3: Bob and Cormano) set out to claim the bounties given for killing the most wanted outlaws in the West. The ultimate aim is to survive long enough to reach the final showdown against Sir Richard de la Rose.

column1: Sunset Riders is an incredibly playable game featuring colourful and well-drawn graphics
column2: with a number of humorous visual jokes keeping players entertained. The side-scrolling action takes place both on foot and on horseback
column3: with the action sometimes broken up with a wild west pursuit; such as having to run along the backs of a herd of fleeing Buffalo.

column1: Each level ends with players entering a one-on-one battle against one of the wanted men they have been pursuing. Weapon power-ups can be found and collected to help players in their quest."

;A 3-D space shoot'em up featuring 2 separate missions; the first is to destroy the planet 'Red Eye' while the second is to wipe out the enemy fleet and their leader. The game's sit-down cabinet featured a seat that vibrated whenever the player was hit
column2: either by incoming fire or by enemy objects such as ships

column4: underneath where the player's thumb sits - was very similar in appearance and feel to that used in Atari's 1983 wireframe classic
column5: ""Star Wars (Atari)""."

column1: 3916;starcas;starcas;"Star Castle (c) 1980 Cinematronics.

;Star Castle is a 1- or 2-player outer space action game designed with features geared for maximum player appeal : A progressively difficult competitive level and a clearly defined enemy which must be both attacked and avoided at various points in the course of play.

The center of the playfield is occupied by the Star Castle which is programmed to constantly home in on the players' ships. Surrounding the Star Castle are three concentric energy rings of twelve segments each
column2: which serve as both a protective perimeter for the Star Castle and a source of points for the player. Contained within the energy rings are three protective mines which seek out the players' ships and destroy them upon collision. The movements of the mines are programmed to simulate the actions of heat-seeking missiles.

column1: The object of the games of Star Castle is to score the maximum number of points possible. This is accomplished by the combination of three elements :
a) Exploding the ring segments.
b) Exploding the Star Castle.
c) Avoiding the Star Castle's mines. A player's turn is over when his ship has been destroyed. The number of ships per game is set by the operator.
For maximum scoring
column2: a player will want to shoot out sections of the energy rings in order to give him a shot at the Star Castle in the center of the screen. As play progresses
column3: there are 2 facts a player must keep in mind :

column1: 1) Exploding all segments in a given ring will cause the entire ring to reappear - thereby eliminating a potential shot at the Star Castle in the center.

2) Exploding the rings in a manner that gives you a shot at the Star Castle will also give the Star Castle a shot at you. The Star Castle is programmed so that its nose always seeks out the player's ship. If there is an open shot at the player
column2: it will take it.

column1: When the Star Castle is hit by a player's missile
column2: it will first implode and then explode with all remaining ring segments. After a one-second delay
column3: the Star Castle will reappear with all three ring segments. If the Star Castle shoots the player
column4: his turn is over.

column1: As play begins
column2: the Star Castle will appear in the center of the screen surrounded by its 3 energy rings. The player's ship appears about halfway up on the right hand edge. By using the control buttons to move forward
column3: right or left
column4: the player maneuvers about the screen using the firing button to launch missiles.

column1: Points are scored by destroying the energy ring segments or the Star Castle itself. Exploding the Star Castle gives an extra ship as well as points. No points are given for the mines that attack the player.

The player's ship can be destroyed in 2 ways : By collision with the mines or by a hit from the Star Castle's torpedo. The mines are launched from the rings and attack the player for approximately ten seconds or until shot. The Star Castle's torpedoes are launched only when there is a clear shot at the player through all 3 rings. At this time the player also has his shot at the Star Castle. Both the Star Castle and the mines get smarter and faster as the game progresses.

The game of STAR CASTLE is not based on time units. The battle rages on until all the players' ships are destroyed. The length of the game depends solely on the skill of the player. It's the age-old challenge of man versus machine."
3917;starcas1;starcas1;"Star Castle (c) 1980 Cinematronics.

;Star Castle is a 1- or 2-player outer space action game designed with features geared for maximum player appeal : A progressively difficult competitive level and a clearly defined enemy which must be both attacked and avoided at various points in the course of play.

The center of the playfield is occupied by the Star Castle which is programmed to constantly home in on the players' ships. Surrounding the Star Castle are three concentric energy rings of twelve segments each
column2: which serve as both a protective perimeter for the Star Castle and a source of points for the player. Contained within the energy rings are three protective mines which seek out the players' ships and destroy them upon collision. The movements of the mines are programmed to simulate the actions of heat-seeking missiles.

column1: The object of the games of Star Castle is to score the maximum number of points possible. This is accomplished by the combination of three elements :
a) Exploding the ring segments.
b) Exploding the Star Castle.
c) Avoiding the Star Castle's mines. A player's turn is over when his ship has been destroyed. The number of ships per game is set by the operator.
For maximum scoring
column2: a player will want to shoot out sections of the energy rings in order to give him a shot at the Star Castle in the center of the screen. As play progresses
column3: there are 2 facts a player must keep in mind :

column1: 1) Exploding all segments in a given ring will cause the entire ring to reappear - thereby eliminating a potential shot at the Star Castle in the center.

2) Exploding the rings in a manner that gives you a shot at the Star Castle will also give the Star Castle a shot at you. The Star Castle is programmed so that its nose always seeks out the player's ship. If there is an open shot at the player
column2: it will take it.

column1: When the Star Castle is hit by a player's missile
column2: it will first implode and then explode with all remaining ring segments. After a one-second delay
column3: the Star Castle will reappear with all three ring segments. If the Star Castle shoots the player
column4: his turn is over.

column2: Limited.

column1: 3922;starfira;starfirea;Star Fire (c) 1978 Exidy.

;Exidy STARFIRE is a single player game which simulates combat between space-going fighters. The player can control the speed and direction of his fighter and attack enemy fighters with his lasers; the enemy fighters shoot fireballs at the player. The object of play is to accumulate points by destroying enemy fighters. A player can buy extra playtime during play and continue the game he is playing
column2: as long as he has any time left; he earns bonus playtime each time he exceeds a bonus score. The game keeps track of 20 high scores - one score for each number of coins accumulated. The initials of high scoring players are displayed during the game's attract mode.

column1: Play Mode - The screen shows a crosshair gun sight at the center of a background of stars; enemy ships move across this background. The background moves as the player works the controls
column2: but the crosshairs always stay at the center of the screen.

column1: The bottom of the screen has several indicators and a message panel.  A thrust indicator shows the player's speed and forward-reverse direction
column2: and a long range scan indicator shows the presence and direction of any enemy ships off the main screen. Other indicators show the player's current score and fuel level. The message panel tells whether the player has hit an enemy ship or been hit himself
column3: whether his laser is ready to fire
column4: etc.

column1: Enemy fighters move in all directions on the screen
column2: getting larger or smaller as they move toward or away from the player. Bonus Exidy pirate ships move from left to right across the screen
column3: and always stay the same size. The fighters and pirate ships come in three colors: blue
column4: green
column5: and gold (actually orange). Blue fighters are worth 10 points
column6: green fighters 20 points
column7: and gold fighters 40 points; all bonus Exidy pirate ships are worth 50 points.

column1: When a target (an enemy fighter or bonus Exidy pirate ship) comes near the crosshairs
column2: two gauge scales appear - one from the right side and one from the bottom of the screen.  At the same time
column3: a warning beep sounds. If the player maneuvers the target into the crosshairs
column4: it is locked-on - the enemy is frozen in the crosshairs for several seconds
column5: and the player can easily destroy it with his laser. When the player locks onto the enemy
column6: a second warning beep sounds
column7: a 'LOCKED!' message appears on the message panel
column8: and the target flashes in the crosshairs.

column1: Press the laser fire button
column2: and four simulated laser beams converge on the center crosshairs from the corners of the screen. If the lasers hit a target
column3: it explodes. Enemy fighters can shoot fireballs at the player; if a fireball hits
column4: the screen flashes and the player is penalized by being reset to blue targets.

column1: STARFIRE produces a wide variety of sound effects. An ENGINE RUMBLE sounds throughout the play
column2: and an EXPLOSION sounds whenever an enemy explodes or the player is hit by enemy fire. There is a LASER sound whenever the player pushes the laser fire button
column3: and a HISS whenever an enemy fighter fires at the player.

column1: There are four different kinds of WARNING BEEP. These warn the player when he is almost locked onto a target
column2: when he is actually locked on
column3: when a target is just off the edge of the screen
column4: and when the laser overheats.

column1: These sounds are heard only during the play mode. There is only one operator adjustment for the sound effects - the volume control.
STARFIRE has 3 player controls: a steering yoke
column2: a thrust control
column3: and a laser fire button. To steer right or left across the screen
column4: turn the steering yoke like an automobile steering wheel; to move down or up
column5: move the yoke in or out. Slide the thrust control T-handle up or down to move forward or back. The laser fire button is on the left handgrip of the steering yoke.

column1: Awards and Bonuses - The operator can set the bonus score to 300
column3: or 700 points
column4: or can turn off the bonus feature.  If the bonus has been set
column5: a player has one chance of a bonus for each 300 fuel units he buys. If he tops the bonus score during any 300 unit period
column6: the game awards him a bonus of 150 fuel units. This bonus fuel is added after the fuel indicator reaches zero. The player can only get one bonus for each 300 fuel units he buys.

column1: The coin accumulator keeps track of the coins a player has spent. STARFIRE maintains twenty high scores : one for players who have only inserted one coin
column2: a second for two-coin players
column3: and so on. Players who spend more than twenty coins are lumped together in the twenty-coin score.

column1: When a player finishes playing
column2: STARFIRE counts the coins he has spent and compares his point score to the appropriate high score. If he has topped that score
column3: the game asks him for his initials (one
column4: two
column5: or three letters); as long as his high score stands
column6: his initials will be on the attract mode score table. If switch 7 of the DIP switch is ON
column7: the score table will stay on screen as long as the laser fire button is pressed.

column1: Every third coin a player spends buys double playtime. That is
column2: STARFIRE awards four coins worth of playtime for each three coins spent."

column1: 3924;starforc;starforc;"Star Force (c) 1984 Tehkan.

;A single player, vertically scrolling shoot-em-up in which the player pilots a spaceship over series series of islands - drifting in outer-space space - shooting enemy spacecraft and ground-based targets. Special symbols appear at regular intervals and can be shot or collected for bonuses and power-ups. Each level has an end-of-level boss that must be defeated before the player can progress to the next level, while the levels themselves are designated by letters of the Greek alphabet.
3925;starfore;starforce;Star Force (c) 1984 Tehkan.

;A single player, vertically scrolling shoot-em-up in which the player pilots a spaceship over series series of islands - drifting in outer-space space - shooting enemy spacecraft and ground-based targets. Each level has an end-of-level boss that must be defeated before the player can progress to the next level, while the levels themselves are designated by letters of the Greek alphabet.
3926;stargate;stargate;Stargate (c) 1981 Williams.
;Stargate
column2: also known as 'Defender II'
column3: will transport you to a whole new dimension in video games! Not only will the skills you learned with ""Defender"" be challenged and refined
column4: but new strategies must come into play if you are to be victorious in rescuing the humanoids from the clutches of the aliens and in entering the Stargate! Your ability to react quickly and with on-target precision will be tested against the evil Yllabian Space Guppies
column5: Dynamos
column6: Space Hums
column7: Firebombers and their Fireballs
column8: Phreds
column9: Big Reds and Munchies! If you succeed in maneuvering your ship into the Stargate
column10: you'll be instantly trans-located to that part of the planet where the humanoids are being abducted! To open up spectacular scoring possibilities
column11: rescue four Humanoids
column12: re-enter Stargate and you'll warp 3 waves ahead in space and time
column13: setting off dazzling special effects and racking up high points!

column1: If you must destroy everything in your path or risk self-destruction
column2: activate the Inviso anti-matter cloaking device and become invisible and invulnerable! Inviso time plus a new ship and a Smart Bomb are earned with every 10
column3: 000 points you score!

column1: If all ten Humanoids in a wave are abducted
column2: the universe will explode into smithereens
column3: leaving deadly Mutants on the attack! Survive until Wave 5 and the universe will be restored
column4: the humanoids safe... but you'll be the target of an Yllabian Dog Fight! There'll be no Landers to abduct the Humanoids
column5: but all the other aliens will have stronger and larger forces concentrated against you! It will be an out space battle reaching the outer limits of aggression and will call up your last ounce of determination and courage!"

column1: 3928;stargrds;stargrds;Star Guards (c) 1987 Bally Midway.
3929;starhawk;starhawk;Star Hawk (c) 1979 Cinematronics.
;Star Hawk is a 3-D wireframe shoot-em-up which places a strong emphasis on player timing. Players move a cross hair around the screen and must blast the approaching enemy spaceships.
The skill level settings affect how quickly the cross hairs move in response to the joystick input. As the game progresses
column2: the speed of the enemy craft increases. If one particular enemy ship is not destroyed quickly enough
column3: it will zap 800 points off the player's score
column4: with the enemy itself also worth 800 points.

column1: Star Hawk can effectively be played indefinitely
column2: providing the player keeps shooting enough enemy ships."

column1: 3930;starjack;starjack;"Star Jacker (c) 1983 Sega.

;Star Jacker is an early vertical scrolling shooter with some interesting characteristics.  The player starts out with three fighters with all of the fighters moving and shooting at the same time. Two fighters trail the lead fighter. Star Jacker features a similar scheme with the Namco game Xevious in that the fighters shoot at enemy fighters in the air while dropping bombs on enemies and targets on the ground level.
When any of the fighters is killed
column2: the game momentarily pauses and re-centers the player fighters before continuing at the same point.  The game is over when all of the player's fighters are destroyed. Star Jacker allows no continues."

column1: 3931;starjacs;starjacks;"Star Jacker (c) 1983 Sega.

column1: 3932;starlstr;starlstr;"Vs. Star Luster (c) 1985 Namco.
3933;starshp1;starshp1;Starship 1 (c) 1977 Atari.
3934;starshpp;starshpp;Starship 1 (c) 1977 Atari.

3936;startrek;startrek;Star Trek - Strategic Operations Simulator (c) 1982 Sega.
;STAR TREK is a 1- or 2-player SEGA Color X-Y video game with computerized speech synthesis. The player finds himself the Captain of the Starship Enterprise
column2: his mission being to rid the universe of a number of threats to the United Federation of Planets.

column1: STAR TREK has a unique method of displaying the information vital to the game play. This method involves the separation of the CRT into three completely separate screens.
The Scanner is where the player sees a top down or plan view of local space
column2: with the Enterprise always in the center of this screen. The Viewer is where the player sees actual apparent 3-D images
column3: as if he were looking out the ships front window. The Status screen displays player score in addition to Shield strength
column4: number of Photon Torpedoes
column5: and amount of Warp energy remaining.

column1: The game begins by introducing Klingons
column2: Starbases and the Enterprise into the Scanner with an exciting shrink down animation sequence. The Enterprise starts with 1 to 4 Shields and Photon Torpedoes (switch selectable). By actuating the rotary knob and depressing the Thrust button the player may maneuver about the Scanner screen.

column1: In order to destroy enemies the player may use either of two weapons : Phasers (the Fire button) or Photon Torpedoes. Each has unique properties.
* Phasers are instantaneous
column2: can destroy only one enemy at a time
column3: and are in unlimited energy supply.

column1: * Photon Torpedoes require time to travel
column2: can destroy many enemies
column3: and are in LIMITED supply. Displayed in the Status screen
column4: Photon Torpedo supply appears as a red bar (squares).

column1: For high speed
column2: the player may depress the WARP button. While this button is held down the Enterprise moves very quickly and cannot be damaged in any way by anything. A blue bar in the Status screen displays the amount of Warp energy available
column3: and shrinks as the Warp button is held down.

column1: The Enterprise is shrouded by an automatic Shield
column2: which protects the Enterprise from enemy fire and collisions. The Shields are displayed in the Status screen as green line segments (a bar). Once the strength of the Shields is depleted
column3: the ship can sustain damage. When damaged
column4: the Enterprise looses ship functions in the following order : Shields
column5: Photon Torpedoes
column6: Warp Drive. If all of these are damaged
column7: the next hit will destroy the Enterprise and end the game.

column1: In order to repair this damage the player may choose to dock with a Starbase. Docking is accomplished by merely flying into a Starbase. The DOCKED message appears
column2: all damage is repaired
column3: and a Shield unit
column4: Photon Torpedo
column5: and some Warp time are added to the ship’s supplies. Although only four of each supply unit is displayed at any one time
column6: 255 can be collected.

column1: The primary enemy is the Klingon Battle Cruiser
column2: which comes in three colors :

column1: * Red Klingon - ignores the Enterprise and sets out to destroy a Starbase
column2: after which the Klingon turns purple.

column1: * Purple Klingon - ignores Starbases and attempts to destroy the Enterprise by firing plasma energy balls. Purple Klingons will stop a certain distance away while attacking so as not to risk collision. After a certain period of time (depending on round)
column2: purple Klingons turn white.

column1: * White Klingons - sometimes known as Maniac Klingons
column2: these Klingons will move VERY QUICKLY and attempt to ram the Enterprise.

column1: Anti-Matter Saucers appear randomly and move about the screen in a confusing fashion. These saucers can be destroyed only with Phasers. If the saucer collides with the Enterprise
column2: it will attach itself
column3: drain your ships Warp energy
column4: then leave quickly.

column1: After a number of rounds
column2: the player advances to the Nomad round. In this sequence Nomad zips about the screen depositing dangerous mines. The mines cause chain reactions which should be avoided. Nomad can only be destroyed with Phasers. Once Nomad has delivered its total load of 30 mines
column3: it waits for the last mine to detonate
column4: leaves the screen
column5: and ends the round.

column1: Every 10
column3: 000 points (operator selectable) the player is awarded a bonus Shield unit
column4: Photon Torpedo and Warp time unit. The two player game is played with players alternating with each complete round. Whenever a player is eliminated
column5: the other player continues and finishes the game."

column1: 3937;starw;starw;"Star Wars (c) 19?? Yamashita.
;Bootlef/Hack of Universal's ""Galaxy Wars""."
3938;starwar1;starwars1;"Star Wars (c) 1983 Atari
column2: Incorporated.

column1: ;Star Wars is a single-player 3-D shoot-em-up based on the legendary movie franchise of the same name. This game is specifically based on the very first Star Wars movie
column2: 'Episode IV: A New Hope'. The player takes on the role of Luke Skywalker (Red Five) whose goal is to blow up the infamous ""Death Star"" by firing a Proton Torpedo into an exposed exhaust port situated on the Death Star's surface.

column1: Before reaching the exhaust port
column2: players must survive three attack phases.

column1: PHASE 1 : The game begins in outer space above the Death Star. Players must engage in a dog fight with Darth Vader and numerous enemy TIE Fighters. All but Vader's fighter can be shot and destroyed. Incoming enemy fire must be avoided or shot to prevent damage to the player's Deflector shields.

PHASE 2 : The X-Wing flies down to the surface of the Death Star and is confronted with a barrage of laser turrets and towers as the X-Wing flies across the Death Star's surface. Any collisions with either the towers or incoming enemy shots will cause damage to the player's Deflector Shields.
The laser tower tops have a progressive scoring incentive that is displayed at the top center of the screen
column2: along with the number of remaining laser tower tops that need to be destroyed before the X-Wing enters the exhaust port trench. If the player manages to destroy all of the towers
column3: a sizeable point bonus is awarded.

column1: PHASE 3 : The X-Wing begins its approach down the trench of the Death Star
column2: heading for the exhaust port situated at the end of the trench. The trench walls are lined with red laser-gun turrets that fire at the player as he makes his approach. Incoming fire must either be avoided or shot. Trench catwalks of varying shapes and heights also appear in later trench runs. These must be avoided as any collision results in damage to Red 5's deflector shields.

column1: If the player survives the trench run
column2: the voice of 'Han Solo' will advise that 'You're all clear
column3: Kid' and the player must quickly shoot the exhaust port to destroy the Death Star. If a trench run is completed without the player having fired any shots other than the shot into the exhaust port
column4: a sizeable point bonus is awarded for 'using the force'. If the exhaust port is missed
column5: Red 5 will plough through the wall at the end of the trench and lose one deflector shield
column6: after which the trench run will start over.

column1: If the player succeeds in blowing up the Death Star
column2: Red 5 makes its escape before turning to view the colourful explosion. Bonus points for Remaining Shield Energy is now scored.

column1: The player is then returned to the fray and whole process begins again. Each successive Death Star run greatly increases in difficulty; TIE Fighters shoot more often
column2: there are more Laser towers and batteries in successive rounds and there are many more obstacles and laser fire during the trench run."

column1: Before each stage begins

column4: Laser

column6: players can choose additional firepower
column7: Homing Missiles
column8: Shielded Options or an energy barrier. Players can stock up on multiple bombs including Small bombs
column9: rockets

column1: An audible signal warns that it's refueling time. Enter a fuel dock and receive 100-300 points. The Tank commander's life isn't an easy one.

column2: he has to watch out for obstacles and rough terrain. Brick walls destroy tanks
column3: although they can be shot away. TNT

column6: though. It's a slip zone like an oil slick and can be driven across. If an alien base is found and destroyed
column7: advance to the next level of difficulty. You bet there's a 'buy-in' feature on this one.

column1: Strategy X. There's never been a war game like it. It blows minds

column1: 3970;streets1;streetsm1;"Street Smart (c) 1989 SNK [Shin Nihon Kikaku].

;You begin by choosing one of 2 fighters (either a blond guy, or a dark haired guy in karate gear). Then you are whisked away to one of many cities on the map to have a battle. The opponents are tough, but simple. This game has no special moves (and has only punch, kick, and jump buttons), and all characters have insanely high energy. So you pretty much just wail away at each other with punches and kicks until someone falls down. An ambulance will show up to haul away your defeated opponent, and a girl in the audience will come out to congratulate you

3977;striderj;striderj;"ストライダー飛竜 (c) 1989 Capcom Company
column2: Limited.

column1: ;(Strider Hiryu)
Strider Hiryu is a multi-directional scrolling platform beat-em-up in which the player takes control of 'Strider Hiryu'
column2: a ninja-style warrior who must defeat a legendary being known as 'Grandmaster Meio'.

column1: Set in a dystopian future in the year 2048
column2: Meio has been watching Earth from his own distant galaxy and has created a space station (known as 'The Third Moon') between Earth and its moon in order to rule over the Human race.

column1: Armed with a curved sword known as a 'Falchion'
column2: Strider must travel the globe to find and destroy Meio. Numerous power-ups can be obtained from metallic item boxes carried by certain enemies. These include an extension to Hiryu's attack range that lasts for one hundred slashes
column3: two types of health aids (represented by the kanji used to write Hiryu's name)
column4: a max health extension
column5: an extra life and a power-up that not only makes Hiryu invulnerable to attack
column6: but also increases his own attack abilities via shadow images of himself for 30 seconds.

column1: Hiryu can also summon robotic companions known collectively as ""options"" that help him fight enemies. These consist of up to two mushroom-like droids
column2: a saber-toothed tiger and a hawk. These are referred to as Options A
column3: B and C respectively.

column1: Strider Hiryu is highly agile and has the ability to latch onto walls and ceilings using a metallic hook; a concept which set the game apart from other platformers and allowed for highly inventive level design.
The game consists of five stages:
* Kazakh Soviet Sot Republic (called ""St. Petersburgh"" during the arcade game's attract sequence)
* Siberian Wilderness
* Aerial Battleship Ballog
* Amazonian Jungle
* The Third Moon.
Each stage is divided into a number of smaller sections
column2: with each section imposing its own time limit. Strider initially has a three-point health gauge (which can be increased to five points with health extension power-ups) and will lose a life when the health gauge is fully depleted. Lives are also lost by either falling into a bottomless pit
column3: or failing to complete a section within the time limit.

column1: The game ends once all lives are lost
column2: but continues are available."

3981;strkforc;strkforc;"Strikeforce (c) 1991 Midway.

;Strike Force is a side-scrolling shoot-em-up and is the third game in Midway's seminal ""Defender"" series. Saurian lizard men have overrun all twenty-two planets that form the New Earth Solar System colonies
column2: capturing and mutating the resident humans into reptiles to use as slave labour at their stronghold base
column3: the Saurian 'Mega-Star Apocalypse'.

column1: Players fly a spaceship over the surface of the of planets
column2: destroying enemy waves and rescuing humans from the alien invaders
column3: with rescued humans hanging from the underside of the player's ship. Once these tasks have been completed
column4: the mothership arrives to pick up the player's ship
column5: together with any humans they have rescued. Players can decide which planets to attack
column6: when to purchase additional firepower and when to attack the Apocalypse.

column1: Strike Force adds several new features to the series. Two players can now share the screen at one time and the surface of each planet is littered with various special weapons that can be picked up and deployed. Humans can be 'mutated' into small green creatures that will fight against the player (although players can still pick them up for points as
column2: with the unmutated humans). The mutants can also use vehicles found on the planet's surface against the player."

column1: 3982;strkzone;strkzone;"Strike Zone Baseball (c) 1988 Leland Corp.
