3986;stunrn2e;stunrun2e;S.T.U.N. Runner (c) 1989 Atari Games Corp.
;Take a seat
column2: grasp the controls
column3: and enter the world of the S.T.U.N. (Spread Tunnel Underground Network) Runner. Players travel ahead in time to the 21st century and experience the thrill of racing in a futuristic form of competitive driving. At the control of state-of-the-art technology
column4: players pilot a billion-dollar vehicle capable of attaining speeds of over 900 miles per hour!

column1: Players control their vehicles with a return-to-center (RTC) flight controller. Control handles adjust shot elevation and include trigger buttons for firing. The start button is also used as a fire button for 'shock waves'.

S.T.U.N. runner is a game of speed. The goal of this game is to travel as fast as possible and complete each race within the allotted time. Numerous enemies prevent the player from achieving this goal. Equipped with powerful lasers
column2: all enemies can be gunned down with the exception of one.

column1: The race through the S.T.U.N. Network is made up of many levels. Each level presents a unique challenge to the player. The player's ultimate goal is to guide the vehicle through the network of levels to reach the 'Ultimate Challenge'. In this never-ending race
column2: players go as far as their driving skills will take them. If the distance they travel qualifies as one of the top five
column3: their name (18 letters) will be displayed along the road for future players to see (only if they reach this distance).

column1: In S.T.U.N. Runner
column2: there is no foot pedal to control speed. Faster speed is achieved by :

column1: * Correctly driving on the fastest portion of the tunnel.
* Staying off side rails (of flat sections).
* Avoiding collisions with enemy vehicles.
* Running over 'boosts' for hyperspeed.
* Avoiding areas under construction.
In turn
column2: the fastest portion of the tunnel is the outer wall. Like a luge or bobsled racer
column3: players use basic laws of physics to attain the fastest speed.  Riding on the inner wall results in a slower speed and hinders a player's ability to reach a finish line. On flat sections
column4: running into side rails creates a visual and audio chattering resulting in a loss of speed. The first race
column5: a training race
column6: called 'Cake Walk'
column7: is intended to teach players how to drive correctly.

column1: Red flashing markers in tunnels and flats are called 'boosts'. By running over these
column2: the S.T.U.N. Runner gets a boost of hyperspeed. In addition to reaching the finish line faster
column3: a S.T.U.N. Runner in boost in invincible. The vehicle can pass through all enemy vehicles unharmed and cannot be shot. In this mode the player's vehicle will appear transparent as though it is a skeleton.

column1: The underground network has three different tunnel sections. They include wide tunnels
column2: narrow tunnels
column3: and tunnels under construction. Under construction sections contain portions that are unsurfaced. These areas do not provide full power to the vehicle
column4: and slow down the S.T.U.N. Runner.

column1: Open areas are called 'flats' and are both narrow and wide. Being above the ground
column2: the player is treated to many views of the earth's surface in the 21st century. On flats
column3: players must avoid driving along the side rails. The friction caused will slow down the S.T.U.N. Runner vehicle.

column1: A S.T.U.N. Runner vehicle has six shields for added protection. Colliding with an enemy results in the loss of one shield. At the end of each race
column2: players are awarded bonus points for each shield remaining. A large bonus is awarded if all shields are intact.

column1: In the tunnels and flats are ramps. These ramps will catapult S.T.U.N. Runners above the track for a brief distance. Ramp jumping is often a good method of crossing areas under construction and avoiding collisions with enemies.
When players do not reach the finish line of a race within the allotted time
column2: the game would normally end. However
column3: they can be allowed to advance to the next level on a continuation.

column1: Special Weapon : In selected races
column2: a 'shock wave' is located along the way.  If the player can pick up the shock wave
column3: the weapon becomes available for use. Also
column4: shock waves can be awarded on some levels if the player hits a predetermined number of stars and completes the level. This information is green in the map at the start of each level.

column1: Players activate the shock wave by pressing the start button. This super weapon will destroy all enemies and hazards within view. It is a one-time weapon
column2: but more than one can be stored. The number of shock waves stored is show as blue and white icons on the screen below the level number display.

column1: Bonus Stars : Additional points can be scored along the way by running over 'stars'. In the first race
column2: the training race called 'Cake Walk'
column3: the stars are red. Players should run over as many stars as possible. In the remainder of the game
column4: all bonus stars are green.

column1: Challenge Races : These are bonus races awarded to players for reaching various points in the game. Races 5
column3: and 15 are challenge races. Each presents a unique challenge to the player.

column1: * Boost Challenge
* Star Challenge
* Kill Challenge
In each challenge race
column2: players have one goal. Instructions are displayed prior to the start of each race. The time clock still operates
column3: but a game will not end because the time expires. This is considered a free bonus for players. Each challenge level has its own high score table.

column1: Ultimate Challenge : For those players skilful and patient enough
column2: an 'Ultimate Challenge' awaits them at the end. It is an endless race filled with enemies and unexpected surprises. The object is to travel as far as possible within the allotted time. Markers on the road display the names of the five best S.T.U.N. Runners. It is a unique method of identifying the best players of the game. These names are also presented on a separate high score table."

column1: Players control their vehicles with a return-to-center (RTC) flight controller. Control handles adjust shot elevation and include trigger buttons for firing. The start button is also used as a fire button for 'shock waves'.

column2: all enemies can be gunned down with the exception of one.

column1: The race through the S.T.U.N. Network is made up of many levels. Each level presents a unique challenge to the player. The player's ultimate goal is to guide the vehicle through the network of levels to reach the 'Ultimate Challenge'. In this never-ending race
column2: players go as far as their driving skills will take them. If the distance they travel qualifies as one of the top five
column3: their name (18 letters) will be displayed along the road for future players to see (only if they reach this distance).

column1: In S.T.U.N. Runner
column2: there is no foot pedal to control speed. Faster speed is achieved by :

When players do not reach the finish line of a race within the allotted time
column2: the game would normally end. However
column3: they can be allowed to advance to the next level on a continuation.

column1: Special Weapon : In selected races
column2: a 'shock wave' is located along the way.  If the player can pick up the shock wave
column3: the weapon becomes available for use. Also
column4: shock waves can be awarded on some levels if the player hits a predetermined number of stars and completes the level. This information is green in the map at the start of each level.

column1: Players activate the shock wave by pressing the start button. This super weapon will destroy all enemies and hazards within view. It is a one-time weapon
column2: but more than one can be stored. The number of shock waves stored is show as blue and white icons on the screen below the level number display.

column1: Bonus Stars : Additional points can be scored along the way by running over 'stars'. In the first race
column2: the training race called 'Cake Walk'
column3: the stars are red. Players should run over as many stars as possible. In the remainder of the game
column4: all bonus stars are green.

column1: Challenge Races : These are bonus races awarded to players for reaching various points in the game. Races 5
column3: and 15 are challenge races. Each presents a unique challenge to the player.

column1: * Boost Challenge
* Star Challenge
* Kill Challenge
In each challenge race
column2: players have one goal. Instructions are displayed prior to the start of each race. The time clock still operates
column3: but a game will not end because the time expires. This is considered a free bonus for players. Each challenge level has its own high score table.

column1: Ultimate Challenge : For those players skilful and patient enough
column2: an 'Ultimate Challenge' awaits them at the end. It is an endless race filled with enemies and unexpected surprises. The object is to travel as far as possible within the allotted time. Markers on the road display the names of the five best S.T.U.N. Runners. It is a unique method of identifying the best players of the game. These names are also presented on a separate high score table."

column1: 3992;stunrun4;stunrun4;"S.T.U.N. Runner (c) 1989 Atari Games Corp.
;Take a seat
column2: grasp the controls
column3: and enter the world of the S.T.U.N. (Spread Tunnel Underground Network) Runner. Players travel ahead in time to the 21st century and experience the thrill of racing in a futuristic form of competitive driving. At the control of state-of-the-art technology
column4: players pilot a billion-dollar vehicle capable of attaining speeds of over 900 miles per hour!

column1: Players control their vehicles with a return-to-center (RTC) flight controller. Control handles adjust shot elevation and include trigger buttons for firing. The start button is also used as a fire button for 'shock waves'.

S.T.U.N. runner is a game of speed. The goal of this game is to travel as fast as possible and complete each race within the allotted time. Numerous enemies prevent the player from achieving this goal. Equipped with powerful lasers
column2: all enemies can be gunned down with the exception of one.

column1: The race through the S.T.U.N. Network is made up of many levels. Each level presents a unique challenge to the player. The player's ultimate goal is to guide the vehicle through the network of levels to reach the 'Ultimate Challenge'. In this never-ending race
column2: players go as far as their driving skills will take them. If the distance they travel qualifies as one of the top five
column3: their name (18 letters) will be displayed along the road for future players to see (only if they reach this distance).

column1: In S.T.U.N. Runner
column2: there is no foot pedal to control speed. Faster speed is achieved by :

column1: * Correctly driving on the fastest portion of the tunnel.
* Staying off side rails (of flat sections).
* Avoiding collisions with enemy vehicles.
* Running over 'boosts' for hyperspeed.
* Avoiding areas under construction.
In turn
column2: the fastest portion of the tunnel is the outer wall. Like a luge or bobsled racer
column3: players use basic laws of physics to attain the fastest speed.  Riding on the inner wall results in a slower speed and hinders a player's ability to reach a finish line. On flat sections
column4: running into side rails creates a visual and audio chattering resulting in a loss of speed. The first race
column5: a training race
column6: called 'Cake Walk'
column7: is intended to teach players how to drive correctly.

column1: Red flashing markers in tunnels and flats are called 'boosts'. By running over these
column2: the S.T.U.N. Runner gets a boost of hyperspeed. In addition to reaching the finish line faster
column3: a S.T.U.N. Runner in boost in invincible. The vehicle can pass through all enemy vehicles unharmed and cannot be shot. In this mode the player's vehicle will appear transparent as though it is a skeleton.

column1: The underground network has three different tunnel sections. They include wide tunnels
column2: narrow tunnels
column3: and tunnels under construction. Under construction sections contain portions that are unsurfaced. These areas do not provide full power to the vehicle
column4: and slow down the S.T.U.N. Runner.

column1: Open areas are called 'flats' and are both narrow and wide. Being above the ground
column2: the player is treated to many views of the earth's surface in the 21st century. On flats
column3: players must avoid driving along the side rails. The friction caused will slow down the S.T.U.N. Runner vehicle.

column1: A S.T.U.N. Runner vehicle has six shields for added protection. Colliding with an enemy results in the loss of one shield. At the end of each race
column2: players are awarded bonus points for each shield remaining. A large bonus is awarded if all shields are intact.

column3: they can be allowed to advance to the next level on a continuation.

column1: * Boost Challenge
* Star Challenge
* Kill Challenge
In each challenge race
column2: players have one goal. Instructions are displayed prior to the start of each race. The time clock still operates
column3: but a game will not end because the time expires. This is considered a free bonus for players. Each challenge level has its own high score table.

column1: Ultimate Challenge : For those players skilful and patient enough
column2: an 'Ultimate Challenge' awaits them at the end. It is an endless race filled with enemies and unexpected surprises. The object is to travel as far as possible within the allotted time. Markers on the road display the names of the five best S.T.U.N. Runners. It is a unique method of identifying the best players of the game. These names are also presented on a separate high score table."

3999;subroc3d;subroc3d;Subroc-3D (c) 1982 Sega.
;SUBROC-3D is an overwhelming 3-dimensional game
column2: with a dual scene system for battles in the ocean or in space. The graphics and sound effects are very exciting!

column1: You command a sophisticated craft and by using the elevation controls you can move it up or down so it can be operated under water or in space.
The periscope-type viewer can be moved from side to side
column2: enabling you to attack more enemies.

column1: Preen the fire button to shoot down the enemy.
The dynamic stereo sound system creates an amazingly realistic surround effect.
Many strangely-shaped crafts
column2: missiles and UFOs suddenly zoom in to attack you; once they are in your sights they can attack you
column3: so shoot first and survive!

column1: The 3-dimensional effect of fast-moving crafts and missiles
column2: combined with the terrifying  explosions seemingly right up close to you are truly bewildering.

column1: To destroy the BARRIER guarding the enemy COMMAND SHIP
column2: you must hit it in the very center.

column1: After blowing up the COMMAND SHIP
column2: you proceed to another round.

column1: The bonus points remaining will be added to your score.
When you reach HIGH SCORE you will get another ship.
In each successive round the score increases by 100 points over the previous round.
Your score and the round are displayed at the top of the screen. Your score and the previous best three scores are displayed over the periscope.
Play ends with the loss of your last ship."

4004;sunsetbl;ssridersb;Sunset Riders (c) 1991 Konami.
;Sunset Riders is a superb sideways scrolling shoot-em-up for one to four players set in America's Wild West. Four sharpshooter bounty hunters (Steve
column2: Billy
column3: Bob and Cormano) set out to claim the bounties given for killing the most wanted outlaws in the West. The ultimate aim is to survive long enough to reach the final showdown against Sir Richard de la Rose.

column1: Sunset Riders is an incredibly playable game featuring colourful and well-drawn graphics
column2: with a number of humorous visual jokes keeping players entertained. The side-scrolling action takes place both on foot and on horseback
column3: with the action sometimes broken up with a wild west pursuit; such as having to run along the backs of a herd of fleeing Buffalo.

column1: Each level ends with players entering a one-on-one battle against one of the wanted men they have been pursuing. Weapon power-ups can be found and collected to help players in their quest."
4005;supbtime;supbtime;"Super Burger Time (c) 1990 Data East.

;Peter Pepper returns almost eight years after the original Burger Time - and this time, there are more evil things in his way, more tools to deal with them (the classic pepper, a skewer, a frying pan, even a water hose), and bigger burgers to assemble. You even have to fight bosses, by heaving hamburgers at them!

;Agent Super Bond is a shooter game like the 007 series games. You have to shoot at objects and people that try to attack you, and find specific objects to complete the level. This game also has very similar spirtes to the Galaxian hardware shoot-em-up know as Lost Tomb.
4010;superbug;superbug;Super Bug (c) 1977 Kee Games.
;A great and pioneer top-view racing game.
Super Bug! Super Thrills!

The player drive a bright yellow ""modified bug"" speeds through tree-lined city streets in a fast moving rally race. The constantly moving streets provide new excitement and driving challenge every time the game is played
column2: as the driver races the clock to cover as much distance as possible for highest score.

column1: Directional arrows appear on the road to warn drivers as they approach turns. Quick reflexes are a must to avoid crashing into curbs and parked cars. And to avoid sliding into oil slicks and sand traps.
Players can select ""Novice"" or ""Expert"" tracks
column2: shift into first
column3: step on the accelerator and take off. The roar of acceleration
column4: crash and skid sounds add to the exciment. Score
column5: Fuel (time remaining) and driver Ratings are displayed on the screen
column6: as well as ""Crunch"" whenever the player crashes."

;Superman is a horizontal video game and may be played by one or two players interactively. The second player controlling a red Superman character
column2: teams up with the first player in this battle against the evil Alien Powers.

column1: Each players uses a joystick to move his Superman character while walking or in flight. Two buttons aside each joystick are used to throw punches
column2: kick or emit Superman's Heat Vision
column3: a high-intensity laser which destroys all in its path. As Suprman picks up various colored crystals
column4: he is awarded with addtitional energy and weapons including a Super Blast Punch and Mass Terminator. Items such as cars
column5: gasoline cans
column6: etc. can also be picked up and hurled at approaching enemies.

column1: The many stages in the game are located in different cities of the U.S. and provide the player with real variety:
1st round: New York
2nd round: San Francisco
3rd round: Las Vegas
4th round: Washington
5th round: Alien Space Ship"
4015;superpac;superpac;"Super Pac-Man (c) 1982 Namco.
;Super Pac-Man is a 1- or 2-player game where you are in control of the legendary Pac-Man. As in the original ""Pac-Man"" game
column2: the goal is to clear each maze
column3: but this time
column4: instead of dots
column5: the maze consists of prizes which are locked away behind gates. There are two ways to access the prizes. You can eat the keys which open a particular gate
column6: and not always the gate which is closest to that key. Or you can crash through the gate after you eat a Super Pill and become Super Pac-Man. You are not required to eat all of the keys in order to complete the stage.

column1: Four Power Pills are in maze and allow Pac-Man to turn the tables on the ghosts and eat them for a short time. When the ghosts begin to flash
column2: time is running out and they will switch back
column3: so beware.

column1: New in this game is the Super Pill. There are two Super Pills in the maze which allow Pac-Man to become Super Pac-Man for a limited period of time. While in Super form
column2: Pac-Man can crash through the maze gates
column3: fly over the ghosts and avoid being killed (or eat them when they're blue)
column4: and travel at super speed whenever the player presses and holds the Super Speed button. When the super power is about to run out
column5: Pac-Man flashes white and then returns to his normal form. You can extend the duration of Super time by eating a regular Power Pill. The Super time will then be extended by the duration of the ghosts' blue time.

column1: Pac-Man loses one life whenever a ghost catches him when the ghost is not blue and Pac-Man is not in Super form. You start with a set number of lives ('Lives' dip switch)
column2: and bonus lives can be awarded to you as you reach or pass certain preselected point values ('Extra Lives' dip switch).

column1: The tunnel is a great way to put some space between you and any ghosts that are on your tail since they can only move half as fast as you when they are in it. In Super Pac-Man
column2: the ghosts are also slowed down by travelling through the passage directly beneath the ghost pen.

column1: Occasionally
column2: a star will appear in the middle of the screen with a picture on the left
column3: and a rotating picture on the right. You may eat the star at any time for bonus points
column4: but if you manage to eat the star when the right picture matches the left one
column5: you will receive a larger bonus.

column1: As the stages increases
column2: the ghosts speed up their pursuit of Pac-Man and they stay blue for shorter and shorter periods of time after he eats a Power Pill until
column3: in the high stages
column4: they do not turn blue at all.

column1: Super Pac-Man also features bonus stages in Stage 3
column2: Stage 7
column3: and every fourth stage thereafter
column4: where there are no ghosts
column5: a time limit
column6: and Pac-Man is in Super form throughout the stage. Your goal is to eat all of the prizes in the given time limit. As with gameplay on the regular levels
column7: you don't need to eat all (or any) of the keys. You are awarded the remaining time in the counter as points for successfully eating everything. With each Bonus stage
column8: the walls and gates change color.

column1: Super Pac-Man remains true to the intermission formula established in ""Pac-Man"". These intermissions are more like the simple humorous anecdotes found in the original game
column2: than the episodic stories told by the intermissions in ""Ms. Pac-Man"" and ""Jr. Pac-Man"". Super Pac-Man features four intermissions :

column1: 1) Pac-Man enters from the left side of the screen
column2: followed closely by the ghosts. When Pac-Man exits the screen to the right
column3: the ghosts stop. Super Pac-Man appears high up from the right and the ghosts helplessly watch as Super Pac-Man flies over their heads and exits to the left. This intermission is played after Stage 2.

column1: 2) As a tribute to the first intermission from the original game
column2: Pac-Man enters from the right
column3: and is followed by what appears to be a super version of Blinky. After they exit to the left
column4: a super Blinky reappears from the left in his blue form
column5: and is now followed by an even larger version of Super Pac-Man. This intermission is played after Stage 6.

column1: 3) Pac-Man enters from the left side of the screen
column2: followed closely by the ghosts. Before Pac-Man makes it all the way to the right
column3: he simply disappears
column4: leaving the ghosts stunned and puzzled. As the ghosts look around for Pac-Man's whereabouts
column5: Clyde looks up and notices the extremely large version of Super Pac-Man falling from the sky
column6: instantly scaring all of the ghosts blue before this super-duper Pac-Man squashes them. This intermission is played after Stage 11
column7: which is the third Bonus Stage.

column1: 4) The extra-large Super Pac-Man enters from the left side of the screen
column2: followed by a pack of 32 ghosts
column3: 8 of each color. After exiting to the right
column4: four scared (blue) super ghosts reappear from the right. Much to their misfortune
column5: they are being chased by 32 normal-sized Pac-Men. This intermission is played after Stage 16 and every 4th stage thereafter.

column1: - CAST OF CHARACTERS -
* Pac-Man - Once again
column2: you control the little yellow hero as you guide him through the maze and onto victory. Pac-Man's goal is to gobble up every target item. He must avoid contact with the ghosts unless they are blue as a result of Pac-Man eating a Power Pill
column3: or when Pac-Man is in Super form as a result of eating a Super Pill. Unlike the other classic Pac-games
column4: Pac-Man does not move any slower when he's eating targets than when he isn't. True to the other Pac-games
column5: however
column6: he is still capable of turning around corners faster than the ghosts
column7: so make as many turns as possible when the ghosts are on his tail.

column1: * Super Pac-Man - After eating a Super Pill
column2: Pac-Man becomes large and in charge. In Super form
column3: he can eat through gates without the use of a key
column4: fly over ghosts without colliding with them (the ghosts actually change in appearance
column5: becoming squat or thin depending on the direction they are moving; this ability does not prevent Super Pac-Man from eating blue ghosts)
column6: moving faster when the Super Speed button is held down
column7: and extending the duration of his super power by eating a normal Power Pill. When Pac-Man's Super power is about to expire
column8: he flashes white just like the ghosts do when they are about to change back to normal.

column1: * Ghosts - Blinky
column2: Pinky
column3: Inky
column4: and Clyde are back. Basically
column5: they behave the same. Blinky follows you more closely than any of the other ghosts
column6: shadowing your trail
column7: Pinky tries to stay one step ahead of you by second-guessing which way you will go and trapping you
column8: Inky usually turns away if you take him head on
column9: and Clyde does his own thing for the most part. In this game
column10: their behavior is a tad more random than in the first game
column11: so patterns cannot be relied upon. Also new in Super Pac-Man
column12: they will exhibit a ""stutter"" behavior from time to time where they seem to shake in one spot briefly before continuing on. This can sometimes save you if you are being chased
column13: or it can mess you up if you are following behind a ghost too closely.

column1: * Scared Ghosts - As in the original game
column2: if Pac-Man eats a Power Pill
column3: the ghosts will turn blue for a short period of time. The higher the stage
column4: the shorter that time becomes
column5: until the ghosts don't turn blue at all (but they do change direction). Eating ghosts scores big points (see Scoring below)
column6: but watch out when they start flashing because they're about to change back to their normal state.

column1: * Power Pills - A carry-over from the original ""Pac-Man"" game. These four large white blinking dots in the corners of the maze allow Pac-Man to temporarily chase and eat the ghosts until they begin to flash and turn back to normal. In this game
column2: eating a Power Pill while in Super form extends Super time into the ghosts' blue time.

column1: * Super Pills - These two green pills grow and shrink in size close to the middle of the maze. When Pac-Man eats one of these
column2: he grows to Super size and gains the power to crash through barriers
column3: fly over ghosts
column4: and use Super Speed.

column1: * Keys - The ultimate prize in the original game becomes an integral tool in this game. Eat the keys to open the gates that block your access to the prizes. You don't have to eat all of the keys to complete the stage. The maze contains 15 keys in all.
* Gates - The doors that block Pac-Man from eating the prizes he needs to eat in order to complete the stage. There are 37 gates in all.
* Prizes - Unlike in the original game
column2: where you had to eat dots and collect the prizes for bonus points
column3: you must eat all of prizes to complete the stage. The maze contains 31 prizes in all.

column1: * Bonus Star - Once Pac-Man has eaten a total of 15 items in the maze (including power pills and super pills
column2: but not including keys)
column3: a bonus star will appear with one picture to the left
column4: and a rapidly changing picture to the right. Eat the star for bonus points
column5: or try to eat the star when the pictures match for an even higher bonus. Try to eat the star when the pictures on either side match and are the same as the current stage's main prize (for example
column6: apples in Stage 1) to score the maximum possible bonus points.

column1: * Tunnel - By going through one end of the tunnel
column2: Pac-Man and the ghosts can cross over to the other side of the screen. Any ghost who goes through the tunnel will move at half speed. This speed decrease also occurs under the ghost pen now."

4046;swat;swat;SWAT (c) 1984 Sega.
;An abstract one or two player shoot-em-up in which the aim is to stop swarms of aliens from building a sectional tunnel from the bottom of the screen to the top.
At the top of each level are blue tunnel sections
column2: while at the bottom are purple ones. Aliens start at the bottom of the screen in the purple sections. As they move through a tunnel
column3: they can build new sections in any direction.

column1: Players can either destroy blue tunnel sections
column2: or 'shove' them to re-align them and prevent the aliens from completing their mission. Purple sections cannot be destroyed but they CAN be shoved. A 'smart bomb' can be deployed which will destroy all nearby enemies
column3: as well as the players
column4: on-screen counter-parts should they be within the blast radius when the bomb explodes. Additional bombs can be earned by destroying blue sections of tunnel.

column1: If the aliens succeed in connecting up a tunnel
column2: additional enemies appear and the challenge increasing substantially. Each round ends when a preset number of 'Blocker' aliens have been destroyed.

column1: There are four types of enemies :
* BLOCKERS - These foes build the tunnels and they can exit the tunnel system or be forced out. If they exit the tunnels
column2: they produce 'Expelers' (see below) and quickly make their way to the bottom of the screen to re-enter the tunnels. This is the only time that they are vulnerable.

column1: * EXPELERS - These enemies
column2: produced by the Blockers
column3: chase the players around the screen and attempt to corner them. They travel at different speeds
column4: generally moving faster as they get closer to SWAT agents.

column1: * ANNGRERS - These cubed-shaped foes are invulnerable to the SWAT agent's fire. Shooting this type of enemy will cause it to chase the players very quickly. They can be destroyed by using bombs
column2: but a new Anngrer will be created in its place at the bottom of the screen. These enemies can travel in and out of the tunnel system wherever they choose.

column1: * SWEEPERS - Along with additional enemy fire
column2: these foes appear in pairs on the left and right sides of the tunnel along if the bottom and top portions of the screen are connected by one continuous tunnel. They will line up with each other on either side of the players' SWAT agents and fire at them. Sweepers require multiple shots to be destroyed."

4061;szaxxon;szaxxon;Super Zaxxon (c) 1982 Sega.
;Super Zaxxon is a 1- or 2-player video game that presents the player with tremendous challenge and excitement never before experienced. The 3-dimensional-like
column2: isometric graphics are produced by projecting the picture at a slant on the screen
column3: putting the player in remote controlled realism with his player ship.

column1: The player ship climbs
column2: dives and strafes to maneuver through the many obstacles it encounters in its flight. In unique game play action
column3: the player ship appears larger or smaller depending on its altitude
column4: casts trailing shadow that follows it just as a real shadow would. This shadow
column5: an altimeter on the video screen
column6: and the points of impact of the player's gunfire
column7: help judge the altitude of the player's space craft
column8: lending new skill and challenge to Super Zaxxon.

column1: Flying at supersonic speeds
column2: the player confronts an ominous floating munitions fortress.  Here the player ship must battle hidden ground-to-air missiles
column3: rotating gun turrets
column4: tracking parabolic antennas and electrifying maser barriers as he banks
column5: climbs and dives to strafe enemy installations and fuel tanks
column6: gaining valuable points towards ships and extra fuel.

column1: Once through the fortress
column2: Super Zaxxon lures the player ship into a foreboding tunnel where the player must use cautious skill and a responsive extra-heavy duty fighter pilot control stick to overcome the limited ceiling in the tunnel and dodge or destroy a terrific onslaught of flying minelayers
column3: enemy ships and self-destructing robot spaceships
column4: yet also avoid the indestructible mines that crowd the dim corridor.

column1: Accompanied by the roar of space wind
column2: the player soars out of the tunnel to face another battle within the enemy headquarters. This is a more heavily defended floating fortress of tighter passageways armed with maser barriers and increasingly heavier firepower from enemy defenses. Overcoming all this
column3: the player is ready to face the ultimate challenge within the enemy headquarters - a bigger-than-life
column4: fire breathing Dragon who can destroy the player ship with a single breath of fire. With an unnerving wail
column5: the fierce Dragon flies forward and unleashes a breath of flame from its huge mouth. But by firing six direct hits on the Dragon's mouth
column6: the player can defeat the Dragon. The game ends with the loss of the last player ship."

column1: 4062;tacscan;tacscan;"Tac/Scan (c) 1982 Sega.
;Tac/Scan is a 1 or 2-player alternate action game
column2: displayed via Sega's Color X-Y video system. Commanding unprecedented firepower
column3: the player maneuvers seven fighter ships in a squadron formation. All seven ships fire at once when the Fire button is pressed
column4: producing a spectacular missile salvo.

column1: The object of the game is to accumulate points by destroying incoming enemy ships while dodging fireballs launched by these enemies. Tac/Scan presents the space battle from two entirely different perspective views in the course of the game
column2: with visually exciting transition sequences interconnecting the two views.

column1: The player begins the game with a seven-ship formation
column2: and a supply of reserve ships which are shown above the player score on the screen. The number of reserve ships at the beginning of the game is switch selectable. An Add Ship button placed next to the Fire button transfers one of the reserve ships in the squadron formation. Where the reserve ships are placed is shown by a half-intensity fighter in the formation. This 'add ship' position continuously cycles between the empty squadron positions
column3: and the advanced player will time the Add Ship function to place squadron fighters at preferred positions.

column1: A player fighter is blown up by contact with either an enemy ship or an enemy fireball. Whenever all seven ship positions become empty the game is over
column2: even if there are remaining reserve fighters shown above the player score. Thus the player must continuously judge when to add reserve fighters by using the Add Ship button. Add them too early
column3: and they might be depleted too fast; use them too late and you risk ending the game with reserve fighters left over.

column1: There is an additional way to add ships to the squadron. During the course of the action
column2: player fighter ships enter the playfield and intermix with the enemy ships. The player can capture these fighters directly into the seven ship formation by steering them into empty fighter positions. The player's missile fire does not blow up friendly fighters--only enemy ships.

column1: Tac/Scan begins with a top view of the battle. For the first ten seconds the player shoots at enemy ships without having to worry about return fire. After this 'warm-up' period
column2: game play escalates dramatically. During this first phase
column3: a different type of enemy appears just after two of the player fighters fly onto the screen. This is the Stinger
column4: which flits around the field and shoots a deadly laser. This ship is a high priority target
column5: since if not dealt with
column6: it will pick off all of the squadron ships and end the game.

column1: When the player attempts to dock a friendly fighter into the squadron formation
column2: he or she has the choice of any of the empty ship positions shown in the squadron. A special feature occurs when the player ship docks into the front-most ship position (marked with a red 'cursor'). Thin causes the squadron formation to regroup into a different pattern. If the load position is occupied
column3: a fighter is added to the reserve count above the player's score.

column1: At the end of the first phase (the top view) the squadron ships regroup
column2: and a dramatic transition sequence takes the player into phase two. This sequence consists of the fighters rising and enlarging in size
column3: then turning into the screen
column4: lighting afterburners
column5: and proceeding to fly forward to continue the battle. The enemy ships now appear far off in the distance
column6: and grow in size as they approach the player's squadron. The player is given chances to rendezvous with friendly fighters
column7: as in phase one.

column1: At the end of this second phase
column2: a space tunnel appears on the screen
column3: and the player uses the rotary control to steer the squadron formation through the tunnel. Any fighter which hits a side wall of the tunnel explodes on contact. A triangular guide is shown during this sequence to show the player where his triangular ship formation should be. If the player keeps the formation centered within the guide
column4: no ships will be lost.

column1: Once out of the space tunnel
column2: the player resumes with the second round. This is a more difficult top view battle
column3: as at the beginning of the game. Tac/Scan proceeds with multiple two-phase rounds (phase one is the top view
column4: phase two is the rear view) until all squadron ships are lost.

column1: A switch option allows bonus reserve chips to he added with certain score values. The factory set option is to add one reserve ship every 30
column2: 000 points.

column1: Regardless of the number of squadron ships on the screen
column2: there are always seven missiles at a time available to the player. If there are seven ships on the screen (a full squadron)
column3: pressing the Fire button launches all seven at once. Another push of the Fire button cancels the seven in flight and launches seven new ones. If the squadron is not full
column4: the seven missiles can be independently targeted. For example
column5: with a single ship
column6: seven missiles can be fired in seven directions
column7: and only when the eighth is shot is the first one terminated (if it is still on the screen).

column1: The 2-player game is played with players alternating after successful negotiation of the space tunnel. Whenever a player is eliminated
column2: the other player continues and finishes the game."

column1: 4063;tactcan2;tactcian2;"Tactician (c) 1981 Sega.
;At its core
column2: Tactician might seem like another Space Invaders / Galaxian clone - you control a small ship at the bottom of the screen
column3: which can actually move up or down a bit
column4: instead of just left and right - but it has a pretty cool gimmick going for it.

column1: At the beginning of each stage
column2: you can ""draw"" a barrier by placing little dots around the playing field. After several seconds
column3: enemies are released from their bases and begin to swarm the screen. They'll usually make quick work of the barrier
column4: but if you shoot the red ball it'll explode and destroy anything near it. Quite a cool concept for something from 1981 - it's a shame that Tactician is so unknown
column5: and that the idea was never expanded on in any other games. Some versions list the game as copyrighted by Sega
column6: but they apparently only distributed the game in certain territories."

4080;targ;targ;"Targ (c) 1980 Exidy.
;Targ is a 1 or 2-player shooter game released by Exidy in 1980. Your town is invaded by Targ riders
column2: you must maneuver the heroic vehicle Wummel to destroy them. From time to time
column3: a Spectar comes into screen
column4: and can be destroyed for extra bonus.

column1: Action takes place into a 9x9 grid
column2: 'Crystal City'
column3: where the player's vehicle must avoid and chase down 10 enemy wedge-shaped vehicles. When all enemies are destroyed
column4: you are awarded an extra bonus and can access the following level. 2 players can alternate in the game. You use a 4-way joystick to control the Wummel
column5: and a pushbutton to fire at enemies. Progressing in the gameplay causes the Targs to become faster and smarter
column6: for a fast and furious gameplay."

;Twin Bee Yahho! differs from Detana!! TwinBee in that the player can adjust their playing style before starting the game to suit their preference. The player begins by choosing between three difficulty settings: Practice
column2: Normal
column3: and Special. Practice course is the game's easiest setting and lasts only three stages
column4: whereas the Special course is the hardest setting and is recommended to expert players. The player will then select between four different charged shots. The regular Charge Shot from Detana! TwinBee is selectable
column5: along with a Charge Punch
column6: a Charge Split (which will cause the player's ship to shoot duplicates of itself)
column7: and a Charge Explosion that fires at eight directions at the same time. The player will then choose between two control styles: one which fires the gun with one button and drops bombs with the second
column8: while the other style shoots and drops bomb at the same time with a single button (either button can be used).

column1: Like in previous Twin Bee games
column2: there are two kinds of power-ups: bell power-ups obtained from the sky and land power-ups that can be retrieved from destroy ground enemies. The bells can be changed to up to six colors this time (yellow
column3: blue
column4: white
column5: green
column6: red
column7: and pink)
column8: each with a unique attribute. GwinBee returns as well as a power-up item
column9: along with the twin attacks that can be performed with GwinBee or another player."

;Tekken Tag Tournament is a 'Dream Match' Iron Fist Tournament, and it does not have a plot fitting within the Tekken story timeline. The game is an enhanced version of Tekken 3 including a new Tag feature - where the player selects two fighters and can change between characters during gameplay, and perform tag-team combos. The first side to have a character to be knocked out is the loser. The character list includes almost (if not all) characters from all 3 previous games.

4117;tempest;tempest3;Tempest (c) 1981 Atari.
;Tempest is a classic into-the-screen shoot-em-up in which the player controls a claw-shaped ""Blaster"" ship that moves around the outer rim of a three-dimensional
column2: wireframe tunnel. Enemies move down the tunnel towards the player's ship and must be destroyed. Any contact with either incoming enemy fire or the enemies themselves will cost the player a life. Completion of a tunnel will see the player warp through ""hyperspace"" to the next tunnel to tackle a new wave of enemies.

column1: The tunnels are each rendered in one of sixteen different geometric shapes. Enemies increase in number as the game progresses and if an enemy reaches the outer rim occupied by the player's Blaster ship
column2: it will chase and attempt to kill the player. Rim enemies can be killed
column3: but this is difficult to achieve.

column1: Some enemies also drag ""spikes"" - in the form of lines in the middle of the corridor - behind them as they travel up the tunnel towards the player. These spikes must be avoided during the ""hyperspace"" warp sequence at the end of the level
column2: as contact results in the loss of a life.

column1: Two ""SuperZappers"" are available per level. The first SuperZapper kills all enemies on the playfield at the time of firing
column2: while the second randomly kills only one enemy on the playfield. The SuperZapper does not affect enemy shots
column3: spikes or enemies that have not yet landed on the playfield.

column1: One new feature Tempest introduces is ""Skill-Step"". This allows players to start a new game on the same level as was previously reached (although the new game must be restarted within thirty seconds) without having to replay previous levels. This allows skillful players to continue being challenged
column2: while less experienced players can try to master higher levels. The 99 skill levels of play includes sixteen different playfields and seven different enemy targets.

column1: * The tubes are divided into cosmic corridors through which the aliens travel
column2: although some aliens such as Pulsars and Flippers can move from one corridor to the next. Regardless of the tube shapes
column3: aliens always begin their invasion from the small
column4: distant end of the tube. The sixteen unique tube shapes are as follows :

column1: 1. Circle
2. Square
3. Plus symbol
4. Bow-tie
5. Stylized Cross
6. Triangle
7. Clover
9. Steps
11. Completely Flat
12. Heart
13. Star
15. Fan
16. Infinity Symbol (figure 8 on its side)
The playfield's colour scheme changes every sixteen levels. In addition
column2: other events also cause playfield colour variation. The SuperZapper causes the playfield to flash as enemies are zapped. Playfield rails flash rainbow colours when a player earns a bonus life and Pulsar enemies cause sections of the nearest rim to disappear and - during the pulse phase - adjacent rails to flash.

column1: Tempest level colour schemes:
*Levels 1-16:
Tunnel - blue
Player ship - yellow
SuperZapper - yellow
Flippers - red
Tankers - purple
Spikers/Spikes - green
Pulsars - N/A (these do not appear until the next colour scheme)
*Levels 17-32:
Tunnel - red
Player ship - green
SuperZapper - cyan
Flippers - purple
Tankers - blue
Spikers/Spikes - cyan
Pulsars - yellow
*Levels 33-48:
Tunnel - yellow
Player ship - blue
SuperZapper - blue
Flippers - green
Tankers - cyan
Spikers/Spikes - red
Pulsars - blue
*Levels 49-64:
Tunnel - cyan
Player ship - blue
SuperZapper - red
Flippers - green
Tankers - purple
Spikers/Spikes - red
Pulsars - yellow
*Levels 65-80:
Tunnel - black (invisible)
Player ship - yellow
SuperZapper - white
Flippers - red
Tankers - purple
Spikers/Spikes - green
Pulsars - cyan
*Levels 81-96:
Tunnel - green
Player ship - red
SuperZapper - purple
Flippers - yellow
Tankers - purple
Spikers/Spikes - blue
Pulsars - yellow
Levels 97 and up - Keeps colour scheme from Levels 81-96
column2: with random shapes from Level 99 onward."

column1: 4119;tempest2;tempest2;"Tempest (c) 1981 Atari.
;Tempest is a classic into-the-screen shoot-em-up in which the player controls a claw-shaped ""Blaster"" ship that moves around the outer rim of a three-dimensional
column2: wireframe tunnel. Enemies move down the tunnel towards the player's ship and must be destroyed. Any contact with either incoming enemy fire or the enemies themselves will cost the player a life. Completion of a tunnel will see the player warp through ""hyperspace"" to the next tunnel to tackle a new wave of enemies.

column1: The tunnels are each rendered in one of sixteen different geometric shapes. Enemies increase in number as the game progresses and if an enemy reaches the outer rim occupied by the player's Blaster ship
column2: it will chase and attempt to kill the player. Rim enemies can be killed
column3: but this is difficult to achieve.

column1: Some enemies also drag ""spikes"" - in the form of lines in the middle of the corridor - behind them as they travel up the tunnel towards the player. These spikes must be avoided during the ""hyperspace"" warp sequence at the end of the level
column2: as contact results in the loss of a life.

column1: Two ""SuperZappers"" are available per level. The first SuperZapper kills all enemies on the playfield at the time of firing
column2: while the second randomly kills only one enemy on the playfield. The SuperZapper does not affect enemy shots
column3: spikes or enemies that have not yet landed on the playfield.

column1: One new feature Tempest introduces is ""Skill-Step"". This allows players to start a new game on the same level as was previously reached (although the new game must be restarted within thirty seconds) without having to replay previous levels. This allows skillful players to continue being challenged
column2: while less experienced players can try to master higher levels. The 99 skill levels of play includes sixteen different playfields and seven different enemy targets.

column1: * The tubes are divided into cosmic corridors through which the aliens travel
column2: although some aliens such as Pulsars and Flippers can move from one corridor to the next. Regardless of the tube shapes
column3: aliens always begin their invasion from the small
column4: distant end of the tube. The sixteen unique tube shapes are as follows :

column1: 1. Circle
2. Square
3. Plus symbol
4. Bow-tie
5. Stylized Cross
6. Triangle
7. Clover
9. Steps
11. Completely Flat
12. Heart
13. Star
15. Fan
16. Infinity Symbol (figure 8 on its side)
The playfield's colour scheme changes every sixteen levels. In addition
column2: other events also cause playfield colour variation. The SuperZapper causes the playfield to flash as enemies are zapped. Playfield rails flash rainbow colours when a player earns a bonus life and Pulsar enemies cause sections of the nearest rim to disappear and - during the pulse phase - adjacent rails to flash.

Tunnel - blue
Player ship - yellow
SuperZapper - yellow
Flippers - red
Tankers - purple
Spikers/Spikes - green
Pulsars - N/A (these do not appear until the next colour scheme)
*Levels 17-32:

column1: 4127;terracra;terracren;"Terra Cresta (c) 1985 Nichibutsu.
;Terra Cresta is a vertically-scrolling shoot-em-up set over a constantly scrolling landscape of islands and enemy installations. The player is under constant attack from enemy spaceship waves
column2: ground-based guns and turrets
column3: dinosaurs and three different mothercraft ships.

column1: The levels are littered with ground-based silos bearing numbers between 2 and 5. These can be shot to release a player ship component
column2: which then attaches to the player's current ship
column3: increasing both its size and firepower. Power-ups available are 2-Wide shot
column4: 3-Rear Shot
column5: 4-Front cannon and 5-Rear shield.

column1: Using the 'Formation' button splits the ship parts into a formation for limited time
column2: giving increased fire power. The number of parts acquired determines the formation. For example
column3: if the player has picked up two ship parts then a triangle is formed
column4: with the player's main ship at the rear of the formation
column5: with additional two ship components positioned at the front edge of the triangle.

column1: When all four numbered parts have been collected
column2: the player's ship transforms into a flaming Phoenix
column3: and is indestructible for a limited time."

4145;thedeep;thedeep;"The Deep (c) 1987 Woodplace.

;You control one or two boats floating along the high seas. The boats are armed with depth charges for dropping on the aquatic wildlife and submarines in the depth far below. Homing torpedoes, Polaris missiles, mines, Stingray style vessels and other boat-wrecking hazards make up the threats to avoid or destroy. Bonus capsules which float up to the surface boost the boat's speed, increase depth charge power, give the player temporary invincibility and other normal features but of a marine vein. The depth charges take their time to float to their target so plan ahead using the map, submarines at different heights in the water pose further problems. This game also has good backgrounds.
4146;theend;theend;The End (c) 1980 Konami Industry Company
column2: Limited.

column1:
;In 'The End' you control a ship whose mission is to zap as many bug-ships as possible, before you run out of lives, or the bugs manage to spell out the word END with little chunks of brick. You can move left and right, and the bugs attack from the top of the screen, coming out of a large mothership. But the bugs have another mission besides just blindly attacking you. That other mission is to systematically steal the bricks from your three bases, and use them to spell out the word END up near the top of the screen.

;This title plays a lot like ""Pac-Man""
column2: except the maze is more detailed. You drive you car around the maze
column3: picking up the money that is laying around everywhere (just like the dots in ""Pac-Man""). Now to avoid being any more like"" Pac-Man""
column4: the designer decided to give you four enemies
column5: who each move around the maze with a distinct personality (but they are cars
column6: not ghosts). In a final attempt to make this game different from ""Pac-man""
column7: the designer then added dollar signs in each corner of the screen
column8: running over these allows you to chase after your foes
column9: and run over them (not at all like ""Pac-Man""). In later levels these dollar signs may be in places other than the corners (finally
column10: something that actually is different than ""Pac-Man""). Each level is finished by clearing all the dollars bills from the board (the game will also rate you with a new 'Crime Level' every time you complete a screen)."

column1: 4163;thndrbdj;thndrbld1;"Thunder Blade [Deluxe Sit-Down model] (c) 1987 Sega Enterprises
column2: Limited.

column1: ;Taking control of a heavily-armed 'battle chopper
column2: the player must battle through a variety of both overhead and 'into-the-screen' 3-D stages.

column1: Each stage is packed with a mixture of enemy choppers
column2: planes
column3: tanks
column4: boats and static gun emplacements
column5: all intent on bringing Thunder Blade crashing to the ground.

column1: The player's 'copter is armed with 2 different weapons; a rapid-fire machine gun and air-to-ground missiles - both of which have unlimited ammunition.
The first half of every stage begins with a top-down
column2: vertically-scrolling section
column3: before switching to an 'After Burner-esque'
column4: into-the-screen section.

column1: Thunder Blade consists of four stages
column2: which are as follows :

column1: * Stage 1 : The game begins in a skyscraper-packed city. Enemies consist of rival choppers
column2: jets
column3: and ground-based tanks and gun emplacements. The level ends over the sea
column4: with the player facing a huge and heavily-armed battleship.

column1: * Stage 2 : This stage begins with the player navigating a desert canyon
column2: before switching to the into-the-screen view and taking the player through a number of stalactite-packed and densely populated caves. A huge ground-based tank awaits the player at the end of the stage.

column1: * Stage 3 : This begins in a river canyon
column2: before moving on to a rain-forest river network. As well the the usual line-up of enemies
column3: heavily-armed boats are introduced. the end-of-level battle takes place in the skies as the player attempts to destroy a massive jet fighter.

column1: * Stage 4 : The 4th and final stage begins with a repeat of the first stage's city level
column2: only this time the action takes place at night. The second half of this stage takes the player deep into an industrial complex
column3: eventually leading to an end-of-game showdown with a massive and heavily-armed gun emplacement."

column1: 4165;thndrx2;thndrx2j;"Thunder Cross II (c) 1991 Konami.
;Taking place in the future of space colonization
column2: the planet Haniamu IV is under attack from a relentless
column3: unknown military force known only as Black Impulse. The strongest Earth ships capable of stopping the total conquering of the planet are the Blue Thunder M-45 (player 1) and the Red Thunder M-24 (player 2).

column1: Thunder Cross is a classic horizontal shooter with 7 stages. Players control the Thunder fighter with up to four ""options""
column2: which arrange up and down vertically and add to the player's attack power. Three weapons are selectable ranging from the Vulcan shot to the Laser and the Boomerang shot (which doubles as a ricochet weapon). Typical of a Konami shooter
column3: Thunder Cross forces the player to beat the game twice in a harder loop of the first seven levels."

column1: 4175;tigerh;tigerh;"Tiger-Heli (c) 1985 Taito.
;The game is a vertical scrolling shooter where the player controls a helicopter taking on hordes of enemies which include tanks
column2: battleships
column3: and artillery. It is interesting to note that
column4: besides some airplanes taking off
column5: there are no flying enemies in the entire game. The player's main weapon is an unlimited supply of missiles which travel a max distance of half the screen's height. The player also has two bombs which destroy all objects within a large circular radius. These bombs can be blown off by enemy bullets.

column1: The player is killed after only one hit
column2: and is re-spawned to a point approximately one whole vertical screen-length later
column3: thus progressing the player past the obstacle that had killed him
column4: albeit at a high cost. The player is given three lives initially and bonus lives are awarded at 20000 points and every 80000 points thereafter. Flashing crosses scattered throughout each level award players power-ups depending on which color the cross is. A red cross will gives the player one side-firing mini-heli which shoots perpendicular to the player's helicopter. A white cross yields a forward firing mini-heli. It is possible to have a mix and match of side-helis
column5: totaling no more than two. The green cross will award the player with an additional bomb
column6: if the player currently has less than two. Grabbing power-ups when not necessary yields 5000 points.

column1: There are a total of four stages
column2: all of which start and end with a helipad. After completion of the last stage
column3: the game will restart in a more difficult mode starting on stage 2. Most of the game's areas contain unnecessary objects to destroy for bonus points
column4: such as oil drums and houses. This was uncharacteristic for shoot 'em ups at the time."

column3: the game will restart in a more difficult mode starting on stage 2. Most of the game's areas contain unnecessary objects to destroy for bonus points
column4: such as oil drums and houses. This was uncharacteristic for shoot 'em ups at the time."

column1: 4177;tigerhb1;tigerhb3;"Tiger-Heli (c) 1985 Taito.
;The game is a vertical scrolling shooter where the player controls a helicopter taking on hordes of enemies which include tanks
column2: battleships
column3: and artillery. It is interesting to note that
column4: besides some airplanes taking off
column5: there are no flying enemies in the entire game. The player's main weapon is an unlimited supply of missiles which travel a max distance of half the screen's height. The player also has two bombs which destroy all objects within a large circular radius. These bombs can be blown off by enemy bullets.

column1: The player is killed after only one hit
column2: and is re-spawned to a point approximately one whole vertical screen-length later
column3: thus progressing the player past the obstacle that had killed him
column4: albeit at a high cost. The player is given three lives initially and bonus lives are awarded at 20000 points and every 80000 points thereafter. Flashing crosses scattered throughout each level award players power-ups depending on which color the cross is. A red cross will gives the player one side-firing mini-heli which shoots perpendicular to the player's helicopter. A white cross yields a forward firing mini-heli. It is possible to have a mix and match of side-helis
column5: totaling no more than two. The green cross will award the player with an additional bomb
column6: if the player currently has less than two. Grabbing power-ups when not necessary yields 5000 points.

column1: There are a total of four stages
column2: all of which start and end with a helipad. After completion of the last stage
column3: the game will restart in a more difficult mode starting on stage 2. Most of the game's areas contain unnecessary objects to destroy for bonus points
column4: such as oil drums and houses. This was uncharacteristic for shoot 'em ups at the time."

column1: 4181;timber;timber;"Timber (c) 1984 Bally Midway.

;Timber is an abstract action game in which one or two players assume the role of a lumberjack and have a limited amount of time to chop down a given number of trees that pop up from the ground. The game is controlled with two joysticks
column2: with one stick controlling the player's movement and the other corresponding to left or right chops with the player's axe. Difficulty increases with each level
column3: with the number of trees needed to be chopped down gradually increasing (maxing out at 19) and the allotted time decreasing.

column1: During a round players must avoid beehives that are thrown at them by grizzly bears. The beehives
column2: however
column3: can be destroyed with the player's axe for a 500-point reward. Some trees contain birds that will run around the level after they have been chopped down
column4: awarding 1
column5: 000 points if touched by the player.

column1: Every couple of levels players are given the opportunity to amass bonus points. The bonus round begins with the lumberjack standing on a floating log. As the log begins to rotate
column2: players must use their reflexes to stay on top of the log. The first two times this is played
column3: the log is relatively large; on future attempts
column4: the size of the log shrinks considerably. The bonus round ends if the player falls off the log or balances atop it for the duration of the round
column5: in which case 1
column6: 000 bonus points are earned.

column1: The two-player simultaneous mode can be played either competitively or cooperatively. In this mode
column2: chopping or pushing down a tree such that it falls on the opponent awards you with 1
column3: 000 points."

column1: 4182;timecrsa;timecrisa;"Time Crisis (c) 1995 Namco.
;A superb
column2: on-the-rails lightgun game in which the player takes on the role of a lone mercenary who must rescue the President's daughter
column3: Rachel
column4: from the clutches of the evil 'Sherudo' and his terrorist gang. The game takes the player into and around Sherudo's clifftop
column5: castle hideout.

column1: As the game's title suggests
column2: time is one of the player's biggest enemies
column3: as each area must be cleared within a strict time limit. Extra time is occasionally awarded
column4: however
column5: when some of the more powerful enemy soldiers are killed.

column1: The game offers the player two different game modes :
STORY MODE : the player must defeat all of the enemies on the level to proceed to the next level.
TIME ATTACK : the player selects one of four stages and must defeat all enemies in the time allowed. The player is given unlimited lives in this mode
column2: but is constantly fighting against a very tight time limit."

column1: 4183;timek131;timekill131;"Time Killers (c) 1992 Strata.

;Cartoony weapon-based fighter wrought with dismemberment and decapitation. 8 characters to choose from and cut apart!
4184;timekill;timekill;Time Killers (c) 1992 Strata.

4185;timelimt;timelimt;Time Limit (c) 1983 Chuo.
4186;timeplt;timeplt;Time Pilot (c) 1982 Konami Industry Company
column2: Limited.

column1: ;The player controls his plane with the 8-way joystick and shoots at the enemies using the Fire button. Time Pilot consists of five different stages of play which are as follows (all these stages are also played in the attract mode unless otherwise noted in the Trivia section below) :
STAGE 1 : A.D. 1910 - The Age of Biplane

This stage features an ordinary blue sky with clouds. The attackers are biplanes coming from random directions. Enemy planes shoots at your plane and throw hand grenades when close to you. After 56 biplanes are destroyed
column2: the Mother Ship appears : a giant orange blimp shooting at you! Only seven hits will destroy the Mother Ship. During the same stage
column3: one to five parachutes will appear. Dock with them for bonus points.

column1: STAGE 2 : A.D. 1940 - The Age of Monoplane
Sky is grey-blue with the same clouds.
Enemies are monoplane fighters
column2: middle-size bombers and large bomber (Mother Ship). Middle-size bombers are aiming constantly at your plane! They can be destroyed by four hits and award 1
column3: 500 points.

column1: STAGE 3 : A.D. 1970 - The Age of Helicopter
Sky is once again grey-blue
column2: only this time a different shade. The same clouds from the first two stages are also present here.

column1: Enemies now are helicopters and large one (Mother Ship). As a new level of difficulty
column2: the helicopters are using homing missiles.

column1: STAGE 4 : A.D. 1982 - The Age of Jet Plane
The sky is purple with the same clouds as the previous three stages.

The enemies are modern jet fighters shooting and launching homing missiles. A modern large jet bomber is the Mother Ship. This is one of the most difficult stages of the game due to increased speed of jet fighters and random-direction attacks.
STAGE 5 : A.D. 2001 - The Age of UFO.
The sky is pitch black with asteroids instead of clouds.

Hard to be reached and very hard to be passed. Great number of UFO's are attacking from any direction changing their angles of attack and throwing at your plane two types of Alien Weapons. The stage is fast paced and the Mother Ship
column2: a superfortress UFO
column3: can not be so easily destroyed. In addition
column4: there are no enemy formations or parachutes in this stage
column5: and there can be no more than 3 UFO's on the screen at a time.

column1: The next
column2: Stage 6
column3: is identical to Stage 1
column4: but the number of planes attacking you
column5: their speed and number of shots and grenades are gradually increased.

column1: TIME PILOT continues with Stage 7
column2: 8... making your mission harder and harder. The game is all over when all your planes are destroyed."

;An arcade interpretation of pinball featuring the flippers, ramps, targets, bonus multipliers etc. of the classic genre it serves to replicate. Each level has a specific graphical style - in keeping with the 'time travelling' theme of the game's title - with each of the game's four tables split into two sections. When the player enters either the top or bottom section of a table, the screen will scroll vertically up or down respectively to follow the action.
4192;tinklpit;tinklpit;Tinkle Pit (c) 1993 Namco.
;The player contols Pitt and Patti
column2: who must walk around the mazes
column3: collecting items and avoiding enemies. They have the power to drop their Tinker power balls
column4: which are both invulnerable to the enemies
column5: and move around by pressing the Line button
column6: therefore creating a line between them and their power balls. Releasing the button makes their power balls come back to them; the enemies are killed by having the power balls slam into them. There are also pieces of popcorn which can be picked up around the mazes - and pressing the Popcorn button
column7: Pitt and Patti can throw them at the enemies
column8: and they shall bounce off the walls until they hit one (or evaporate if they have not done so by the end of the stage).

column1: Killing all enemies in a maze advances the player to the next stage; however
column2: in the event of one enemy remaining
column3: he will make for the nearest corner of the maze
column4: say ""Bye-bye!""
column5: and disappear - which will detract from the ""Pursuit Bonus"" that the players will receive after they defeat Mao at the end of the game."

column1: 4198;tkmmpzdm;tkmmpzdm;"Tokimeki Memorial Taisen Puzzle-dama (c) 1995 Konami.

;Tokimeki Memorial Taisen Puzzle-dama is a game in the Taisen Puzzle-dama series featuring the female characters from the Konami dating-sim ""Tokimeki Memorial."" The game is set up as a two player versus puzzle game with CPU opponents for the single player game.

'Coins' drop in sets of two's from the top of the screen and players must form chains of three or more same colored coins to make them disappear. Clearing multiple chains at a time sends locked coins to the other side. These locked coins are enclosed in clear spheres which are removed when a nearby coin is cleared from the screen. This can set off more chains which adds to the strategy of the game.
If the coins get stacked up to the top of the screen then the player loses the game. Upon continuing the player will restart the same match."

4207;tmnt2;tmnt2;"Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles - Turtles in Time (c) 1991 Konami Industry Company
column2: Limited.

column1: ;The sequel to 1989's hugely successful original
column2: 'Turtles in Time' once more sees the four heroes taking on Shredder and his army. Gameplay remains similar to the original game
column3: but the experience is enhanced further with the obligatory improved graphics and sound effects. 'Turtles in Time' also features a larger variety of levels
column4: as now the battle between good and evil rages across time as the Turtles travel to prehistoric
column5: pirate and Wild West times in their pursuit of the elusive Splinter.

column1: Yet again
column2: Konami's mastery of the genre was in evidence as the manic energy and humour of the cartoon and comic-book series upon which the game is based was captured perfectly."

column1: 4210;tmnt2pj;tmnt2pj;"Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles スーパー亀忍者  (c) 1989 Konami.
;(Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles - Super Kame Ninja)
A sideways scrolling beat-em-up in which up to four players can choose to play as either 'Leonardo' (blue
column2: katana blades)
column3: 'Raphael' (red
column4: sais)
column5: 'Michaelangelo' (orange
column6: nunchakas) or 'Donatello' (purple
column7: bo staff) as the infamous turtles fight against the might of Shredder's army to try and rescue 'April O'Neil' and 'Splinter'
column8: before a final confrontation with their arch-enemies 'Krang' and 'The Shredder'.

column1: Ninja Turtles featured just two buttons - for 'Jump' and 'Attack' - making for simple and immediate gameplay. Visually the game made great use of its license and perfectly captured the spirit of both the original comic-book and cartoon series upon which it was based. The game also featured a 'buy-in' option
column2: meaning that new players could join in at any time."

4219;tnzs;tnzsjo;The New Zealand Story (c) 1988 Taito Corp.
;Set in Antipodean country of the game's title
column2: The New Zealand Story is an incredibly cute and challenging platform game featuring Tiki the Kiwi bird
column3: possibly the most lovable arcade character ever created. Tiki's fellow Kiwi birds have been kidnapped by an evil walrus and Tiki is charged with rescuing his friends.

column1: The New Zealand Story is a superb
column2: constantly inventive and very demanding platform game that features a wide variety of intelligent and distinctive enemies; such as heavily armed ducks
column3: angry walruses
column4: and whales made of ice that spit giant snowflakes.

column1: During his quest
column2: Tiki can commandeer a variety of different weapons and vehicles - the latter of which include balloons and a hovercraft. The level design is superb
column3: with exploration often rewarded with either bonus items
column4: alternate routes to the end of the level
column5: or secret level warps that transport the player to a later level (see 'TIPS AND TRICKS' for more details)."

4225;toggle;toggle;Toggle (c) 1985 Bally Sente.

;A shoot 'em up where the player and the computer duel in a well/arena in tanks, where the red tank shoots vertically and the yellow tank shoots horizontally. A level is won by beating the computer in the amount of squares claimed. A square is claimed by running over it with the tank, where it turns the color of the tank that ran over it. There are special items that reverse the squares claimed by the player and computer, other ones that fill an entire row of squares with the color of the tank that got the bonus, and others that speed up the tanks' speed. The player has to have more squares claimed at the time the race/duel ends, and can disable the computer's tank by shooting it up close or by smashing into it at the sides that don't have the cannons.

column1: 4229;tokij;juju;"JuJu Densetsu (c) 1989 TAD.

;The game is a typical platformer in which the player must traverse several levels with a miniboss at the end. Despite his apparent handicap - his slowness as an ape - and the fact that almost any attack can kill him
column2: Toki is able to spit powerful shots that will help him in defeating enemies and obstacles that try to slow him down in his mission. There is a timer for each stage.

column1: JuJu can make use of items such as power-ups for his spit: lucky rabbit feet which can give Toki bursts of super-human agility and jumping skill
column2: clocks which add extra time to the countdown
column3: fruit which can add to JuJu's bonus points
column4: keys which unlock bonus areas
column5: a special helmet that protects him from upwards attacks
column6: extra lives
column7: and magic coins which when collected in abundance can obtain Juju an extra life."

column1: 4230;tokimbsj;tokimbsj;"Tokimeki Bishoujo (c) 1989 Nichibutsu.

4232;tokiob;tokiob;Scramble Formation / Tokio (c) 1986 Taito Corp.
;Flying over the city of Tokyo in your bi-plane you must shoot down hordes of enemy planes whilst avoiding their attacks.
Collect and control multiple biplanes to increase your firepower and help you to victory."
